DOC.HEAD: Lab Tries To Explain Why Hazelwood Blood Samples Were Mislabeled
DOC.TEXT: A laboratory accused of mishandling blood samples taken from Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood issued a statement Thursday attempting to explain what happened. Lawyers for Hazelwood said the statement left too many questions unanswered. They continued to assert that the blood testing for alcohol was botched and followed by a cover-up which denied Hazelwood his right to a fair trial earlier this year in Alaska in the nation's worst oil spill. Compuchem, the North Carolina parent company of ChemWest, a Sacramento laboratory that received Hazelwood's blood, acknowledged that three glass tubes containing his blood were mislabeled by a lab technician. That took place when the tubes were received four days after the Exxon Valdez struck a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound in March 1989, spilling 11 million gallons of crude in the nation's worst oil spill. The lab's finding that Hazelwood's blood had a .06 alcohol content was the cornerstone of his prosecution on criminal charges. Though a jury acquitted him of being intoxicated, the image of the drunken skipper hung over the proceeding. Hazelwood's lawyers contend discrepancies in descriptions of the tubes in which the blood for Hazelwood's blood was shipped to California for the alcohol test suggest the lab results could be for the wrong person. Coast Guard technician Scott M. Conner, who drew Hazelwood's blood 10{ hours after the Exxon Valdez grounding, testified in the Alaska trial and before the National Transportation Safety Board that he placed Hazelwood's blood in three 15-milliliter tubes. Two had gray stoppers and one had a red stopper, he said. ChemWest's first inventory sheet showed it had received Hazelwood's blood in ``three 10 milliliter red stoppered tubes'' on March 28, 1989. The colored stoppers are used to differentiate the contents of the blood tubes. Gray-topped blood tubes contain a chemical added to prevent blood alcohol from fermenting and thus reaching a reaching a higher level. Red tubes are used for drug testing and are considered unreliable for alcohol because they are untreated. On Thursday, Compuchem's statement said adhesive evidence tape obscured a technician's view of the blood tube stoppers. ``While the color of the vial stoppers was initially misidentified because the stoppers were covered by adhesive evidence tape, this was subsequently discovered and properly corrected,'' said the lab statement. But on May 1, 1989, the inventory sheet appears to have been changed. the number 3 is crossed out and a 1 is substituted for the number of red tubes. A hand-written line adds that two gray-stoppered tubes were received. The size of the tubes is still logged at 10 milliliters. Hazelwood's lawyers were outrage at the lab's explanation about the tape. ``Blood was taken from all of the crew members that day,'' said attorney Thomas Russo. ``If there were security seals on his tubes they should have been on all of the tubes. How come they got the others right? '' Identifications on samples of all other crew members conformed with Conner's testimony, he said. ``Why did she say the stoppers were red if she couldn't see them? did she just make that up?'' Russo asked, referring to technician Karen S. Metcalf who signed the documents. He noted that even after the corrections, ``the sizes of the tubes were still wrong.'' Compuchem Vice President Paul Brunswick, whose name appeared on the statement was unavailable for comment late Thursday. A call to his North Carolina office after business hours was unanswered. ``There was nothing that occurred during the ChemWest handling and-or testing of the Hazelwood samples that invalidates the chain of custody or the laboratory testing results,'' said the statement. Hazelwood's lawyers complained that the blood documents were withheld from them until four months after his trial was over, though they had repeatedly asked to see everything relevant to the blood tests. The lab said the documentation went to ``authorized officials'' and to the National Transportation Safety Board when the trial began in February. ``There are strict legal limitations regarding the release of such information to others,'' it added. ``These precautions are necessary to protect individual rights and confidentiality.'' Hazelwood lawyer Michael Chalos had a different interpretation of the withholding of documents. ``What they did was deprive Capt. Hazelwood of his rights,'' Chalos said. He alleged that the NTSB, the Coast Guard and the State of Alaska also may have had the documents and withheld them. ``ChemWest handled the receipt, testing and reporting of the Hazelwood samples correctly and totally in compliance with established forensic drug testing procedures,'' said the statement issued for Compuchem by a New York public relations firm. The NTSB is scheduled to issue its final report on the Exxon Valdez disaster next Tuesday. Russo and Chalos have said the newly discovered documents should be taken into account if the board is planning to say whether Hazelwood was intoxicated. A Coast Guard administrative law judge suspended Hazelwood's captain's license for nine months in a plea bargain announced Wednesday. The Coast Guard dropped two charges including one that he was intoxicated, and Hazelwood pleaded no contest to two other charges including one that he drank alcohol within four hours of sailing.

DOC.HEAD: Animal Rights Activists Monitor Annual Pony Swim
DOC.TEXT: Animal rights activists kept watch Wednesday as about 150 wild ponies made the 65th annual Chicoteague Island pony swim. A crowd of about 40,000 people, including the activists, saw the ponies complete a 10 to 15 minute swim across the quarter-mile-wide channel to this barrier island from Assateague. Bonnie Scribner of Voice for Animals, a Charlottesville-based group, said after the watching the swim that she ``had seen nothing amiss.'' ``But the swim is just part of it,'' she said. ``We don't approve of the sale of foals under four months of age. She said last year there was no veterinarian available and two ponies died. Her organization came to make sure a veterinarian was present. There were two on duty and Ms. Scribner said she was delighted. The animals are thought to be the descendants of ponies who washed ashore during Colonial times from shipwrecks. The ponies gained fame from Marguerite Henry's children's classic ``Misty of Chincoteague,'' first published in 1947. Activists had said they wanted to monitor the 65th roundup, penning and auction of the wild horses by the community's volunteer fire department. Gail Eisnitz of the Humane Society of the United States said the event is ``real stressful for the horses and ponies. We feel it is animal exploitation for human entertainment and for big bucks.'' Some of the foals will be sold at auction Thursday by the fire department to control the herd size. Last year, the department made $40,000 on the sale of 77 foals. Ed Moran, president of the Chincoteague volunteer fire department, said all the money raised, including that from a $25 video of the swim, goes ``back into the community.'' He said it pays for maintaining the departments three fire trucks and four ambulances. About 20 to 25 people wilted in the midday heat and were taken by ambulance for treatment at the Island Medical Center, then released, said ambulance chairman Ollie Reed. The Humane Society of the United States has been monitoring the annual event for 20 years. Ms. Eisnitz said conditions for the animals have improved. But in the last two years, six animals have died. As a result of those deaths, the Chincoteague National Wildlife Refuge on Assateague threatened to revoke the fire department's permit to graze the animals on the refuge if the department did not provide a veterinarian for the swim, penning and auction.

DOC.HEAD: Man Accused of Stealing Two City Buses
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of hijacking two city buses from depots early Wednesday told detectives he wanted to work for the Transit Authority, police sources said. The first bus was grabbed in Manhattan and driven 25 miles across the borough of Queens. But it wasn't until the second bus was spotted zooming out of the Queens depot at 4:45 a.m. that the double theft was discovered. A sharp-eyed transit manager later spotted the second bus coming off the Triborough Bridge in Manhattan, recognized that it was in the wrong borough and started a chase that resulted in the suspect's capture. Darius McCollum, 25, of Queens, was charged with grand larceny after his arrest at Grand Central station at about 6 a.m., said police spokesman Officer Scott Block. Police sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said McCollum told detectives he stole the buses because the Transit Authority wouldn't hire him. Investigators were checking Transit Authority records to see whether McCollum had applied for a job or taken a test to become a bus driver. Detectives were also trying to verify McCollum's boasts that he had commandeered a subway train about 10 years ago, as a teenager. Twenty-five city buses have been stolen in the last 12 months, according to Transit Authority statistics. ``Unfortunately, it's going up. We are seeing a trend,'' said Transit Authority spokeswoman Caren Gardner. McCollum is considered a suspect in other bus thefts, said Transit Police spokesman Al O'Leary. ``What someone wants to do with a Transit Authority bus, I can't begin to tell you,'' Ms. Gardner said. The bright blue and silver buses, which are 40 feet long by nine feet wide ``are kind of recognizable and not usually taken for joyrides.'' The manager who spotted the bus at 5:30 a.m. waved down a police car and officers gave chase. The driver jumped from the moving bus in front of Grand Central, and the bus rolled into a parked New York Telephone truck, causing no damage to either vehicle, Ms. Gardner said. McCollum was arrested inside Grand Central.

DOC.HEAD: Americans on Rose: First Jail, then Hall of Fame
With PM-Poll-Method
DOC.TEXT: Americans say Pete Rose deserves a place in two venerable institutions: the federal prison system and the Baseball Hall of Fame. Eighty-one percent in a national Associated Press poll said it was right for Rose, baseball's all-time hit leader, to be sentenced to federal prison last week. He got a five-month term last week for cheating on his taxes. At the same time, a majority said Rose should be allowed to work in baseball again, even though he was banished from the sport for gambling last year. And two-thirds said he deserved election to the Hall of Fame. Most respondents also said Rose's problems did little to damage his sport. Fifty-six percent said he had not hurt baseball's image, and among those who said he had done damage, only about a third said it was serious. Rose, 49, ex-manager of the Cincinnati Reds, can apply for reinstatement to baseball, and 63 percent said he should get it at some point. Rose becomes eligible in December 1991 for election by sports writers to the Hall of Fame. With 4,256 hits in a 24-year career, he was virtually assured of the honor before he ran afoul of the baseball commissioner and the law. His chances now are less certain. The poll did not specify an election date for Rose, asking only if he should be named to the Hall of Fame ``at some point.'' Baseball fans were a bit more likely than non-fans to favor him for the hall, 71 to 63 percent, and men were more supportive than women, 74 to 62 percent. Women also were slightly more likely than men to say Rose had damaged baseball's image, 43 to 36 percent. But men were a bit harder on Rose in other areas: They were more likely than women to say he deserved jail time, 85-78 percent. And while 67 percent of women said Rose should be allowed back into baseball at some point, that fell to 59 percent of men. In most cases, opinion was roughly the same among respondents who called themselves baseball fans as among non-fans. Fifty-four percent said they were fans _ 61 percent of the men and 48 percent of the women. The telephone survey of 1,004 adults was conducted for the AP from Friday through Tuesday by ICR Survey Research Group of Media, Pa., part of AUS Consultant Cos. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus three percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Poll-Rose
DOC.TEXT: This Associated Press poll was conducted by telephone July 20-24 among a random sample of 1,004 adults in the continental United States. Interviewing was done by ICR Survey Research Group of Media, Pa. The results were weighted to adjust for variations in the sample. The poll has a 3-point margin of error, meaning that 19 of 20 times its findings should be within 3 points of the result if every adult American were asked the same questions. The error margin is larger for subgroups. There are other sources of potential error in polls, including the wording and order of questions. These are the questions in this poll; because of rounding, sums may not total 100: 1. Pete Rose has been sentenced to five months in prison and fined for cheating on his taxes by failing to report about $350,000 in income. Do you think it was right for Pete Rose to get jail time, or not? Yes: 81 percent. No: 13 percent. Don't know or no answer: 6 percent. 2. Pete Rose was banned from baseball last year for his involvement with gamblers. Do you think that ban should be lifelong, or should he be allowed to work in baseball again at some point? Lifelong: 28. Work again: 63. DK-NA: 9. 3. Though he's been banned from baseball for gambling and convicted of a tax felony, as a player Pete Rose had the most base hits of any ballplayer ever. Do you think he should be elected to baseball's Hall of Fame at some point, or not? Yes: 67. No: 25. DK-NA: 8. 4a. Do you think Pete Rose has hurt baseball's image, or not? Yes: 39. No: 56. DK-NA: 5. 4b. (If yes) Would you say he's hurt it seriously, or not too seriously? Seriously: 14. Not too seriously: 25. DK-NA: 1. 5. Do you consider yourself to be a baseball fan, or not? Yes: 54. No: 45. DK-NA: 1.

DOC.HEAD: National Airline Halts Flights To Sweden
DOC.TEXT: Israel has ordered its state-owned El Al airline to halt its twice-weekly flights to Stockholm in response to changes in Sweden's airport security arrangements. ``The new security procedures made by the government of Sweden do not answer the security requirements of the government of Israel,'' Yehiel Amitai, spokesman for the Ministry of Transportation, said Wednesday. He would not say what changes had been made but said his ministry could not allow the continuation of El Al flights that were not ``adequately guarded.'' Amitai said the decision would be reversed if Sweden returned to the previous security arrangements. The Transportation Ministry, citing the principle of mutuality, also banned all charter flights originating in Sweden from landing in Israel. The Scandinavian carrier SAS does not operate regular flights from Stockholm to Israel. El Al has canceled its flights in the past over security arrangements. Usually it involves the presence of Israeli security people who want direct responsibility for the safety of the aircraft and passengers, something not every country is willing to allow. El Al flights are considered prime targets for Palestinian guerrillas, and security is very stringent. In December 1985, guerrillas of the radical Abu Nidal Organization launched attacks against the El Al counters in the Rome and Vienna airports, killing 16 people.

DOC.HEAD: American Animal Rights Activist Posts `Theses' At Vatican
DOC.TEXT: An American animal rights activist posted a petition in St. Peter's Square calling on Pope John Paul II to declare that animals have immortal souls, and sought a meeting with the pontiff. But security guards quickly took down the statement on Wednesday and shooed away the activist, John Stockwell of Berkeley, Calif., and several of his followers. And a private audience was not granted. Stockwell, a 55-year-old geologist and school teacher, compared his initiative to that of Martin Luther, the Protestant Reformation leader who posted his historic 95 theses on the door of a castle church in Wittenberg, Germany, in 1517. ``What we're seeking is the beginning of a humane and ecological reformation,'' Stockwell said. He said he had hoped for a meeting with the pope but was not granted one. Stockwell and several followers attended the pope's general audience Wednesday morning but they were given seats far from the pontiff. Later, the group gathered in St. Peter's Square and Stockwell taped a sheet of paper containing his 10 ``theses'' to the base of a marble column near the entrance to the basilica. After photographers snapped pictures, Vatican guards moved in, removed the petition and asked the group to leave the area. Stockwell applauded a recent statement by the pope that God's breath also touched animals, but said he wanted John Paul to go further. His petition declares that all animal species have immortal souls. It also calls for a ban on hunting, fishing, medical and scientific research on animals and all forms of abuse and cruelty. In an address to scientists in 1982, the pope said, ``It is certain that animals are at the service of man and can hence be the object of experimentation. Nevertheless, they must be treated as creatures of God which are destined to serve man's good, but not to be abused by him.''

DOC.HEAD: Bobbies Get on Their Bikes to Fight Crime
DOC.TEXT: An experiment in putting British bobbies on bikes to fight crime has ended successfully in the northern England town of Sheffield, police said. Plainclothes officers spent two weeks cycling the streets and arrested more than a dozen car thieves in Sheffield, 145 miles northwest of London. ``At first I was a bit skeptical but it has been an unqualified success,'' South Yorkshire police superintendent Peter Hale said Wednesday. Hale said the force was considering ordering more of the 18-gear mountain bikes for other officers.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Arab Pleads Innocent to Inciting Violence with Poetry
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli Arab poet has pleaded innocent to charges he incited anti-Israeli violence with his writings. At the opening day of his trial Wednesday, Shafik Habib, a 49-year-old accountant from Nazareth, acknowledged he had written the book of poetry on which the charges are based. But he denied that his ``political poetry'' constituted incitement. Habib was jailed and then held under house arrest for several weeks in June after police charged that his poems could incite violence. The military censor banned further publication of the poems. The action was taken under an anti-terror statute that dates back to the days of British control. The arrest ignited protests by Arab legislators and Arab writers' unions. They said they feared the move could signal a government crackdown on writers and other artists. The court in this northern port city was told Wednesday that Habib's poetry urged violence against Jews and supported the 31-month Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip. The charges say Habib's poetry encourages readers to fight back with stones, Molotov cocktails and explosives. Judge Rahamin Tsemah agreed to delay further proceedings until Sept. 30 after Habib complained that the translation of his book from Arabic to Hebrew was not precise.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Fire Rocket-Propelled Grenades on Presidential Palace
DOC.TEXT: Guerrillas fired two rocket-propelled grenades at the presidential palace late Wednesday, less than three days before President-elect Alberto Fujimori is to take office. Police said damage to the palace in downtown Lima was minor. The attack took place just after outgoing President Alan Garcia met with a group of judges to sign a law reforming Peru's judiciary, police and witnesses said. One grenade exploded against the rear wall of the building and the other exploded on the roof. The grenades were launched by two men from next to a small car parked 100 yards from the palace's rear entry. The men then fled in the car, police said. Afterwards, in comments to reporters, Garcia discounted the importance of the attack. ``All they prove with their pistols and bombs is that they're psychologically inferior. They have to resort to violence because they cannot convince people through politics,'' he said. Police set up roadblocks throughout downtown Lima and detained hundreds of people. They said they were unsure which of Peru's two rebel groups staged the attack _ the Maoist Shining Path or the pro-Cuban Tupac Amaru. In other attacks late Wednesday, Shining Path rebels burned a city-owned bus in a poor Lima neighborhood. In another poor area of the capital, rebels from the same group bombed a telephone exchange, causing moderate damage. The Shining Path has conducted a violent campaign against Peru's government throughout the last decade.

Here is the text of the letter written by David H. Souter on behalf of the judges of the New Hampshire Superior Court on May 13, 1981 to Roma H. Spaulding, chairwoman of the Health and Welfare Committee of the New Hampshire House.

Dear Madame Chairman: I am writing as a member of the committee to speak for the Superior Court on proposed legislation that would affect the court. The full court met on May 7 and directed me to write to you to express the court's position on SB 194, which you have scheduled for hearing on May 13. The judges do not believe it is appropriate for the court to take a position on the basic question addressed by the bill, whether parental consent should be required before an abortion may be performed upon an unmarried minor. The court's concern is directed, rather, to that provision of the bill that would require a justice of the Superior Court to authorize the performance of an abortion upon such a minor when there is no parental consent, if the justice determines ``that the performance of an abortion would be in ... the (best) interests'' of a minor who is ``not mature.'' The members of the court find two fundamental problems inherent in this provision. First, it would express a decision by society, speaking through the Legislature, to leave it to individual justices of this court to make fundamental moral decisions about the interests of other people without any standards to guide the individual judge. Judges are professionally qualified to apply rules and stated norms, but the provision in question would enact no rule to be applied and would express no norm. In place of a rule or a norm there would be left only the individual judge's principles and predilections. As carefully considered as these might be, they would still be those of only one individual, not those of society. Much criticism of the role of the judiciary in this country has characterized judicial activity in the application of constitutional standards as no more than the imposition of individual judges' views in the guise of applying constitutional norms of great generality. The provision that I have quoted from the present bill would force the Superior Court to engage in just such acts of unfettered personal choice. The court's second concern is with the necessarily moral character of such choice and the resulting disparity of responses to requests that judicial discretion be exercised. As you would expect, there are some judges who believe abortion under the circumstances contemplated by the bill is morally wrong, who could not in conscience issue an order requiring an abortion to be performed. There are others who believe that what may be thought to be in the ``best interests'' of the pregnant minor is itself just as necessarily a moral as a social question, upon which a judge may not morally speak for another human being, whatever may be that judge's own personal opinion about the morality of abortion. Judges in each category would be obligated to indicate that they could not exercise their power in favor of authorizing abortions to be performed on immature pregnant minors. The inevitable result would be required shopping for judges who would entertain such cases. In other words, a principled and consistent application of the quoted provision would be impossible. For these reasons I have been directed to request on behalf of the court that any bill you may pass on this subject not authorize the exercise of judicial choice by justices of the Superior Court to determine whether an abortion should be performed upon a pregnant, immature minor whose parents do not consent to that course of action. Yours respectfully, David H. Souter, Justice New Hampshire Superior Court

DOC.HEAD: One Way or Another, Budget Cuts Are Likely to Affect Older Americans
With PM-The Elderly-Box
DOC.TEXT: Reps. Ronald Machtley and James McClure Clarke have a message for the budget negotiators who are thinking of cutting Social Security and Medicare. Don't. ``That's the poison pill for any solution,'' said Machtley, R-R.I. ``Social Security would be awful,'' said Clarke, D-N.C. ``Medicare should be only a last resort.'' Machtley and Clarke both represent districts with large numbers of retired people and both expect tight re-election races this fall. But their reluctance to slash Social Security and Medicare is shared by most members of Congress. That's why budget bargainers, who are likely to cut programs that help the elderly, are exploring those reductions with all the trepidation of kids tiptoeing into an isolated, dark cave. ``F-16s (fighter planes) don't vote, senior citizens do,'' said House Majority Whip William Gray, D-Pa., referring to the Democratic preference to cut deeply into the defense budget. ``That's a political reality of an election year.'' Negotiators from the White House and Congress have been trying for 11 weeks to reduce the federal budget deficit by increasing taxes and trimming programs. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said Wednesday that the two sides had agreed to present specific proposals as early as week's end. The talks are being watched closely by senior citizens' organizations. Those groups have warned the negotiators to leave Social Security alone and go after Medicare only as part of a package in which all groups _ not just the elderly _ bear some pain. ``It would be very tough to argue to the people affected by these cuts that it's a fair sacrifice for them if they look around and see other people not suffering with the same intensity,'' said lobbyist John Rother of the 32-million-member American Association of Retired Persons. Members of both parties involved in the budget talks say it now appears unlikely that Social Security benefits will be cut. ``Social Security has been described as the third rail of American politics. If you touch it, you die,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., a negotiator who favors restraining the program's growth. But the Bush administration supports some cuts in the program _ which helps support 39 million elderly and disabled people and their dependents _ and the issue isn't completely off the bargaining table. Medicare, which provides health coverage for 33 million elderly and disabled Americans, appears targeted for at least $3 billion in reduced payments to doctors and hospitals. The reason Social Security and Medicare are vulnerable boils down to arithmetic. Budget negotiators are trying to reduce next year's projected $169 billion deficit by at least $50 billion. That's a lot of money, even for a $1.2 trillion budget, so the bargainers are looking for big targets. They've found them in Social Security and Medicare. Social Security is the biggest federal benefit program and will cost $245 billion this year. Medicare will have a $97 billion price tag. Together, they account for more than one dollar of every four the government will spend in 1990. As the country's population ages _ and medical costs soar _ these programs are expected to grow even more. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office projects that by 1995, Social Security will cost $338 billion and Medicare will cost $183 billion. ``They can at least arguably stand a reduction,'' said Frenzel, who is retiring from Congress. These programs are even more vulnerable because by some measures, the nation's elderly are a relatively well-off group. Advocates for the elderly dispute those measures, contending that large numbers of senior citizens live below the poverty line. ``That's the wrong group of people being asked to sacrifice,'' said AARP's Rother. Senior citizens groups are already gearing up for a fight, sending letters and serving notice to lawmakers that millions of voters know what is going on. Their campaign is aimed at a Congress that vividly recalls the Democrats' 1986 recapture of the Senate, which many credit to the Republicans' willingness to cut Social Security. ``This can be political dynamite,'' said Sen. Don Nickles of Oklahoma, who heads the Senate GOP's election committee.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Durenberger
DOC.TEXT: This is a list of rules violations for which the Senate Ethics Committee said Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., should be denounced: _Using a book contract with Piranha Press, a small Minneapolis publishing house, to collect speaking fees in 1985 and 1987 over the Senate's limits on honoraria. He has agreed to repay $95,000, less what taxes he paid on the income. _Structuring real estate transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium to obtain Senate reimbursement for staying there during trips to Minnesota. He refunded $11,005 of the payments and agreed to return another $29,050, plus interest. _Failure to report the receipt of travel expenses in connection with the book-promotion appearances and trips to the Boston area, which he used to visit a marriage counselor. _A ``pattern of prohibited communications'' concerning the condominium with the trustee of the blind trust in which the property was held. _Acceptance of free limousine service during the Boston trips in violation of Senate gift limits. _Conversion of a $5,000 campaign contribution to personal use by turning it over to Piranha Press instead of his campaign treasury.

DOC.HEAD: WALTER MEARS: Searching for a True Picture of the Soviet Economy
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It's an argument among statisticians, economists and intelligence analysts, matching eye-glazing formulas and rival numbers that measure the magnitude of Soviet military spending _ with a very big price tag behind the debate. Central Intelligence Agency estimates of the Soviet economy, its performance and the share Moscow was spending on the military have been a factor in U.S. defense planning and budgeting for the past 40 years. Now the CIA numbers are being challenged. A Democratic senator says Soviet economic strength has been vastly overestimated for years, prompting an American military buildup that helped run the United States deep into debt. A top economic adviser to President Bush said he thinks the Soviet gross national product last year was substantially lower than the CIA estimated. Soviet economists, free to speak after decades of Cold War silence on such topics, say their nation's economic performance was far weaker than the CIA judged it to be. And an analyst at the Defense Intelligence Agency said at a Senate hearing that the CIA ``clearly understates'' the share of the Soviet economy devoted to military expenditures. William T. Lee, a longtime CIA critic, said that agency's methods are flawed and ``likely to be as unreliable, and misleading, in the future as in the past.'' But the CIA insists that essentially, it has been correct. ``I think we have done a very good job on a very complex issue,'' George Kolt, CIA director of Soviet analysis, said last week at the Senate Foreign Relations Committee hearing. ``But that does not mean that our numbers are totally accurate. They are estimates that are most likely on the high side.'' The current CIA estimate is that the Soviet gross national product amounts to 51 percent of that in the United States, which had a 1989 GNP of $4.2 trillion. Michael J. Boskin, chairman of Bush's Council of Economic Advisers, said he thinks the Soviet GNP is about one-third that of the United States. At a conference sponsored by the American Enterprise Institute in April, Soviet economists and statisticians offered even lower estimates. One Soviet official, Victor Belkin, said his nation's GNP could be as low as 14 percent of that in the United States, and no higher than 28 percent. Sen. Daniel Patrick Moynihan, D-N.Y., says the CIA estimates of Soviet economic strength and military capabilities in the mid-1970s led to the massive defense buildup that began when Jimmy Carter was president and accelerated under Ronald Reagan. Moynihan said the Senate committee should look further into the consequences of government statistics about the Soviet Union. ``Would we have spent as much on our military during the 1980s if we had believed that the Soviet defense burden simply was not sustainable?'' he asked. ``I think not, and if I am correct, then this issue has been a momentous one for the state of the American economy.'' Moynihan said that just as the United States was launching its military buildup, ``Soviet economists were predicting disaster for their economy.'' The CIA's Kolt said that while the agency considers its estimate of the defense burden generally accurate, the threat to the United States isn't represented by that number anyhow, but by Soviet weapons and forces. And those are easier to count than economic statistics. Defense spending accounts for about 6 percent of the U.S. gross national product. Kolt said the CIA had estimated that 15 to 17 percent of the Soviet gross national product has been going into military spending, although that has declined since last year. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said he thinks it is running at about 25 percent but doubts it will stay that high. ``Soviet military spending will decline as a matter of policy, and because it can't be sustained,'' he said. ``... I think they are in a depression.'' Nevertheless, Cheney said, the Soviet military is maintaining and modernizing its strategic forces. ``That's what makes them a superpower and they won't give that up,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Thailand-Vietnam Rice Fight Cutting U.S. Export Prospects
DOC.TEXT: A trade spat between two big Southeast Asia rice producers is helping dampen export prospects for U.S. rice farmers. But an Agriculture Department report says ``tight supplies are likely to keep U.S. prices firm'' in the coming year, at least above sagging world prices. ``Over the last year, world prices have weakened in response to increased competition in world markets, especially between Thailand and Vietnam, and a drop in world trade,'' the report said Wednesday. The export competition is expected to heat up further in the 1990-91 rice marketing year that begins Aug. 1. Currently, the report said, Vietnam has cut into Thailand's markets by selling at ``prices substantially below'' those offered by Thai exporters. Thailand is the world's largest rice exporter. ``Recently, Thailand announced an export subsidy scheme in an effort to increase exports, but the response has been weak,'' the report said. Meanwhile, Thailand's market share dropped from 40 percent in 1989 to 31 percent forecast for 1990. ``It is expected that Thailand will aggressively compete with Vietnam to regain market share in 1991,'' the report said. The U.S. global market share is forecast to fall to about 18 percent in 1991 from 20 percent the past two years. USDA analysts said tight supplies and relatively high prices ``may hinder U.S. competitiveness'' in some foreign markets. Analysts said U.S. rice production this year may be about 158 million hundredweight, up only 2.3 percent from the 1989 harvest, based on acreage and yield-trend projections. The first official rice estimate will be included in USDA's Aug. 9 crop report. ``However, conditions to date indicate that yields may not match last year's record,'' the report said. ``Rain and wet field conditions this spring delayed planting in the Mississippi Delta, which could reduce yield potential.'' Currently, based on the latest projections, the U.S. rice stockpile going into the new marketing year on Aug. 1 is expected to be 23.8 million hundredweight, down from 26.7 million a year ago and 31.4 million two years ago. If production and total use turns out as projected, the rice stockpile a year from now could be about unchanged from the current level, the report said.

A report to Congress says the Agriculture Department should review more closely a proposal to remove import inspections on Canadian meat and poultry entering the United States. The proposal was announced by USDA last month, with July 30 set as a deadline for public comments. If adopted, the experimental plan would be in effect for one year. Officials of the department's Food Safety and Inspection Service said Canadian products would still be thoroughly inspected at slaughter and processing plants under ``a system that is nearly identical'' to the U.S. system and standards. But re-inspection of random samples at border points would be eliminated under the proposal. A reciprocal nod would be given U.S. products entering Canada. The General Accounting Office, the investigative arm of Congress, said in a recent report that the department's inspection agency has not documented how it arrived at the determination that Canada's system is virtually identical to that of the United States. Further, the GAO said, ``unexplained 1989 rejection rates'' for Canadian meat inspected randomly at border points are cause for concern. According to the report, USDA inspectors rejected about 3 percent of the selected products, compared with 1 percent in 1988. ``Without an adequate explanation, the rates could be interpreted as indicating a decline during 1989 in the effectiveness of the Canadian inspection system,'' the report said. Assistant Agriculture Secretary Jo Ann Smith told a Senate hearing on July 12 that the meat proposal is a spinoff from the U.S.-Canada Free Trade Agreement that went into effect Jan. 1, 1989. The goal, she reminded lawmakers, is to promote economic growth in both countries. Smith said some U.S. producers and manufacturers are worried that Canada will intrude on the American market. ``But as with any trade agreement, it's a two-way street,'' she said. ``We will see Canadian products move to the United States, just as we will increasingly market and sell U.S. products to Canadian consumers.'' The industry's American Meat Institute told the same Senate panel that the open-border proposal ``deserves a fair chance to work.'' Michael J. Copps, the trade association's senior vice president for legislative affairs, said the one-year experiment is a ``necessary and logical step to eliminate trade barriers'' between the two countries.

A South African cousin of kleingrass, which is popular in areas of scant rainfall, may some day be added to the list of U.S. forage crops, the Agriculture Department says. The regular kleingrass is liked because of its ability to thrive in inhospitable settings with little water, the department's Agricultural Research Service said Wednesday in a report. But kleingrass has a major drawback for seed producers: a tendency to shatter when harvested, dumping its seed on the ground almost as fast as it ripens. Scientists estimate only 10 percent of the seed is actually harvested. The South African kleingrass, however, retains about twice as much of its seed. The new line was discovered in 1976 and is being evaluated by scientists, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Official Fled to U.S. Via Moscow
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: For nearly a decade, Ramon Gonzalez Vergara dreamed of leaving Cuba for a better life, but he was afraid to defect on his travels abroad for fear his family would be punished by the Castro government. Finally, Vergara told a news conference Wednesday, he received his ``lucky break'' when he was assigned to Moscow as Cuba's deputy secretary at the Council on Mutual Economic Assistance, the Soviet bloc's economic confederation. Vergara, 50, an economist, took his wife, his mother-in-law and his two children, ages 14 and 11, on his foreign posting. While in Moscow, Vergara and his wife plotted how they would leave the Soviet Union but didn't tell their children about their plan, he said in his first public appearance in this country. Because it was too dangerous to talk aloud in their Moscow apartment _ Vergara feared electronic eavesdropping _ he and his wife communicated using chalk on a blackboard. He said they walked in the park when they wanted to iron out their plans. Finally, on June 25, the Vergara acted on their plan. The family went to Berlin for a holiday and then crossed the border in a Soviet-made Lada vehicle. The car worked well, Vergara said, joking that the Soviets ought to be proud of their vehicles. ``We knew we only had a 72-hour grace period,'' Vergara said. The family drove quickly across the continent to Madrid where they had relatives. In Spain, Vergara sought asylum at the U.S. Embassy. Vergara, whose appearance was sponsored by the Cuban-American National Foundation, is one of the growing number of Cubans who are carrying out plans to leave, said Jackie Tillman, who works with the anti-Castro group. In his remarks, Vergara said the Soviet Union could not sustain the huge amounts of aid that have propped up the Cuban economy. ``The Soviet aid helps a lot to maintain the standard of living'' in Cuba, he said. U.S. officials estimate the Soviet Union's grants and subsidies to Cuba amount to $5 billion annually, but some private economists say that figure may be high. Vergara confirmed the $5 billion amount, but he said he doubted it would continue at a time of belt-tightening and shortages in the Soviet Union itself. ``They can't maintain the same levels of past year,'' he said. ``Of course, the Cuban government is aware of the situation; they have felt the first symptoms.' Vergara, who described Cuba's economy as being in recession, said Havana's trade with the Soviet Union amounts to 75 percent of the total. Trade with former Soviet satellites such as those in Eastern Europe amounted to between 12 percent and 17 percent of the total, he said. While trade with Eastern Europe has eroded in recent months, Cuba is reaching out to trading partners in Latin America and China, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Summer Camp Teaches Political Junkies the Art of the Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Bob Zuckerman came to rub shoulders with the pros and Selma Ford arrived harboring hopes for a job back home in Ohio. One hundred political enthusiasts converged on Washington Wednesday for the kickoff of the Democrats' annual campaign summer camp. The intense, five-day training seminar is designed to teach would-be political pros the imprecise art of the campaign _ everything from how to control unpredictable candidates to how to curry favorable press coverage. Participants will plunge themselves into a campaign between mock state senate candidates Ann Neu Age and Bob ``Sonny'' Legion, working from candidate profiles, financial background and polling data. Once the race is on, a local newspaper, the Daily Plan-It, covers the changes in the political climate and keeps the campaigns informed of the candidates' sometimes unpredictable behavior. The training camp was started in 1985 with the aim of electing Democrats to state legislatures in key states before the 1990 census. This year's crop of campers includes seasoned campaigners and novices alike. Zuckerman, a New Jersey state Senate aide who has worked in several state-level campaigns, said he hopes to make new contacts and polish his campaign skills _ learning from ``political professionals here who have years and years of experience.'' Ford, a student who just finished a Washington internship, hopes to translate her training into a job on the gubernatorial campaign of Democrat Anthony Celebrezze in her home state of Ohio. ``It's wonderful experience _ and I want him to win,'' she said. Democratic Party Chairman Ronald Brown opened camp with a pep talk, telling participants the key to Democratic gains over the next decade lies in the success of statehouse races this year. Those elections are crucial to both parties, since each side wants to have the upper hand when states redraw congressional and legislative districts based on the 1990 census results. ``The only way to ensure fairness in reapportionment is to make sure that the hand that draws the lines is the hand of a Democrat,'' Brown said. After the opening ceremonies in Washington, participants went to rural Piney Point, Md., for the remainder of the training camp.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Calls Tax Amnesty Counterproductive
DOC.TEXT: Granting temporary amnesty to tax evaders in order to reduce the budget deficit could make honest taxpayers feel cheated and lose more money than it gains, the Bush administration says. ``A federal tax amnesty program ... is a gamble with our tax system's most important asset _ the general willingness of taxpayers to obey the law,'' said Michael J. Graetz, deputy assistant secretary of the treasury for tax policy. The vast majority of taxpayers, who already comply with tax laws, might feel cheated if they see that those who knowingly broke the rules are allowed to escape punishment, Graetz told the House Government Operations subcommittee on consumer affairs Wednesday. Tax amnesty is a popular proposal in Congress as lawmakers look for ways to reduce the budget deficit without raising taxes or cutting spending too deeply. The Internal Revenue Service estimates that cheating on income taxes will cost $87 billion in lost revenue this year. In addition, the long-term backlog of taxes that corporations and individuals admit owing but have not paid will total in the $80 billion range this year. Several bills would give wayward taxpayers six months in which to settle their accounts with the IRS. In return, the agency would waive penalties _ and, under some bills, forgive interest _ and forgo civil or criminal prosecution. The bills also promise considerably toughened enforcement after amnesty ends and include an expanded auditing and collection force at the IRS. ``As we battle headlong to reduce our uncontrollable budget deficit, debating over whether to cut essential programs or impose unwanted taxes on our citizens, we should take advantage of the benefits that a tax amnesty program yields,'' Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., sponsor of one amnesty bill, told the subcommittee. Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., noted that the 1991 budget prepared by the Senate Budget Committee endorses the amnesty program he has proposed, which congressional authorities estimate would bring in an extra $63.7 billion over five years. ``It's both fiscally irresponsible and insulting to the vast majority of honest taxpayers in this country if we fail to tap this revenue from those who haven't complied,'' Conrad told the subcommittee. Graetz, the Treasury official, called Conrad's estimate an exaggeration. ``We do not believe a federal amnesty program would raise large additional revenues, and there is a risk that such a program, in fact, might lose revenue,'' he said. IRS Commissioner Fred T. Goldberg Jr. also said ``a general federal tax amnesty would be ill-advised and counterproductive.'' Even so, he said, the IRS is studying results from the 31 states that have offered amnesty and considering proposals that ``might be designed to provide an opportunity for a fresh start to those individuals who are not reached by our current tax administration efforts.'' State amnesties have produced $1.6 billion in gross revenues, but Graetz and Goldberg said there is no reason to expect a federal amnesty would bring in large amounts. Federal enforcement efforts already are far more effective than those used by any state, Graetz said. In addition, a considerable part of the increased state revenues probably were attributable to the tougher enforcement that accompanied amnesty, he said. Goldberg said any workable amnesty would have to be highly targeted and part of a massive program to update IRS computers and tighten enforcement. There should be no forgiveness of interest or amnesty in tax-shelter cases, he said. Under the best of circumstances, Goldberg said, there are serious doubts that the IRS could implement any amnesty program during the next several years.

DOC.HEAD: Backers Will Keep Seeking Family Leave Law
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of guaranteed unpaid family leave for workers say Congress will keep sending a bill to President Bush until he signs it or they gain enough votes to override his veto. ``George Bush is going to have a family leave bill on his desk every year he is in office,'' said Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn. Backers fell 53 votes short of the two-thirds majority needed in the House to override on Wednesday, sustaining Bush's veto of a family leave bill with a 232-195 vote. ``We're going to have this kind of legislation enacted, if not this year in this session, next year or the year after,'' said House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash. ``It's inevitable.'' Fifty-seven Democrats voted with Bush to sustain the veto, along with 138 Republicans. Voting to override were 194 Democrats and 38 Republicans. The vote kept Bush's perfect veto record intact. It was the 13th veto of Bush's presidency, and Congress has failed to override any. Democrats, and some Republicans, denounced Bush's veto and said it would provide Democrats with an issue in the fall elections. They pointed to polls that show large majorities of the public support the idea. The bill would have required employers _ except those with fewer than 50 workers _ to provide unpaid, job-protected leave of up to 12 weeks to workers who have new babies or family illness or other emergencies. Those in the highest-paid 10 percent within a company would have been exempt. Employers would have been required to continue health insurance benefits for those on leave. Once the employees returned, they would have to be restored to their previous jobs or equivalent positions. Opponents charged the bill would be an onerous and costly new burden for businesses and hurt workers by discouraging employers from offering other types of benefits. Rep. Steve Bartlett, R-Texas, praised Bush for his ``courageous veto'' and charged the bill would have imposed a ``one-size-fits-all benefit'' without regard to need. Dodd, who guided the bill through the Senate, said he would introduce a new version in that chamber next week. He said it would have only minor differences and acknowledged it may be difficult to push the issue again in this session. Foley said Democrats would not try to push a milder version of the bill this year. He said the vetoed measure was a moderate bill, requiring only unpaid leave, and that most industrialized nations have programs that meet or exceed it. ``Further adjustment to satisfy the president, I think, would have to reduce the bill to a nullity, and I for one am not willing to do that,'' Foley said. Business groups had strongly opposed the measure. Though confident of victory, more than 50 lobbyists from a coalition of business groups worked Capitol Hill sporting buttons that said ``Sustain the Veto.'' Democrats pointed to Bush's own campaign rhetoric in his 1988 presidential campaign, in which he said he supported the idea of unpaid family leaves. Some Republicans criticized the president too. ``Where's our heart?'' asked Rep. Arthur Ravenel, R-S.C.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Leaders Wary of Forswearing Contributions
DOC.TEXT: Senate committee leaders aren't giving up campaign donations from groups affected by the panels' decisions, although some senators are shedding contributions from savings and loan interests. A spot check of various committee chairmen and ranking minority members turned up none willing to follow the lead of the Banking Committee's Donald Riegle, who says he no longer will accept campaign money from interest groups under his panel's jurisdiction. ``My inclination is to believe it's an isolated incident from someone who's under the gun,'' said Michael Traugott, a University of Michigan political scientist and authority on campaign finance. ``I would put it under the heading of damage control.'' Riegle is among five senators whose ties to Charles Keating Jr. and his failed Lincoln Savings and Loan are the subject of an ethics committee investigation. ``Riegle's been under some pressure because of the Keating affair and this may be the way he wants to deal with it,'' said David Shapiro, spokesman for Sen. Richard Lugar, R-Ind., ranking Republican on the Agriculture Committee. ``But there hasn't been any cloud'' over donations from farm interests, he said. Nevertheless, Lugar postponed a fund-raiser with agriculture groups until the Senate completes work on the 1990 farm bill, Shapiro said. ``There's a heightened sensitivity to how things appear.'' Spokesmen for several chairmen and ranking minority members said the senators screen individual contributions and return any that appear tainted. But none were ready to ban all contributions from one of their biggest sources of campaign dollars. Among those surveyed: _Energy and Natural Resources chairman Bennett Johnston, D-La. He received $180,461 from energy industry political action committees from 1983 through 1988, according to a study by the public-interest group Common Cause. _Environment and Public Works chairman Quentin Burdick, D-N.D., who received $97,103 from energy PACs and $327,700 from labor PACs, some of which have an interest in environmental legislation such as the pending Clean Air Act rewrite. _Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee chairman Ernest Hollings, D-S.C., who received $828,842 from business PACs. _Jake Garn, R-Utah, ranking Republican on the Banking Committee, who received $195,375 from financial institution PACs including $77,600 from those tied to S&Ls. Riegle, D-Mich., last week announced he was giving the U.S. Treasury an amount equal to all contributions he has gotten and kept from S&L interests since 1983. Rising public outrage over the multibillion-dollar thrift mess is making the return of S&L money an increasingly popular means of declaring independence from the troubled industry. Riegle led the Senate in contributions from PACs representing banks, S&Ls, securities firms and others in the financial industry, accepting $344,133 from 1983 through 1988, Common Cause said. Finance Committee chairman Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, refuses money from subsidiaries controlled by foreign corporations because he favors legislation to outlaw contributions by those PACs, spokesman Jack DeVore said. Bentsen was the top recipient of contributions from business PAC donations, with $1.8 million. Sen. John Glenn, D-Ohio, chairman of the Governmental Affairs Committee, ``accepts contributions legally given and legally received and he votes his conscience,'' spokesman Rebecca Bell said. She declined to elaborate. Glenn received $693,166 from PACs between 1983 and 1988. Sen. Alan Cranston, D-Calif., chairman of the Veterans' Affairs Committee, has no plans to follow Riegle's lead, a spokesman said. He received $1.5 million from PACs from 1983-88, and ranked seventh in receipts of labor PAC money with $410,600 and ninth in finance PAC receipts with $209,195. Glenn and Cranston are targets of the ethics committee probe, as are Riegle and Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and John McCain, R-Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Alliance Moves for Uniform License Revocation Laws
DOC.TEXT: An alliance of government and private highway safety advocates wants to give police the power to take away a drunken driver's license on any road in the country. Claiming successes in 29 states where automatic revocation laws are in effect, the heads of the National Transportation Safety Board and the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration called Wednesday for a campaign to pass similar laws in the rest of the nation. The aim is to give police in every state the power to suspend the license of a driver who refuses or fails a roadside breath test for alcohol consumption. The action is taken administratively, without a court decision. A nonjudicial hearing may be held if the driver appeals. The laws have passed all court tests in states where they have been applied, officials said. In most states, the illegal level of alcohol in the blood is 0.10 percent, but five states _ California, Colorado, Oregon, Maine and Utah _ have set the level at a more stringent 0.08 percent. The surgeon general has recommended that all states adopt the tougher law and eventually go as low as 0.04 percent for adults and 0.00 for any driver under 21. More than 1.6 million drivers are arrested each year on drunken driving charges, and about half of all the 45,000 traffic fatalities each year are alcohol-related, according to the traffic safety agency. ``We hope the coalition will stay active until we get the administrative revocation law in all 50 states,'' said NTSB Chairman James L. Kolstad, whose independent board has called for such laws in its investigations of drunken driving accidents. Kolstad and traffic safety agency Administrator Jerry R. Curry met with representatives of safety advocacy groups, the insurance industry, police organizations and others to plan a campaign for passage of laws in the remaining 21 states. ``The fact that in the morning a driver has a license, and if he or she is foolish and drinks at lunchtime and then fails a breath test, the license is lost on the spot'' would be a strong incentive against drinking and driving, Kolstad said. Curry said he had followed drunken drivers through the process of losing their licenses, being taken to a hospital for verifying tests, being processed at a police station and then having to be driven home by someone else. ``It's an absolutely debilitating experience. You think you're a criminal. You are a criminal. This is a violent crime,'' he said. ``Without such laws, we have to go through the court system, and if we're not able to get a trial date, that particular drunk's license might not be pulled for months,'' Curry said. The administrator said the laws may be tough to get passed in legislatures where it has become a states' rights issue. ``It's going to be a hard push,'' he said. Opponents of the laws include some police agencies who are concerned about the extra hearings required when driver's appeal the revocations, from trail lawyers who defend arrested drivers, and from some state motor vehicle officials concerned about the administrative costs. The federal government offers incentives of up to several million dollars to states which pass automatic revocation laws. Among organizations participating in the campaign are the American Association of Motor Vehicle Administrators, American Automobile Association, American Trucking Associations, Insurance Institute for Highway Safety, International Association of Chiefs of Police, Mothers Against Drunk Driving, Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association and National Safety Council. States that do not have the automatic revocation laws are Alabama, Arkansas, Georgia, Idaho, Kentucky, Massachusetts, Michigan, Montana, Nebraska, New Hampshire, New Jersey, New York, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, South Dakota, Tennessee, Texas, Virginia and Washington.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Frank-Ethics
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the six House members who have been reprimanded by their colleagues. In addition, 23 House members have been censured, a more serious punishment, and four have been expelled. _ Austin J. Murphy, D-Pa., reprimanded in 1987 for ghost voting. _ George V. Hansen, R-Ind., reprimanded in 1984 for financial misconduct. _ Charles H. Wilson, D-Calif., reprimanded in 1978 for false statements. _ John J. McFall, D-Calif., reprimanded in 1978 for campaign violation. _ Edward R. Roybal, D-Calif., reprimanded in 1978 for lying under oath. The Ethics Committee had recommended censure. _ Robert Sikes, D-Fla., reprimanded in 1976 for financial misconduct.

DOC.HEAD: Losses Mount at S&Ls Outside Government Control
With PM-S&L Losses-States
DOC.TEXT: The nation's privately run savings and loans continue to pile up losses despite an all-out effort by the government to seize failed institutions. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision said Wednesday that the 2,505 S&Ls outside government control on March 31 lost $271 million in the first three months of this year. That marked a sharp improvement from the $3.1 billion loss in the final three months of 1989, but it was a drop from the slight $10 million profit in the first quarter of last year. Information was withheld on an additional 350 still-open institutions controlled by the Resolution Trust Corp., an agency created last year to close and sell failed thrifts. It is expected to issue data on those institutions next week. Nearly one-quarter of the surviving institutions lost money and S&Ls overall lost money in 20 states. Although there was a vast improvement in Texas, the state hardest hit by the S&L crisis, the industry deteriorated in Northeastern states hit by lackluster real estate markets. Texas thrifts lost $110 million in the January-March period, compared with $2.2 billion in the same period a year earlier. However, S&Ls in New York lost $162.9 million, compared with a $61.6 million profit a year ago. Massachusetts lost $68 million, compared with a $100,000 loss. The industry in Connecticut lost $104.2 million, compared with a $3.5 million profit. Analysts contended that reporting profit results separately for private and government-controlled thrifts amounts to sugar-coating bad news and interferes with their ability to analyze the entire industry. The thrift office collects information from both sets of S&Ls and in the past had always released both groups of figures. ``It's hogwash,'' said Bert Ely, a financial institutions analyst in Alexandria, Va. The thrift office ``wants to be the good news boys.'' However, thrift office director Timothy Ryan declared, ``I'm not ... Mr. Rosy Scenario.'' ``Putting the two together presents an inaccurate picture of the industry,'' he said. In Wednesday's report, the thrift office did not say how much the losses were reduced by government subsidies to S&Ls bailed out in 1988. Ely estimated the subsidy at between $1 billion and $1.5 billion per quarter. The 1988 deals are coming under increasing criticism from Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, and others in Congress who say they provided acquirers with virtually guaranteed profits for very little investment. Ryan, in a news release, greeted the first-quarter results as a sign of progress. ``It appears that deposits and profits are returning to the strong part of the industry,'' he was quoted as saying. However, at a news conference, Ryan told reporters it was too soon to draw conclusions from the data. He said he would not know if the industry is capable of surviving until sometime early next year. ``Should we jump up and down and declare victory?'' he asked. ``No. This is still a very tough situation, in my view.'' The thrift office divided the S&L industry into four parts: 310 institutions expected to fail, 311 struggling thrifts that may fail, 620 S&Ls that are somewhat weak but are expected to survive and 1,264 institutions in good shape. Only the institutions in the last group earned what investors consider an acceptable return, $692 million. The next best group earned a subpar $192 million. The struggling S&Ls lost $281 million and the expected failures lost $874 million. ``You have an enormous segment of the industry that isn't making it,'' Ely said. Wednesday's report was about a month late. Ryan said the agency had changed its data collection process and hoped to release the reports on time in the future.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Budget-The Elderly
DOC.TEXT: Here are some of the tax increases and spending cuts for fiscal 1991 that budget negotiators are considering that would affect the nation's elderly:
DOC.HEAD: Social Security
DOC.TEXT: _A three-month delay in the annual cost of living adjustments that are made each January. _Increasing the portion of benefits subject to federal income taxes from 50 percent to 85 percent. _Lowering the income level at which recipients must pay income taxes on their Social Security benefits, now $25,000 for individuals and $32,000 for couples, to $12,000 and $18,000 respectively.
DOC.HEAD: Medicare
DOC.TEXT: _Reducing the reimbursements hospitals get for capital improvements. _Slowing the growth of the rates doctors are paid for performing various procedures. _Limiting payments to hospitals for interns and residency programs they operate. If the budget negotiators decide that even more cuts are needed in Medicare, they may choose these areas. _Increase the $28.60 monthly payment Medicare enrollees pay for their coverage. _Increase the $75 annual deductible, which is the amount of medical costs Medicare recipients must pay before the government begins sharing their expenses. _Increase the 20 percent share of medical expenses that Medicare beneficiaries must pay.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Criticizes Mexican Demand for Turnover of Drug Agent
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh says Mexico's request for the arrest of a federal drug agent investigating the 1985 torture-murder of a colleague could disrupt improved law enforcement cooperation. Thornburgh on Wednesday lashed out at the Mexican government's refusal to cooperate in the investigation of the killing of Enrique Camarena, a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent who was abducted in Guadalajara. Thornburgh said Mexico's request for the extradition of DEA Agent Hector Berellez and an informant who arranged the April 2 kidnaping of a Guadalajara doctor charged with participating in Camarena's killing was a ``step backward'' in improved U.S.-Mexican law enforcement cooperation. The attorney general said Mexico appeared to be retaliating for continued U.S. efforts in the case, which include the indictment earlier this year of two former high-ranking Mexican law enforcement officials on charges they participated in the killing. ``Unfortunately, it would appear this most recent action that's contemplated by the government of Mexico is in some way intended to retaliate for some of these efforts,'' Thornburgh said at the National Press Club. ``We were obviously distressed by what could lead to a breakdown in what had up to this date been a very constructive relationship between Mexican and American authorities.'' The Mexican government last week formally asked the State Department to arrest Berellez and Antonio Garate Bustamante on charges of illegally abducting Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain. Alvarez, a 42-year-old gynecologist, was seized at his office by four armed men and flown to El Paso, Texas, where he was arrested by DEA agents on charges of participating in the killing of Camarena. Garate has said in interviews that he arranged for Mexican police to kidnap Alvarez. Berellez testified in court that he was authorized by senior DEA officials to approve the operation and offered to pay $50,000 as reward plus expenses. Thornburgh said the request for the two extraditions marred a ``vast improvement in relationships between Mexican and American law enforcement authorities'' that began when President Carlos Salinas de Gortari took office in late 1988. He reiterated U.S. ``determination to see this prosecution through'' and said ``it's a mistake for the government of Mexico not to cooperate in this investigation, not to bring to justice those persons who have engaged in acts or contributed to this dreadful incident.'' ``We will not rest until we have brought to the bar of our justice those persons responsible,'' Thornburgh said. ``We hope and expect that our friends and neighbors in Mexico will understand our outrage and our determination to see this case through to completion. ``We need to act together to deal with the drug traffickers, to deal with the money launderers,'' the attorney general said. ``And a step backward in that regard is something I think brings dismay to all of us in law enforcement.'' The Alvarez kidnaping sparked accusations that the United States was encroaching on Mexican sovereignty. Thornburgh defended DEA's role in the Alvarez arrest during an interview May 10 when he invited the delivery of other defendants in the Camarena case that the Mexican government has declined to turn over to American authorities. The defendants still at large in Mexico include the former head of the Mexican Federal Judicial Police and the former head of the Mexican branch of Interpol, the international law enforcement agency.

DOC.HEAD: Republicans Say Bush Must Fight for Defense Dollars
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans say President Bush risks losing the battle over military spending to the Democrats unless he becomes personally involved in the fight. ``There's no guidance. I'm flying by instinct,'' Rep. Bill Dickinson of Alabama, ranking Republican on the House Armed Services Committee, said after he and other lawmakers met with Bush on Wednesday. The president reiterated his support for the level of military spending adopted by the Senate Armed Services Committee _ a total of $289 billion that slashes $18 billion from his original request for the 1991 fiscal year. In a session with Vice President Dan Quayle, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and national security adviser Brent Scowcroft, Bush also urged lawmakers to approve continued production of the B-2 bomber, elements of the anti-missile Strategic Defense Initiative and other major weapon systems. But with the House Armed Services Committee beginning to craft a defense bill today to the House-approved figure of $283 billion _ and Democrats certain to push for deep cuts, GOP lawmakers pressed the administration to indicate what level of spending is acceptable. ``There's no bottom line for SDI. No suggestion for B-2,'' said Dickinson. He said he is willing to operate on his instincts but would prefer that the administration state ``what is totally unacceptable.'' Republicans conceded that the administration is faced with a difficult task because congressional and White House negotiators have yet to reach agreement on how to cut $50 billion from the deficit in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. ``The whole thing is lost in the mist of the budget summit,'' said Rep. Joseph McDade of Pennsylvania, ranking Republican on the House Appropriations defense subcommittee. In the White House session, McDade said he proposed that Cheney and the ranking members of the congressional armed services and defense appropriations subcommittees work to reach agreement on a military budget total. But that proposal received little support from lawmakers who want to avoid pre-empting the budget summit. Conservative Democrats and Republicans are also pushing the president to lobby harder for various weapons, warning that without a phone call from Bush or an invitation to the White House the program may be severely cut or killed. ``Everybody indicated that the president has to engage himself,'' McDade said. ``He understands it.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said after the White House meeting that it will take strenuous efforts by Bush, Cheney and Scowcroft to save the B-2 stealth bomber. The House Armed Services Committee is poised to follow its chairman, Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., and end the program at the 15 planes currently in production. Support for the radar-evading aircraft is eroding in the 100-member Senate, where opponents say privately they have 40 solid votes to cancel the weapon. The dire predictions come as Aspin's committee is weighing a reduction in Bush's proposed budget of $4.7 billion for SDI to $2.9 billion, said congressional sources who requested anonymity. The Senate Armed Services Committee, in approving its version of the bill, cut nearly $1 billion from the president's request. Several House Armed Services panels were beginning work on the defense bill today, with the seapower and strategic and critical materials subcommittee facing the toughest task _ cutting $3 billion from Bush's request of $16.3 billion for the Navy. The panel's chairman, Rep. Charles Bennett, D-Fla., said it will likely approve funds for one Trident nuclear missile submarine and one Seawolf attack submarine. The Senate Armed Services Committee, in its bill, approved $1.2 billion for the Navy's 18th Trident sub but deferred the administration's request to buy two Seawolfs for $2.3 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 9:30 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Documents Show Controls Relaxed Despite Concerns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Prenoon lead likely with hearing testimony
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission relaxed the control of low-level radioactive wastes despite repeated concerns expressed by staff advisers and the Environmental Protection Agency, internal documents show. The documents were obtained by a congressional panel that is questioning the decision, announced last month, that the NRC no longer regulate a wide range of low-level radioactive materials from nuclear power plants, laboratories and hospitals. NRC commissioners were called to defend the action today before the House Interior energy and environment subcommittee. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., the subcommittee's chairman, said the NRC policy ``has the potential to endanger the public health'' and ``is an open invitation to abuse by unscrupulous operators'' who want to dump radioactive materials in ordinary landfills. Under the new policy, such low-level wastes as gloves, clothing, lab equipment and even buildings and equipment at nuclear power plants can be disposed of as if they were normal garbage if radiation doses are below a certain level. The commission plans to consider exempting various wastes on a case-by-case basis as requests for exemptions are submitted by industry under the new policy guidelines. NRC Chairman Kenneth M. Carr has argued that the policy change represents a way to save lives because federal and state regulators will be able ``to spend our resources on threats that are more important.'' But representatives from the EPA, a half-dozen members of Congress and a number of state radiation control officials were expected to testify against the NRC action, announced on June 27. According to documents obtained by Miller's subcommittee, the EPA as well as key NRC staff members expressed concern repeatedly during the two years the new policy was being debated that too many wastes are being deregulated. The NRC decision would exempt from special control wastes that subject individuals to radiation doses of less than 10 millirem per year _ half the level of a normal chest X-ray. ``We believe that is too high a level (of exposure) for a blanket deregulation criteria and is not protective of the public health,'' the EPA's Office of Radiation Programs, concluded in a briefing paper submitted to the subcommittee. The EPA made similar arguments to the NRC before the policy change was made. The EPA maintained that the 10 millirem cutoff for regulatory action could result in as many as three additional cancer deaths for every 10,000 people exposed. ``Numerous standards established by the EPA, including those for drinking water, set upper limits of risk at lower levels,'' it said. According to internal NRC memos and other documents, key commission staff members also expressed strong reservations about the 10 millirem cutoff level as the new policy was debated in 1988 and 1989. A staff report in June 1988 urged that only wastes with radiation doses of 1 millirem per year be deregulated. Among those who objected to the 10 millirem cutoff was Robert M. Bernero, acting director of the NRC's Office of Nuclear Material Safety and Safeguards, according to the documents. Bernero in one memo to his NRC superiors expressed concern about the health effects to individuals who may be subject to numerous exposures of such wastes and the long-term effect on such materials on the waste stream. But the objections from Bernero and other staffers were overruled by senior NRC officials, the documents indicated. The EPA later suggested the cutoff be set at 4 millirem per year, but that was rejected. ``In their zeal to relax the regulation of the nuclear industry, the NRC commissioners have ignored the objections of their own staff experts, the Environmental Protection Agency, the states and the public,'' said Miller. The nuclear industry _ as well as the NRC commissioners _ have argued that the wastes that are at issue emit only extremely small doses of radiation.

DOC.HEAD: Treasury Chief Leans Toward Limiting Deposit Insurance to One Account
DOC.TEXT: Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady appears to be leaning against lowering the $100,000 limit on deposit insurance but in favor of restricting insurance to one account per person. In an appearance Wednesday before the Senate Banking Committee, Brady refused to be pinned down on what specific changes he favors in deposit insurance. But he said, ``I can't see a rush to lower it (the insurance limit) at this particular time.'' Asked about limiting insurance to one account per person, he said, ``If you were going to start any place, that would be a place to start.'' Brady said the Treasury was studying a proposal to charge depositors a fee for insurance, an idea that sparked a furor when it was first floated by the Bush administration in January 1989 and then quickly withdrawn. Currently, depositors do not pay for insurance directly. However, banks and savings institutions pay a premium. Charging banks with risky portfolios more for deposit insurance is an idea ``we should look very closely at,'' Brady said. His statements were similar to views expressed by Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan to the Banking Committee earlier this month. Brady agreed with Sen. Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich., the committee chairman, and Sen. Jake Garn of Utah, the senior Republican on the panel, that Congress should overhaul the financial system next year. He said his department would make specific recommendations on the overhaul after the end of this year when it completes a study of the issues. Many economists blame deposit insurance for encouraging savings and loan owners to speculate wildly because they knew the government would pay off depositors if their gambles soured. However, Brady said the S&L crisis should not deter Congress from permitting commercial banks to venture into the insurance and securities industries. ``I don't think we ought to take the thrift debacle and make it such a big factor in our minds that we don't face the issues in the banking industry,'' he said. The thrift industry was deregulated without requiring S&L owners to risk more of their own money, Brady said. Consequently, any expansion of bank powers ought to be linked to strong capital requirements, he said. ``We learned all too painfully from the thrift crisis that a crucial protection for the taxpayer is requiring firms to have a substantial amount of their own money at risk to absorb losses,'' he said. ``We will not propose changes to the financial services regulatory structure that would increase the taxpayers' exposure,'' Brady said. ``...
