Retaining the status quo is not an attractive option.'' Banks are losing some of their best business to securities firms, who underwrite short-term borrowing called commercial paper for major companies, he said. At the same time, banks have been hindered from freely expanding across state lines and fully entering such lucrative fields as insurance and securities, the Treasury secretary said. As a result, banks have had to concentrate their lending in riskier areas such as commercial real estate lending, energy and farm loans and leveraged buyout loans, he said. Brady suggested ``there are lessons to be learned'' from the banking system in Europe, where banks enjoy much wider financial powers than in the United States. He also said the complex system of financial regulation in the United States ought to be streamlined. Currently, there are three federal agencies regulating banks, another overseeing S&Ls and one supervising credit unions, plus 50 state regulatory agencies. ``We ... need to explore the reform of our regulatory structure, although, to be frank, the inevitable turf fights involved may prevent the full achievement of this goal,'' Brady said.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Bill Headed for House Floor Action
DOC.TEXT: Major legislation to curb job discrimination is headed for House floor action with sponsors brushing off Bush administration warnings that it would usher in the use of minority hiring quotas. ``We did not bring forth a bill that will lead to quotas or any danger of quotas,'' Rep. Don Edwards, D-Calif., said Wednesday before the House Judiciary Committee approved the bill, 24-12. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., said last week that the measure, which closely matches a bill already passed by the Senate, would not come up for House floor action until after lawmakers return from their August recess. Civil rights forces, however, are urging him to reconsider and bring the bill to the floor before the break. Five Supreme Court decisions last year would be effectively overturned by the bill, the top legislative priority of the civil rights movement. Provisions range from a ban on racial harassment in the workplace to punitive damages for discrimination victims in extreme cases. At the core of the debate is a provision designed to overcome a Supreme Court ruling that favors employers in certain discrimination lawsuits. Until last year, companies could win if they proved the employment practices leading to the disparity were required by ``business necessity.'' The new ruling made it easier for employers, placing on those filing suit the burden of proving the practices in question were not business necessities. The combination of damages plus the bill's definition of business necessity would trigger an upsurge in discrimination suits, critics say. ``This should really be called the plaintiffs' lawyer's full employment act of 1990,'' Rep. F. James Sensenbrenner Jr., R-Wis., told the Judiciary Committee. Under the bill, business owners would feel compelled to turn to racial and ethnic hiring quotas as a way of protecting themselves in advance from such lawsuits, the administration contends. President Bush has said repeatedly that he would like to sign a bill to combat job bias but not one that would lead to quotas. The Judiciary Committee's majority Democrats easily beat back Republican-sponsored amendments designed to limit damages courts could award discrimination victims and tighten the rules governing fair-hiring lawsuits. Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., conceded ``there are horror stories about over-enforcement'' of similar laws, but he said such instances were rare and that those intent on discriminating often would find the means to get away with it. ``The advantage is overwhelmingly with the sophisticated bigot,'' he said. Rep. Henry J. Hyde, R-Ill., said the problem was that the phrasing of the bill does more than merely negate last year's Supreme Court decision and actually represents gains for civil rights forces. ``I would concede the employer groups do not want a level playing field _ they want one that assists them,'' Hyde said. ``But I also learned that the civil rights groups do not want a level playing field.'' The House Education and Labor Committee, whose chairman, Rep. Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., is a chief sponsor along with Edwards, already has approved the legislation. Two minor amendments were adopted by the Judiciary Committee before it approved the measure. One would clarify the definition of business necessity. The second would encourage the use of dispute resolution procedures outside the court system to resolve discrimination cases. Rep. Craig T. James, R-Fla., a veteran attorney, expressed skepticism. He said urging non-judicial settlements was ``a beautiful sentiment'' but that the amendment was ``a waste of paper'' because it would never be used.

DOC.HEAD: In New Political Climate, Neophyte Challenges Communist Boss
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mongolians frequently use only one name. ^An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: In a legislative race epitomizing the conflict between young reformers and the old guard in the new political climate, a lawyer with no political experience is taking on the Communist Party boss. Ganbold, the 29-year-old candidate of the fledgling Party of National Progress, favors rapid privatization and bold political change. He says he volunteered to challenge 61-year-old Gombojavyn Ochirbat, arguably the most powerful man in Mongolia, in Ulan Bator's 12th District race for the Great People's Hural. It is the first time the Hural's 430 seats are being contested by non-Communist parties, and the Communists say that shows how far Mongolia has strayed from its authoritarian past in the seven months since they agreed to reform under pressure of pro-democracy street rallies. Ganbold and other opposition candidates want more change _ and are finding considerable support among voters in the capital. In last Sunday's primary, Ochirbat received the most votes but nearly half went to opposition candidates, including Ganbold. The other opposition parties are now backing Ganbold, the only remaining opposition candidate in the district, and have given the race top priority in this Sunday's second, decisive round of balloting. ``The Communist Party in Mongolia is already going down, not just the organization but the theory of communism. I decided it would be appropriate not to allow the head of the Communist Party to be a deputy,'' Ganbold said Wednesday. He spoke at party headquarters in a traditional-style ger, or nomad's tent, after returning from a full day of meeting with voters. He was weary but exhilarated. ``One of my fears that older people would be against me disappeared today, as I met a lot of older people who said they were willing to back me,'' he said. The communist Mongolian People's Revolutionary Party, which has ruled this Central Asian nation for seven decades, clearly regarded District 12 as a safe place for Ochirbat to run. It is one of several bleak, impoverished shantytowns on the fringes of Ulan Bator. Many of its 5,300 registered voters have come recently from the countryside, where Communists are strongest and where there is little news of the revolution that has swept other Soviet bloc nations. Neither candidate is from the district _ residency is not a legal requirement. Ochirbat may have expected that the residents could not resist the chance to have the ruling party chief as their Hural delegate. The party chairman, a white-haired, dignified-looking man, took office in March after popular demonstrations swept the incumbent of six years from power. His past posts include head of the party ideology department, president of the party-controlled trade union and deputy chief of the party Organization Department. Ganbold is a junior-level officer in the Ministry of Law and Jurisdiction. Like many Mongolian intellectuals, he studied in the Soviet Union and says he learned there that communism doesn't work. He can make a good case that it hasn't worked well for District 12. ``The district has no kindergarten, no schools,'' Ganbold said. ``The electricity stops sometimes. There is no telephone in the district.'' Ganbold said he has cannot promise that he could provide the services the district lacks, but can vow to give the problems more attention. He admits his campaign got off to a slow start _ he didn't begin door-to-door visits until Wednesday. But he said Ochirbat still hasn't campaigned in person, sending high party officials instead. At a news conference Tuesday, Ochirbat said some Communist Party members criticized the district's Communists for not campaigning harder on his behalf. But he did not announce any plans for taking a more active role. Nor did he outline any program for helping the district, saying only that his party was now firmly on the path of reform.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Charged With Falsifying Repair Records
LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines may have put thousands of passengers at risk by falsifying jet maintenance records, federal prosecutors said in announcing indictments against the carrier and nine of its managers. Eastern, struggling to rebuild in bankruptcy court after a bitter strike, replied that corrective actions have been taken and the airline now is safe. Federal regulators agreed. Unprecedented in the airline industry, the 60-count indictment unsealed Wednesday charged Eastern and high-level managers with conspiring to falsify safety and maintenance records to avoid flight delays and cancellations. ``The motivation was to get the airplanes into the air. An airline only makes money with planes in the air,'' said Andrew J. Maloney, a U.S. attorney in New York. Maloney said the charges involved critical items, including radar, landing gear, automatic pilot instruments and fuel systems, but that none of the alleged violations caused accidents or injuries. ``Thousands of innocent passengers may have been put at risk every day by the criminal actions of these defendants,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement. The charges, returned by a grand jury in Brooklyn, capped a 10-month investigation. Plea bargain talks collapsed when Eastern refused to admit to a conspiracy. The indictment charges conspiracy, fraud, falsification of documents and obstruction of justice. It names Eastern and high-level managers including Edward Upton, former vice president of maintenance and engineering, and Thomas Lewis, Eastern's maintenance director for the region from Washington to Montreal. If convicted, Eastern faces a fine of up to $30 million. The other defendants face up to five years in prison and fines up to $250,000 on each count. Until a few days ago, five of the defendants were employed as maintenance supervisors by Eastern, Maloney said. A 10th employee will be charged separately, he said. The alleged violations took place from July 1985 to October 1989 at Kennedy and La Guardia airports in New York, Hartsfield Airport in Atlanta and Eastern headquarters in Miami. By tampering with log books, work cards and computerized maintenance records, Eastern caused ``aircraft that were not properly maintained or repaired to fly and carry unsuspecting passengers,'' the indictment charged. The Federal Aviation Administration said Eastern now meets federal safety standards, and Eastern said in a statement that it had taken ``full corrective action.'' ``As a result, Eastern has become the most scrutinized airline in the industry,'' the statement said. ``And today there is no question that Eastern is safe.'' The investigation began after an Eastern maintenance supervisor told Maloney about irregularities. The grand jury found that Eastern managers had ordered that maintenance not be performed on aircraft and that records be made to reflect that it was, Maloney said. He said managers pressured supervisors and mechanics to get the planes in the air ``or perhaps risk their jobs.'' Among the irregularities cited were a failure to properly pump accumulated water out of jetliner fuel tanks. The water can freeze at high altitude and clog fuel lines. It also makes fuel gauges read high. Workers in Atlanta installed defective or untested cockpit instruments to make it appear that repairs had been made, Maloney said. Eastern employees went on strike on March 4, 1989. The airline filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code five days later. Pilots and flight attendants quit the strike several months later, but mechanics remain on strike. Maloney said prosecutors had no evidence of improprieties at Eastern since court-appointed trustee Martin Shugrue began running the airline in in April. The indictments validate strikers' claims, an official of the Machinists union said. ``Thousands of passengers were put on aircraft when they shouldn't have been,'' Tony Chapman, vice president of Machinists Local 1690, said in Atlanta.

DOC.HEAD: Space Agency Gets Good News Amid Gloom: A Flawless Launch
LaserPhoto CBS3 of July 25
DOC.TEXT: NASA's failure to fix Atlantis' hydrogen leak bumped another shuttle flight into 1991. A team of NASA experts, meanwhile, began looking into the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope's woes. But the space agency also got a bit of good news Wednesday: A thrice-delayed launch of an unmanned Atlas rocket went off without a flaw. ``It's good to have something positive happen,'' NASA spokesman Jim Cast said. ``It's a definite boost to NASA morale.'' After three postponements due to mechanical problems and bad weather, the rocket blasted into space with a NASA and Air Force satellite that will study electric and radiation fields far above Earth. Earlier in the day, a last-ditch effort to fix Atlantis at the launch pad failed. Atlantis became the second shuttle in two months to be sent back to the hangar for repair of a hydrogen leak. The leak reappeared when liquid hydrogen was pumped into Atlantis' external tank. It was the third such test of Atlantis, but the agency still was unable to pinpoint the leak. NASA postponed the shuttle's secret Pentagon flight from this month to November. Columbia, the first leaky shuttle rolled back from the launch pad, now will be next to fly. Its astronomy mission, originally scheduled for May, is set for September. ``We have every reason to believe that we have no more problems ahead of us on Columbia,'' said William Lenoir, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's space flight program. The space agency has replaced Columbia's leaky plumbing. Its leak was believed to be larger than the one plaguing Atlantis and in a different place. Atlantis' delay means NASA must bump another flight into 1991. A second Atlantis mission set for this year, with the Gamma Ray Observatory, originally was scheduled for November and now probably will be early next year. Nine shuttle flights had been planned for 1990. The number is down to seven now. The shuttle developments came as a space agency team began investigating the cause of NASA's highest-profile problem: the flawed mirror on the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope that is sending back blurry images. The seven-member team, led by Lew Allen, director of NASA's Jet Propulsion Laboratory, took testimony in secret Wednesday at the plant where the mirror was made, Hughes-Danbury Optical Systems Inc. of Danbury, Conn. Allen said the group hoped to find a ``smoking gun and a fingerprint on the trigger.'' The flaw has halved the effectiveness of Hubble, placed in orbit in April by astronauts aboard Discovery, the last shuttle to fly. A repair mission by space-walking astronauts is planned for 1993. The Hartford Courant reported Wednesday that scientists may have discovered the flaw in May 1981 but dismissed the evidence because they believed it was the result of a faulty testing apparatus. On the shuttle front, NASA officials had hoped Atlantis' problem could be solved by tightening bolts around the suspected leak area, a flange in a pipe that carries liquid hydrogen from the tank to the main engines. The leak was discovered in a fueling test June 29, after which NASA temporarily grounded the three-shuttle fleet. NASA wants to get at least one shuttle up before Discovery's October mission with Ulysses, a satellite that will explore the sun's poles.

DOC.HEAD: Government Will Not Unfreeze Marcos Money for Quake Relief
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino will not agree to release funds frozen by U.S. courts so that former first lady Imelda Marcos can donate money to earthquake relief, Press Secretary Tomas Gomez said today. On Wednesday, a lawyer for Mrs. Marcos said the former first lady had offered to donate about $5 million for earthquake relief if U.S. and Philippine officials agree to release money frozen by American courts. ``The point is, if she (Mrs. Marcos) is really sincere about giving money, she can get in touch with the Philippine National Red Cross. That's as simple as that,'' Gomez said in an interview. Gomez said Mrs. Marcos, widow of the late President Ferdinand Marcos, had money beyond that in the frozen accounts that she could donate to the relief effort. Asked if the government was willing to unfreeze the Marcos accounts, Gomez said: ``Of course not. Why should the government? They (accounts) are all sequestered. ``The trouble with Imelda is she is so insincere,'' Gomez said. ``She is using the disaster for her foolishness.'' Mrs. Marcos lawyer, James Linn, said some of the Marcos assets frozen by the 1986 court order are in Swiss banks and some in Hong Kong. He did not give an estimate of amount in the accounts. Linn said U.S. officials would be asked this week to issue a court order releasing the funds. Philippine officials claim Marcos had kept up to $10 billion in Swiss accounts, but no proof has been offered to support the amount claimed. The July 16 earthquake killed more than 1,600 people, injured more than 3,000 and destroyed the homes of 90,000 people in the northern Philippines. Official preliminary estimates of damage totaled nearly $700 million. This is expected to rise as reports from remote areas reach Manila. On July 2, a federal jury in New York acquitted Mrs. Marcos of racketeering, fraud and obstructing justice in connection with the alleged theft of more than $220 million from the Philippines treasury during Marcos' 20-year rule. Mrs. Marcos has remained in New York, rather than returning to Hawaii, where she had lived since fleeing Manila during the 1986 military-civilian uprising the Mrs. Aquino rode to power. Her husband died in Hawaii in September. Both the Philippines and U.S. governments have banned Mrs. Marcos return to her homeland, citing national security threats.

DOC.HEAD: Report Charges Israel, In Effect, Condones Needless Deaths
DOC.TEXT:
An American human rights group is accusing Israel's government of condoning needless killing of Palestinians by failing to curb soldiers' excesses or to adopt tight rules on opening fire. ``Israeli policies all too often encouraged a lack of restraint by IDF (Israel Defense Force) troops,'' says a 126-page report released Wednesday by Middle East Watch, which is based in Washington, D.C., and New York. The group says the death toll from army gunfire in the 31-month Palestinian uprising could be drastically cut ``if senior military and civilian officials were determined to stop unjustified killings.'' The report comes on the heels of similar findings by other human rights groups. Early this month, Amnesty International said many Palestinian victims in the uprising died ``in circumstances suggesting excessive use of force or deliberate killings.''
In a written response to the Middle East Watch report, the army denied that Israel ignores Palestinians' rights or condones violations. ``Israel is concerned about the issue of human rights no less than its critics,'' the army said. It said that Israel has imposed stricter restrictions on soldiers opening fire than mandated under international law. The army also said the report completely ignores ``wide-ranging incidents of terrorism in the uprising,'' including killings by Palestinians of fellow Arabs as alleged collaborators with Israel. Eric Goldstein, the group's research director and author of the report, said Middle East Watch officials have condemned ``collaborator killings'' in testimony before U.S. congressional committees. The report says troops have confronted the uprising with loaded M-16 or Galil assault rifles, while army figures show that soldiers were faced with guns in only 5 percent of incidents. The other 95 percent involved stone throwing, slingshots and such weapons as iron bars. ``The imbalance of weaponry underscores the propriety of treating the intefadeh (uprising) as a civil revolt rather than a war,'' the report says. In 450 Palestinian deaths through June 1989, no more than 16 soldiers were court-martialed on charges of causing death and no more than 10 were convicted, says the report, which was released in Jerusalem and Washington. The report uses the army death toll of 670 Palestinians killed in army gunfire in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. According to figures gathered by The Associated Press, 724 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldier and civilians in the revolt. At least 242 Palestinians have been slain by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators. Forty-five Israelis also have been killed. An Israeli human rights group said last month that soldiers violated firing orders by shooting 14 Palestinians in the head, chest or back despite regulations calling for them to aim for their legs. The Israeli Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories, known in Hebrew as Betselem, had studied casualties during disturbances following the May 20 massacre of seven unarmed Arab laborers by a deranged Israeli civilian.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Gains In Tokyo, Stocks Drop
DOC.TEXT: The dollar gained against the Japanese yen in Tokyo on Thursday, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange lost ground. The dollar closed at 150.11 yen, up 0.98 yen from Wednesday's close of 149.13 yen. After opening at 150.25 yen, the currency ranged between 149.70 yen and 150.25 yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues shed 331.52 points, or 1.05 percent, closing at 31,369.75. The index fell 1.19 points on Wednesday. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bond was quoted at 85.79 points as of 3 p.m., down from Wednesday's close of 85.98. The yield stood at 7.460 percent, up from 7.425 percent. Currency dealers said the dollar opened higher as traders showed their belief that easing U.S. interest rates had receded, but then weakened slightly on dollar-selling by importers. ``The dollar turned a bit bearish,'' said Kozo Yoshida, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank. Yoshida said the dollar's retreat from its opening was partly attributable to an easing of tension in the Persian Gulf. Diplomatic sources, based in the Persian Gulf, said Iraqi troops would begin pulling back from the border with Kuwait Thursday prior to direct talks to try to solve the two nation's dispute over land and oil production. Kuwait had insisted that Iraq withdraw what it claimed were massed forces at their common 100-mile border before Kuwait would sit down for negotiations this weekend with Baghdad, said the sources who spoke anonymously. On the stock market, the Nikkei index started falling with a wait-and-see attitude prevailing among many market players, coupled with the yen's weakness against the dollar, said a dealer with Nomura Securities, who spoke anonymously.

DOC.HEAD: Rocket Blasts Off with Radiation-Monitoring Satellite
With PM-Space Shuttle, Bjt
LaserPhoto CBS3 of July 25
DOC.TEXT: A satellite that will illuminate Earth's invisible magnetic field in shades of red, white and blue orbited the world today after a flawless ride into space on an unmanned rocket. The 143-foot Atlas rocket roared into a clear sky Wednesday from Cape Canaveral Air Force Station and the satellite separated as planned after several delays. ``It's always a good feeling to see a launch vehicle leave the ground,'' NASA manager Sid Saucier said. ``So far, everything is going great.'' It was the fourth attempt in six days by NASA and rocket builder General Dynamics to launch the Atlas, the first commercial version of the rocket ever flown. The postponements were caused by a helium leak, bad weather and a corroded power transfer switch in the rocket. The weather was perfect as the Atlas boosted the $189 million Combined Release and Radiation Effects Satellite to an orbit 217 miles by 22,236 miles high to study radiation in space. The 2-ton satellite, a joint program of NASA and the Defense Department, holds 24 chemical-filled canisters that will be ejected starting this fall. Ultraviolet rays from the sun will ionize the released barium, lithium and other chemicals, creating large, glowing clouds that will spread along Earth's magnetic field lines. The barium-laden clouds will resemble the aurora borealis, or the northern lights. The display will be visible to the naked eye, enabling scientists to measure electric fields in space and see how they interact with normally invisible charged particles. The first releases will be made over American Samoa in the South Pacific in September. Four months later, people in North America will get their first glimpse of the clouds. Additional canisters will be released next summer over the Caribbean, providing a view from Florida and the southern portions of Alabama and Georgia. Wednesday's launch was the first of a commercial Atlas and the eighth commercial rocket launch by an American company. NASA used earlier versions of the Atlas to launch planetary probes and other mid-size payloads.

DOC.HEAD: Lab Mouse Supply Restored After Fire
DOC.TEXT: A year after fire wiped out the nation's leading producer of laboratory mice, breeders at the Jackson Laboratory are nearly back to full production. Last year, the director of the National Institutes of Health said the loss of the mice was ``creating a very serious problem for research scientists all over the world.'' Now, production had returned to almost 80 percent of what it had been, laboratory director Kenneth Paigen said Wednesday. Before the May 10, 1989, fire, the lab distributed 2 million mice a year to 11,200 laboratories worldwide. Many of the mice, which carry unusual mutations and conditions that mimic human diseases, are unavailable anywhere else. ``The demand now is greater than it has ever been before,'' Paigen said. The laboratory's mice were used in 80 percent to 90 percent of the scientific studies with mice published in leading journals last year, Paigen said. Ninety-six percent of mouse studies on AIDS relied on Jackson Laboratory mice, he said. The fire destroyed the large mouse breeding facility at the laboratory, but did not spread to the research labs, which are in a separate building. Four hundred thousand mice died in the fire. But at least some individuals or frozen embryos of all strains survived, so no valuable mutant mice were permanently lost. The threat of another supply interruption remains, however, because temporary breeding facilities set up in trailers after the fire could suffer power losses, Paigen said. Ground has been broken for the construction of new permanent breeding facilities, he said. The recovery's total cost is expected to be $32 million, of which Congress has approved up to $25 million.

DOC.HEAD: Aerospace Executive To Head Independent NASA Committee
DOC.TEXT: Norman R. Augustine, chief executive of Martin Marietta Corp., will head a committee created by the Bush administration to review NASA's plans for the future of the nation's space program. The committee is to report in four months on all phases of the space program and make recommendations for alternate approaches when appropriate. Augustine was the only appointee named in an announcement Wednesday by Vice President Dan Quayle, who is head of the National Space Council. The announcement said Augustine was recommended by Richard H. Truly, the administrator of National Aeronautics and Space Administration.
DOC.HEAD: Report Sets Timetable for Developing High-Speed Magnetic Train
DOC.TEXT: The Army Corps of engineers has laid out a plan under which the federal government can help U.S. industry develop high-speed magnetic trains by the year 2000. The corps' ``Preliminary Implementation Plan,'' released Wednesday, sets a timetable under which various federal agencies would evaluate and eventually oversee the development of magnetic levitation trains in the United States. Under the plan, the federal agencies studying the feasibility mag-lev trains should know by 1993 whether the United States can regain the lead in this transportation technology. ``We believe there is a golden opportunity for magnetic levitation in this country,'' said Dan Mauldin, deputy director of civil works for the Army Corps of Engineers. Sen. Harry Reid, D-Nevada, said the report echoes what he and Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y., have been saying: ``If we want a U.S. mag-lev and its benefits, we must put U.S. money into it. Foreign money will get us foreign mag-lev systems.'' Mag-lev trains are propelled by magnets on a cushion of air over a rail. Such trains could travel up to 300 miles per hour, use less energy than conventional transportation modes and would be cheaper to ride than airplanes, according to the report. So far, only the Japanese and the Germans have developed prototype mag-lev trains but several projects are under discussion in the United States. Mag-lev was invented and pioneered in the 1960s and 1970s by Americans, including James Powell and Gordon Danby at Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island. But U.S. advances stopped around 1974 when the federal role in mag-lev development ended, Moynihan said at a news conference. The report released Wednesday estimated it would cost between $800 million and $1.2 billion to develop a 20-mile, single track demonstration project, not including the cost of land for right of way.
DOC.HEAD: Foreign Investors Pulling Billions Out of United States
DOC.TEXT: Foreign investors sold $4.2 billion worth of American stocks and bonds more than they bought in the first three months of 1990. The Securities Industries Association reported Wednesday that the biggest item was a net sale of U.S. Treasury bonds: $6.5 billion worth. There were also net sales of $3.3 billion worth of U.S. stocks. Net foreign purchases of bonds issued by U.S. agencies and private companies amounted to only $5.6 billion. The association called these figures a sign that the United States can no longer count on foreigners to finance its federal budget deficit and provide money for U.S. industry. Net sales of U.S. Treasury bonds by Japan alone amounted to $2.9 billion, compared with net purchases of $1.4 billion in the last quarter of 1989. Japanese also sold a net $702 million worth of stock in U.S. companies and $84 million worth of their bonds. In 1989 foreigners bought nearly $55 billion worth of U.S. Treasury bonds, a record level.

DOC.HEAD: Rescue Workers Were Afraid of Air Bag
LaserPhoto NY6
DOC.TEXT: Emergency workers and bystanders showered in the middle of a busy street to wash off a powdery residue, 22 people were taken to the hospital and two federal agencies are investigating. A major chemical spill? No, a minor rear-end auto accident in which one car's air bag deployed. ``Nobody at the scene had a handle on the procedures for the situation and there were a lot of people there with a lot of emergency experience,'' said Jeff Wells, who heads the ambulance service in neighboring Weehawken. Federal transportation and consumer officials say that the hysteria was unnecessary and that the incident in this New York City suburb points up the need for rescue workers to learn how to handle accidents involving air bags, standard equipment in about 3 million 1990 cars. The confusion began when Patricia Sanchez's 1990 Plymouth Sundance hit a car stopped for a red light and her car's air bag deployed. The nylon bag stored in the hub of the steering wheel inflates in one-twentieth of a second and deflates through vents in its side within a few more seconds. Packed in cornstarch or talcum for lubrication, the deployed bag gives off a puff of powder and leaves a fine white residue inside the car. But rescue workers believed the air bag had exploded and spewed sodium hydroxide, a form of lye, on Ms. Sanchez. A quarter-gram of sodium hydroxide, along with a small amount of baking soda, are created as byproducts of the chemical reaction that inflates an air bag in a front-end collision, said Tim Hurd, spokesman for the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, which is investigating the crash. The amount of lye is minuscule, and it's only a minor irritant, he said. But rescue crews cut away some of Sanchez' clothes, thinking they were contaminated with chemicals. Firefighters cordoned off the intersection, set up a shower in the street and rinsed off anyone who came in contact with the powder. Emergency workers, fearing more trouble with the bag, cut it out of the car and now can't find it. ``They were frightened of the powder,'' said Louis Ciavatti, acting city fire chief. ``It could have been overplayed.'' ``There is absolutely no reason to hang back and delay treatment because an air bag has deployed,'' Hurd said. The problem is that air bags and the way they work are still a mystery to many people, said Frank Ghiorsi, regional director for the National Transportation Safety Board, which is also investigating the July 14 crash. Hurd said he interviewed Sanchez and she does not think the air bag malfunctioned. He also said there were no stray bag fragments or other evidence of an explosion in the car. Twenty-two people were taken to Jersey City Medical Center, and 10 of them were treated as if they had been exposed to sodium hydroxide, said hospital spokeswoman Sheila Paris Klein. Sanchez also was treated for chemical burns and spent two nights in the hospital. But federal investigators believe Sanchez only suffered friction burns from the inflating air bag. They don't believe any of the other injured were exposed to lye. Clarence Ditlow of the Center for Auto Safety in Washington, a consumer group that supports air bags, said drivers have suffered friction burns but never chemical burns from air bags. Alan Miller, a spokesman for Chrysler Corp., which manufactures the Sundance, said the company will investigate the incident. Passive restraints, either air bags or automatic seat belts, are required in front seats in all 1990 domestic cars. Bags are contained in all Chrysler U.S.-made cars, about half of Ford Motor Co. cars and about 15 percent of General Motors Corp. cars. GM held a seminar in June to teach U.S. and Canadian firefighters about the new technology and rescue techniques involving air bags.

DOC.HEAD: Marilyn Quayle Released Four Days After Hysterectomy
DOC.TEXT: Marilyn Quayle has been released from Bethesda Naval Hospital, four days after undergoing a hysterectomy. The vice president's press office said Wednesday that the operation was performed because Pap smears indicated she had ``severe dysplasia,'' a cell abnormality that experts said can be a precursor to cervical cancer. The announcement was the most specific yet about the surgery performed on the vice president's wife. ``Mrs. Quayle had two abnormal Pap smears earlier in the year,'' Quayle press secretary David Beckwith said in a written statement. ``A Cone biopsy was performed and revealed sever dysplasia. A hysterectomy was performed Saturday morning. ``Because of early detection due to the excellent work of the cytologists at the National Naval Medical Center, Mrs. Quayle is expected to have a full and complete recovery,'' he said. Dr. Allan B. Weingold, chairman of the department of obstetrics and gynecology at George Washington University Medical Center, said severe dysplasia is ``a premalignant disease'' that is ``100 percent curable'' by a hysterectomy. ``She is cured,'' said Weingold, who was not involved in treating the vice president's wife. He said experts grade dysplasias as mild, moderate and severe. Beyond that, the cell abnormalities are classified as carcinoma in situ, or already advanced to the cancerous state, and, in the final stage, as invasive cancer. Not all dysplasias become cancers. ``She was two steps away on the benign side from invasive cancer,'' said Weingold. ``It's 100 percent curable by the kind of surgery she had. That's the whole purpose of the Pap smear.'' A hysterectomy involves removing all or part of a woman's uterus, ending her ability to bear children. Mrs. Quayle turns 41 on Sunday. The Quayles have three children, ages 16, 13 and 11.

DOC.HEAD: De Beers Tightens Grip on Diamond Market With Soviet Deal
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union will get more badly needed foreign hard currency by selling its rough diamonds exclusively through the South African giant De Beers in a five-year multibillion-dollar agreement. The company is advancing the Soviets $1 billion against future diamond sales, said officials who announced the agreement on Wednesday. The Soviet Union, among the world's largest diamond producers, reached the deal with De Beers because it wanted to sell a huge stockpile of diamonds without disrupting the market, De Beers said. The Soviet Union had refused to deal directly with the South African company because of apartheid, but now is willing to openly do business with De Beers' new Swiss arm, De Beers Centenary AG. South Africa-based De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., controlled by the Oppenheimer family of South Africa, established the publicly-held Swiss company in May. De Beers Centenary said in a statement that it reached the agreement with Glavalmazzoloto of the USSR for the exclusive export and sale of the Soviet Union's diamond production. Glavalmazzoloto is the main administration for precious metals and diamonds under the Soviet Union's council of ministers, De Beers said. It said its Luxembourg-based subsidiary, Centenary Holdings SA, has agreed to make a secured advance of $1 billion to Glavalmazzoloto against future diamond deliveries. Repayment would be made over five years beginning in November, it said. Nicholas Oppenheimer, deputy chairman of De Beers Centenary, said as a result of the agreement that the Soviet Union, at a time of ``considerable financial strain,'' was assured ``a steady flow of funds from diamonds'' during the life of the contract. Company officials estimated the contract could be worth as much as $5 billion. Moscow has been seeking foreign credit as it tries to bring market-oriented reform to an economy plagued by shortages. The Soviet diamond stockpile will be held at De Beers' London-based marketing arm, the Central Selling Organization, as collateral for the $1 billion advance, De Beers said. The organization, a 57-year-old cartel, has the financial resources to hold large stocks of diamonds, which is how it keeps the market stable. Although De Beers said it had had no direct contact with the Soviet Union since 1963, diamond experts say De Beers already sells most of the Soviet Union's West-bound diamonds. All the world's major diamond producers, including Botswana, Australia, Tanzania, Zaire and Namibia, have sales contracts with De Beers Centenary. The Central Selling Organization, as a result, markets 80 percent of the world's rough diamond production of some 100 million carats. The organization had sales of $4.09 billion last year. Large-scale diamond mining began in the Soviet Union in the 1950s and is concentrated in the Yakutia region of North Eastern Siberia, De Beers said. The Soviet Union doesn't disclose the value of its output.

DOC.HEAD: Mystery Remains Over AWOL Trek of Arrested Soldiers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Or was ...', to CORRECT spelling of Augsburg sted Augsberg
DOC.TEXT: Six U.S. soldiers who went AWOL from intelligence posts in West Germany and were arrested at a Florida beach known for UFO reports won't be court-martialed. But many other questions about the bizarre case remain. Were the six _ five men and a woman _ acting on ``psychic input'' from biblical figures and preparing for the world's end, as a friend of one suggested? Did they plan to move to the West and live ``like a survivalist group,'' as a police captain said he was told by two in the group? Or was there another explanation of the events that began unfolding when the six, who held top-secret security clearances, left the 701st Military Intelligence Brigade in Augsburg, West Germany, early this month? ``Don't judge them yet. They have a right to defend themselves,'' said Anna Foster, at whose Gulf Breeze, Fla., home four of the six were arrested July 14. Ms. Foster, a civilian described by authorities as a psychic, is not charged in the case and said she could not elaborate. The Army offered the six ``non-judicial punishment'' _ no trial by court-martial _ after an investigation by the Army Intelligence and Security Command found no evidence of espionage, officials said Wednesday. At Fort Knox, Ky., where the six were being held, Maj. Ron Mazzia said they could receive reductions in pay or rank, or both, and could be fined. Specific terms will be determined by an officer acting as a sentencing judge. Having lost their security clearances, the six might be discharged, Mazzia said. They were reported missing in West Germany on July 9. On Friday the 13th, Pfc. Michael Hueckstaedt was stopped in Gulf Breeze for driving a van with non-working taillights. A computer check found him listed as absent without leave. Army information and a search of the van revealed the whereabouts of the five other soldiers, Gulf Breeze police Capt. Kenneth Hicks said. Besides Hueckstaedt, 19, of Farson, Wyo., they are Pfc. Kris Perlock, 20, of Osceola, Wis.; Pfc. William Setterberg, 20, of Pittsburgh; Spc. Vance Davis, 25, of Valley Center, Kan.; Spc. Kenneth Beason, 26, of Jefferson City, Tenn., and Sgt. Annette Eccleston, 22, of Hartford, Conn. Hicks said Ms. Eccleston and Hueckstaedt said little when questioned by him and the FBI. ``Really the only thing they said is they were heading out west and they were just going to kind of live out in the woods, kind of like a survivalist group,'' Hicks said. He said they mentioned Santa Fe, N.M., and Texas. As the six were moved first to Fort Benning, Ga., and then to Fort Knox, another story emerged. It focused on Beason, doing his second hitch in the Army. Beason had trained in Pensacola and dated and corresponded with Ms. Foster. He always was interested in science fiction. Beason created miniature spaceship models and other artwork and was trying to write a book, friends said. ``He can draw or make anything, as long as it's not real,'' said Beason's brother-in-law, Charles Reed. Four or five years ago, Beason hired commercial photographer Stan Johnson of Bybee, Tenn., to photograph some of his creations. Johnson and his wife, Vivian, a former English teacher, helped him with his writing. They're in their 50s and said they became a kind of second family for Beason. During a two-week visit last Christmas, Beason seemed his usual self, but in a few phone calls since May, he took a different turn. ``He just reeled and rambled and ranted,'' said Mrs. Johnson, describing one call. She said he thought ``the disciples and some of the other spirits have talked to him or else one of the other people in that group, the group that was arrested _ and told them the Rapture is near and for them to prepare for it.'' Some fundamentalist Christians believe that during the Rapture, believers will be swept to heaven before the world ends. Some relatives who helped raise Beason after his parents divorced were fundamentalists, friends said. Mrs. Johnson said Beason wouldn't be swayed when she questioned his statements. ``He'd say, `You just don't understand. I am a chosen. ... I've been told to do this,''' she said. Do what, specifically? Beason said he and the others would go to Florida on ``a missionary project'' to prepare for the end, Stan Johnson said. ``The real interesting part of this was that, when the second coming of Christ occurred, Jesus Christ was going to arrive in a spaceship.'' Reed added: ``He thinks he's doing ... what God wants him to.'' Beason and Hueckstaedt found a used Volkswagen van after they flew from West Germany to Tennessee and apparently picked up the other AWOL soldiers for a drive to Gulf Breeze, a Florida Panhandle town whose claim to fame is the number of reported sightings of unidentified flying objects. A symposium of the Mutual UFO Network concluded there July 8, police said. Lee Perlock, the mother of Kris Perlock, said her family was close and their religious practices were mainstream. Other relatives of the soldiers said the same thing about their religious backgrounds but were reluctant to discuss details of discussions with them after the arrests. Notified of the Army's disciplinary decision, Mrs. Perlock's husband, Ron, reacted with relief. ``This has been going on for so long, not knowing.'' They hope to see their son soon. In the meantime, Mrs. Perlock said softly, there are ``a lot of unanswered questions.''

DOC.HEAD: Advance In Disease That May Have Afflicted Lincoln
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have found a defect in the body's ``scaffolding'' that may cause a genetic disease that makes people unusually tall and lanky and might have affected Abraham Lincoln. The disease, called Marfan syndrome, can also include severe heart problems that may cause basketball players to die suddenly on the court, Dr. Reed Pyeritz of the Johns Hopkins School of Medicine in Baltimore said Wednesday. Pyeritz and his colleagues identified the defect in a protein called fibrillin, a component of the elastic fibers in skin, blood vessels and ligaments. ``There's something wrong with the scaffolding and glue that holds us together,'' Pyeritz said at the Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor, where some of the nation's leading researchers have gathered for an annual genetics course. Lynn Sakai of the Oregon Health Sciences University, who collaborates with Pyeritz, has identified the gene for fibrillin and is now conducting studies to determine its function. She said in a telephone interview that she and Pyeritz soon will be able to confirm whether a defect in the fibrillin gene and the consequent defect in fibrillin itself are the cause of Marfan syndrome. Meanwhile, a research group in Finland has obtained preliminary evidence through an entirely different approach that the genetic defect for Marfan syndrome is on chromosome 15, one of the 23 pairs of human chromosomes. If the fibrillin gene is also on chromosome 15, that will be further evidence that the gene is indeed the cause of the disorder, Sakai said. ``If fibrillin is lnked, that would be quite a breakthrough,'' she said. Doctors have speculated that Lincoln had Marfan syndrome, not only because he was tall and lanky but also because toward the end of this life he had an illness that could have been congestive heart disease, Pyeritz said. That is one of the consequences of a defect that causes the aorta, the principal output vessel from the heart, to expand and tear. The aorta problem is also what causes the on-court death of basketball players and can cause sudden death in others with Marfan syndrome, Pyeritz said. The discovery of the gene for Marfan syndrome would enable doctors to begin devising new treatments, but it would not guarantee any change in the near future for Marfan victims, Pyeritz said. People with the disorder can currently be helped by surgery to replace part of the aorta with a dacron tube, Pyeritz said. Other aspects of the disease can be difficult to treat, however. Many patients have a dislocation of the lenses in their eyes, and some are blind. Others have curvature of the spine, chest deformities and loose joints. The work by Pyeritz and Sakai and their colleagues identifying fibrillin comes after researchers have tried for years to determine what defect could cause such a wide range of symptoms. The elastic fibers containing fibrillin are found in eye ligaments, bones, blood vessels and other affected tissues, Pyeritz said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Stocks Fall
DOC.TEXT: The dollar moved higher against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, while the key index on the Tokyo Stock Exchange fell for the fifth consecutive trading day. The dollar closed at 150.11 yen, up 0.98 yen from Wednesday's finish of 149.13 yen. It opened at 150.25 yen, the day's high, and moved as low as 149.70 yen. The dollar has gained 2.86 yen in the six trading days after it fell to 147.25 yen last Wednesday. Spot transactions totaled $10.112 billion, down from Wednesday's $11.130 billion. ``The sentiment toward the dollar turned strong in the afternoon,'' said Chiyuki Watanabe, a dealer with Sanwa Bank. In addition to diminishing prospects for easing U.S. interest rates, Ms. Watanabe said another negative factor for the yen was a mid-day local news report that Tokyo tax authorities have decided to impose a total of $46.6 million in taxes on Japanese securities firms which allegedly compensated losses of major clients after the 1987 Black Monday stock plunge. News reports said more than 10 securities companies compensated a combined total of as much as $113 million for their major institutional and individual clients. Officials of the Tokyo Tax Administration refused to comment on the report, saying an investigation is still under way. The news reports said the tax agency determined that the costs used as compensation by securities firms involved fell under ``entertainment expenses,'' which are subject to taxation. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 331.52 points, or 1.05 percent, closing at 31,369.75. The index shed a marginal 1.19 points on Wednesday. The Nikkei index has lost 1,685.87 points in five trading days. Volume on the first section was estimated at 330 million shares, down from Wednesday's 350 million shares. Yozo Asai, an analyst with Yamaichi Securities, said weakening bond prices and concern over higher interest rates in Japan dampened the market. ``To make matters worse, the news of (securities firms' compensation of losses) made many market players lose'' confidence,'' Asai said. In bond dealings, the price of the benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bond slipped to 85.62 points as of 5 p.m. (4 a.m. EDT), down from Wednesday's 85.98. The yield stood at 7.500 percent, up from 7.420 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Jeans commercials showing Marla Maples dumping two supermarket tabloids into a trash can have been banned from CBS and NBC. The 15-second spots feature Maples, rumored to be Donald Trump's mistress, in a pastoral setting wearing No Excuses jeans and holding copies of the National Enquirer and Star. An Enquirer headline reads: ``Trump Mistress Close to Suicide.'' ``The most important thing we can do today is clean up our planet. And I'm starting with these,'' Maples says as she tosses the papers. ``Things look better already.'' Beth Bressan, a CBS vice president in charge of program practices, said the ad was rejected as ``unduly disparaging towards those newspapers.'' ``Our longstanding policy is not to sell ad time for the airing of private disputes,'' said Rick Gitter, NBC vice president of ad standards. Neil Cole, president of New Retail Concepts, which makes the jeans, said he doubted his company would change the commercials. ABC hasn't made a decision on the spots. The Fox network and the Turner Broadcasting System have decided to air the ads beginning Aug. 15

Dimitrios I, spiritual leader of 250 million Eastern Orthodox Christians, visited Niagara Falls as part of his monthlong tour of the United States. The 75-year-old patriarch leaned against a railing Wednesday and gazed at Horseshoe Falls. Dimitrios I did not mention the falls in either of his public addresses in upstate New York. But American Orthodox leaders said visiting the cataract had been his dream since childhood. ``All the Europeans, they dream someday to see these phenomena,'' said Bishop Timotheos of Detroit, whose diocese includes upstate New York. Later in the day the patriarch went to Boston, the final stop on the first ever U.S. visit by a holder of his office. Dimitrios I has sought to bridge the gap between the Greek and other national Orthodox churches in the United States.

Singer John Denver has helped set up an institute in Aspen, Colo., on saving the environment. Denver said the Aspen Institute on Global Change aims to bring together researchers and people who want to get involved at the local level. Saving the environment is ``the most important task that faces the human race at this time,'' Denver said at a news conference Wednesday. The institute will be co-sponsored by the Amway Corp. of Ada, Mich., the U.N. Environment Program and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Amway's chief operating officer, William Nicholson, said the direct-marketing company has committed $500,000 to the institute over the next five years. NASA said it contributed $40,000.

Brenda Feigen, co-founder of Ms. Magazine and producer of the movie ``Navy SEALS,'' says she did her part to improve the action film's portrayal of women. ``Navy SEALS,'' starring Charlie Sheen, features the elite force of highly trained Navy teams fighting terrorists. ``I think it is feminist, humanist to hate terrorism. It is natural and logical,'' Feigen said. Feigen concedes she was concerned about the portrayal of women in the Orion release. She runs the production company that made the film. ``There were scenes with the role of Claire (co-star Joanne Whalley-Kilmer) that made no sense ... and in one instance there was a reference to her so obscene I can't even repeat it,'' she said. ``I said this has to go.'' Her next project is more directly tied to her past work with the American Civil Liberties Union and the women's movement _ a made-for-TV movie about two black girls in the South sterilized against their will.

DOC.HEAD: $5.2 Million Award Winner in Jail Over $700 Alimony Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A Maryland windshield wiper inventor who was awarded $5.2 million in a patent infringement lawsuit against Ford Motor Co. is serving a 120-day sentence for nonpayment of alimony. Montgomery County Circuit Judge J. James McKenna sentenced Robert W. Kearns of Gaithersburg on Friday after a contempt hearing that day on Kearns's refusal to comply with terms of a 1989 divorce decree, court records show. Kearns, 63, refused to vacate his house and share award proceeds with his ex-wife. On July 13, a federal court in Detroit ordered Ford Motor Co. to pay Kearns royalties for his patent for intermittent windshield wipers. Kearns, who was once offered $30 million to settle the Ford case, has similar patent infringement suits pending against General Motors Corp., Chrysler Corp. Daimler-Benz AG, Honda Motor Co. Toyota Motor Corp., Nissan Motor Co. and 24 other car manufacturers. Kearns could be released from the Montgomery County jail in Rockville before the 120-day period ends if he meets all of the conditions set by the judge. Court records said Kearns must pay $700 in back alimony for June and July and remove his belongings from the Gaithersburg house by Aug. 15. A buyer is ready to settle on the property once Kearns vacates it, the documents said. Kearns has listed the Omni International Hotel in Detroit as a temporary address. McKenna also ordered Kearns to designate his former wife, Phyllis Kearns, as the primary beneficiary of his life insurance policies, said William Paton, a Rockville lawyer familiar with the suit. Paton said McKenna also has asked Kearns to establish ``some sort of financial mechanism'' for Phyllis Kearns to receive 10 percent of the award from his patent litigation. Kearns and his wife filed for a divorce April 9, 1986, in Montgomery County Circuit Court. A revised final divorce order was issued in May 1989 by Judge Peter Messitte. Earlier this month, Kearns filed an appeal to the Maryland Court of Special Appeals contesting McKenna's order to vacate the home, court records said.

DOC.HEAD: Hazelwood Could Be Skippering Ship in Nine Months
LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: Former Exxon Valdez skipper Joseph Hazelwood could be back in command of a ship in nine months under a penalty imposed by the Coast Guard for the nation's worst oil spill. Hazelwood, in an interview, said he was satisfied that the Coast Guard dismissed misconduct and negligence charges against him and decided to let him to resume his career. At a Coast Guard hearing Wednesday, Administrative Law Judge Harry Gardner suspended Hazelwood's captain's license for nine months and put him on probation for three more months. Misconduct and negligence charges were dismissed after Hazelwood agreed to enter no-contest pleas on two other counts: that he violated Coast Guard policy by drinking liquor less than four hours before taking command of the tanker, and that he improperly left the vessel's bridge while it was headed for jagged Bligh Reef. But Hazelwood said after the hearing he was angered by newly disclosed papers about crucial blood-alcohol tests that had implied he was drunk when the tanker spilled nearly 11 million gallons of crude last year. Hazelwood's attorneys said the blood analyzed may not have been his. ``It's what we said all along and nobody would listen to us,'' Hazelwood said. ``The possible skulduggery that goes along with it is enough to make anybody angry. ``If it weren't for our discovery of this, it would have been buried forever and a lot of people with political agendas would have been very happy.'' Hazelwood's attorneys contended that evidence may have been covered up, a charge the Coast Guard and National Transportation Safety Board denied. The 987-foot tanker was en route from the Alaskan port of Valdez to Long Beach on March 24, 1989, when it struck the reef in Prince William Sound. Wednesday's hearing followed a trial in which an Alaskan jury acquitted Hazelwood of charges of intoxication and recklessness, but convicted him on a misdemeanor of negligently discharging oil. He is appealing. ``We've cleared the two major hurdles as far as my personal life is concerned,'' said Hazelwood, 43, of Huntington, N.Y. ``Of course, I'd like to wake up tomorrow morning and it would all be done, but that's not going to happen.'' He said his life has been consumed by litigation since the disaster put his name in headlines. Asked if could he ever see a time in his life when he would be free of litigation, Hazelwood sighed and said, `Not in this century. I can see going into the year 2000 with some pending litigation of some sort.'' Hazelwood said he thought his experience might drive other tanker captains out of the business. ``Everything in your private life is paraded in public, and you're lampooned from pillar to post. Is the job worth it? I still haven't made up my mind. A lot of good people will leave the field rather than risk this.'' Hazelwood said he had pondered going into some other field, perhaps even law given his exposure to it, as he waits nine months to be eligible to reclaim his captain's license, issued in 1966. ``But I can't foresee myself putting on a pinstripe suit, grabbing a bag and getting on the Long Island Rail Road every day,'' he said. ``But I won't foreclose anything.'' The Coast Guard offered no explanation for dismissing the charge that Hazelwood was intoxicated during performance of his duties, with a blood alcohol level over the Coast Guard's .04 percent limit. Also dismissed without explanation was a charge he left an improperly licensed third mate in control of the ship. Hazelwood's attorney, Michael Chalos, disclosed during the proceeding the defense recently found documents indicating that the blood test taken 10{ hours after the spill was mishandled and unreliable. In interviews, Hazelwood's lawyers said the tardy disclosure of the alcohol records constituted misconduct by the Coast Guard and the NTSB, which had access to the documents. The Coast Guard said the blood matter had nothing to do with the plea agreement. The NTSB said in a statement the blood sample was tested at certified labs and the NTSB had no control over the results. Michael Peat, director of ChemWest Analytical Laboratories in Sacramento, where the sample was analyzed, denied the specimens were tampered with, but declined to elaborate.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher As Market Waits For Economic Data, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was higher in European trading late this morning but dealers said they didn't expect any major movement until Friday's release of U.S. economic data. Gold prices were weaker in modest trading. Dealers said the dollar could move in either direction if there were any surprises in Friday's second-quarter data on the U.S. gross national product. Though some dealers said a general dollar bearishness persisted, others said the currency might be headed for a small recovery after recent declines, based on technical considerations. Some dealers also said a slight dollar rise was warranted because of political turmoil in East Germany, which could have a negative impact on the strength of the German mark. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.98 yen to a closing 150.11 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 150.55 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6251 West German marks, up from 1.6170 _1.3808 Swiss francs, up from 1.3715 _5.4470 French francs, up from 5.4185 _1.8312 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8215 _1,189.25 Italian lire, up from 1,183.62 _1.1522 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1518 In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.8088, down from $1.8125 late Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $370.60 a troy ounce this morning, down from $373.25 bid late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $370.60, down from $372.50 late Wednesday. Gold in Hong Kong rose $2.11 to close at a bid $369.94. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $4.86 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $4.89.

DOC.HEAD: One of Three Released Detainees Back in Custody
DOC.TEXT: Police have again arrested one of three lawyers authorities detained without charge for 20 days in a crackdown on advocates of multiparty democracy, a police official said today. The government of President Daniel arap Moi announced Wednesday that it released Gitobu Imanyara as well as two other lawyers, Mohamed Ibahim and John Khaminwa. However, Imanyara, who edits a monthly magazine often critical of the government, was immediately rearrested ``in connection with other criminal allegations against him,'' said Noah arap Too, head of the Criminal Investigation Department. He said officials were questioning Imanyara, 37-year-old editor of the Nairobi Law Monthly, which has served as a platform for the advocates of political pluralism in this one-party East African nation. ``If at the end of the day we don't find any evidence (supporting the allegations), we will release him,'' otherwise, he will be charged, said Too. He declined to discuss the case further. Imanyara, Ibrahim and Khaminwa were detained July 5 in a wave of arrests that netted Kenya's most prominent proponents of multiparty democracy. President Moi and other Kenyan leaders argue that more than one political party could lead to war among the nation's approximately 40 tribes. Those still detained include former Cabinet ministers Charles Rubia and Kenneth Matiba, and Raila Odinga, a businessman son of a former vice president, Oginga Odinga. The government gave no reason for the lawyers' release. However, clergymen, lawyers and foreign governments, including the United States, had severely criticized the detentions. The detentions came two days before the date set by pro-democracy forces for a rally to forward their cause. The government banned the July 7 rally, sparking riots in Nairobi, four other major towns and rural areas, in which at least 28 people died and scores of others were injured. Kenyan law permits detention without charge or trial of individuals considered a threat to state security.

DOC.HEAD: New Orleans District Attorney Acquitted of Gambling, Racketeering
LaserPhoto NU3
DOC.TEXT: District Attorney Harry Connick said he was ready to begin his re-election campaign after a federal jury acquitted him of gambling and racketeering charges. The U.S. District Court jury on Wednesday also were acquitted actor Paul Burke, former assistant U.S. Attorney Patrick Fanning and New Orleans businessman Wilson Abraham of similar charges. Three other men charged in the December indictment, accused bookmaker Walton Aucoin, and two of his employees, Steve Bertolino and William Condon, were convicted on two counts each of gambling and racketeering. ``I really thought we shouldn't be here,'' Connick said after the verdicts were returned. ``I didn't expect to be convicted.'' Prosecutors claimed that Connick, at the urging of his three acquitted co-defendants, illegally returned seized records to Aucoin so the admitted bookie could pay off and collect gambling debts. Connick maintained that Aucoin was entitled to have his gambling records returned under state law. Aucoin said he needed them to pay federal taxes on his gambling income. Before the trial started, Connick said the charges were contrived by U.S. Attorney John Volz as part of a political vendetta. Connick is a Democrat, Volz a Republican. Before the jury began deliberating the case Wednesday morning, Connick, 63-year-old father of Grammy-winning jazz musician Harry Connick Jr., went to Baton Rouge to qualify for re-election in the Oct. 6 primary. He has been Orleans Parish district attorney since 1974. ``I'm ready to get on with campaigning,'' Connick said after the verdicts. ``I don't think this will hurt my chances for re-election. I think the people of New Orleans will know what was going on here.'' The indictment came after a yearlong investigation begun by Volz, who later turned the case over to the Justice Department to avoid any appearance of bias or conflict. Volz didn't answer his office telephone and he was not at home Wednesday evening.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Youths Attacked With Baseball Bats
DOC.TEXT: Several men armed with baseball bats attacked a group of Jewish youths before dawn today in the chic Opera district of the capital, police sources and a French news agency reported. A reporter for Agence France-Presse said he was among several witnesses to the attack, carried out by unidentified young men at about 1 a.m. According to the agency, the attackers approached a parked car containing an unspecified number of young Jewish men, recognizable by their yarmulkes. The gang pulled the Jewish youths out of the car and clubbed them, injuring at least two seriously enough to require emergency treatment and hospitalization later, AFP reported. The attackers fled, menacing bystanders with their bats. Police sources confirmed the AFP account and said two men were later taken into custody and were being held pending identification by witnesses to the attack. The specific motive for the attack was not known. A wave of anti-Semitic vandalism followed the desecration in May of a Jewish cemetery in Carpentras, where a corpse was dug up. The incidents shocking the country and drew loud denunciations from most political leaders about a perceived rise of anti-Semitic and anti-immigrant feeling in France.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Army Begins Removal of Chemical Weapons from West Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to ADD several protesters, heavy security. Picks up 9th pvs, `Environmental groups ...' ^By TERRENCE PETTY
DOC.TEXT: A convoy of trucks today began spiriting away a vast cache of deadly nerve gas once secretly stored by the United States just outside this small West German town. The snaking convoy removed the first batch of 100,000 gas-filled artillery shells stored at a U.S. military site at Clausen, which is near Kaiserslautern in the southwest part of the country. The lethal cargo, destined for destruction on a Pacific atoll, is being removed under a 1986 U.S.-West German agreement at a cost of $83.1 million. Hundreds of crack paramilitary West German police troops lined the convoy route and stood guard on overpasses as the the long line of 80 trucks began shuttling the shells at about 8 a.m. Vans carrying police with riot gear accompanied the convoy. The first trucks arrived at Miseau, about 30 miles away, 2{ hours later. At Miseau, the containers are to be loaded onto special trains that will take them to Nordenham, on the North Sea, where they will be placed aboard U.S. Navy ships for transport to Johnston Atoll. The weapons will be destroyed in a specially built incinerator on the U.S. atoll about 800 miles southwest of Hawaii. Only about 20 of the 80 trucks that left Clausen actually carried the chemical weapons sealed in air-tight containers, said U.S. Army spokesman Jim Boyle. He said the rest contained decontamination crews, firefighters, West German and U.S. soldiers, police, monitoring teams and medical staff. ``The chemical team is equipped to contain any incident,'' he said. ``The operation is going as planned.'' Only four protesters were spotted. They draped posters, including one that said ``Evil is simply being shifted from here to the Pacific,'' over a stone wall next a church along the convoy route in Clausen. They said they were protesting the U.S. decision to destroy the weapons on the atoll and said it would jeopardize the populace there. ``This solution is the worst of all worlds,'' said protester Ursula Siegmayer. She said she had participated in earlier chemical weapons protests, ``But we're not proud of our success. This is a catastrophe.'' The West German government is paying $31.2 million of the removal costs; the U.S. cost is $52 million. Environmental groups, which for years had campaigned for the removal of the chemical weapons, had sought to block the transport, charging that the safety measures were inadequate. The environmental Greens party, one of the strongest opponents of chemical weapons, went to court to try to block the removal. But an administrative court in Cologne ruled Friday there was no evidence to prove the Greens' contention that faulty data had been used to calculate the risk of transportation. Several groups of private citizens concerned about the safety of the transport had also unsuccessfully tried to block the operation through court action. ``The shells are safe to handle and transport due to their construction and condition. The munitions, without fuses, are double packed in vapor-proof secondary steel containers and military vans for transport,'' the U.S. Army said in a statement announcing the beginning of the operation. The approximately 100,000 artillery shells _ in 6-inch and 8-inch sizes _ are loaded with liquid nerve agents, according to Boyle. They were brought to Clausen between 1958 and 1968, where they have remained since. Clausen is the only site in West Germnay where chemical weapons are stored. Boyle said the Army has done everything to make sure the operation goes ahead without a hitch. ``There is safety measure upon safety measure redundant throughout the operation,'' he said. One convoy will take the weapons daily from Clausen to Miesau over the next 30 days. The rail transport to the North Sea port will take about a week and will be conducted at night. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and former President Ronald Reagan agreed in 1986 to remove the chemical weapons by 1992. The timetable was advanced by President Bush. It was only in March that authorities acknowledged that the chemical weapons were stored in Clausen.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Slam Nation's Mid-Section, Hurricane Watchers Eye Arthur
DOC.TEXT: Residents in the nation's heartland mopped up after severe thunderstorms that dropped as much as 11 inches of rain in Oklahoma. More thunderstorms were expected today. Tornadoes touched down Wednesday in Minnesota and Nebraska, while hail fell in Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, Wyoming and Montana. Local flooding was reported in Oklahoma, Arkansas, Wyoming, South Dakota and eastern Massachusetts. Eleven inches of rain fell on Lawton, Okla., in five hours Wednesday, but no major flooding was reported. On Wednesday, rain also fell in Florida, Georgia, Mississippi, Louisiana, South Carolina, Pennsylvania, New York, Wisconsin, North Dakota, Missouri, Iowa, Colorado, New Mexico, Idaho and Washington state. A strong dust devil in Redding, Calif., tore large pieces of tile from a roof, the National Weather Service said. The high temperature for the nation Wednesday was measured in Imperial, Calif., where the mercury hit 109 degrees. DOC.HEAD: What's in a Name? Ask Homer Simpson
DOC.TEXT: Homer Simpson is no longer bothered by the question: ``What's in a name?'' ``It's a big joke,'' the 36-year-old bar owner said. ``When I try to order a pizza, cash a check, use a credit card, all kinds of things, I usually get laughs.'' The Madison man is the unlucky inheritor of one of the country's most talked about names, shared with the patriarch of television's ``The Simpsons.'' Things haven't been the same for Simpson since the animated series began on the Fox network. Simpson said he was teased as a child because his name was Homer, but he thought those days were over. ``The name was unusual _ kids looked for something to poke fun at and there it was, but it blew over when I was 16 or 17,'' Simpson said. ``Then when the show came on, I said, `Oh no, here it goes all over again.''' He has been featured in Time magazine, newspapers and on television, and he gets a lot of telephone calls. ``At home, I get a lot of prank calls, usually from little kids,'' Simpson said. ``I usually talk to them and tell them Bart's outside playing around.'' He's kidding. He really doesn't have a son name Bart like the television Homer. His son's name is Chris, but his wife has the same birthday as the animated guy. Simpson said he shares traits with his TV namesake, including the nickname Moe. Both enjoy betting on football and go to dog tracks. ``I started watching the show's credits because I thought it had to be somebody I grew up with,'' he said. ``It was too strange.'' Simpson said having a suddenly famous name has not been too great a burden. ``It's been fun and there's been no harm done by it,'' he said. ``I've put up with being Homer Simpson all my life, so it really doesn't bother me anymore.''

DOC.HEAD: Agreement On First Meeting Of Prime Ministers, But Border Crossing Blocked
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with anti-government protest at Panmunjom, unification minister statement, details of disagreement. Picks up 13th pvs, `Lee Hae-hak...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SEL1
DOC.TEXT: North and South Korea signed a historic agreement today calling for their prime ministers to meet for the first time in an effort to end four decades of Cold War confrontation on the divided peninsula. Yet in a scenario which has become commonplace in inter-Korean relations, the day ended in controversy, name-calling, and dissidents shouting anti-Seoul government slogans near the border. The acrimony erupted over the aborted border crossing by five North Korean civilians and threatened to spread a blight on today's accord. The planned fall talks between the prime ministers would focus on easing political and military tensions, promoting exchanges and other moves toward cooperation between the two states formed 42 years ago. By signing the accord, North Korea's Communist government of Kim Il Sung tacitly recognized the legitimacy of the Seoul government of President Roh Tae-woo. ``This precious fruit will open a decisive chapter in a road to ending national division and achieving peaceful unification,'' said South Korean chief delegate Song Han-ho. North Korean chief delegate Paik Nam Jun said the agreement ``will open a new chapter in the history of the national division.'' The 19-point accord was signed at the truce village of Panmunjom located inside the 2{-mile-wide Demilitarized Zone which separates the communist north from the capitalist south. The first prime ministers' talks would be held Sept. 4-7 in Seoul. A second meeting is to be held Oct. 16-19 in the North Korean capital of Pyongyang. The two prime ministers _ Kang Young-hoon of South Korea and Yon Hyung Muk of North Korea _ are ceremonial figureheads with little policy-making roles. But their meeting as the highest level ever between the two rival states is seen as symbolically significant. Within an hour of the document's signing, however, the rival Koreas became embroiled in disagreements over housing and travel arrangements for five North Koreans who were to have crossed the border today for a two-day visit in Seoul to plan a Korea-wide rally for unification. Eight hours after the crossing was to take place, it was effectively canceled. A communist official reportedly hung up the phone during a conversation with a South Korean official. Shortly thereafter, a North Korean radio broadcast blamed the south for blocking its delegates. The Seoul government had insisted that the North Koreans stay in a luxury Seoul hotel. The North Koreans wanted to stay with South Korean dissidents at a church house _ and travel in the dissidents' cars. Three disappointed South Korean dissidents waiting as a welcoming party started chanting anti-government slogans. ``Down with (President) Roh Tae-woo who blocks unification!'' they shouted. In Seoul, Unification Minister Hong Sung-chul issued a statement saying ``all indications compel us to doubt if North Korea really had any intentions to make (the crossing and) the rally come off as scheduled.'' He said ``our door remains open.'' Lee Hae-hak, one of three South Korean dissident leaders at Panmunjom, called it ``a political show.'' He said cancellations of the North Koreans' visit would make it difficult to plan and hold the unification rally that had been planned for Aug. 15. The five were to be the first civilians since a 1985 family exchange to cross the border with the approval of both governments. Paik, the North Korean delegate, said if citizens on both sides of the border have difficulty in arranging the rally, ``relations of the south and north would further deteriorate and it would have an irreparably bad impact on the holding of the high-level talks.'' Proposed sites for the Aug. 15 rally include the capitals of either North or South Korea or Panmunjom. The Koreas were divided after World War II. They fought a three-year civil war that ended in 1953 and have remained rivals since. Their border is the most heavily fortified in the world, with more than 1.5 million armed men on either side. South Korea offered last week to open its border to North Koreans for unrestricted travel for five days starting Aug. 13. It challenged North Korea to do the same for South Koreans. The north has said it would open the border on a limited basis on Aug. 15 to Koreans desiring unification. The two sides have become bogged down in a blitz of proposals and conditions, and it remains unclear whether there will be any crossings. Aug. 15 is the 45th anniversary of the liberation of Korea from Japanese colonial rule. It is a sentimental holiday on both sides of the border.

DOC.HEAD: Remains Believed To Belong To Americans Flown Out
