DOC.NOTE: Eds: To CORRECT numbers found in provinces and in Choeung Ek, SUB one graf for 13th, `Four were ... late 1978.
DOC.TEXT: With a blessing by Buddhist monks, six sets of human remains were flown out of Cambodia today for tests to see whether they are the bones of Americans missing from the Vietnam War. It was the first time since the end of the war in 1975 that communist Cambodia has allowed the repatriation of suspected remains of those missing in action, or MIA. A somber American military honor guard escorted six flag-draped aluminum caskets on board a U.S. Air Force C-141 that took off for Hawaii, where the remains will undergo forensic examination to try to identify them. Buddhist monks chanted prayers during a 15-minute memorial service conducted before an altar covered with flowers and burning incense. The six caskets sat behind the altar, and a monk sprinkled holy water to bless the dead. ``The United States appreciates the support of the Phnom Penh authorities for this undertaking,'' said Air Force Lt. Col. Thomas Boyd, spokesman for the repatriation team. ``We consider this an important humanitarian undertaking which, if successful, will help to alleviate the suffering of American families.'' The team had flown to Phnom Penh earlier today from Bangkok, Thailand, to join the group of military experts who had examined 28 sets of remains collected by the Cambodians and chose six for further tests. In Hawaii, the remains will be analyzed and identified by the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory. The remains were given an initial examination by a six-man military team in Phnom Penh on Tuesday and Wednesday _ the first such MIA mission to Cambodia since the 1975 communist takeover. ``We came and did our work and the cooperation was everything we asked for,'' Lt. Col. Joe Harvey, the U.S. team leader, told reporters Wednesday after meeting with Dith Munty, first deputy foreign minister of the Vietnamese-backed government. Harvey's team examined 28 sets of remains in a tiny laboratory at Cambodia's only medical college. The teak caskets contained bones, skulls and at least two sets of military identification ``dog tags.'' A Cambodian Foreign Ministry spokesman said his government paid $2,000 for the return of some remains from remote provinces. Harvey said six sets warranted further analysis in Hawaii. Two were found in outlying provinces and four were from Choeung Ek, an area southwest of Phnom Penh that was used as a mass execution ground by the fanatical Communist Khmer Rouge who ruled from 1975 to 1978. The Khmer Rouge were ousted after Vietnamese forces invaded Cambodia in late 1978. It was unclear if the remains found in Choeung Ek dated from the period when the Khmer Rouge held power. Eighty-three American servicemen and eight U.S. civilians are listed as missing in action in Cambodia from the Indochina war. The U.S. mission broke a long political stalemate between Washington and successive communist governments in Phnom Penh over the MIA issue. Boyd said past U.S. efforts to examine remains in Cambodia had been ``either ignored or politicized.'' He said Washington would consider sending another team to examine more remains, but added that this was not discussed during his group's visit. The United States does not recognize the Phnom Penh government. But a week ago, it announced it was withdrawing recognition of the Khmer Rouge-dominated guerrilla coalition that is fighting the Phnom Penh government, and would open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian civil war. Cambodia's Deputy Interior Minister Khim Ponn, head of a newly formed MIA commission, said he wanted to discuss normalization of diplomatic relations. But the Americans limited talks to MIAs. Most of the Americans missing in Cambodia are airmen whose planes were downed during bombing raids from 1969 to 1973 on the Ho Chi Minh Trail, the major supply route for the North Vietnamese into South Vietnam that wound through the mountains of eastern Cambodia. A total of 2,300 Americans are officially listed as missing in action in Indochina. Aside from those in Cambodia, 1,678 are missing in Vietnam, 533 in Laos and six in China's coastal waters.

DOC.HEAD: Liberian Capital Under Attack on Two Fronts
DOC.TEXT: EDITORS NOTE: The following is based partly on a pool report from journalists in Monrovia. Associated Press correspondent Michael Goldsmith was a member of the pool.

Rival rebel groups are closing in on the city from two directions in heavy fighting for control of the capital. As the battles raged Wednesday, the airfield that was Monrovia's last link to the outside world also came under attack. Fighters of rebel leader Charles Taylor resumed their offensive in the eastern part of the city. Followers of a rival rebel commander, Prince Johnson, fought off government soldiers who tried to retake Bushrod Island in the north. With gunfire echoing all around, acting Information Minister Paul Allen Wie told reporters that President Samuel Doe had no plans to step down, despite the advancing armies. ``The president thinks it is worth dying for his country,'' Wie said at a news conference at the Ducor Palace Hotel. He distributed a news release quoting Doe as saying a sudden resignation ``would lead to greater anarchy and ethnic tragedy in Liberia.'' ``I cannot heed the advice ... to quit the leadership of Liberia because it would introduce a dangerous precedent of outrageous rebellion and instability into the West African region,'' Doe said. Early Wednesday, pro-Doe troops attacked two bridges that link the city center with rebel-held Bushrod Island, but they were repulsed by heavy fire. One squad of government soldiers was seen crawling across one of the bridges but was pinned down under the heaviest gunfire yet heard in the battle for the city. Some of the soldiers lay motionless as though dead or injured. Others ran back to the safety of the government positions. Shells were also seen exploding on the other bridge, hitting a government jeep which was trying to lead an attack from that side. The wreckage of the jeep sat in the middle of the bridge. Government troops, firing from the city center, shelled rebel positions on the far side of the bridges, some rounds falling close to the city's main oil storage depot, which was in rebel hands. State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said it appeared Johnson's men controlled the island, which includes the port. Johnson is believed to have split with Taylor sometime in the past three months, and some diplomats say his army is now stronger than Taylor's National Patriotic Front. A few miles away to the east, rebels waded across a swamp and attacked Spriggs-Payne Airfield, the last way out of the city that was not in rebel hands. It was unclear whether fighters of Johnson or Taylor launched the airfield attack. Further east in Paynesville, Taylor's men resumed their offensive. Diplomats reported heavy fighting in that area, where the rebels had been blocked several weeks by government soldiers. Diplomats said Taylor's forces surrounded and effectively neutralized government troops who were barricaded inside the radio and television stations east of the city. The rebels did not attack them in order to spare the facilities, the diplomats said. The government, which the rebels accuse of corruption and human rights abuses, repeated its allegation the United States was actively aiding the insurgents. The United States has denied the accusation, and Boucher said its offer to provide safe passage out of the country for Doe stood. Doe met Tuesday with U.S. Ambassador Peter De Vos but did not ask for help in leaving the country, Boucher said at a Washington briefing. ``The Liberian people are disappointed by the United States,'' Wie told the reporters. Doe expelled the chief of the U.S. Military Mission to Liberia, Col. David Staley, on Friday after accusing him of actively supporting the rebels. On Tuesday, the government accused the United States of launching an attack on Doe's presidential mansion from a submarine, a charge immediately denied by Washington. People who said they witnessed the attack said it came from a rebel gunboat offshore. The fortified mansion returned the fire and later announced that five civilians were killed on a nearby main road. Monrovians continued their desperate search for food and water in a city where all shops were closed and where utilities have been shut down for more than a month. As many as 5,000 people were jammed into a U.S.-owned fuel storage depot near the embassy, in the exclusive Mamba Point district, seeking haven from attacks by soldiers who were going on looting sprees and attacking civilians. Most government soldiers are members of Doe's Krahn tribe. Since the insurgency began in December, they have attacked civilian members of the Gio and Mano tribes, which provide the main support for Taylor. Sixteen ambassadors met with the acting foreign minister Wednesday to complain about being harassed by troops at checkpoints throughout the city.

DOC.HEAD: New Repairs Planned For Freeways Damaged By Quake
DOC.TEXT: Two quake-ravaged freeways will remain closed six months later than planned because of revised design and construction changes on the elevated roadways. Director Robert Best of the state Department of Transportation said Wednesday an independent, private panel of engineers discovered more construction work was needed to cope with disaster-type stresses on the Central and Interstate 280 freeways. Two weeks ago, officials said the freeways, which carry 250,000 vehicles a day, would reopen in October. The freeways resemble the Cypress Freeway that collapsed in Oakland during the Oct. 17 earthquake. The quake measured 7.1 on the Richter scale, killed 67 people and caused an estimated $7 billion in damage. The new freeways are expected to withstand a quake registering 8.2 on the Richter scale. Nicholas Forell, chairman of the independent review panel, said repair work on the elevated roadways involves ``an immense engineering task. ``There is no precedent to these freeways anywhere in the world,'' Forell said. About $5 million of $39 million in original repair contracts on the two freeways has been spent to date, Best said. The revised plans could bring costs to $80 million, he said. Asked why work was started before all engineering reviews were in, Best said, ``We did that to try to expedite the reopenings ... we felt there was a good chance that work could be accommodated by getting the contracting going. ``We were taking a gamble to get these facilities opened a few months earlier than if we had waited.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Vetoes Recording Labeling Bill, Plans Abortion Announcement
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to RECAST lead; ADDS new grafs 8-10 with background on abortion bill, Picks up 8th graf pvs., `In 1985 ...' ^By GUY COATES
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Buddy Roemer said his belief in free speech led him to veto a bill that would have required warning labels on recordings that some say promote deviant behavior. The Democratic governor also planned to announce Friday whether he would veto the nation's strictest state abortion bill. Roemer vetoed the record labeling bill Wednesday as he was flanked by supporters that included Tipper Gore, president of a parents organization that pushed for voluntary labeling, and Jason Berman, president of the Recording Industry Association of America. The bill would have mandated labels for recordings with themes of rape, murder, suicide, incest, illegal drug use, child abuse and satanic worship. It also would have prohibited the sale of such recordings to people under age 17. Retailers, manufacturers and distributors of recordings would have been subject to possible six-month jail terms and $5,000 fines. Musicians and recording industry officials had threatened to boycott Louisiana if Roemer signed the bill, but he denied the pressure influenced his decision. ``As a parent and as a governor, this legislation has presented to me my most severe philosophical conflict,'' Roemer told reporters. ``My strong belief about decency in the proper upbringing of my own children versus my strong belief and dedication to freedom of speech ... and my innate desire to avoid excessive governmental interference.'' There also is pressure for Roemer to veto the abortion bill. He said he received a letter signed by law professors from Harvard, Yale, Georgetown, Stanford and other universities who concluded that ``there is virtually no chance that this particular bill would be sustained by the United States Supreme Court.'' The bill, passed in the last days of the Legislature this month, would prohibit abortions except to save the life of the mother or for cases of incest and rape. Doctors performing abortions could be sentenced to up to 10 years in prison and fined $100,000. Roemer declined to say whether he plans to veto the abortion bill Friday or allow it to become law without his signature. In 1985 when Mrs. Gore, wife of Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn., helped organize U.S. Senate hearings on record labeling, various record company executives said they planned to label records that contained explicit lyrics. State Rep. Ted Haik, the sponsor of the Louisiana bill, said the music industry can't be trusted. ``He apparently has learned nothing from the past experiences of broken promises of the music industry to develop a uniform labeling system,'' Haik said of the governor. Elton John, Ray Charles, Randy Newman, Patti LaBelle and other performers protested the bill. The Neville Brothers, favorite sons in Louisiana, called the bill racist and threatened to stop performing in their home state. The National Academy of Recording Arts and Sciences threatened to end consideration of New Orleans as a site for the Grammy Hall of Fame if the bill became law. Music industry organizations threatened to cancel planned conventions in the city. Radio stations had ``label day'' marathons, playing records that disc jockeys thought would fall under the ban. Among them were such classics as ``Stagger Lee,'' ``House of the Rising Sun,'' ``Love For Sale,'' and ``Mack the Knife.'' In May, the recording industry unveiled a voluntary labeling system that it hoped would halt state campaigns for mandatory labeling. ``We believe this voluntary system responsibly addresses the parental concerns without crossing over the line that results in unconstitutional limits on freedoms of expression,'' Berman said. ``This industry-wide standard logo provides an easily recognizable tool to assist parents who wish to monitor the music their children are buying.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Agrees To Talks With Kuwait, Diplomats Say Iraq To Pull Back Troops
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 6 grafs to UPDATE with Iraq denying there was military buildup. Pickup 5th, `Oil-rich...' TRIMS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Iraq has agreed to pull thousands of troops back from its disputed border with Kuwait, diplomatic sources say, after apparently forcing Kuwait to agree to end oil overproduction. Today, Iraqi newspapers suddenly ceased what had been daily attacks on Kuwait, and an Iraqi official confirmed that Iraqi and Kuwait representatives would open talks this weekend in the Saudi Arabian port of Jiddah. But the official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said President Saddam Hussein has not backed down on demands that Kuwait cut oil production, pay for oil Baghdad claims was pumped illegally from a field that straddles the countries' undemarcated border and forgive billions of dollars in loans. ``The ball is in the Kuwaiti court now,'' he said. Diplomatic sources said late Wednesday that tens of thousands of troops reportedly sent to the border earlier this week by Saddam would begin withdrawing today. In Geneva, where OPEC was holding a mid-year meeting, Iraq's oil minister denied there had even been a troop buildup, as published reports and diplomats had said. ``There is no such thing as massing of troops along the border,'' said Issam Abdul Rahim al-Chalabi. Oil-rich Iraq, with a $70 billion foreign debt after a fall in crude prices and a costly war with Iran, last week threatened military action against fellow oil producers Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for contributing to the overproduction that has driven down the price of crude. Iraq has 17 million people, including 1 million soldiers. Kuwait has 1.8 million residents, 20,300 in the armed forces. The U.A.E. has about 1.6 million residents and a military with about 43,000 personnel. In Geneva, OPEC oil cartel members this week are trying to put a lid on production to drive up the price, and officials from Kuwait and the U.A.E. indicated Wednesday that they are ready to go along. That agreement, along with mediation efforts by Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak and other Arab leaders, appears to have reduced tensions considerably. The Persian Gulf sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Kuwait had insisted that Iraq withdraw the forces it reportedly massed on the countries' 100-mile border before it would negotiate this weekend with Baghdad. They credited intensive mediation Tuesday and Wednesday week by Mubarak and King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. The announcement of direct Iraqi-Kuwaiti talks was made by Mubarak on Wednesday in Cairo even as the Iraqi media stepped up an anti-American campaign in response to U.S. military muscle-flexing in the Persian Gulf. The Pentagon had announced Tuesday that U.S. warships and aircraft were holding a ``short-notice exercise'' in the Persian Gulf with the U.A.E., a clear show of support for the two small states challenged by Baghdad. In Baghdad, Saddam summoned U.S. Ambassador April Glaspie for talks on Wednesday. Government radio gave no details of the meeting. In Kuwait, diplomatic sources said Saddam had assured Mubarak he would not use military force as long as Kuwait agrees to the following conditions: paying compensation for $2.4 billion in oil Iraq claims Kuwait stole, and holding direct talks on a border dispute. The oil allegedly stolen was from the Rumaila oil field, which straddles the border. Iraq claims Rumaila is exclusively its own. In addition, Iraq wants Kuwait to write off billions of dollars in loans it granted Iraq during the 8-year Iran-Iraq war that ended in August 1988. It also wants the reopening of a border air corridor. The dispute flared last week when a bellicose-sounding Iraq accused Kuwait of stealing the oil and alleged that Kuwait and the U.A.E. were causing a slump in oil prices by exceeding their OPEC production quotas. Baghdad's move was widely interpreted as seeking to pressure the two small states into agreeing at this week's meeting of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to a proposal to cut oil output.

DOC.HEAD: Treatment Blocks Kidney Disease In Rat Experiment
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUBS 4th graf, `Such a...', with 2 grafs to CLARIFY that reference to kidney complications occurred in interview, not the research paper. Pickup 5th graf pvs, ``The work raises.''
DOC.TEXT: A disease that can cause kidney failure has been arrested in rats by an experimental drug, raising hopes for a new human therapy, researchers said today. The disease, called glomerulonephritis, strikes perhaps 100,000 Americans a year, researcher Dr. Wayne Border said. A medication like the one used in the experiment may someday be able to stop the disease's progression, so patients wouldn't need dialysis or transplants, he said. Such a treatment may also work for a similar kidney complication of diabetes and high blood pressure, Border, a kidney specialist at the University of Utah School of Medicine, said in an interview. The rat study was published today in the British journal Nature. The work raises ``exciting possibilities'' in a new line of research, said Dr. Ira Greifer, professor of pediatrics and nephrology at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine and Montefiore Medical Center in New York. Existing drugs don't always work and can produce major side effects, he said. But it will take more research to determine what the new approach means for treating human disease, cautioned Dr. Lawrence Agodoa of the National Institute of Diabetes, Digestive and Kidney Diseases. Glomerulonephritis (pronounced glo-MER-u-low-neh-FRI-tis) is an inflammatory process that can destroy ball-shaped kidney structures called glomeruli. The structures help remove wastes from the bloodstream. If destruction is extensive enough, wastes can accumulate in the bloodstream and cause death. Glomerulonephritis can appear by itself or in conjunction with a chronic disease called lupus, strep throat or a variety of infections. The researchers gave rats a form of glomerulonephritis by making the rats' disease-fighting immune system attack the glomeruli. Although the cause of the human disease is not well understood, such an attack frequently appears to play a key role, they said. Then they injected some of the rats with proteins called antibodies that would seek out and latch onto a natural substance called transforming growth factor beta. Previous studies suggested that this substance stimulates the glomeruli to produce a protein meshwork that leads to destructive scarring. The scientists reasoned that if the antibodies could bind to the growth factor and disable it, the production of the meshwork might stop. Agodoa said nobody has yet shown that the growth factor plays a role in human glomerulonephritis. Greifer said he doubted the work would apply to kidney scarring caused by high blood pressure, because that scarring comes from a different process. Other researchers in the study were Selya Okuda of the Utah medical school, Erkki Ruoslahti and Lucia Languino of the La Jolla Cancer Research Foundation in La Jolla, Calif., and Michael Sporn of the National Cancer Institute.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Denounces Durenberger While Also Praising Him
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs graf 4, And as, to CORRECT Armstrong's state.
DOC.TEXT: It might have been a tribute to an honored elder statesman, so lavish was the praise _ and not the unanimous condemnation of a senator for deliberately breaking Senate rules. The Senate voted 96-0 Wednesday to denounce Sen. Dave Durenberger for financial wrongdoing. But first, senators called the Minnesota Republican a man of conscience, of influence, of decency. Afterward they lined up to hug him, shake his hand and pat his shoulder. He is, after all, one of them. And, as Sen. Bill Armstrong, R-Colo., put it, ``After this is all over and we denounce him, we still want him to be our friend.'' Durenberger was disciplined for violating Senate speaking fee and gift limits, misleading the Senate on real estate transactions involving his Minneapolis condominium and converting a campaign contribution to personal use. The Senate also ordered him to make restitution of up to $123,000 for money he received improperly. Durenberger has agreed to repay the money. The judgment marked the 24th time in 201 years that the Senate disciplined one of its own. The main case against him was made by Sen. Howell Heflin, D-Ala., chairman of the Ethics Committee. ``I wish there was ambiguity here, but there is none. I wish I could find innocence, or at most inadvertence, or inattention, or simple ignorance in Sen. Durenberger's actions here, but I cannot,'' Heflin said somberly. Durenberger sat nearly impassive through the three hours of emotional remarks, clasping his hands tightly at times and staring intently at each senator who spoke. The debate was unusually personal, with senators referring frequently to Durenberger simply by his first name. And the chamber was unusually full, with all committee business suspended for the solemn proceeding. Durenberger made his reputation building bridges among senators, politically and personally, and many of them indicated they could not forget that as they struggled with their duty. ``As senators we must unflinchingly exercise the judgment which is required,'' said Sen. Carl Levin, D-Mich. ``As a human being, I remain a steadfast friend of Dave Durenberger's and an admirer of the legislative work he has accomplished.'' Several senators said they found it hard to reconcile the evidence with the cheerful, capable man who for 12 years has played major roles in legislation affecting the disabled, minorities, the elderly, rural communities, the environment and health care. ``We all know what happened. Some of us watched it with startled mien,'' said Republican Whip Alan Simpson of Wyoming. ``I still cannot understand,'' said Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., vice chairman of the ethics panel. Durenberger has said his judgment was impaired by family problems _ the death of his first wife, a troubled remarriage, four sons going through difficult adolescences and tremendous financial stress. But Rudman said none of that could excuse his conduct. And Durenberger, looking him in the eye from across the aisle, nodded solemnly in agreement. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, noted with approval Durenberger's ``resolve to reform,'' a theme that suffused the Minnesotan's brief floor remarks after the vote. He vowed to be a better man, a better senator. He said he would work harder, shoulder more responsibility. He called the moment an ending but also a beginning. ``I ask your forgiveness,'' he said. ``I need your friendship.'' Later, Durenberger said his decision to ``take my medicine'' and forge onward rather than resign was due to strong support from his colleagues. He said their comments Wednesday ``caused me to believe that if anything, I'll be even more effective'' in the future. Durenberger, who has four years before he must face voters back home, was not the only one who saw good coming from his ordeal. ``He could have withered and fallen into self-pity and bitterness,'' said Simpson. Instead, he said, ``I have seen my friend soften and mature and grow in this terrible process.'' ``Sometimes hard times bring people together,'' said Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., a member of the ethics panel. He said the Senate has not always been congenial lately, but ``today I sense a sense of feeling together, a sense of closeness and a sense of brotherhood.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Aid Necessary for Perestroika
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today his country needs Western assistance to make his reform program work, and he promised that any aid will be repaid. Gorbachev spoke at a news conference after a day of meetings with Italian Premier Giulio Andreotti, the president of the European Community. Andreotti is a leading proponent of providing aid to the Soviet Union. No agreements were reached in the talks about Italian or European aid to boost Gorbachev's reform program. Gorbachev said the Soviet Union needs help producing more food and consumer goods for the market, and that factories need a chance to work with foreign firms to boost their productivity. As an example of Soviet inefficiency, Gorbachev has said 25 percent of the nation's crops are lost during harvesting and storage. The resident of the Russian Federation, the Soviet Union's largest republic, today warned of a food shortage ``catastrophe'' in Russia unless efficiency improves. ``We have to gather it carefully, preserve it and get it onto the table of the Russian people,'' Boris N. Yeltsin said. ``The existing food situation in our republic is critical,'' he said in an appeal on the front page of the Sovietskaya Rossia newspaper. ``To prevent a catastrophe, we must improve it immediately.'' As an incentive, Yeltsin said the government would issue special coupons to agricultural workers, from farmers to tractor drivers, allowing them to buy goods that have been in short supply. Russian Prime Minister Ivan Silayev warned in a separate interview that if the market is not soon saturated with food and consumer goods ``the situation will be unpredictable.'' ``The prices will simply skyrocket and the shadow economy will capture everything,'' he told Pravitelstvenny Vestnik newspaper. Gorbachev said the next two years of reforms will be crucial. ``In these two years, in which we will have to make the most difficult changes, we need this kind of help,'' Gorbachev said. Some of the aid should be given quickly ``to reduce the difficulty of the problems, and so perestroika does not slow down,'' he said. However, he added, the Soviet Union ``cannot depend on foreign sponsors'' to fix its economy, but must depend largely on itself. Aid to his country will not be ``a handout,'' he said, but temporary assistance that must be paid back. The West German government has guaranteed $3.1 billion in bank loans to the Soviet Union, and together with France it pushed the European Community to endorse an immediate $15 billion aid program. But European leaders refused to go along with the plan, as did leaders of the world's seven largest capitalist powers meeting in Houston, Texas, earlier this month. President Bush says a program to provide the Soviet Union with Western advisers and know-how would be of greater benefit than economic aid until the Soviet Union makes greater changes in its economy. He also has asked Gorbachev to cut aid to countries like Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Bus Driver Convicted in Bus Shooting
DOC.TEXT: A striking Greyhound bus driver was convicted on two federal charges involving shots fired at a company bus in March. A U.S. District Court jury on Wednesday found Dennis Daniels guilty on charges of endangering a bus with reckless disregard for people's safety and use of a firearm. Daniels, 42, faces up to 20 years in prison and $250,000 fine on the first count, and a mandatory five years in prison and a maximum fine of $250,000 for use of a firearm. He was free on $50,000 bond, pending sentencing. Daniels was convicted of firing shots March 9 at a Columbus-to-Cincinnati bus on Interstate 71 near Mount Sterling, about 25 miles southwest of Columbus.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Durenberger, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout to make it a list of those censured in all of Senate history, sted just 20th Century
DOC.TEXT: This is a list of the nine senators who have been denounced, condemned or censured by their colleagues. Senate historians say the sanction, which requires a majority vote of the full Senate, is the most severe punishment short of expulsion. Denouncement, condemnation and censure are different terms for the same sanction. _Dave Durenberger, R-Minn. Denounced July 25, 1990, for financial misconduct. _Herman E. Talmadge, D-Ga. Denounced in 1979 for financial misconduct with an aide, including improper collection of reimbursements. _Thomas J. Dodd, D-Conn. Censured in 1967 for spending campaign funds for personal use. _Joseph R. McCarthy, R-Wis. Condemned in 1954 for obstructing the legislative process and insulting senators. _Hiram Bingham, R-Conn. Censured in 1929 for hiring employee of state manufacturers association to help him with tariff legislation. _John L. McLaurin, D-S.C., and Benjamin R. Tillman, D-S.C. Censured in 1902 for fighting on the Senate floor. _Benjamin Tappan, D-Ohio. Censured May 10, 1844, for releasing to the New York Post a copy of President John Tyler's message regarding a treaty on annexation of Texas. _Timothy Pickering, Federalist-Mass. Censured Jan. 2, 1811, for reading confidential documents into the Senate record. Fifteen senators have been expelled, the most serious punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Begins Asian Trip; Says No Agreement Yet on Afghanistan
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III today sought to reduce speculation that an agreement with the Soviet Union on Afghanistan could be announced during his four-nation visit to Asia. ``There's no agreement on Afghanistan,'' Baker was quoted as telling reporters on his plane to Jakarta. ``It's a product of the rumor mill.'' The U.S. Embassy in Jakarta released a statement with the Baker comments. Prior to Baker's departure, U.S. officials had indicated the secretary of state would try to clear the remaining roadblocks to a cease-fire in Afghanistan during the Asian trip. They said Baker and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, who are to meet Aug. 1 meeting in Irkutsk, Soviet Siberia, would discuss a timetable for Afghanistan's President Najibullah to step down. ``The Soviets hinted at a deal; they haven' fleshed it out,'' an administration official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Tuesday. ``The thread of the deal is going to be pursued in Irkutsk by Baker.'' ABC News had said earlier this week that Shevardnadze and Baker already had made a deal to end the Afghan civil war, but the administration official disputed that report. The Bush administration has been hoping for a breakthrough to end the war between Afghan government forces armed by the Soviet Union and a guerrilla coalition fighting with American-supplied weapons funneled through Pakistan. The Soviets have not yet told the United States how Najibullah might be removed from power in Kabul, said the administration official. The Soviet Union installed the Najibullah government in 1979, but the government in Kabul has been unable to impose its will on the countryside. The Soviets withdrew their troops last year but continue to supply arms. In Indonesia, Baker will attend a meeting of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations on Friday and Saturday. ASEAN said in a statement Wednesday that a change in Cambodia's representation in the United Nations would hurt the search for peace in Indochina. Last week, the United States withdrew its recognition of the guerrilla coalition that holds Cambodia's U.N. General Assembly seat. Baker was quoted as telling reporters on the plane that the change of U.S. policy on Cambodia was ``an example of our need to adjust to new circumstances.'' Washington also announced last week it would open talks with Vietnam on a settlement in Cambodian and would no longer support the right of the guerrilla coalition to represent Phnom Penh in the world body. Those steps could open the way to a broader rapprochement between the United States and Hanoi, shifting the balance of power in Southeast Asia. Hanoi supports the Cambodian govenment. The abrupt U.S. policy change underlined the failure of years of ASEAN-led diplomacy to negotiate a settlement. ASEAN helped form the Cambodian resistance group in 1982. U.S. officials said the shift was designed to prevent the Khmer Rouge, the strongest of the three guerrilla groups, from gaining power in Cambodia. The Khmer Rouge took power in 1975 and slaughtered hundreds of thousands of civilians before being ousted by Vietnam in 1978. ASEAN includes Thailand, the Philippines, Singapore, Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei. Later in the Asian trip, Baker will later hold talks in Singapore and visit Outer Mongolia.

DOC.HEAD: 3-year-old Latest Victim In New York Gun Battles
DOC.TEXT: Mushrooms don't grow in New York, they die. Nine mushrooms _ street slang for bystanders who pop up during gunfights _ have been killed this year, including a 3-year-old boy who was shot as he slept this morning. ``The people in the streets don't care. To them, shooting is normal. Everybody has a gun. The law? That's irrelevant,'' said Thomas Reppetto, head of the watchdog Citizens' Crime Commission. Repetto spoke Wednesday, just a few hours before Yaritimi Fruto died at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn. The girl, who celebrated her first birthday last Friday, was shot Tuesday by the same gun that killed her father. Her shooting came two days after 9-year-old Veronica Corales was mortally wounded by a bullet to the head as she slept in her parents' car after a trip to Great Adventure amusement park in New Jersey. Veronica died Tuesday at Brookdale shortly before Yaritimi arrived. And at about 4 a.m. today, a 3-year-old whose name was withheld by police was fatally shot above the right eye as he slumbered in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. Police said a gunfight had broken out between shooters outside and inside the boy's building. ``They're in the way, underfoot, so let's squash 'em down. That's the way they feel about innocent bystanders in New York City in 1990,'' said Reppetto, a former police officer. ``It's not something recent. It's just getting more attention. It's becoming more common, and it will grow,'' he said. More and more bystanders are getting shot around the city, statistics show. Reppetto cited a study by his group that showed the number of bystanders shot in New York City quadrupled between 1978 and 1988. A University of Maryland professor of criminology, Lawrence W. Sherman, did a study that showed a jump in the slayings of bystanders every year from 1985 through 1988. The number in the first year was five; in the last, it was 12. This year's total is running slightly ahead of that: nine in seven months, police said. The shootings have left survivors anxious to get away from the violence which has produced record murder counts in each of the last two years, with a new high expected in 1990. Veronica's uncle, Willy Cosme, blamed it on the neighborhood. ``Growing up around here, other little kids often learn the bad side of life,'' he said. The Brooklyn police precinct where Veronica's family lives is the deadliest in the city, with 97 murders in 1989. ``New York is so crazy now,'' said Berkley Tatum, whose 18-year-old son was shot to death Tuesday on his way to the grocery store. ``People have no values ... Why would anyone want to stand on a roof, fire a gun at an innocent kid in a car? It's all over. The city is finished.''

DOC.HEAD: Precede BEIRUT
Syrian Army Fuel Truck Hits Hotel; Seven Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with police revising earlier, unofficial death toll down to seven, other details. No pickup. ADDS byline.
DOC.TEXT: A Syrian army fuel truck that apparently lost its brakes crashed into the lobby of a hotel in this eastern Lebanese town, touching off a fire that killed seven people and injured 11, police said today. The truck rolled downhill out of control into the Kassouf Hotel on Wednesday night, said a police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations. He said the truck ``blew up into a ball of fire that blazed across the hotel's four floors. Most of the victims were sleeping in their rooms when the accident took place.'' The dead included the hotel owner and her two sons and the driver of the truck, police said. The fire gutted the hotel's first two floors, blackened the rest of the building and turned eight vehicles in the parking lot into piles of twisted metal. Initial reports on local radio stations had said 45 people were killed, but after the confusion died down, authorities gave the lower death toll. The injured were admitted to hospitals in the nearby Bekaa valley town of Zahleh for treatment of burns and cuts, police said. The spokesman said none of the injured was in critical condition. Chtaura, 20 miles east of Beirut, is a shopping town on the main highway linking Lebanon with Syria, the main supply route for Syrian troops based in Lebanon. The police spokesman said fire engines and civil defense teams fought the blaze for several hours before extinguishing it at about 4 a.m. Syria has 40,000 troops deployed in east and north Lebanon as well as Beirut and part of the mountainous range southeast of the capital under a 1976 peacekeeping mandate from the Arab League.

DOC.HEAD: Salvador, Leftist Rebels Agree to Form Panel to Monitor Human Rights
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to ADD that mission not to begin work until cease-fire reached, ADDS comments from government and rebel delegations. Changes byline.
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for El Salvador and leftist guerrillas agreed today to have a U.N. commission monitor human rights in El Salvador, where tens of thousands of civilians have died in the civil war. The accord was reached after an all-night negotiating session in San Jose. The talks turned to the human rights issue after failing to make progress on a cease-fire in the decade-old war. The commission would not begin work until a cease-fire agreement is reached. Nevertheless, negotiators said the rights accord was a significant step. It was the first concrete agreement between the sides since peace talks began in May, and both delegations had expressed concern that the absence of an accord in the San Jose talks might deal a devastating blow to the negotiating process. Salvadoran guerrillas have long accused the rightist government of human rights abuses, and human rights groups say at least 30,000 people have died at the hands of right-wing death squads. The latest victims include six Jesuit priests, their cook and her 16-year-old daughter, who were shot to death early Nov. 16 at Central American University. ``The accord reached today between the government of El Salvador and the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front rebels doesn't close the topic of human rights, but it is a partial accord,'' said Alvaro de Soto, a U.N. mediator. De Soto said the accord ``without doubt helps clear the way for progress on other items of the agenda.'' ``We're enormously satisfied,'' said Oscar Santamaria, the justice minister and chief of the government delegation. ``This accord is a very meaningful advance.'' Guerrilla commander Schafik Handal, leader of the rebel negotiating team, said the document ``is an accord of great value.'' But he cautioned that the issue of overhauling the armed forces was still pending. ``This (human rights) accord will not mean a great deal unless we advance in the field of demilitarization of Salvadoran society,'' he said. The talks began Friday, and the top agenda item was the overhaul of the armed forces, which the rebels have demanded before they stop fighting. During 20 hours of talks, negotiators failed to make even slight progress on that issue. It was the third round of talks this year aimed at ending the conflict that has killed 72,000 people, most of them civilians. The massacre of the Jesuits focused new attention on the civilian toll. It stunned the world and prompted calls from some U.S. politicians to reconsider aid to the El Salvadoran government, which stands at $1 million a day. Several soldiers were arrested in the case, but they have not been brought to trial. No officer has ever been convicted of human rights abuses in El Salvador. The U.N. mission will be headed by an appointee of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar and will comprise ``as many agents as are necessary.'' ``The mission will enjoy broad powers to adopt any initiative it deems appropriate for the promotion and defense of human rights,'' said a joint communique. It said the mission will be free to document and denounce rights violations; conduct unrestricted interviews with all people; make recommendations to both the government and guerrillas; and publish its reports, conclusions and recommendations. The mission is to begin work as soon as a cease-fire is reached. The government said the accord was a big step toward fulfilling requirements for a cessation of hostilities, and they demanded the rebels modify their positions in order to meet a September target date for a cease-fire. But the insurgents insist that accords on military issues _ including a purge of rights abusers from the officer corps, an end to military impunity and drastic reduction of troop strength _ be reached prior to halting combat. Rebel chiefs say a September cease-fire may be unrealistic. A joint communique said the military issue would receive ``priority consideration'' at the next round of talks, scheduled Aug. 17-22 in San Jose.

DOC.HEAD: Some Areas Still Cut Off Ten Days After Quake
DOC.TEXT: Relief supplies still have not reached some areas cut off by landslides triggered by the devastating July 16 earthquake, Defense Secretary Fidel Ramos said today. The relief effort has also been hampered by logistical problems and quarreling over supplies, said Ramos, who is chairman of the National Disaster Coordinating Council. ``The uneven distribution of goods comes from competition at the community level as to who should get the relief goods,'' he said. ``Sometimes the relief goods intended ... to reach a certain family does not get to that family because of some misdelivery along the way.'' Ramos said he had ordered an investigation of why some supplies had failed to reach their destination. The defense chief also said relief efforts were focusing on northern towns accessible only by helicopter because of landslides. According to the latest figures, the earthquake left at least 1,653 people dead, more than 1,000 missing and presumed dead, more than 3,000 seriously injured and nearly 90,000 homeless. Officials estimated today that property damage totaled $903 million, an amount that was expected to increase. The quake, which measured 7.7 on the Richter scale, was the strongest to strike the Philippines in 14 years. Government officials moved to seek a suspension of debt payments so the Philippines can devote more resources to earthquake relief. The nation has a $26 billion foreign debt. Rep. Margarito Teves, a member of the government's Foreign Debt Council, said today that the Philippines would try to negotiate a 2{-year debt-payment moratorium with its chief creditors, the 14-nation Paris Club. The Paris Club includes the United States, Japan, France, West Germany and Britain. President Corazon Aquino's Cabinet agreed Wednesday to seek a moratorium after some lawmakers began pushing for a unilateral halt in debt repayment. The Aquino government opposes such a move.

DOC.HEAD: School Board Fires Teacher Who Accidentally Killed Student
DOC.TEXT: A teacher who accidentally killed a tardy student by closing the school gate as the girl tried to squeeze through will be fired, education authorities decided today. They also agreed to discipline five other education officials in connection with the case, which raised widespread criticism of the rigidity in many Japanese schools. On July 6, Toshihiko Hosoi closed the front gate of Hyogo Prefectural Takatsuka Senior High School in Kobe, 270 miles west of Tokyo, promptly at 8:30 a.m. in an effort to teach students a lesson about coming to school on time. Ryoko Ishida, 15, was caught in the heavy metal gate and died of a crushed skull. The school had a policy of closing the gate at 8:30 each morning. Published accounts of the incident differ, but most say the teacher closed the gate suddenly to teach the students a lesson about being late. The prefectural education board decided today to fire the teacher because he failed to take adequate safety measures. Police are questioning the teacher on suspicion of professional negligence. The high school principal, Atsuo Nomura, also resigned under pressure today, and the Hyogo prefecture board of education cautioned the school's head teacher and the prefectural superintendent of education and gave ``serious notice'' to two vice superintendents of education. Commentator Morse Saito, writing in the Mainichi Shimbun, said the Kobe high school's strict gate-closing rule was meant to give students with bad grades a way to win job recommendations. ``By graduation, (teachers) could recommend most students as being prompt even though some had low grades. This is important for (students) seeking employment after high school. The elite don't need it,'' he wrote. Discipline also often includes corporal punishment, according to Morikatsu Imahashi, a professor at Ibaraki University and a longtime corporal punishment opponent. ``Teachers often slap, punch, kick,'' he said in an interview. In September, teachers buried two junior high school students in Fukuoka, a city on the southern island of Kyushu, in sand up to their necks. Media reports said the teachers suspected the students of bullying their classmates.

DOC.HEAD: New Law Permits Wine Sales in Ballparks, Racetracks, Arenas
DOC.TEXT: ``Wine heah! Get your ice cold chardonnay!'' Sure, it sounds unlikely, but it won't be illegal in New York state much longer. Soon, ballpark vendors will be allowed to hawk Pouilly Fuisse with the peanuts or Chateau Lafite with the crackerjack. A law legalizing wine sales at ballparks and racetracks was signed Wednesday by Gov. Mario Cuomo. It's aimed at boosting sales for New York's struggling wineries, officials said. The law goes into effect in three months. Nobody's popping corks at New York's two baseball stadiums, where team representatives say they don't expect much demand for wine at ballgames. ``I wouldn't even know how to serve Chablis. Chilled, right?'' said Joel White, head of customer services for the Yankees. Wine coolers, which have already boosted New York's grape sales 40 percent since they were legalized, ``have pulled the grape industry right out of the doldrums,'' said Assemblyman Vincent Graber of Buffalo. Maybe so, but will they give fans new reason to head the ballparks? ``Maybe this is something for the tennis crowd,'' White said. ``They're much more chi-chi than our fans.''

DOC.HEAD: Fire at Landfill Forces Evacuation of 600
DOC.TEXT: Some 600 people in three counties evacuated their homes as fire engulfed a landfill, officials said. The blaze sent a plume of smoke Wednesday over West Point in Hardin County, and some residents complained of nausea and eye and throat irritation, but no one was hospitalized. The fire was underground when it was reported about 5 p.m. Wednesday, but it had covered the entire one-acre landfill by early today Residents evacuated from this community of 1,500, located 15 miles southwest of Louisville, remained away from their houses this morning, and the fire continued to burn. Early Wednesday evening, firefighters tried dousing the blaze with water, then tried moving dirt in an attempt to smother the fire. The fire's cause remained unknown, according to James Molloy, executive director of state Disaster and Emergency Services. Asbestos shingles, wood and plastics were among the materials burning, said Marc Kaiser, deputy director of Disaster and Emergency Services in Bullitt County.

DOC.HEAD: Private Eye and Editor Fined for Contempt
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court today fined the magazine Private Eye and its editor $18,100 each for publishing articles that prosecutors said could have affected the outcome of the notorious Yorkshire Ripper murder case. They also alleged the articles were intended to discourage the defendant's wife from pursuing a libel case against the satirical magazine. Lord Justice Roger Parker, speaking for a three-judge panel, said: ``I regard it as of the greatest importance that it should be clear that articles of this nature within a short time of trial are not to be tolerated.'' Outside court, Private Eye editor Ian Hislop said: ``I'm disappointed. We will pay the fines and it's a slap on the wrist.'' The Court of Appeal panel upheld the Attorney General's appeal against a High Court ruling that favored the magazine in March. The High Court found that two February 1989 articles did not pose a threat to the administration of justice in the trial of Peter Sutcliffe, who became known as the Yorkshire Ripper. Those articles claimed the defendant's wife, Sonia Sutcliffe, had provided her husband with a false alibi and defrauded the Department of Health and Social Services. They were printed while Mrs. Sutcliffe was pursuing a libel case against the magazine for alleging she tried to cash in on her husband's notoriety by agreeing to sell her story to a newspaper. Prosecutors said that in addition to possible influencing jurors in the murder trial, the articles were aimed at dissuading Mrs. Sutcliffe from continuing the libel case. She won a $109,000 award in May 1989 in the libel action and also received a $181,000 settlement from the magazine. Lord Justice Parker said he ruled out imprisoning Hislop in the contempt matter but he said, ``Any similar conduct in the future would be unlikely to attract such leniency.'' Peter Sutcliffe was jailed for life in 1981 for killing 13 women and attempting to kill another five. Mrs. Sutcliffe was not implicated in any of the crimes.

DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with 6 grafs to update with hearing testimony. Pickup 4th graf pvs: ``Rep. George...''
DOC.TEXT: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission relaxed the control of low-level radioactive wastes despite repeated concerns expressed by staff advisers and the Environmental Protection Agency, internal documents showed today. The documents were released by a congressional panel that is questioning the decision, announced last month, that the NRC no longer regulate a wide range of low-level radioactive materials from nuclear power plants, laboratories and hospitals. At a hearing before the House Interior energy and environment subcommittee, a number of congressmen expressed concern that states would be forced to accept radioactive wastes from other states as part of normal garbage destined for landfills. States like West Virginia and Indiana, already targets for out-of-state garbage shipments, fear they ``will become the dumping ground'' for radioactive wastes, said Rep. Joe Rahall, D-W.Va. ``I'm concerned where we're heading in terms of nuclear wastes,'' said Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., who said states will be prevented from restricting such shipments under the NRC rules. The NRC's commissioners were expected in later testimony to defend the policy change as no threat to public health. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., the subcommittee's chairman, said the NRC policy ``has the potential to endanger the public health'' and ``is an open invitation to abuse by unscrupulous operators'' who want to dump radioactive materials in ordinary landfills. Under the new policy, such low-level wastes as gloves, clothing, lab equipment and even buildings and equipment at nuclear power plants can be disposed of as if they were normal garbage if radiation doses are below a certain level. The commission plans to consider exempting various wastes on a case-by-case basis as requests for exemptions are submitted by industry under the new policy guidelines. NRC Chairman Kenneth M. Carr has argued that the policy change represents a way to save lives because federal and state regulators will be able ``to spend our resources on threats that are more important.'' But representatives from the EPA, a half-dozen members of Congress and a number of state radiation control officials were expected to testify against the NRC action, announced on June 27. According to documents obtained by Miller's subcommittee, the EPA as well as key NRC staff members expressed concern repeatedly during the two years the new policy was being debated that too many wastes are being deregulated. The NRC decision would exempt from special control wastes that subject individuals to radiation doses of less than 10 millirem per year _ half the level of a normal chest X-ray. ``We believe that is too high a level (of exposure) for a blanket deregulation criteria and is not protective of the public health,'' the EPA's Office of Radiation Programs, concluded in a briefing paper submitted to the subcommittee. The EPA made similar arguments to the NRC before the policy change was made. The EPA maintained that the 10 millirem cutoff for regulatory action could result in as many as three additional cancer deaths for every 10,000 people exposed. ``Numerous standards established by the EPA, including those for drinking water, set upper limits of risk at lower levels,'' it said. According to internal NRC memos and other documents, key commission staff members also expressed strong reservations about the 10 millirem cutoff level as the new policy was debated in 1988 and 1989. A staff report in June 1988 urged that only wastes with radiation doses of 1 millirem per year be deregulated. Among those who objected to the 10 millirem cutoff was Robert M. Bernero, acting director of the NRC's Office of Nuclear Material Safety and Safeguards, according to the documents. Bernero in one memo to his NRC superiors expressed concern about the health effects to individuals who may be subject to numerous exposures of such wastes and the long-term effect on such materials on the waste stream. But the objections from Bernero and other staffers were overruled by senior NRC officials, the documents indicated. The EPA later suggested the cutoff be set at 4 millirem per year, but that was rejected. ``In their zeal to relax the regulation of the nuclear industry, the NRC commissioners have ignored the objections of their own staff experts, the Environmental Protection Agency, the states and the public,'' said Miller. The nuclear industry _ as well as the NRC commissioners _ have argued that the wastes that are at issue emit only extremely small doses of radiation.

DOC.HEAD: Police Recommends Illegal Weapons Charges Against Klein
DOC.TEXT: Police recommended that an army reservist be charged with illegal weapons exports in connection with an Israeli arms shipment diverted to Colombian drug lords, Israel radio said today. The April 1989 shipment of 400 Galil assault rifles, 100 Uzi submachine guns and ammunition was destined for the Caribbean island nation of Antigua, but it ended up with reputed Colombian drug kingpin Gonzalo Rodriguez Gacha. Israel radio said police recommended that Col. Yair Klein be charged with exporting weapons without a permit. The report did not specify Klein's alleged role, nor say whether he was involved in diverting the arms to Colombia. Police spokeswoman Ruth Schlesinger would not comment on the report. She confirmed that the National Police Major Crimes Unit completed its investigation of Klein and sent the results to the stat prosecutor. Justice Ministry spokeswoman Etty Eshed said her office had not yet received the police material. Klein could not be reached for comment. He has denied wrongdoing. Klein has said the shipment was intended for a training school he wanted to set up in Antigua for Panamanian rebels opposed to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. When plans for the school fell through, Klein said, the Panamanians wanted the weapons shipped to Panama, but somehow they were diverted to Colombia. In Colombia, accusations surfaced last year that Klein was involved in traning assassination teams for Gacha, who was killed in a December battle with Colombian police. Klein denied the accusations. In May, a Jerusalem magistrate's court charged Klein with illegally exporting military expertise and material to a group in Colombia. The charge said Klein made a deal with a group known as ``The Farmers' Organization'' in Colombia in April 1988. It made no mention of the drug cartel. Defense Ministry officials said Klein did not have permits required for conducting training or exporting arms.

DOC.HEAD: Governors Facing Tough Decisions on Implementing Educational Goals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 8-9, The nation's, with statement from chief state school officers.
DOC.TEXT: Five months after agreeing with President Bush on lofty goals to produce ``an American renaissance in education,'' the nation's governors meet this weekend to decide who will oversee the task and how to assess students' progress toward that target. The governors, traveling to Mobile, Ala., for the 82nd annual meeting of the National Governors' Association, hope to agree on the makeup of a bipartisan commission and its role in evaluating progress in reaching the six national education goals. The governors also intend to decide how students should be tested and which learning skills should be measured. While discussions began soon after the goals were outlined, Mike Cohen of the governors' association said this week a consensus still has not been reached on many details. ``There's no horrible impasse,'' said an association official who requested anonymity. ``But building a consensus on anything is just not an easy process. ... These are not people who normally agree on a lot of things.'' At stake are the goals Bush set forth in his State of the Union address in January. The governors, who met with the president last fall in an ``education summit,'' gave their approval to the goals a month later. Besides making American students ``first in the world in math and science'' by the year 2000, the goals call for improving student competence in English, history and geography; increasing the high school graduation rate to at least 90 percent; upgrading early childhood education; improving adult literacy and freeing schools of violence and drugs. The nation's state school officers called on the governors and the president to adopt an eight-step set program of national strategies including enactment of a federal education ``goals bill'', transfer of military personnel and technology to teaching jobs and schools to achieve the goals. The Council of Chief State School Officers said in a statement sent to the chief executives that the governors and president have raised national expectations and should implement an agenda that would link student performance with what the nation expects them to know and be able to do. The governors are leaning toward organizing the commission along three tiers. They would include a policy-steering group _ possibly made up of governors _ to oversee the student assessment process, an advisory group of high-level education specialists and business officials, and a staff to carry out the advisory group's recommendations. Perhaps more contentious will be determining a way to measure student success in achieving the national goals. Most states test students on their general academic knowledge. But decades of widely reported dismal results have forced educators to reassess the most commonly used testing and assessment methods. Even within the Bush administration, there is disagreement on the meaning of standardized test scores. Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos released his department's annual ``wall chart'' of state-by-state performance reports over objections from the White House. Thirty-two states test elementary pupils statewide, with the most popular tests being the California Achievement Test, the Stanford Achievement Test, the Metropolitan Achievement Test, the Science Research Associates Test, the Comprehensive Test of Basic Skills and the Iowa Test of Basic Skills. The other 18 states allow local officials to pick the tests given to students in their district. The National Council of Teachers of English has said repeatedly that standardized testing distorts and debases the language arts curriculum. Many people wrongly conclude that high scores on multiple-choice tests are proof of students' ability to use the language effectively in life and in learning, the group said. If not standardized tests, what? Several states are experimenting with innovative testing methods _ most of which have been lumped under the category ``performance-based testing.'' Such assessments can include teachers' evaluations of students' work based on collections of their essays, poems and drawings. Michigan, Illinois, California and Connecticut have been leaders in this movement, said Lawrence Rudner of the Education Department's Educational Resources Information Center. Florida has a five-year plan to phase out standardized tests. ``The concept is that standardized, multiple-choice tests are limited because of the breadth and depth of what they can test,'' Rudner said. Students also need to be tested on how well they work in groups and on their problem-solving abilities, for example. The American Federation of Teachers has called for ``phasing out standardized, multiple-choice tests and replacing them with reliable, valid and educationally appropriate alternatives.'' AFT President Shanker said performance-based assessments more accurately depict the status of American education than standardized tests. A harsh critic of all assessment methods is Albuquerque, N.M., physician John Jacob Cannell, leader of Friends for Education, a non-profit citizens' group. ``Performance-based assessment is another form of cheating,'' Cannell said in an interview. He contends that 83 percent of 5,143 elementary school districts and 73 percent of 4,501 secondary districts report standardized achievement test scores above national norms, as do 48 of the 50 states. ``In an honest test,'' he said, ``half the states would be below average instead of having all of them claim to be above. And by being below the national average, then schools would be forced to spend extra money and admit that they are failing.'' Cannell contended that many teachers and principals now coach students on test questions, give students more than the allotted time to take tests and even alter answer sheets to raise scores.

DOC.HEAD: Delta Cuts Back on PGA Participation As Racial Furor Grows
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with new 2nd graf with mayor saying country club expected to add black members; SUBS grafs 6-9 pvs. beginning `Birmingham mayor ...' with 6 grafs of further details of mayor's press conference. Picks up 10th graf pvs., `New members ...' A version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: Delta Airlines will reduce its participation in next month's PGA Championship, joining other advertisers protesting the lack of black members at the host Shoal Creek Country Club. Meanwhile, Mayor Richard Arrington said today he expects the country club to add blacks as members within a year. Toyota and Anheuser-Busch on Wednesday joined IBM in canceling plans to run commercials during ABC and ESPN telecasts of the tournament. Toyota and IBM officials said they pulled the spots because Shoal Creek has no black members. Anheuser-Busch did not give a reason for dropping its ads during the Aug. 9-12 tournament. ESPN is broadcasting the first two days of the golf tournament, with ABC carrying the last two days. Bill Berry, a spokesman for Delta, told USA Today that Delta may have a ``presence'' in the tournament because of contractual obligations, but that it would reduce its participation. ``This is one of those embarrassments we have no control over,'' he said. Delta is an official sponsor of the PGA Tour. Arrington, who is black, has tried to smooth over the controversy. He has insisted that Birmingham has become racially progressive in the past two decades. At a news conference today, he said Shoal Creek members have ``given me their commitment'' that blacks will be considered for membership within a few months. He said it usually takes six months for an ``expedited membership'' at Shoal Creek. Based on commitments to him from a number of Shoal Creek members, he said he was confident that the club ``will include blacks within the next year.'' Officials at Shoal Creek, founded in 1977 and site of the 1984 Professional Golfers' Association Championship, have said the club does not ban black members and that blacks have been guests there. But club founder Hall Thompson angered many when he was quoted in a newspaper story as saying the club could not be pressured into accepting blacks. He later apologized and said he was quoted out of context. Arrington released a letter today from Thompson in which the founder assured the mayor that race would not be a factor in evaluating proposed new members. New members must be invited to join. Memberships cost up to $35,000, with an additional yearly fee. The PGA said July 14 that in the future it would consider clubs' membership policies in picking tournament sites. The Rev. Abraham Woods, who has called for picketing of the tournament, said Wednesday the club should at least ``set a timetable for actively recruiting blacks.'' The planned protests could be averted if Shoal Creek accepted Arrington as a member, said Woods, president of the Birmingham chapter of the Southern Christian Leadership Conference. Arrington, who does not play golf, has said he is ``not the country-club type.'' He is now in his third term as Birmingham's first black mayor. Mark Mandel, manager of sports information for ABC, declined to comment on the impact of the Shoal Creek developments or the network's view of the matter. Chris LaPlaca, ESPN's vice president of communications, said, ``Our sales people have not been officially notified by the corporate types so there's nothing for us to say at this point.''

DOC.HEAD: Souter Courts Senate to Confirm His Supreme Court Nomination
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; INSERTS 10th graf, Asked about... to UPDATE with reaction to letter; no pickup
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Souter-Abortion, Bjt
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: David Souter met today with the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee that will consider his Supreme Court nomination and refused to answer reporters' questions about abortion and affirmative action. Souter spent an hour in private discussions with committee chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., who will preside over the confirmation hearings expected in September. The quiet New Hampshire jurist continued to dodge questions by reporters following him as he made his courtesy calls. Asked if there was any way to get him to talk about his views on abortion, he responded: ``In a word, no.'' How about affirmative action? ``Same word,'' he said. ``I like that word.'' But he kidded a reporter to ``keep it up.'' After his meeting with Biden, Souter said, ``I look forward to making my positions clear to the extent it is constitutionally appropriate'' when the hearings begin. Biden declined to reveal the contents of their discussions. Souter did write a letter on the abortion issue nine years ago, asking the New Hampshire Legislature not to pass a law that would put judges in the position of having to decide whether minors can have abortions. Souter wrote the letter at the direction of his fellow state Superior Court judges, and abortion-rights advocates say they don't interpret it as an friendly or hostile to their position. Asked about the letter today, Souter said, ``I think you should save any issue of that sort ... for the confirmation hearing where I'm sure that issue will be addressed.'' Meanwhile, Attorney General Dick Thornburgh told the National Press Club he thought Souter would deflect the Senate's questions if they strayed too close to the controversial. ``To try to pin down any prospective appointee on a specific issue or a specific case would seem to me to verge on the improper and certainly be unwise,'' the attorney general said. ``I think I trust to Judge Souter's wisdom and experience to enable him to walk the line between giving the members of the Senate an appropriate road map to his judicial philosophy, politely declining to respond to questions that are case or issues-related,'' Thornburgh said. Several senators have said they would try to probe Souter's views, with the understanding it was not proper to ask how he'd vote on specific cases. The nominee has not addressed many of the nation's politically most sensitive issues during seven years as a state judge or while serving on the federal bench in Boston since April. In his chitchat Wednesday with senators and the press, Souter said he might be well portrayed by a recent comment that he was a ``classic Down-Easter,'' a term that normally refers to the private, reserved style of people in the southeast part of Maine. During a visit with Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, himself a former federal judge, the two men expressed mutual admiration for retired Chief Judge Frank Coffin of the 1st Circuit. Souter recalled once receiving a complimentary letter from Coffin. ``I would frame it, but that would be ostentatious,'' said the 50-year-old bachelor who, except for years away at college, has lived in the same farmhouse near Concord, N.H., since he was 11 years old. Asked by reporters for his feelings two days after Bush made his choice, Souter said, ``I really don't have any substantive feeling to express.'' ``I think the best news I have is the blood is circulating to the brain well enough now so that I'm beginning to have some feelings,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to incorporate information from Secret Service spokesman
DOC.HEAD: Plate Used to Make $100 Bills Reported Missing
DOC.TEXT: The Bureau of Engraving and Printing said today it has mislaid a steel plate bearing Benjamin Franklin's picture that was formerly used to print $100 bills. The Secret Service was notified and sent two agents to investigate, bureau spokesman Ira Polikoff said. Polikoff said the bureau believes the plate is still in its building and is working on the theory that it has gone astray because of a clerical error. The plate is one of about 3,200 made last year, Polikoff said. It is about three feet by eight feet and weighs eight pounds. ``It's not something you can easily fold up and put in your pocket,'' the spokesman said. Polikoff said anyone leaving the building with any package larger than a billfold is routinely searched. He said this applies even to the highest level officials of the bureau. The plate turned up missing during a monthly inventory check July 6. Polikoff said it had been found to be defective, so was no longer being used in printing bills and was scheduled for destruction. ``We believe at this point it was nothing more than a clerical error,'' Polikoff said. Polikoff spoke by telephone from San Francisco. He said that before he left Washington Tuesday, the Secret Service sent two agents to investigate. He said the service is routinely informed in such cases. The spokesman said he did not know anything about the Secret Service's investigation. Rich Adams, the Secret Service spokesman in Washington dealing with the case, said agents were interviewing employes at the printing plant and had not reached any conclusions.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Secret Police Now Legal In Poland
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet KGB has come in from the cold in Poland, where it now has an officially registered mission after decades of covert influence on the secret service here, the new Interior Minister told lawmakers. The KGB delegation, headed by a general, has the status of Soviet Embassy staff, said Minister Krzysztof Kozlowski, the Solidarity-backed journalist who recently took control of the ministry that oversees the police. ``If we objected, there would be agents anyway, only we would not know who they are,'' Kozlowski told a meeting of Solidarity parliament members Wednesday. The minister said cooperation with the KGB until recently ``reached deep into the ministry, with standing KGB advisers, consultants and liaison officers installed in various departments and divisions.'' ``This kind of presence has ended, and will never return,'' Kozlowski said. Cooperation now is on ``completely new principles.'' Decisions are now made between the ministries, and recent discussions included Poland's promise to assist Soviet Jews in emigrating, Kozlowski said. The new minister replaced Gen. Czeslaw Kiszczak, one of four Communists who remained in the Solidarity-led government formed last September.

DOC.HEAD: Major Rivers Burst Banks, 1 Million People Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Most major rivers in Bangladesh have burst their banks because of heavy rain, leaving more than 1 million people homeless, officials and news reports said Thursday. At least 38 people drowned or died in houses which collapsed from the flooding, they said. Major roads were impassible. The Brahmaputra and Ganges rivers inundated large parts of 13 of the country's 54 districts, an official at the Flood Control Center said. The worst-affected area was the northern district of Sirajganj, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. At least 300 villages in the district have been washed away and large tracts of rice paddies inundated. President Hussain Muhammad Ershad toured Sirajganj and ordered immediate relief measures. Giasuddin Ahmed, the top administrator of Sirajganj, said in a telephone interview that all schools and colleges in the district had been closed and the buildings were used to shelter the homeless. At least 500,000 people lost their homes in the flooding, he said. Other officials said at least 1 million people were affected nationwide. Floods are an annual problem in Bangladesh, a low-lying nation of 110 million people. Most major rivers of the Indian subcontinent flow through Bangladesh before emptying into the Bay of Bengal.

DOC.HEAD: Communists and Neo-Fascists Scuffle in Italian Senate
DOC.TEXT: Communists and neo-fascists scuffled in the Italian Senate on Thursday and one man was hit in the eye by a flying object, news reports said. The president of the Senate, former Premier Giovanni Spadolini, suspended the session for 30 minutes and expressed his ``deepest bitterness'' over the incident. Italian news agencies said the fracas was triggered by remarks by Francesco Pontone of the neo-fascist Italian Social Movement. He reportedly accused the Communists of approving the nominations of security service officials in the 1970s who were later linked to the now outlawed Propaganda Due (P-2) Masonic lodge. Neo-fascist Senator Cesare Pozzo was treated in the Senate infirmary for injuries to his right eye.

DOC.HEAD: Japan's Long-Grounded Nuclear Ship Suffers Another Mishap
DOC.TEXT: In its first voyage since being grounded 16 years ago for a radiation leak, Japan's sole nuclear-powered ship suffered yet another mishap because of a faulty emergency signal, officials said Thursday. The Mutsu's 8,242-ton nuclear reactor shut off automatically Wednesday when an emergency light indicated the temperature of the ship's primary coolant water had risen too high, said a spokesman for the Japan Atomic Energy Research Institute. Upon investigation, however, ship officials discovered that the temperature was at the required 523 degrees and concluded that the alarm system was at fault, he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The official said there was no leak of radioactivity from the ship, which had been cruising in the Pacific Ocean 217 miles east of Inubozaki Point, about 60 miles east of Tokyo. The ship will continue on its course, he said. The $673 million vessel has been plagued by a series of accidents since its maiden voyage in 1974 when the ship's reactor leaked radiation. Protests by anti-nuclear groups and local residents and fishermen in several ports throughout Japan first prevented the ship from being repaired and later from finding a home for several years. Since 1988, it has been anchored at the specially built port of Sekinehama in northern Japan. The Mutsu left port July 10 to begin a series of tests to gauge the impact of wave vibrations on the reactor and to check its safety systems.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli-Made Unmanned Helicopter Crash-Lands On Test-Flight
DOC.TEXT: A small, unmanned reconnaissance helicopter being developed by Israel for its navy crash-landed during a test flight, a spokeswoman said Thursday. The crash came two days after the government-run Israel Aircraft Industries unveiled the prototype and said it had undergone a series of successful tests. The drone ``landed hard'' after one of its systems malfunctioned during a flight at the Mata testing ground in Jerusalem, said IAI spokeswoman Sylvia Beit-Halachmi. Some damage was caused to the drone's twin rotors. The purpose of the trial flight was to ``identify possible malfunctions in order to overcome all hitches before beginning production of a reliable instrument,'' she said. The helicopter, which weighs about 2,450 pounds, is to be flown by remote control from navy ships and is to feed back intelligence information.

DOC.HEAD: Jet Fighter Crashes After Striking Bird
DOC.TEXT: A French jet fighter crashed Thursday after striking a bird during a training mission in Chad, the Defense Ministry said. The pilot was slightly hurt as he ejected.
