The Mirage F1 was part of France's Operation Sparrowhawk, in which about 1,000 soldiers are deployed in support of Chad's government. Chad's forces are engaged in sporadic fighting with rebels, which the government claims are backed by Libya. The Defense Ministry said an investigation of the accident had been launched.

DOC.HEAD: Son of Prominent Union Leader Found Slain in Argentina
DOC.TEXT: Police said today they were questioning three men about the kidnapping and murder of the son of a prominent union leader whose body was found in a resort city south of Buenos Aires. Guillermo Ibanez was kidnapped July 6. News reports said kidnappers demanded a ransom of $2 million from his father, Diego, leader of the powerful state oil workers union and a former national legislator. The body of the union leader's 28-year-old son was found Wednesday in Mar del Plata, 250 miles south of Buenos Aires. He had been shot in the back of the neck. The kidnapping was front-page news, and the discovery of the body was the lead story in every Buenos Aires newspaper today. President Carlos Menem planned to attend the funeral, scheduled for later today. Police arrested three men thought to have kidnapped and killed Ibanez and were questioning them today. No charges were immediately filed. The kidnapping and slaying were denounced by human rights organizations, unions, religious groups and top politicians. The oil workers union stayed off the job today to show their sympathy for the Ibanez family and to repudiate the ``monstrous crime.'' Menem indicated he favored the death penalty for the suspects if they are charged and convicted in the case. ``Do such beasts deserve to live?'' he said in an interview.

DOC.HEAD: Two Firefighters Killed Near Olympia
DOC.TEXT: Two firefighters were killed Thursday while battling a blaze in a pine forest near the site of ancient Olympia, police said. ``They were ahead of everybody else with a hose when the fire outflanked them and just swallowed them up,'' an officer said in a telephone interview from the nearby town of Pirgos, 195 miles west of Athens. Forestry officials were unable to estimate the damage to the forest of Palaiovarvassaina because the fire was still raging and was fanned by strong wind, the officer said on condition of anonymity. Olympia, a sanctuary that was the site of the ancient Olympic Games founded in the eighth century B.C., is located in lush pine forests in the western Peloponnesos peninsula. Excavations have revealed part of the temple of Zeus, one of the seven wonders of the ancient world.

DOC.HEAD: Chernobyl Children Arrive For Recreation
DOC.TEXT: About 100 Soviet teen-agers who were victims of the Chernobyl nuclear reactor disaster have arrived for a monthlong vacation in Denmark, newspapers said Thursday. The children, ages 13 to 15, will spend time in outdoor scout camps and will stay a week with Danish families. Under a project of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, about 1,200 Chernobyl-area children will have holidays in western European countries this summer. The group for Denmark arrived Wednesday. The children suffer from blood, glandular and other disease, following the April 1986 explosion at the nuclear power station. ``The air at home has completely changed since the accident. We have been told not to go into certain parts of the town,'' said Luda Balmasheva, 13, of Kirov. ``Vegetables now have a completely different taste,'' said Alexander Tatrinov, 15, of Zhlobin.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands Attend Signing Ceremony for Anti-Bias Bill
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 4-6 with provisions of law bgng ``The bill...; deletes final 7 grafs, redundant material
DOC.TEXT: As several thousand advocates for the disabled looked on, President Bush today signed an act banning discrimination against the nation's 43 million handicapped people. ``Every man, woman and child with a disability can now pass through a once-closed door to a bright new era of equality, independence and freedom,'' Bush said as he signed the measure in a ceremony on the South Lawn. The president likened the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990 to the dismantling of the Berlin Wall as a symbol of freedom for a once-oppressed people. It ``takes a sledgehammer to another wall,'' he said. The bill prohibits discrimination against the disabled in employment, public accommodations, transportation and telecommunications, and defines as disabled anyone who has a mental or physical impairment limiting ``some major life function.'' The disabilities bill, like other major civil rights legislation, includes a variety of sanctions for violators, including those who discriminate in hiring. It allows victims of employment discrimination to seek back pay, reinstatement and attorneys' fees. However, the law exempts businesses with fewer than 15 employees from the hiring provisions. The measure includes new protection for AIDS-infected workers. ``This day belongs to you,'' Bush told the audience gathered outside the White House. It was one of the largest bill-signing ceremonies ever held at the White House. About 2,000 people, representing groups that lobbied for the bill, sat in wheelchairs or on folding chairs at the ceremony in bright sunshine with temperatures in the mid-80s. White House officials had considered moving today's ceremony inside and reducing its size because of the anticipated heat. But protests from disability groups, including a threat by some to hold a separate ``people's signing'' ceremony outside the White House gates, persuaded officials to go ahead with the outside ceremony. ``We considered moving it inside because of the heat concerns. There could be up to two hours of sitting in the hot sun. But the disabled community said heat was no problem,'' said White House spokeswoman Alixe Glen. Some activists had suggested that the White House notion that disabled people are too frail to sit out in the summer sun showed the very kind of bias the legislation was designed to end. In signing the bill, Bush said, ``This historic act is the world's first comprehensive declaration of equality for people with disabilities.'' He called it an ``historic new civil rights act.'' The crowd gave one of its loudest cheers when Bush said the law would give the disabled expanded access to transportation. ``It's just fantastic. It's a tremendously exhiliarating feeling,'' said Gordon Anthony, 35, an activist and marketing consultant from Los Angeles who uses a wheelchair. ``Employers are going to start reaching out to the disabled,'' he said. ``It may open doors for what I do in my future career. There may be better opportunities.'' In advance of the ceremony, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater called the bill ``a milestone in President Bush's decade-long personal commitment to the rights of the disabled.'' ``I think it affects a broader scope of people than any law since the 1964 (Civil Rights) Act,'' Fitzwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandeal, De Kerlk Meet After Row Over Arrest of ANC Member
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 3 grafs to UPDATE with source saying the meeting has taken place. Pickup 3rd, `De Klerk's office...'
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk held an urgent meeting with African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela today after the ANC denounced the arrest of a senior member, a source said. The president's office announced the meeting a day after the arrest of Mac Maharaj, who is also a Communist Party leader. Police said Maharaj was being held in connection with a plot they said involved Communist members of the ANC. Neither the president's office nor the ANC would say if the meeting had taken place in Pretoria, but a reliable source who spoke on condition of anonymity said it had. The source had no details about what was discussed. De Klerk's office said the president wanted to meet with Mandela because it appeared the ANC ``does not appreciate the seriousness of facts brought to light'' by a recent police investigation into the alleged plot to seize power. Many members of the ANC's 35-member National Executive Committee are also members of the South African Communist Party. A radio report said the meeting had already taken place, but de Klerk's office denied that. In recent weeks, police have arrested 40 members of the ANC under the Internal Security Act, under which Maharaj is being held. The act allows authorities to hold detainees in solitary confinement without legal representation and interrogate them until they give ``satisfactory answers.'' Maharaj had been organizing a Communist Party rally planned for Sunday to mark the party's emergence as a legal political group after years as an underground movement. The party, headed by Joe Slovo, was legalized by the white-minority government in February. For years, the government had portrayed it as a terrorist organization operating under Soviet control. Maharaj's arrest was a ``concerted attempt to disrupt our rally,'' party spokesman Jeremy Cronin told a news conference. He claimed police were trying to spread fears of a conspiracy by Communists to seize power if government talks with the ANC failed. ``There's no `red plot' whatsoever,'' he said. Before the de Klerk-Mandela meeting was announced, Cronin said andela would attend the planned rally in the black township of Soweto outside Johannesburg and make a major statement about the ANC's relationship with the Communist Party. He gave no details. Mandela said earlier the opposition group would go ahead with talks Aug. 6 with the government despite the arrest. The ANC, which condemned Maharah's arrest, and the government are trying to clear the way for talks on ending white-minority rule and extending political rights to the black majority. ANC leaders have said the arrest of Maharaj and other Communist members of the ANC will be discussed with the government at the Aug. 6 talks. The talks are aimed at clearing away obstacles to a cease-fire and proceed with formal negotiations to end white minority rule. After postponing talks once because of police action, ANC leaders said they would continue to object to such activity, but would not allow anything to interfere with progress toward an end to apartheid. One of the obstacles to negotiation, the ANC has said, is the existence of the Internal Security Act, under which Maharaj and other ANC members have been detained indefinitely for questioning. ANC leaders appear to believe that they have a better chance of getting their members freed, and ending such arrests, by negotiating with the government. The government has said little about the reported arrests, except to warn all political groups not to try to seize power and affirm its determination to maintain law and order. Mandela and other ANC officials have refused to sever their organization's ties with the Communist Party despite domestic and international criticism. Communist Party leaders plan a major drive for working class supporters in South Africa's main industrial centers. The communists say they plan to be a democratic party representing workers and have attempted to distance themselves from the excesses of communist groups in Eastern Europe and elsewhere.

DOC.HEAD: Tea Room Bags Top Honors
DOC.TEXT: A couple in Chichester, Sussex, on Thursday bagged top honors for running the nation's best spot for a spot of tea. The national Tea Council selected Shepherd's Tea Rooms as the best place in Britain to get a cup of tea. The sedate tea room in a historic building serves 700 pots of tea a week in 10 different blends to locals and tourists in Chichester, nine miles northeast of Portsmouth. The tea room is run by newlyweds Richard and Yvonne Spence. Everything from the taste of the tea to the courtesy of the staff and the ambience of the rooms was considered during a number of secret visits, said the Tea Council's executive director, Illtyd Lewis. ``You might ask why so much trouble over a pot of tea, but tea is our national drink,'' Lewis said. According to the Tea Council, more than 80 percent of people in Britain surveyed said they drink tea, which accounts for 43.9 percent of all beverages consumed except for tap water.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker Ruled Too Ill To Stand Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Honecker unfit to face charges. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A medical panel has ruled that deposed Communist leader Erich Honecker is too ill to be prosecuted, but that an 82-year-old former secret police chief is fit enough to face criminal charges. Honecker, who ruled with an iron hand before being toppled in last year's pro-democracy revolution, had been charged with corruption and abuse of power. He is suffering from kidney cancer and is staying at a Soviet military hospital outside Berlin. The government said even though allegations of abuse of office and corruption justify criminal prosecution of Honecker, the 77-year-old former leader's health is too precarious. West Germany is still pursuing murder charges against Honecker for his part in promulgating the notorious shoot-to-kill order which led to the deaths of at least 192 people trying to flee into West Germany. The former secret police chief, Erich Mielke, was formally placed under arrest today pending an investigation of charges he harbored terrorists and jailed critics of the former regime. Mielke, the onetime chief of the now-disbanded domestic intelligence network, had been in a Berlin hospital undergoing a medical evaulation to determine his competency to face the charges. The competency decisions were based on the results of an independent medical panel's evaluation of Honecker, Mielke, and several other members of the ousted Communist regime, said federal spokesman Peter Przybylski. Mielke's arrest brings to three the number of former Communist officials who have now been judged competent to face investigation. Also being held is former East German labor union chief Harry Tisch and former Communist Party economist Guenter Mittag. Mielke's arrest follows reports that terrorist suspects linked to some of the most notorious attacks of the past two decades regularly lived in or traveled through East Germany with the approval of authorities, including his secret police. Eight reputed members of the Red Army Faction, blamed for a series of killings and bombings in West Germany in the 1970s and 1980s, have been arrested in the past several weeks in East Germany. Some had been living there for more than a decade. All had assumed names, and some said they were given housing and false identities by the former secret police. The secret police, known as the Stasi, intimidated, harassed and monitored millions of people and was considered one of the most skilled and feared intelligence networks in the world.

DOC.HEAD: Hasenfus: Secord, Southern Air Skimped on Safety to Boost Profits
DOC.TEXT: The surviving crewman of a downed Contra supply plane today tearfully recounted the dramatic last moments of a 1986 plane crash that helped unravel details of the Iran-Contra affair. The testimony came from Eugene Hasenfus, who with the family of co-pilot Wallace Sawyer Jr. is suing Richard Secord and Miami-based Southern Air for allegedly misleading the crew and using aircraft without adequate safety equipment. Hasenfus, his voice cracking, said his C-123 was flying into southern Nicaragua on Oct. 5, 1986 with supplies for a Contra force pinned down by Sandinistas. He said that suddenly a Sandinista rocket struck the plane. ``There was a loud explosion from the right. I was astounded. The whole plane was on fire,'' Hasenfus said. Wearing a parachute, Hasenfus jumped through the open cargo door and was in a near state of shock as the aircraft spiraled to the ground. He evaded the Sandinistas overnight in the jungle but was captured the next day. Sawyer and two crewmen died in the crash. As he testified today, Sawyer's wife, Kasanee, of Magnolia, Ark., and Hasenfus' wife, Sally, watched intently with tears in their eyes as well. The crash of Hasenfus' plane was a key revelation leading the Reagan administration to acknowledge illegally diverting money from Iran arms sales to the Contras. Prior to recounting the crash, Hasenfus said he was hired through the Southern Air headquarters at Miami International Airport and understood he was working for a front company operated by that airline. He said the crews complained that there was no safety equipment such as parachutes and that the navigation radios did not work properly. Hasenfus' suit says Southern Air skimped on safety to boost profits in the Contra supply effort. But defense lawyers in the federal suit said in opening arguments Wednesday that Hasenfus knew the risks when he joined the fight against communism in Central America. Secord's lawyer, Thomas Spencer, said his client never met or made any promises to the crew and that they knew the dangers of supplying the Contras in enemy territory. Secord, a retired Air Force major general, pleaded guilty Nov. 8, 1989, to lying to congressional investigators when he said he was unaware of any money that went to Oliver North's benefit from the maze of companies he used in the Iran-Contra affair. He is serving a two-year probation. Southern Air attorney Robert Beckman told the six-member jury Wednesday that the airline was not responsible for the crew or the crash. He said Hasenfus and Sawyer had contracted with Corporate Air Services, which he acknowledged worked with Southern Air. But he strongly denied Corporate Air was merely a front for his client. Southern Air was once owned by the CIA and continues to do contract work for the government. Hasenfus' lawyers say they are still calculating damages. On Wednesday they submitted some figures to Secord showing actual damages of about $2 million for Sawyer's family and about $1 million for Hasenfus.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Urged Legislature Not To Involve Judges In Abortion Decisions
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 5-6, The letter, with lack of reaction from right-to-life groups and White House.
DOC.TEXT: As a state judge nine years ago, Supreme Court nominee David Souter urged New Hampshire's legislature not to adopt a law that would have put judges in the position of approving abortions for minors if their parents refused permission. Souter did not express a personal stand on the issue, but said his fellow judges had decided that a measure then pending before the state legislature would promote ``shopping for judges'' because it did not include guidelines on how judges should act. Therefore, he said, the bill would unfairly leave such decisions up to individual judges with varied opinions on abortion, resulting in inconsistent application of any such law. Asked about the letter in Washington today, Souter said, ``I think you should save any issue of that sort ... for the conbfirmation hearing where I'm sure that issue will be addressed.'' New Hampshire abortion rights activist Peg Dobbie said Wednesday Souter's letter was critical to efforts to kill the legislation. She added, ``But while it helped us, you can't read into it anything about how he might feel personally about abortion,'' an issue likely to dominate Souter's Senate confirmation hearings. The letter drew silence from right-to-life groups, who had no immediate reaction. At the White House, press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``We have no reaction to it one way or the other.'' Dawn Johnsen, legal director for the National Abortion Rights Action League in Washington, said the letter was reason for the Senate to probe Souter's views on constitutional issues surrounding abortion during its hearings. But she said NARAL did not view the letter as revealing Souter's inclinations on the central abortion issue. ``I think it is not very illuminating on Judge Souter's position on the constitutional right to privacy, including the right to choose,'' Johnsen said. She said it ``suggests that Judge Souter might vote with conservatives on the court to allow a law that mandated parental consent without any escape valve for teen-agers who are victims of child abuse and family violence,'' and thus are unable to discuss an abortion with their parents. ``I don't see much reason for encouragement,'' Johnsen said. ``At best it's neutral. It's a complicated letter on just the judicial bypass. ... There are people who are looking for the silver lining, but I don't think this is it.'' The 1981 letter, written to the chairwoman of the legislative committee considering a parental consent bill, is one of Souter's few public actions addressing the abortion issue. In his one abortion-related decision on the issue as a judge, Souter gave little insight as to how he might vote if confirmed and confronted with the opportunity to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion. In 1986, Souter sided with the majority in a ruling that said physicians have a responsibility to test unborn children for birth defects and, in the event defects are detected, to counsel the pregnant woman about options -- including abortion. A month after the Roe vs. Wade decision, Souter was among the Concord Hospital board members at a meeting at which the board approved allowing abortions at the hospital. Two board members contacted Wednesday, Dean Williamson and Marily Wilson, said they recalled only non-controversial discussion and a unanimous voice vote in favor of allowing abortions. Neither recalled Souter speaking during the discussion. ``This was a medical procedure vote, not a social issues vote,'' Ms. Wilson said. ``It was not over the rights or wrongs of abortion but rather about our responsibility as a medical facility in light of the law.'' In his 1981 letter on behalf of fellow Superior Court justices, Souter said the bill before the legislature failed to provide guidelines for the judges to use in deciding whether to allow minors to receive abortions if they did not have parental consent. Abortion-rights advocates said there was nothing in the letter to shed light on Souter's personal views on abortion. ``I can't for a minute say that this indicates he is opposed to restrictions on abortion; it's too vague to make any interpretation at all,'' said Peg Dobbie of the New Hampshire chapter of the National Abortion Rights Action League. ``I wish we could say that you could interpret this that way, but you could just as easily say that he favors a parental consent law but just doesn't think the court or the judges should be involved.'' Indeed, other Superior Court judges since Souter was elevated to the state Supreme Court have sent virtually identical letters to the legislature during debate of other parental-consent bills over the past decade, all of which have been defeated. The U.S. Supreme Court has ruled that parental-consent laws must contain an option permitting a judge to decide if the minor seeking an abortion does not want to consult her parents. Souter's two-page letter said the court was not taking a position on whether the legislature should require parental consent. The judges objected that in passing the bill, legislators would be endorsing as the will of society ``to leave it to individual justices of this court to make fundamental moral decisions about the interests of other people without any standards to guide the individual judge.'' Without clear guidelines, Souter wrote, ``there would be left only the individual judge's principles and predilections.'' And, he said, ``as carefully considered as these might be there would still be those of only one individual, not those of society.'' Souder noted that the judiciary often is criticized for imposing its views on the society at large and said the pending parental consent law would force an individual justice to impose his or her individual view. ``As you would expect, there are some judges who believe abortion under the circumstances contemplated by the bill is morally wrong, who could not in conscience issue an order requiring an abortion to be performed,'' Souter wrote, without giving his own view. ``There are others who believe that what may be thought to be in the `best interests' of the pregnant minor is itself just as necessarily a moral as a social question upon which a judge may not morally speak for another human being whatever may be that judge's own personal opinion about the morality of abortion.'' Such internal conflict would lead to ``shopping for judges who would entertain such cases,'' Souter wrote. Several legislators reached late Wednesday said the current chief judge on the Superior Court, Richard Dunfey, circulated a virtually identical letter to lawmakers last year when they were considering a similar measure. When Souter served as New Hampshire attorney general, he supported obscenity indictments against Penthouse magazine and a drug store that sold its July 1976 ``Bisextennial'' issue. Souter's office did not bring the initial charges but represented a county prosecutor before the New Hampshire Supreme Court 12 years ago when the defendants sought to have the indictments dismissed. The high court refused to dismiss the indictments, but it did declare unconstitutional a portion of the state law's definition of sexual conduct. The case was among dozens Souter's office argued before the state court while he was attorney general in 1977-78. Collectively, they show he supported positions much like the tough law-and-order approach he later took as a state judge.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak, West German Leaders Make Controversial Austrian Visit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with meeting, three attending luncheon. Pick up 4th graf pvs, `American Rabbi...'
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia today warned of the dangers of lying about the past in comments indirectly critical of President Kurt Waldheim, his host during a controversial visit to the city. Havel and the West German president, Richard von Weizsaecker, met briefly with Waldheim as the Salzburg Festival of music and drama opened. Most Western leaders have shunned Waldheim for concealing his Nazi past, and the presidents' visit angered Jewish groups. Both leaders repeatedly emphasized the visits were private, not official. No private meetings with Waldheim were planned. Havel, Weizsaecker and Waldheim attended a lunch given by Salzburg governor Hans Katschthaler, the official host, before Havel and Weizsaecker left for home. American Rabbi Avi Weiss was arrested with an associate inside the festival hall after they forced their way into the lobby shouting: ``It's a shame to meet Waldheim!'' Weiss and three other activists also protested Wednesday outside Weizsaecker's sprawling West Berlin palace, wearing concentration camp uniforms. Havel's comments in the opening ceremony were made in the context of changes in Eastern Europe over the past year that instituted democracy. While he never mentioned Waldheim's name, some of the language appeared clearly directed at the Austrian president, who sat stone-faced in the first row. ``The expectation that one can negotiate his way through history without punishment and be able to rewrite his own biography is part of the traditional madness of middle Europe,'' said Havel. ``Whoever tries to do this, hurts himself and his fellow citizens. Waldheim, a former U.N. secretary-general, drew international criticism for concealing his service as an intelligence officer with a Nazi army unit implicated in atrocities in Yugoslavia and Greece during World War II. He has denied wrongdoing. Since his election in 1986, Waldheim has been shunned by most Western nations, including the United States. This month, Cypriot President Georgios Vassiliou became the first Western head of state to make an official visit to Austria since Waldheim's election. Pope John Paul II met with Waldheim in 1987. Heinz Galinski, head of the German Jewish Council, said last week he was ``shocked'' over Weizsaecker's meeting with Waldheim. Weiss, in a statement Tuesday, condemned both Waldheim and Weizsaecker. ``We view the meeting of Havel and Weizsaecker with Waldheim as obscene and we will be raising a voice of moral conscience against Waldheim, who is an unrepentant Nazi,'' the rabbi said. ``We especially are outraged that at a time of German reunification, the president of West Germany is meeting with Waldheim. The only way Germany can move forward is to reject people like Waldheim,'' Weiss said. ``I am attending a cultural event as a private person,'' Havel said in an interview published Wednesday by the Salzburger Nachrichten newspaper. ``However, at the time of the visit I am also president _ that is something one cannot discard, that is to say something official remains attached to any of my visits.'' While Havel criticized Western leaders for continuing to steer clear of Waldheim, he made it plain he was unlikely to make a state visit to Austria as long as Waldheim is president. Waldheim's term is to expire in 1992. The Czechoslovak state news agency CTK carried a statement today by Havel's office saying the former dissident accepted the invitation to the festival last year, when it appeared unlikely the then-ruling Communists would let him go.

DOC.HEAD: Postmaster Supports Child-Proof Packaging of Drugs
DOC.TEXT: Postmaster General Anthony Frank endorsed legislation Thursday to require child-proof packaging of mailed medicine samples, saying it could ``head off a disaster before it happens.'' The bill was inspired by an incident last March in Saline, Mich., in which a group of children ages 3 to 8 obtained sample packages of Tylenol gelcaps from an open mailbox area in an apartment complex. The Postal Service typically places mailed samples in open racks or on tables in the mail area of apartment buildings when the packages don't fit in mailboxes. The children, pretending the gelcaps were cocaine, were crushing them and apparently intended to inhale the powder. But an adult saw what was happening, confiscated the medicine and notified police. Frank said he had received no reports of children actually ingesting direct-mail medicine samples. ``We all have it in our power to head off a disaster before it happens and what a great feeling that is for a change,'' he told the House Subcommittee on Postal Operations and Services. ``We stand foursquare behind the bill.'' No opposition surfaced during the subcommittee hearing. Voicing support for the bill were Donnelley Marketing, the company that handled the Tylenol mailing; the Direct Marketing Association; the Third Class Mail Association; and two agencies of the U.S. Postal Service. The bill would require that pharmaceutical and hazardous household product samples sent through the mail be packaged in child-proof containers. The Postal Service would refuse to deliver samples not meeting the standard. James Douglas, director of the Saline Department of Public Safety, said about 110 sample packages of Tylenol gelcaps were taken from the children. The University of Michigan's poison control center later told police that as few as six of the gelcaps could cause serious, or even fatal, liver disease in a 40-pound child. That is the typical weight of children ages 3 to 5, Douglas said. An overdose of aspirin and similar drugs would not cause any readily observable symptoms such as vomiting or unconsciousness, he said. Poison control officials told him the only way to determine whether a lethal dosage had been consumed is to conduct a ``blood screening'' within six hours of the time the drug was ingested, Douglas said. ``This truly is a situation where a tightening of rules and regulations could prevent a threat to public safety,'' said Rep. William Ford, D-Mich., a co-sponsor of the bill. Donnelly Marketing already has adopted a policy requiring child-proof packaging of medicine samples it distributes, senior vice president Ellen M. Farley said. While supporting the legislation, she said its effective date _ Oct. 1 or 60 days after its enactment, whichever is later _ might not give manufacturers enough time to comply. An additional six months should be allowed, Ms. Farley said.

DOC.HEAD: At the Movies: ``Presumed Innocent''
DOC.TEXT: In their publicity material for the movie ``Presumed Innocent,'' Warner Bros. asks reviewers not to reveal the ending or say whether Rusty Sabich (Harrison Ford) is innocent or guilty. It's an interesting request, considering that the 1987 Scott Turow best-selling novel sold more than 1 million in hardback and millions more in paperback. Needless to say, a lot of people know Rusty's fate. But nothing that happens at the beginning of the Alan J. Pakula courtroom thriller, or even as it unravels, sets up the end. The movie is plump with twists, turns and blind alleys. Who can be trusted? Who is innocent? Who is guilty? The novel is set in mythical Kindle County, in an unidentified Midwest city with Chicago-style politics and corruption. The movie was shot in Detroit. Rusty, a married, top-flight prosecutor, is assigned to investigate the murder of another prosecutor, Caroline Polhemus (Greta Scacchi), with whom he had been sexually involved. Polhemus was found bludgeoned to death and tied up in what appeared to be an act of sexual bondage. But a glass containing a little beer and Rusty's fingerprint is left in plain view, making it real easy for police to point a finger. A telephone check also finds numerous calls made from Caroline's number to Rusty's number and vice versa, including a call made the day of the murder. Rusty wasn't the only man bedding Caroline. His boss, Raymond Horgan, the chief prosecuting attorney, also was intimate with Polhemus. Horgan is in the midst of a bitter campaign for his seat against the smarmy Nico Della Guardia. Horgan (Brian Dennehy) loses the election and serves up Rusty _ on a platter once he discovers Rusty's relationship to Caroline _ to his former foe. Rusty hires the best defense lawyer around, the scholarly and elegant Sandy Stern (Raul Julia), and the game is afoot. Woven into the courtroom suspense is a thread of corruption that goes back to Polhemus' days as a probation officer and somehow involves Della Guardia's sidekick, a moldy little prosecutor named Tommy Molto (Joe Grifasi). The strength of ``Presumed Innocent'' is its rich gallery of well-developed characters. Its weakness is perhaps in execution of the final plot turn. The book crafts duplicity and surprises far better than the almost labored denouement presented on film. And a key clue, one the camera sweeps by in a flash, and pivotal to knowing who the murderer is, never really blossoms. Caroline Polhemus is a nasty piece of work, disliked by men because she's aggressive and beats them at their own game. She volunteers to tackle sex crimes, cases usually relegated to the worst lawyers in the department because they're a no-win situation. However, it is unfortunate that the author and now the filmmakers seem to think that the only way a smart woman can succeed professionally is by sleeping her way to the top. Polhemus is sexually attracted to Rusty because he represents power in her office and is just a step away from the No. 1 spot, a spot she covets. But why is Rusty drawn to her? There is no chemistry or sexual tension between them. But he falls into her arms after a tough child abuse trial like a lovesick puppy. Ford plays Rusty straight, almost too straight. He loves his wife, we surmise and is happily married, we suppose. Or, is he bored by a wife who whines about being a housewife and mother? He admits he does not love Caroline but she's gotten into his blood. Or, perhaps just the passion and lust have. Theirs is a purely sexual bond. Still, his motive for engaging in a professionally and personally dangerous affair is fuzzy. Scacchi, a European beauty, is seductive and hungry as Caroline. She can be an ice queen, but has a gentler side as when she coaxes an abused child into testifying against his mother. As Rusty's wife, Barbara, Bonnie Bedelia radiates compassion, frustration, love and fear. It is one her strongest performances. Julia puts in a good turn as Sandy Stern, and Paul Winfield adds charm and humor to courtroom prancing as the trial judge, Larren Lyttle. There's also good support from Brian Dennehy as Raymond Horgan and John Spencer as the hard-working detective whose loyalty and sense of duty figure importantly in the end. Pakula (``All the President's Men,'' ``Sophie's Choice'') takes his time unraveling the story from the screenplay written by himself and Frank Pierson (``Dog Day Afternoon''). He plays for reactions, underlying motives, the quirky human element. And here, he has a great similarity to Otto Preminger's handling of courtroom suspense in 1959's ``Anatomy of a Murder'' with James Stewart. But missing is the hard-edged tension Billy Wilder sculpted in 1957's ``Witness for the Prosecution.'' Both are gripping dramas. Both rely on the element of surprise to make a compelling film. And both are among the best courtroom dramas ever made. Now ``Presumed Innocent'' has joined the ranks. ``Presumed Innocent'' is a Mirage Production, produced by Sydney Pollack and Mark Rosenberg with Susan Solt as executive producer. It is rated R for strong sexual content and unpleasant shots of the murdered victim.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.HEAD: With Frank-Ethics
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., was joined by two other lawmakers beset by recent sex scandals in abstaining from a vote Thursday on expelling Frank from the House because of his official actions on behalf of a male prostitute. Joining Frank in voting ``present'' on the vote to expel him were Reps. Gus Savage, D-Ill., and Donald E. Lukens, R-Ohio. The House rejected 390-38 the move by Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., to expel Frank. Savage was sharply criticized earlier this year by the House Ethics Committee following an inquiry into allegations that he tried to molest a Peace Corps volunteer during a visit to Zaire. Lukens was defeated in the Republican primary in Ohio in May for his party's nomination for re-election after he was convicted last year on charges resulting from having sex with a 16-year-old minor. It is customary for the legislator being judged in a disciplinary proceeding by the House or Senate to vote ``present.''

DOC.HEAD: Roseanne Barr Booed for Shrill Rendition of National Anthem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last two grafs, `The Associated...' to UPDATE with efforts to reach spokesmen today. ADDS byline.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GOS5, GOS2
DOC.TEXT: Roseanne Barr made an obscene gesture and spit on the ground after she was booed at a San Diego Padres game for a shrill rendition of the national anthem in front of 30,000 baseball fans. The comedian and star of ABC's ``Roseanne'' appeared to struggle Wednesday night with an echo from the sound system as she sang between games of a doubleheader with the Cincinnati Reds, said Ron Seaver, the Padres' promotions director. Barr plugged her ears with her fingers at the start of the song, then sang in a shrill voice. After the boos began, Barr reached toward her crotch and spit on the ground. Barr's husband, Tom Arnold, later made a ceremonial pitch with no reaction, but Barr got more boos as she waved to the crowd and left with him. ``The Padres understand that many people were concerned about Roseanne Barr's rendition of the national anthem,'' Seaver said. ``She was doing the best she could under the circumstances of the audio delay and she certainly meant no disrespect to the national anthem.'' Barr said she was pleased with her performance. ``I think I did great and people wanted more,'' she told a reporter for KFMB-TV before leaving the field. Asked about the boos, she said, ``Yeah, well, just because they weren't up front.'' At least two Padres players were upset by her singing, spitting and gesture afterward. ``I was embarrassed as a person and I was embarrassed for them (the Padres),'' said Padres pitcher Eric Show, who was on the field. ``I can't believe it happened. It's an insult. There are people who died for that song.'' ``I thought it was a disgrace,'' Padres outfielder Tony Gwynn said. ``When they said she was going to sing the national anthem I thought something like this was going to happen.'' Tom Werner, who become the chairman and managing partner of the Padres this season and also is co-creator and executive producer of ``Roseanne,'' had invited Barr to sing ``The Star-Spangled Banner.'' He would not comment after Barr's performance. Barr's publicist George Freeman and ``Roseanne'' show and Werner spokesman David Brokaw didn't immediately return telephone calls today.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent: Sting Had Ended, But Then Barry Called For Drugs
Ess: UPDATES with testimony from FBI agent. ADDS that defense is apparently nearing the end of its case; moves up that Barry not expected to testify. EDITS throughout to tighten. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: An FBI agent testified today that he thought the Jan. 18 undercover sting operation against Marion Barry had failed until the mayor unexpectedly asked for crack cocaine. Lawyer R. Kenneth Mundy called Agent Ronald Stern to the witness stand in an attempt to show that the FBI entrapped the mayor. The defense was nearing the end of its case, and Mundy said it was unlikely Barry would testify. Agent Ronald Stern said at Barry's cocaine and perjury trial that an undercover agent carrying crack cocaine left a hotel room where Barry had gone to meet ex-model Rasheeda Moore. Barry had said initially he didn't want the crack. ``There was no longer any drugs in the room,'' Stern said. ``As far as we were concerned, the operation was over. Stern, who was monitoring the sting from a nearby room at the hotel, said Barry then told Ms. Moore to call the undercover agent back. On the FBI videotape of the sting shown earlier at the trial, Barry tells Ms. Moore: ``Got get some. Go get it.'' She calls the undercover agent back to the room to retrieve the crack. ``The important thing here is what Mr. Barry was thinking,'' Stern testified. ``He believed that'' the undercover agent ``was an opportunity for drugs.'' The FBI and police rented eight hotel rooms for the sting and provided the drugs used in the operation, Stern said. Earlier, Barry's lawyers suggested that prosecutors had intimidated witnesses into testifying falsely against the mayor. Mundy played for the jury a Feb. 28 news broadcast of U.S. Attorney Jay Stephens exhorting witnesses to come forward and cooperate in the criminal investigation of Barry. Stephens made the statement the day that Barry pleaded innocent to cocaine possession and charges. ``The time is now to come in,'' Stephens said in the broadcast. ``The alternative of course is prosecution.'' Government witness Lloyd Moore testified that the broadcast was a factor in his decision to begin cooperating with government investigators. Moore testified that he saw Barry use drugs about 10 times. ``You testified truthfully?'' assistant U.S. attorney Richard Roberts asked Moore on cross-examination. ``Yes,'' replied Moore, who is an attorney. There is ``nothing unusual about seeking the assistance of witnesses in solving crimes?'' asked Roberts. ``They do it every day,'' replied Moore. On Wednesday, a Virgin Islands couple testified that the FBI had badgered them about their repeated statements that they never saw Barry use drugs on a 1986 sailboat ride. Carmen Benjamin said she was interviewed three times by agents, the final time late last year when she and her husband were summoned to FBI headquarters in Washington. She testified that she felt so ``pressured'' and ``harassed'' that she pounded her hand on the table. She said she demanded that the interogation end, but that agents continued to question her. Mrs. Benjamin said she was snorkeling while the sailboat was anchored in the Virgin Islands and didn't pay much attention to Barry and Ms. Moore. The mayor is accused of 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor conspiracy charge and three felony counts of lying to the grand jury. Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis testified earlier that he and Barry smoked marijuana aboard the sailboat, on which the Benjamins were passengers. Did the FBI and a city police detective ``attempt to pressure you to change your story?'' Robert Mance, one of Barry's lawyers, asked Albert Benjamin. ``Yes,'' Benjamin replied.

DOC.HEAD: Bicycle Brigade Versus Baby Brigade in Sri Lanka's Deadly War
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Police on bicycles zigzag through jungle tracks, dodging land mines in a deadly game with teen-age Tamil rebels. It is the ``bicycle brigade'' against the ``baby brigade,'' as police call the young militants of the Tamil Tiger militia. Some are as young as 12, and their most successful weapons are homemade mines that have blown the legs off dozens of commandos since fighting resumed last month. As a result, officers of the Special Task Force, police trained to fight the Tamils, formed the ``bicycle brigade.'' ``The bicycle tire has more chances of avoiding the buried explosive than a boot. The damage causes less injuries as the blast is cushioned by the bicycle,'' said senior commando Upali Sahabandu of the Special Task Force. The mines, which consist of high explosives packed into wooden boxes with two small AA batteries, have been dubbed Johnnies, Dice or Batta by the Sri Lankan troops. They are hidden in culverts under the jungle roads of Tirukovil, which was once a Tamil stronghold. The government claims its troops now control a 33-mile stretch of the eastern coast between Lahugala, south of Tirukovil, and Kalmunai to its north. Special Task Force chief Lionel Karunasena said his unit of 125 men has mastered the art of anticipating rebel moves. The rebels operate in groups of five to seven to minimize losses. ``We do the same. We know their game, they know ours. So we are even,'' Karunasena told a group of visiting reporters. ``That is why they avoid tangling with our bicycle brigade or hit us with mines on these roads,'' he said. His unit is part of the 2,500-member Special Task Force trained to help in the war against militant Tamils fighting for an independent homeland. Commandos moved into the town and set up camp in its main hospital this month, forcing the once-dominant Tamils to slip into the jungles. People in the town, 135 miles east of Colombo, say that although the troops control the area during the day, the rebels return from the jungles to prowl at night. ``A dog's bark in the dark is a sure sign the Tiger rebels are around. Nobody else moves out at night,'' said the Rev. Thaya Seelan, a Tamil Methodist priest. The commandos say their taking of Tirukovil, which has ample jungle cover to the west and the Indian Ocean to the right, dealt a severe blow to guerrilla operations. ``Tirukovil is vitally located for jungle based hit-and-run attacks. Without Tirukovil as a base ... it will be difficult for the terrorists to launch any campaign to clear government forces in the eastern coast,'' said Sahabandu, the veteran anti-guerrilla fighter. Karunasena said he plans to ``first secure our hold here,'' then move toward rebel strongholds in the eastern districts of Ampara and Batticaloa. The Tamil Tigers have been fighting since 1983 to set up a homeland in the north and the east, complaining of discrimination by the majority Sinhalese. Tamils make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people and the Sinhalese account for 75 percent. More than 2,850 combatants and an unknown but large number of civilians have died in the latest round of fighting, which began June 11 after a 13-month cease-fire. ``When will this end? When will the killings stop? When will the gods intervene?'' moaned Murugesu Tirunavakarasu, a chili planter whose only son, Raju, disappeared three years ago. ``We don't want anything else but to be left in peace. You people from outside don't know the hell we have gone through,'' the 68-year-old farmer said. Schools, banks and government offices have been shut for several months. There are no vehicles or buses on streets except commando jeeps and armored troop carriers. But there are scenes of normalcy. Acres of paddy sway in the breeze, waiting to be harvested. Buyers haggle in the market. Fishermen throw their nets into a murky lagoon, watched by women carrying reed baskets. A short distance away, five commandos tighten their bullet bandoleers around their chests, climb on their bicycles and push away into the bush.

DOC.HEAD: Senators Urge Additional Changes in U.S. Policy Toward Cambodia
DOC.TEXT: Sixty-six senators of both parties called Thursday for President Bush to make further changes in U.S. policy toward Cambodia, including permitting development aid and direct talks with the communist government in Phnom Penh. The senators, nearly two-thirds of the Senate, also challenged administration assertions that there is no consistent military coordination between the two non-communist factions fighting the Cambodian government and the feared Khmer Rouge rebels with whom they are allied. Those signing the letter, led by Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., spanned the political spectrum in the chamber. Their move reflected growing congressional fears of a Khmer Rouge military victory, inadvertently abetted by the United States. The group included 13 Republicans and 53 Democrats. On July 18, about a week after the original letter to Bush began circulating in the Senate, Secretary of State James A. Baker III announced that the United States was withdrawing its support for a U.N. seat for the rebel coalition. Baker also said the United States would open a limited dialogue with the government of Vietnam, which installed Hun Sen in power before withdrawing its troops last year. And he said limited U.S. humanitarian aid could begin flowing to Cambodia, which is the subject of a 15-year-old U.S. embargo. In the letter sent to Bush on Wednesday, the senators welcomed those moves, but said additional steps would be necessary to demonstrate that keeping the Khmer Rouge from re-taking power is the highest aim of U.S. policy. The Khmer Rouge were responsible for the deaths of more than a million Cambodians during their 3{-year rule in the late 1970s as they sought to force their vision of a communist agrarian state on the country. People executed or died of starvation and disease. The senators called for three additional steps: _ Pressing the government of China, which U.S. intelligence estimates provides $100 million a year in military aid to the Khmer Rouge, to end its support for the communist rebels. _ Opening direct contacts with the Hun Sen government in Phnom Penh aimed at arranging free and fair elections supervised by the United Nations. _ Permitting U.S. development aid to flow to Cambodia to strengthen and redirect its beleaguered economy. In addition, the group called for closer scrutiny of the $7 million in overt non-lethal aid and the estimated $13 million in covert military aid which the United States now sends each year to the rebel coalition. The letter emphasized that U.S. law bars any aid which has ``the effect of promoting, sustaining or augmenting, directly or indirectly, the capacity of the Khmer Rouge... to conduct military operations.'' It did not call directly for an aid cutoff, but asked the administration ``to thoroughly investigate'' reports of military cooperation between the non-communist rebels and the Khmer Rouge ``to ensure that there is no tactical or strategic cooperation.''. The Senate Intelligence Committee voted June 28 to cut off the covert aid program. The Central Intelligence Agency and Defense Intelligence Agency, in briefings for interested officials, have described how the three allied rebel groups share supply lines which are controlled by the Khmer Rouge, and coordinate their anti-government attacks. Deep inside Cambodia, the lines between the separate fighting forces are blurred, the intelligence reports say, and the rebel group of Prince Norodom Sihanouk, backed by the United States, serves as a political front to bring respectability to the Khmer Rouge. ``The Khmer Rouge are marching again, and from the reports I have received they are marching together with the forces of Prince Sihanouk,'' Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, said in a floor speech. The letter concluded: ``We believe that after 20 years of turmoil and tragedy, the people of Cambodia deserve an opportunity to determine their own future free of fear of the Khmer Rouge.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Upholds Will Leaving Most of Estate to Four Cats
DOC.TEXT: Clementine, Gene, Martha and Smudge are fat cats now. A judge ruled that the four cats can legally inherit the lion's share of their owner's estate, with the money going to pay for their foster care in a new home. Clinton County District Court Judge C.H. Pelton decided Wednesday that the will of Melody Stanton is clear in its meaning. It asked that the estate be placed in a trust ``for the care and comfort of the only possessions I have in my life, my animals, my cats.'' ``No one was ever so kitty-nuts as she was,'' said Ms. Stanton's mother, Eleanor Hodge of Camanche. Ms. Hodge said her daughter's tombstone has a black cat engraved on it. Three of the four cats are black. Ms. Stanton, 42, died in November after a long illness. Clementine, Gene, Martha and Smudge stand to gain more than $10,000. Ms. Stanton's total estate is valued at about $19,000, but about a third of that will go to pay debts. Ms. Stanton stipulated that the cats ``be placed in foster care with people who love them,'' and that the cats should ``be given tender loving care and loving companionship at all times.'' The cats are staying at a Clinton veterinary clinic until a judge rules on who should take care of them permanently. Ms. Hodge said she would take the cats if she did not already have four of her own. She is Ms. Stanton's only heir and would be entitled to the estate if all four felines died. She also was named executor of the estate.

DOC.HEAD: Carnival Workers Tie the Hitch on Carousel
DOC.TEXT: A merry-go-round served as their cathedral and carousel horses as pews for Denise and Ricky Appleton's wedding _ just the perfect altered altar for a couple of carnival workers. ``It'd make good pictures,'' the groom said Tuesday after the ceremony at the Ottawa County Fair. Appleton, a 38-year-old accountant and handyman for the W.G. Wade Carnival, tied the knot in the same spot he began dating 28-year-old Denise Rolen, a fellow carnival employee, two years ago. Rolen was escorted by her father to the carousel along a rose petal trail laced with electrical cords from concession stands. Instead of the usual carnival calliope music, ``We've Only Just Begun'' was piped out. Witnesses included carnival workers who surrounded the merry-go-round, between the ``Supa-bounce'' game and a french fry stand, to hear the Rev. Ben Jansen perform the ceremony. ``I encourage creativity. I tell them, `Let's do what you would like to do,''' said Jansen, who has performed weddings at rodeos and hockey rinks. After the rings and vows were exchanged, the two left the carousel under a shower of popcorn. ``We're having chile-cheese dogs at the reception,'' the new Mrs. Appleton said.

DOC.HEAD: Dallas Museum to Exhibit Stolen Medieval Art While Lawyers Negotiate
DOC.TEXT: Art treasures allegedly pilfered by an American soldier at the end of World War II have been given to a Dallas museum while attorneys for his family and an East German church haggle over ownership of the treasure. Attorneys for the church in Quedlinburg and for the heirs of former Army Lt. Joe T. Meador, who allegedly took the centuries-old objects, announced the agreement today at the Dallas Museum of Art. The museum agreed to provide a ``temporary, neutral safe haven,'' said museum director Richard R. Brettell in a statement. However, the pieces will not be displayed publicly until the lawsuit brought by the church is settled. ``Claimants presently contemplate permitting the museum subsequently to display the objects ... with terms for any display to be negotiated later,'' the statement said. The objects to be brought to the museum include articles of gold, silver, ivory and crystal dating from the 8th to 14th centuries, the museum said. The agreement was reached today between law firms representing both sides. The items have been in Whitewright, about 60 miles north of Dallas, and Dallas since 1945, the museum said. The artworks have been stored recently in safety deposit boxes in banks in those cities. The Lutheran church, Stiftskirche-Domgemeinde of Quedlinburg, claims Meador, who lived in Whitewright, stole the trove while his unit was guarding a mine shaft where the items had been hidden. Attorneys for Jack Meador of Whitewright and Jane Meador Cook of Mesquite, brother and sister of the deceased soldier, have been negotiating a proposed move of the treasures to the Dallas museum. The ownership lawsuit is being heard by U.S. District Judge Sidney Fitzwater of Dallas, who is expected to review the agreement. Fitzwater on July 9 ordered the heirs and the church to agree on a facility to store the items until the case is settled. Meador, who died in 1980, bequeathed the artwork to his siblings.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: In Margaret Thatcher's favorite book, the working class rises up to take bloody revenge against the rich. That's just one of the insights gathered by librarian Margaret Berketa in a survey of the rich and famous' reading habits as part of a major project to mark the International Year of Literacy. More than 150 celebrities have replied to her letters requesting details of their favorite books, and the responses are still flowing in. Among them are letters from members of the British royal family who because of protocol politely declined to nominate one book. But Mrs. Thatcher, in the midst of a record-breaking term as Britain's prime minister, praises ``A Tale of Two Cities'' by Charles Dickens, which has one of the most famous opening lines in literature: ``It was the best of times, it was the worst of times.'' Dickens' story is set during the French Revolution, and the hero is beheaded by the guillotine in the tragic finale. Mrs. Thatcher says it was her favorite book as a child. Singer Cliff Richard, known as the Peter Pan of pop, likes the passion of ``Wuthering Heights'' by Emily Bronte. Actor Larry Drake of ``L.A. Law'' likes ``Catch 22'' by Joseph Heller. ``Took me three or four attempts to get past the first chapter,'' Drake wrote. ``Contains the most wrenching scene in literature _ the final revelation of the death of Snowden, the tail gunner.'' Heavy metal guitarist Angus Young of the group AC-DC chose ``A Confederacy Of Dunces'' by John Kennedy Toole and ``Schultz'' by J.P. Donleavy. The most popular books in the survey were ``Wind in The Willows,'' the adventures of Toad, Rat and Mole; and Tom Wolfe's acidic look at New York's social classes, ``The Bonfire of The Vanities.''

Cher's sudden fear of flying is delaying her concert tour. It started when her chartered USAir plane developed engine trouble Wednesday and had to make an emergency landing in New Jersey. The incident shook Cher up and she refused to fly, preferring to travel by train to Boston and then by bus to Halifax, promoter Jack Livingstone said Thursday. Her sold-out concert originally scheduled for Wednesday night in Halifax has been rescheduled for Friday. Thursday's planned show in Moncton, New Brunswick, has been moved to Saturday night, and a Saturday concert at Old Orchard Beach, Maine, has been moved to Sunday. Fans who can't make the rescheduled concerts will get their money back.

Roger Daltrey, lead singer of The Who, accepted a $272,000 settlement Thursday in his lawsuit against a nearby farm that he blamed for the deaths of up to 500,000 fish at his own trout farm. Daltrey and his company, Beju Bop Ltd., had sued owners of The Home Farm where a leak of liquid fertilizer in August 1986 entered a river and caused damage at Daltry's Iwerne Springs Fish Farm in Dorset in southwest England. Daltrey, 45, originally had sought damages of $905,000. The Home Farm had admitted liability, but disputed the amount of damages. Daltrey had told the court that the dead fish included 1,000 valuable brood fish capable of producing millions of eggs a year. During a two-day hearing before the settlement was reached, Daltrey gave detailed testimony showing a surprisingly extensive knowledge of fish farming. He said he had been interested in trout farming since he built his own fishery in 1979.

President Chaim Herzog of Israel underwent knee surgery Thursday after tearing a tendon in a fall in his garden, a spokeswoman president said. The operation involved stitching the tendon, said spokeswoman Penina Kirshenbaum. ``The president had a successful operation this morning and will be released from the hospital in a few days,'' she said. Herzog, 72, has served for seven years as president, a position that's largely ceremonial.

DOC.HEAD: Juror Removed From Money Laundering Case; Reportedly Called Drug Cartel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with juror dismissed but no information made public. Picks up 5th graf, `Five employees.' DELETES now redundant 11th graf, `Deliberations can...'.
DOC.TEXT: A juror today was removed from deliberations for a huge money-laundering trial after reports that a member of the jury apparently telephoned members of a Colombian drug ring for more information. U.S. District Judge William Terrell Hodges held a closed hearing today on whether to declare a mistrial. Few details were available because of a gag order in effect for lawyers and their clients for the duration of the trial. But court clerk John Gay said the original panel of 12 is down to eleven. Alternate jurors were dismissed after testimony ended, and deliberations can continue with eleven jurors when both sides agree. There was no immediate indication if any action was taken against the dismissed juror. Gay said transcripts of today's hearing and two meetings Wednesday will be made public when they are transcribed, but that could take several days. Attorneys learned Wednesday that one of the 12 jurors undertook some independent investigation, including making telephone calls to purported Medellin drug cartel members in Colombia, and then shared information with another juror, according to a report in today's Tampa Tribune. Five employees of the Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International and a Colombian airplane broker are accused of conspiring with an undercover U.S. Customs Service agent to launder $14 million in proceeds from the sale of cocaine in six U.S. cities. The first public indication of trouble in the six-month trial surfaced Wednesday morning when jurors were sent home shortly after reporting to begin their fourth day of deliberations. The judge met privately with prosecutors and defense attorneys twice Wednesday to discuss the situation. The lawyers and court personnel refused to discuss the problem or divulge what occurred during the private meetings. The newspaper reported that the juror who telephoned cartel members got the phone numbers from an address book that was introduced into evidence at the trial. Authorities took the book from the briefcase of one of the defendants, Colombian Rudolf Armbrecht, when he was arrested in a Miami motel in October 1988. U.S. Attorney Robert W. Genzman and Larry Curtin, spokesman for the Tampa FBI office, had no comment. Jurors were specifically instructed by Hodges to decide the case only on evidence and testimony presented during the trial and were told to avoid and ignore any outside information. They have not been sequestered and have been allowed to return home throughout the trial. The defendants in the case are Ian Howard and Sibte Hassan of BCCI's Paris branch; Amjad Awan and Akbar A. Bilgrami of BCCI's Miami branch; Syed Aftab Hussain, who worked in Panama; and the Colombian aircraft broker, Armbrecht. The bankers were arrested Oct. 6, 1988, at a fake wedding staged by the Customs Service to lure the bankers to Tampa. They were taken into custody after being separated from their families under the pretext of attending a bachelor's party. Two BCCI subsidiaries pleaded guilty in January to the money-laundering charges and forfeited $15 million to the government, more than triple the previous largest penalty ever assessed against a bank.

DOC.HEAD: Rabbit Drowns; Owner Laughs if Off
DOC.TEXT: Madeline and Woody Hovatter's rabbit died in their pool, and Mrs. Hovatter could only laugh. The Phoenix couple's Volkswagen Rabbit was blown into the pool during a Saturday night storm. ``The wind just picked it up and threw it in there, I guess,'' Mrs. Hovatter said. ``It's a Rabbit. She tried to jump the pool, but she couldn't jump far enough. ``I laughed. What can you do? If crying would have brought it back up, I would have cried my eyes out. But I knew that wouldn't work, so I laughed.'' A crane pulled the car from the pool on Tuesday, but not before Mrs. Hovatter took a swim with it. ``I stood on the roof and pretended I was surfing,'' she said. ``It's finally out. I hope it doesn't get blown somewhere else now.'' Mrs. Hovatter said the car, which was a total loss, wasn't covered by the couple's insurance because they carry only liability on it. But she said they have another car.

DOC.HEAD: Tropical Storm Arthur Gaining on Puerto Rico and Hispaniola
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with storm weakening, Puerto Rico dropped from warning. Picks up 7th graf, `Storm warnings...'.
DOC.TEXT: Tropical storm Arthur weakened today as it moved slowly through the Caribbean Sea, its winds dropping from near-hurricane strength of 70 mph to 50 mph, the National Hurricane Center said. A tropical storm watch remained for the southern coasts of Haiti and the Dominican Republic, but the storm was on a track that made it less of a threat to Hispaniola, the island shared by the two countries, forecasters said. At noon EDT, Arthur's top sustained winds of 50 mph _ well below the 74 mph minimum-hurricane strength _ were centered near latitude 15.3 north and longitude 69.0 west, or about 230 miles south-southeast of Santo Domingo, Dominican Republic. It was moving west-northwest at 20 and was expected to continue that motion through the day, said Hal Gerrish, a hurricane specialist at the center in suburban Coral Gables. ``Some further decrease in strength is likely during the next 24 hours,'' he said. Storm warnings for Trinidad, Tobago, Grenada and Grenada dependencies were discontinued Wednesday after the storm passed through from the Atlantic. Grenada reported winds gusting to 55 mph early Wednesday when the center of Arthur passed over the island, and heavy rains were reported on Tobago and other islands in the area, said Bob Sheets, director of the hurricane center. Arthur, the 1990 Atlantic hurricane season's first named storm, grew from a depression, the second of the 1990 season, that formed Sunday in the open Atlantic. The hurricane season runs from June 1 to Nov. 30.

DOC.HEAD: GE Agrees To Fine In Defense Fraud Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge fined General Electric Co. $10 million today for overcharging the government about $8 million for an Army battlefied computer system. U.S. District Judge Lowell Reed Jr. called the fine ``adequate, fair, and in the best interest of the public.'' Federal prosecutors said GE, convicted in February on 286 criminal counts, agreed to pay $10 million for those charges. Under the deal, GE waived its right to appeal. Reed also sentenced Gerald A. Leo, 52, a former employee of Management & Technical Services Co., a GE subsidiary, to 10 months in prison and fined him $15,000. Leo was convicted on four counts of mail fraud and one count of trying to deceive federal investigators in the case. ``He never did anything,'' his wife, Mary, yelled as Reed handed down the sentence today. Leo will remain free while his case is appealed. James Badolato, another former employee of the same subsidiary, faced sentencing later today. Badolato, 43, was convicted of misleading auditors and submitting false documents. Assistant U.S. Attorney Nicholas Harbist said the fine was the second largest criminal fine imposed in any defense contracting case. The largest, he said, was $17 million against Northrop in a case involving defective parts for a cruise missile. Prosecutors said the company also agreed to pay $8.3 million to settle related civil suits and $11.7 million to settle unrelated civil suits. GE, the nation's second-largest defense contractor, was convicted in February of four counts of mail fraud and 282 counts of making false claims. The government charged that the GE subsidiary did not tell the government in 1983 that it had shaved its costs by hiring substantially less-expensive subcontractors to help build the battlefield computer system. The defense contract was worth $250 million.

Six Sets of Remains Shipped Back to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Six sets of remains that may be those of missing American servicemen were flown to the United States on Thursday after a U.S. honor guard saluted and Buddhist monks prayed to console the dead. It was the first time since the Vietnam War ended in April 1975 that Communist authorities in Cambodia have delivered suspected remains of those missing in action, or MIA. ``The United States appreciates the support of the Phnom Penh authorities for this undertaking,'' said Lt. Col. Thomas Boyd, a U.S. spokesman. ``We consider this an important humanitarian undertaking which, if successful, will help to alleviate the suffering of American families.'' Cambodia is ready to cooperate with future American MIA missions, the official news agency SPK on Thursday quoted the deputy interior minister, Khim Ponn, as saying. He heads an MIA commission formed last month to cooperate with local officials in the MIA search. U.S. officials had accused the Vietnamese-backed government, which the United States does not recognize, of using the issue to exact political concessions. An appeal this year by Sen. Charles Robb, D-Va., broke the deadlock. Also, Washington announced a week ago that it was withdrawing recognition of the Khmer Rouge-dominated guerrilla coalition that is fighting Phnom Penh, and would open talks with Vietnam on ending the Cambodian civil war. Sources in Washington said Secretary of State James A. Baker III favors opening talks with Phnom Penh as the next step. The 14-member military team flew to Phnom Penh for the airport repatriation ceremony. Buddhist monks in saffron robes chanted prayers in Pali during a 15-minute memorial service before an altar covered with flowers and burning incense. The six caskets sat behind the altar, and a monk sprinkled holy water to bless the dead and speed their rebirth. The American military honor guard escorted six aluminum caskets, each draped with a U.S. flag, on board an Air Force C-141 that took off for Hawaii. In Hawaii, the remains will be analyzed and identified by the Joint Casualty Resolution Center and the Army Central Identification Laboratory, agencies that account for America's wartime missing. A total of 2,300 Americans are listed as missing in action in Indochina. Aside from the 83 in Cambodia, 1,678 are missing in Vietnam, 533 in Laos and six in China's coastal waters. At least eight American civilians are also listed as missing in Cambodia, according to U.S. officials. The six remains were among 28 sets that Cambodian authorities said they have recovered in recent years. A Foreign Ministry spokesman said his government paid $2,000 for the return of some remains from remote provinces. Six U.S. military specialists examined them in a tiny laboratory at Cambodia's only medical college on Tuesday and Wednesday, and decided that six warranted further tests. The team was the first known official U.S. contact with the Phnom Penh government. Two of the six remains that were repatriated were found in eastern provinces bordering Vietnam. U.S. planes heavily bombed the area during the war in failed attempts to interdict the Ho Chi Minh Trail, Communist North Vietnam's main supply route to U.S.-backed South Vietnam. U.S. officials said most of the American servicemen missing in Cambodia were airmen. The other four sets were from Choeung Ek, a southwest suburb of Phnom Penh that the Khmer Rouge used as a mass execution ground when they ruled from 1975 to 1978. The Khmer Rouge were ousted after Vietnam invaded Cambodia in late 1978. Boyd said Washington would consider sending another such team to examine more remains, but added that this was not discussed during his group's visit to Phnom Penh.

DOC.HEAD: States Far From Mexico Preparing for Africanized Bees
DOC.TEXT: The ``killer'' bees poised to invade the United States from Mexico are beginning to worry officials in states as far away as Maine and Hawaii. State agriculture inspectors from 32 states turned out for a four-day Africanized bee conference, which opened Wednesday in Weslaco, about 10 miles from the Mexican border. Some said they expect their states eventually to be infested, either by the bees migrating naturally, or being transported as stowaways on ships or truck trailers. ``With modern transportation, it's conceivable that a swarm could stow away on a ship and establish itself in Hawaii,'' said Kenneth Teramoto, chief of biological control of plant pests with the state of Hawaii's Department of Agriculture. ``We'll find out what Texas and some of the other states are going to do about the Africanized honey bee and we'll set up a state plan,'' Robert Mitchell, state apiarist for the Delaware Department of Agriculture, said he came to Weslaco to learn more about the Texas Africanized honey bee management plan. He said his state is preparing for the eventual arrival of the aggressive bees either by ship or truck. Other states represented at the conference included those as distant as Washington and Vermont. ``They're all concerned that they need to be speaking with a coordinated voice and a coordinated approach to dealing with the spread of the Africanized bee in the United States,'' said Anita Collins, head researcher with the U.S. Department of Agriculture's Honey Bee Research Lab at Weslaco. ``The main concern is we don't want to harm the beekeeping industries in those states, because they are our first line of defense in fighting the Africanized bees,'' she said. Twenty-two swarms of Africanized bees have been found and destroyed since 1979 at U.S. ports aboard ships from Latin America. The most recent swarm was found at the Port of Houston earlier this month in the hold of a ship from Mexico. The hard-to-manage bees eventually are expected to cost U.S. beekeepers as much as $58 million per year, according to the USDA. Expected drops in bee-pollinated crop production could cost U.S. farmers as much as $40 million per year. Most attending the symposium co-sponsored by the National Association of State Departments of Agriculture and Texas A&M University are involved in regulating honey bees in their states. The Texas Africanized bee management plan includes the establishment of a 100-mile quarantine zone at the southern tip of the state, and the sampling of all bee colonies within two miles of a confirmed Africanized find. Any Africanized bees will be destroyed. But the state has not provided the estimated $800,000 needed to fund the plan in its first year, said John Thomas, a Texas A&M extension entomologist. He said the bees have been wrongly branded as killers, although about 600 deaths have been attributed to them, mostly in South America. Their sting is no worse than that of regular bees, but they tend to attack by the hundreds if they sense a threat to the colony. ``People are going to have to be much more alert,'' Thomas said. ``It's like if we had only garden snakes in the Rio Grande Valley, and then we introduced rattlesnakes.'' Beekeepers are also worried about the Africanized bees because they are harder to control and less productive than domestic honey bees. Africanized bees are the hybrid offspring of a swarm of African bees that escaped from a research project in Brazil in 1957. They have expanded their range through Latin America since then. Scientists previously had expected them to cross into southern Texas by now. But none has been found closer to the border since November, possibly because a harsh winter and prolonged drought reduced the food supply needed for migration.

DOC.HEAD: Reporter Sarah McClendon Feted By Texans
DOC.TEXT: Turning 80 isn't bad at all, especially when Texans are wishing you well, reporter Sarah McClendon said Thursday at a birthday bash given by the Texas State Society and Texas Breakfast Club. ``Don't let anybody worry you about being 80. It's great,'' Ms. McClendon told 350 Texans gathered for breakfast in a House office building. Ms. McClendon, a Tyler, Texas native, was the first woman admitted to the National Press Club. She has reported from Washington for nearly 50 years and become well known for asking tough questions at presidential news conferences. President Bush sent a congratulatory letter and so did former House Speaker Jim Wright. Seven current Texas congressmen paid tribute, including Rep. Jack Brooks, who worked with her as a reporter at the Beaumont Enterprise in 1939. ``Being a Texan means you use your individuality and have enough guts and courage to stand out and be a good citizen,'' she said. ``I'm not quitting because I have a lot of questions I want to ask George Bush.'' Ms. McClendon, who has covered every president since Franklin Roosevelt, said her favorite was fellow Texan Lyndon Johnson even though he once prodded four newspapers to cancel her service. When she was finished speaking, the Texas congressmen stood up and started barking her name as reporters do to get the president's attention at news conferences.

DOC.HEAD: Communist Chief Feels Sting of Voters' Questions in Mongolia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Mongolians frequently use only one name.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Communist Party chairman defended himself and his party Thursday before irate voters who demanded to know the truth behind purges and cover-ups over seven decades of authoritarian rule. ``I didn't repress anybody,'' the white-haired, dignified Gombojavyn Ochirbat told about 200 people from Ulan Bator's 12th election district, where he is running for a seat in the national legislature. The contest has become the most dramatic one in the first multiparty elections ever held in this long-isolated, Soviet-bloc nation. It pits the 61-year-old Ochirbat, a long-time party official who stresses moderation, against a 29-year-old lawyer with no political experience who favors bold moves toward democracy and economic privatization.
