On Sunday, the district's approximately 5,000 voters will decide whether Ochirbat, arguably the most powerful man in Mongolia by virtue of his party post, should also sit in the 430-seat legislature, the Great People's Hural. ``The Communist Party in Mongolia is already going down, not just the organization but the theory of communism,'' said Ochirbat's opponent, Ganbold of the recently formed Party of National Progress. ``I decided it would be appropriate not to allow the head of the Communist Party to be a deputy.'' Ochirbat became party chief in March when street protests inspired by Eastern Europe's anti-Communist revolution forced Mongolia's top Communists to resign. He has overseen the country's first tentative steps toward democracy, but insists it should remain socialist. On Thursday, he shared a podium with Ganbold as District 12 held a free-wheeling meet-the-candidates night that would have been unheard of not long ago. Residents of the impoverished shanty district on Ulan Bator's western fringe eagerly called out questions about past purges, a recent scandal involving a public prosecutor, rumored price increases and restrictions on emigration. ``In the past (the Communist Party) made many mistakes,'' Ochirbat said, speaking calmly but firmly. ``But we shouldn't just accuse the party of mistakes. It also has done good things. ``My father also was repressed,'' he added. ``In 1932 he was arrested with a couple of friends. I know history quite well. But we should understand the situation of that time.'' Ganbold's Party of National Progress has said it is running in part against Ochirbat's record as a ranking official of the past Stalinist regime. He was in charge of party ideology during the 1960s, when a group of intellectuals were purged. But Ochirbat said he was not involved. Speaking about another 1960s purge of two party officials accused of being pro-Chinese, he said: ``Everybody believed they were enemies of the people. I was young then, I believed it, too. But now, according to the archival materials, we can certainly say ... this was a fabricated case.'' Afterward, local residents said the contest would be close. ``It's very democratic,'' said Dorj, rolling a cigarette outside the tiny meeting hall. ``I think I'll vote for the Communists _ but I also support the democrats because they put forward the most interesting proposals.'' Most of the opposition parties have joined in what is called a ``democratic coalition'' to back key candidates such as Ganbold. In Sunday's primary, Ochirbat led with more than 2,500 votes to Ganbold's more than 1,300, according to partial official figures. But opposition candidates altogether won nearly as much as Ochirbat _ showing that he is not invincible. With just the two competing in the second round, Ganbold's party believes he has a chance. ``Most young people support Ganbold,'' said a local backer, Turtoghokh. Ganbold began campaigning door-to-door Wednesday _ a bit late, he admitted. But in an interview Wednesday night, he said he was warmly received. ``One of my fears that older people would be against me disappeared today, as I met a lot of older people who said they were willing to back me,'' he said. Ganbold, a junior-level officer in the Ministry of Law and Jurisdiction, said he knew hard times as a child as his mother struggled to raise five children by herself. He said he can relate to the problems of District 12's residents. ``The district has no kindergarten, no schools,'' Ganbold said. ``To go shopping they have to go two bus stops. Even the electricity stops sometimes. There is no telephone.'' The lesson, he said, is that communism doesn't work. ``Communism is a foreign idea to Mongolia. That is why a lot of Communist Party members do not back it ideologically, they just belong.'' But while meeting the voters, he soft-pedaled his ideological attacks and kept his promises moderate. ``If elected I will try to solve at least one of the smallest things I've promised,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.HEAD: Census Survey Finds Many Elderly Need Assistance With Daily Activity
DOC.TEXT: More than 8 million Americans, more than half of them elderly, need help with at least one daily activity because of a health problem, according to a Census Bureau report released Thursday. About 16 percent of the population that is 65 and older needed help with household chores, meal preparation or personal hygiene, according to the 1986 Census survey, which is the latest data available. These senior citizens make up about 54 percent of the total number of Americans 15 and older who need assistance to perform at least one everyday activity. The rest are under age 65. About 5.6 million of those needing assistance lived with a family, while 2.3 million lived alone and 300,000 lived with non-relatives, according to the survey. The survey also found that 5.8 million people over age 15 were providing care to a household member, and about a quarter of these caregivers were 65 or older. More than 15 million people were helping people outside their household.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Apparently Gets AIDS From Infected Dentist, CDC Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: For release 6 p.m. EDT; time set by source
DOC.TEXT: In the first case of its kind, federal researchers reported Thursday that a woman apparently got AIDS from her dentist during a tooth pulling, even though he was wearing gloves and a mask. The case has prompted the government to review its guidelines for AIDS prevention during medical procedures even though ``the possibility of another source of infection cannot be entirely excluded,'' the federal Centers for Disease Control said. It said all evidence was ``consistent with'' the patient being infected during her trip to the dentist. The dentist, who had been diagnosed three months earlier, was wearing protective gloves and a mask, as recommended, while extracting two molars for the patient, who was visiting him for the first time. ``We don't know exactly what happened during that procedure,'' said Dr. Harold Jaffe, deputy director for science in the CDC's HIV-AIDS program. ``We have to assume there was some kind of an accident that exposed the patient to the dentist's blood.'' But there was no indication of that. The patient didn't remember the dentist having any cuts, the dentist didn't recall any accidents _ such as sticking himself with the anesthetic needle _ and dental records indicated the procedure ``should have been uncomplicated,'' the CDC said. Officials of the American Dental Association said the CDC may have jumped to conclusions. ``We're not happy about it,'' said Dr. Enid Neidle, director of scientific affairs for the Chicago-based ADA. ``We think it is not a totally conclusive case of transmission. ... We are not happy at any report that could raise fears on the part of the public that the dental office is a place of danger and infection.'' CDC officials stressed that there is no reason to believe the virus was transmitted just because a dentist with AIDS came close to a patient. ``We are not suggesting some unique, previously undescribed kind of transmission,'' Jaffe said. ``And we're certainly not suggesting to people they should be afraid to go to their doctors and dentists.'' The case has prompted the government to review its recommendations for AIDS prevention in medical settings. ``We will be looking at the guidelines to see if they need to be modified to decrease the chance this might happen again,'' Jaffe said. AIDS activists worried that the report would spawn new fears about the disease. ``I think that's inevitable,'' said Paul Sathrum, program director for the National Association of People With AIDS. ``The hysteria is always out there. ... Any little thing like this always brings it back to the surface. ``This may be the type of situation that would provide ammunition for the forces who would love to see more restrictions on people with HIV. I hope that doesn't happen.'' Two years after the woman's trip to the dentist, she was diagnosed with a rare pneumonia that strikes some AIDS patients. She then tested positive for the AIDS virus. A lengthy investigation found no risk factors for AIDS in the woman's past, such as intravenous drug abuse or numerous sex partners. She said she had two boyfriends before her diagnosis; both tested negative for the virus. The CDC, as is its custom, did not identify the dentist or patient, except to describe the patient as a young woman. DNA ``virus sequence'' tests performed on the dentist and the patient led investigators to believe their specific viruses were ``closely related,'' with ``a high degree of similarity between the strains,'' the CDC said. Still, Neidle said, the ADA believes too little is known about the details of the tooth extraction and what might have caused the infection, including whether the patient was subsequently treated and whether some complications might have arisen in the placement or removal of stitches. Jaffe said there was no indication that the dentist failed to follow any guidelines for preventing AIDS transmission. ``The only question,'' he said, ``would be whether or not the dentist should have continued in practice'' after being diagnosed with AIDS. The ``most obvious'' guide for that, he said, ``is whether the person is physically or mentally able to do his or her job.''

DOC.HEAD: NBC's ``Today'' Gets Lowest Ratings in Nearly Seven Years
DOC.TEXT: Despite a revamped format and the return of Joe Garagiola as co-host, NBC's ``Today'' show last week suffered its lowest ratings in nearly seven years, according to Nielsen audience estimates Thursday. While ABC's ``Good Morning America'' won its 29th consecutive ratings victory with a 4.2 average, ``Today'' was well behind with a 2.9, its lowest average since the week of Aug. 6, 1983, when it had a 2.8 average. ``CBS This Morning'' show remained a distant third with a 2.2 average. All three shows declined by a tenth of a point from the previous week. ``Today'' is attempting to recover from a ratings slide that began in January after 13-year veteran Jane Pauley left the show. She was its co-host when it hit its previous ratings low in 1983. As part of its comeback bid, ``Today'' added the popular Garagiola as a third co-host in June, has moved to a larger studio at NBC headquarters, and plans another change in September, a new set. Comparisons for ratings for last week and the same week in 1989 show that ``Good Morning America'' increased its audience by a big margin, 420,000 homes, while ``Today'' audience was down by 754,000 homes. The ratings for ``CBS This Morning'' were unchanged, but the show was seen in 37,400 more homes than in the same week last year. A ratings point currently represents 921,000 homes, compared with 904,000 homes last year.

DOC.HEAD: Armored Truck Spills Quarters
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of quarters spilled through an unlatched door after an armored truck hit a bump while rumbling across the Ross Island Bridge. ``Quarters were flyin' everywhere,'' said Allen Schmuck, who, with his friend, Tod Larsen, was traveling across the bridge Wednesday when three bags fell out of the truck. Traffic was stopped for about 20 minutes on the bridge, one of several spanning the Willamette River in Portland. The truck from Oregon Armored Service Inc. stopped right away and police arrived within five minutes. ``There must have been $2,000 to $3,000 worth of quarters spread all over for about 30 yards,'' said Terry Barker, a Portland traffic officer. A shovel and broom were used to gather the coins. Company officials declined to say how many quarters were involved, but police said no money was stolen.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo: Tax the Rich to Balance the Budget
With AM-Budget Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration could balance the federal budget if it raised the taxes of Americans with incomes of more than $200,000, New York Gov. Mario Cuomo said Thursday. ``If you want to find wealth, don't come to us and take it out of the pockets of children,'' Cuomo said. ``Don't come to us and take it out of the pockets of the people who are trying to run the drug programs.'' Cuomo made his comments at a news conference with state and local officials concerned that federal budget negotiators are considering eliminating state and local taxes as a deduction. That, the state and local officials said, would constitute double taxation and an infringement on states' rights. Earlier Thursday, Sen. Robert Packwood said a $10,000 cap on state and local tax deductibility would unduly hurt the rich. Packwood, the ranking Republican on the Senate Finance Committee, said 97.4 percent of the losers under such a plan would be people with incomes over $100,000 and 86 percent of the losers would be people with incomes over $200,000. ``If that isn't a tax on the wealthy, I don't know what is,'' Packwood said. However, Cuomo advocated raising federal taxes for the wealthiest Americans. ``It hurts nobody, it's fair to everybody and it avoids this kind of calamity,'' said Cuomo, who has been mentioned as a possible contender for the 1992 Democratic presidential nomination. Administration and congressional negotiators have been meeting for 11 weeks to try to agree on a budget package. On Wednesday, most GOP leaders involved in the talks backed a new White House proposal. The new administration proposal would raise about $3 billion by limiting the deductibility of state and local income taxes on federal tax returns, a GOP bargainer said Thursday. Such deductions would be limited to no more than $10,000, said the negotiator, who asked not to be identified. Gerald McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, said the Reagan administration also tried to raise revenues in 1985 by ending deductibility. ``And again, the attack is a thinly veiled attempt to preserve the incredible shift of tax burden from the wealthy to the middle class,'' he said. ``It's a shell game _ a way to pass off the federal deficit onto the budgets of states and localities.'' William J. Althaus, the Republican mayor of York, Pa., said: ``It's stupid, it's unfair and it suffers from what I can only call incomplete candor on the part of the government.'' Democratic Mayor David N. Dinkins said he recently balanced New York City's budget by raising local taxes. ``One of the reasons we did so is because of the deductibility of those taxes,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Adds $20 Million to Farm Bill to Stop Zebra Mussel Spread
DOC.TEXT: The Senate has approved a $20 million research and prevention program to keep zebra mussels from invading farm irrigation systems. The striped mollusk, which is not native to North America, has caused problems at water and power plants throughout the Great Lakes. They attach to water intake pipes and clog them. An amendment authorizing the $20 million over five years was added to the 1990 farm bill by Sen. Daniel P. Moynihan, D-N.Y. ``Unlike other infestations, this one is irreversible,'' Moynihan said in a statement Thursday. ``The zebra mussel is here to stay ... Within 20 years' time it will have spread through the entire surface water system of North America.'' The amendment, which the Senate passed late Wednesday, directs the Department of Agriculture and the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to develop a program of research, prevention and design criteria for irrigation systems with an emphasis on keeping the mussels out. On Wednesday, scientists expressed surprise that the tiny mollusks are spreading through the Erie Canal system from Buffalo, N.Y., and now threaten Rochester, N.Y. and the Finger Lakes region. ``Frankly, I did not think their advance would be this fast,'' said Cameron Lange, a biologist studying the mussels' movement for a consortium of power companies. ``I thought we might find a few at Lockport during our late July sample but I did not think they'd reach Rochester by now.'' Rochester is about 60 miles east of Lockport, N.Y. In May, the Senate Committee on Environment and Public Works authorized $37.5 million in grants and research funding for control of the mussel. The provision is part of the pending Water Resources Development Act of 1990.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Riders May Get Free Ride if Bus Late
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to CORRECT to `ridership'
DOC.TEXT: Late buses would mean free rides, under a plan being considered by the Southern California Rapid Transit District board to lure passengers. ``We're going to put our money where our mouth is,'' board President Nick Patsaouras said Wednesday. ``I am positive our ridership will increase ... and if it (costs) a million or two, so be it. We're making a long-term investment.'' If the board approves the four-month pilot program, a free ride would be given to passengers whose bus is more than 15 minutes late beginning Sept. 1. If riders have monthly passes, credit would be given toward the purchase of the next month's pass. Ridership has fallen from 1.8 million passengers a day to 1.3 million per day during the past five years, Patsaouras said. The Rapid Transit District, which operates in Los Angeles, Orange and Riverside counties, will evaluate the on-time performances of the buses at year's end.

DOC.HEAD: EPA, Lawmakers Criticize Eased Rules on Low-Level Radioactive Wastes
DOC.TEXT: The easing of federal controls on low-level atomic wastes poses public health concerns, the Environmental Protection Agency said Thursday, while lawmakers said the new policy could make some states into dumping grounds for radioactive garbage. The decision last month by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission to deregulate some low-level atomic wastes from laboratories, hospitals and nuclear plants came under attack at a hearing by the House Interior energy and environment subcommittee. Rep. George Miller, D-Calif., the subcommittee chairman, accused the NRC of ``coziness'' with the nuclear industry and said if the commission does not reverse its policy Congress should protect states from being forced to accept such wastes in landfills. At least two states _ including Pennsylvania and Maine _ already have enacted laws specifically prohibiting radioactive wastes in conventional landfills. The NRC, however, has maintained that federal policy overrides state and local statutes. Under the policy announced June 27, low-level wastes including gloves, clothing, lab equipment, dirt and even buildings and equipment at nuclear power plants can be disposed of as if they were normal garbage _ if radiation doses are below a certain level. NRC Chairman Kenneth Carr told the subcommittee that the issue is one of ``how safe is safe enough'' and promised that ``the public and the environment will remain properly protected.'' But Miller said the easing of federal requirements on such wastes ``has the potential to endanger the public health'' and is ``an open invitation to abuse by unscrupulous operators'' who want to dispose of radioactive materials. Some states that already are targets of out-of-state garbage shipments fear they ``will become the dumping ground'' for radioactive wastes, said Rep. Joe Rahall, D-W.Va. He added if that becomes the case ``I fear there will be an all-out rebellion in West Virginia.'' Miller's subcommittee released internal documents showing that both the EPA and some NRC staff advisers have strongly opposed the NRC policy because they believe it covers too broad a range of low-level wastes. The exemption from federal regulation would apply to wastes that subject individuals to radiation doses of less than 10 millirems a year _ half the level of a normal chest X-ray. ``We believe that is too high a level (of exposure) for a blanket deregulation criteria and is not protective of the public health,'' the EPA's Office of Radiation Programs concluded in a briefing paper made public by the subcommittee. The EPA estimated that the 10-millirem threshold for regulatory action could result in as many as three additional cancer deaths for every 10,000 people exposed. Richard Guimond, director of the Office of Radiation Programs, testified that one concern is the possible cumulative effect of the disposal of such wastes. A single landfill, for example, may contain numerous categories of wastes, each of which would be exempt because they individually meet the NRC cutoff for regulation. The EPA and some NRC staff members had urged that the cutoff be much lower. Guimond noted that the International Atomic Energy Agency considered an individual dose of 1 millirem per year as a reasonable cutoff. Carr, the NRC chairman, said the agency would consider petitions for exemptions on a case-by-case basis. But he said a relaxation of controls on low-level wastes is needed to help return about 40 nuclear sites under NRC jurisdiction to general use. The Energy Department also has sought a clearer policy from the NRC on low-level wastes to help its cleanup of weapons plants. ``No human endeavor involves a zero level of risk,'' said Carr. ``The levels of radiation exposure we are talking about here, while not zero, are exceedingly small.''

DOC.HEAD: Council on Aging Worker Fired for Tipping Press to Feature Story
DOC.TEXT: A food server who urged a newspaper to profile a 115-year-old man was fired from her job at the Council on Aging because she was not authorized to contact the media, officials said. Betty Scanlan, 60, earned $3.80 an hour serving lunch to about 10 senior citizens. She also set aside lunches for sailors who delivered food to elderly patrons of the council's Meals on Wheels program. Scanlan called the Pensacola News Journal after a sailor said he delivered meals to a man who claimed to be 115. A reporter said she'd investigate the claim and also wanted to write about Navy volunteers from Corry Station Technical Training Center. ``I thought it would be great for the sailors to get a little recognition ... I didn't think it'd be such a disaster,'' Scanlan said Wednesday. On July 18, Scanlan accompanied the reporter to a church where sailors were picking up meals. Later that day, Scanlan was fired because personnel policy stipulates that only the council's chairman, executive director and project directors ``may officially represent the agency in making public announcements, speeches and comments about agency business,'' council officials said. The newspaper has yet to run the stories.

DOC.HEAD: House Reprimands Frank
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs with editing.
DOC.TEXT: The House today reprimanded a repentant Rep. Barney Frank for his official actions on behalf of a male prostitute. Lawmakers first rejected more severe punishments proposed by Republicans. ``I'm here to offer an apology and an explanation,'' the Massachusetts Democrat told a hushed audience shortly before the 408-18 vote for reprimand. He said he took some of the actions cited by the ethics committee ``to conceal my homosexuality.'' ``I should have known better. I do now, but it's a little too late,'' said a subdued Frank, who acknowledged his homosexuality publicly in 1987, a year after the events that led to the House probe. The vote against expulsion, proposed by Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., was 390-38. The vote against censure, proposed by GOP Whip Newt Gingrich, was 287-141. Censure would have stripped Frank of his Judiciary subcommittee chairmanship. The reprimand, which was recommended by the House ethics committee, carries no penalty other than the vote by Frank's colleagues. ``This should not be perceived as a referendum on purely private conduct or lifestyle,'' said Rep. Julian Dixon, D-Calif., chairman of the House ethics committee. ``The recommendation before the House today I think is consistent with prior precedents.'' Dannemeyer said Frank had knowingly permitted his apartment to be used as a house of prostitution _ charges that the Massachusetts Democrat has denied and that the House ethics committee found groundless. ``Are there standards in our society that we will affirm for ourselves and our children? That's the issue,'' Dannemeyer said. Frank has admitted he fixed parking tickets and wrote a misleading memo for Stephen Gobie, whom the lawmaker first paid for sex and later hired as a personal assistant using his own money. It was the second time in two days that Congress had acted to discipline one of its own. On Wednesday, the Senate voted 96-0 to denounce Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., for financial improprieties, and ordered him to repay up to $123,000. Like Durenberger, Frank is popular with his fellow lawmakers. The Democratic leadership expressed confidence in advance the House would do no more than issue an official reprimand. Some Republicans decided to make Frank's behavior an election-year issue, though. Frank ``is not who is on trial today,'' said Dannemeyer. ``It is the House of Representatives who is on trial today.'' The question, Dannemeyer said, is ``do we tolerate, do we condone a member of this body who knowingly permits a house of prostitution to be operated out of his residence?'' Dixon called Dannemeyer's statements ``selective garbage.'' ``The committee's responsibility was to sort out fact from fiction and 12 men in this House _ six Republicans and six Democrats _ have tried to do that in this report,'' Dixon said during floor debate with Frank looking on fromthe Democratic side of the aisle. Dannemeyer ``insults the intelligence and the literacy of the members of this House who have read this report.'' House Speaker Thomas Foley, members of the ethics committee, many fellow Democrats, and a homosexual rights group support Frank's position that a reprimand is appropriate. Rep. John Myers of Indiana, the ranking Republican on the ethics committee, said he supported the reprimand recommendation and hoped the debate would not be partisan. ``This is a discipline matter,'' Myers said. ``It isn't a party position. It isn't something that should be decided on a partisan basis. It's entirely too important for that.'' The 12-member ethics committee, split evenly between Democrats and Republicans, dismissed charges that Frank was aware Gobie was operating a prostitution ring out of Frank's Capitol Hill apartment in 1987. Frank has said he immediately kicked Gobie out of his apartment when he learned about the illicit business. Instead, the committee cited Frank for sending a misleading memo to a Virginia prosecutor who was overseeing Gobie's probation on a sex and drug felony conviction. The panel said the 1986 memo could be interpreted as an attempt to persuade authorities to be lenient toward Gobie. The committee also said Frank improperly used his congressional authority to avoid paying 33 parking tickets, some of them run up by Gobie while on personal business. Among those lobbying on Frank's behalf was the Human Rights Campaign Fund, the nation's largest gay and lesbian organization. ``We're concerned that Congressman Frank is being held to a higher standard than any member of Congress has been held to,'' said Gregory King, a spokesman for the group.

DOC.HEAD: Commons Breaks Up For Summer After Tough Session For Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: The House of Commons began a 10-week recess on Thursday after a turbulent session marked by Cabinet upheavals, disputes over Europe and a slump in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's fortunes. Her ratings are better than they were in the early spring when she trailed the opposition Labor Party by 23 percentage points in the polls. But her Conservative Party remains an average of 12 percentage points behind Labor. Inflation, widely seen as the key to Mrs. Thatcher's hopes of winning an unprecedented fourth successive term, is running at nearly 10 percent, despite two years of steep increases in interest rates to curb it. Conservative Party popularity has tended to decline as interest rates rise. But what lay behind two dramatic resignations from her 22-member Cabinet in the past nine months was not unpopularity with the electorate but differences within the party over the quickening pace toward closer political and monetary union of the European Community. With the departure of two other longtime Cabinet ministers for what they describe as family reasons, Mrs. Thatcher has had to reshuffle the government ranks half a dozen times since the parliamentary session opened in the fall. Conservative Party Chairman Kenneth Baker, musing Thursday over the chances of Mrs. Thatcher winning again, said: ``We've a long way to go.'' Since winning power in 1979, the prime minister has led the party to two subsequent general election victories. ``We've come through much more difficult phases than this,'' Baker added in a radio interview. ``We were massively unpopular in 1981 and we won the '83 election. We were massively unpopular in '86 and won the '87 election. We're not as unpopular now. ... We're in very good shape to win this (next) election.'' Mrs. Thatcher must call the next election by mid-1992, but 1991 is more likely if inflation is falling. There is some good news for the 64-year-old British leader. There are signs that an unpopular new local government tax, the so-called poll tax, which provoked riots this spring, is becoming less of an issue. And the government also is pumping money into the problem with a $5.4 billion special grant announced this month designed to head off another rise next year. The tax, averaging $690 annually for each adult, has already pushed average household bills up by one-third, and its introduction this spring helped send the Thatcher ratings plunging. The Cabinet upheavals began in the fall. Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson, the top treasury official, quit when Mrs. Thatcher refused to fire a part-time adviser who shared her wariness about linking the pound to other major European currencies. This month, Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley, a fellow right-winger and probably her closest ally in the Cabinet, resigned after making anti-German remarks. His assertions that European monetary union was a ``German racket to take over Europe,'' and that ceding British sovereignty to the European Community was like surrendering to Hitler caused a furor. They also provided an embarrassing reminder of Mrs. Thatcher's often uneasy relations with the rest of the 12-nation community and prompted speculation that _ despite her swift rejection of Ridley's remarks _ she secretly shares his views. ``She has to watch her back, every politician does, and her back is Europe,'' David Owen, a former Labor foreign secretary and leader of the now defunct Social Democratic Party, told a gathering of U.S. reporters recently. Meanwhile, another ex-Cabinet minister and pro-European, former Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, is running an undeclared campaign for the party leadership. Polls show that Heseltine, 57, is the favorite to succeed her. However, Mrs. Thatcher has notably softened her stance on Europe in the past few months, seeking to avoid isolation and pressing with greater diplomacy her opposition to greater centralization. ``She is a superb psychiatrist,'' Owen said. ``There is only one card Heseltine has to play and that's the European one. If she offends the majority of pro-Europeans in the Conservative Party, then he is back with a chance.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Signs Landmark Legislation, ^Laserphotos WX12, WX14, WX15
DOC.TEXT: On a White House lawn crowded with people in wheelchairs, President Bush signed landmark legislation Thursday banning discrimination against the nation's 43 million disabled. ``Every man, woman and child with a disability can now pass through once-closed doors into a bright new era of equality, independence and freedom,'' Bush said as he signed the Americans with Disabilities Act. He called it ``another Independence Day, one that is long overdue.'' The crowd of more than 3,000 that spilled across the South Lawn was the largest ever at a White House bill-signing ceremony, said deputy press secretary Alixe Glen. Many of those attending were disabled, and they applauded loudly as Bush said the law will ban discrimination in the workplace, assure access to restaurants, hotels and shopping centers, expand access to public buses and rail systems, and require telephone companies to provide special services for the deaf. The law bans discrimination against people with disabilities, including AIDS, and defines the disabled as anyone with a mental or physical impairment limiting ``some major life function.'' Bush invoked the opening words of the Declaration of Independence, saying, ``we are keeping faith with the spirit of our courageous forefathers who wrote ... `that all men are created equal.''' ``Tragically, for too many Americans, the blessings of liberty have been limited or even denied,'' Bush said. The president likened the Americans with Disabilities Act to the dismantling of the Berlin Wall. The law ``takes a sledgehammer to another wall,'' he said. ``We will not accept, we will not excuse, we will not tolerate discrimination in America,'' Bush said. When he sat down at a table to sign the bill with a flourish of ceremonial pens, many in the crowd rose for a better view, only to sit quickly back down as those in wheelchairs called out, ``Down in front!'' Bush offered the fourth and last pen to the Rev. Harold Wilke, 75, an armless United Church of Christ minister from Claremont, Calif., who had delivered an invocation that spoke of ``the breaking of the chains which have held back millions of Americans with disabilities.'' Wilke, who teaches at Union Seminary in New York City, suggested the pen go instead to Ginny Thornburgh, wife of the attorney general and a longtime activist for the disabled. ``The president said, `All right, I'll give it to Ginny, but I'll give you mine,''' Wilke said later. As Bush reached into his pocket, Wilke deftly slipped his foot out of his loafer, took the pen with his toes and slipped it back into his shoe. A moment later, seated beside Barbara Bush, he put the pen into his pocket. Those watching the ceremony were enthusiastic. ``It's just fantastic. It's a tremendously exhilarating feeling,'' said Gordon Anthony, 35, an activist from Los Angeles in a wheelchair from a spinal cord injury. Anthony is a successful marketing consultant, but he said the law ``may open doors for what I do in my future career. There may be better opportunities.'' ``Employers are going to start reaching out to the disabled,'' he said. Maggie Behle, 10, of Salt Lake City, darted nimbly through the crowd on a single crutch. She was born with one leg, but is a downhill ski racer. Her mother, Sue Behle, boasted that Maggie has encountered few obstacles she cannot overcome, but the Behles have a second daughter, Kate, 15, who is autistic and retarded. Mrs. Behle, who works with a state agency for the handicapped, said she hopes the Americans with Disabilities Act ``will mean that Kate can have a job, that she can be employed.'' Karen Friedman of the Human Rights Campaign Fund, which lobbies for gay causes, called it a ``very historic day because it will stop discrimination against people with AIDS and HIV infection.'' The disabilities bill includes sanctions for those who discriminate in hiring. It allows victims of employment discrimination to seek back pay, reinstatement and attorneys' fees. However, the law exempts businesses with fewer than 15 employees from the hiring provisions. To businesses worried about the new mandates, Bush called the disabled ``a tremendous pool'' of potential workers ``who will bring to jobs diversity, loyalty, proven low turnover rate and only one request: the chance to prove themselves.'' Sen. Bob Dole, R-Kan., who lost use of his right arm in World War II, said the law was ``a giant step forward.'' ``It will be some burden'' on business, Dole said, ``but it's going to make it much easier'' for America's disabled.

DOC.HEAD: Two Air Force Jets Crash in Death Valley
DOC.TEXT: Two Phantom F-4 fighter-bombers out of George Air Force Base crashed Thursday in the Mojave Desert. Two crew members survived and two were missing. The cause of the 10:50 a.m. crash was not immediately known, said Air Force Tech Sgt. Rick Corral of George Air Force Base. He said an emergency team from the base was en route to the remote site, about 30 miles north of Death Valley National Monument. More details were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Most American Indians Descended From Single Small Band
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Nearly all American Indians are descendants of a single small band of pioneers who walked across what's now the Bering Strait from Asia 15,000 to 30,000 years ago, a genetics researcher said Thursday. The descendants of this hardy group make up 95 percent of American Indians, including the Mayans, Incas and many other spread throughout North, Central and South America. The exceptions are the Eskimos and Aleuts of the Arctic rim, the Navajos, Apaches and a few others who arrived later, said Douglas Wallace of Emory University in Atlanta. ``It was clearly a small migration,'' Wallace said of the ancestral group. He based his findings on studies of the genes that are related to the body's energy production. The genes were extracted from blood samples from members of three different Indian groups. In a presentation during a genetics course at the Jackson Laboratory in Bar Harbor, Wallace also reported using the same energy-producing genes _ called mitochondria _ to identify for the first time the cause of a form of epilepsy. The mitochondrial genes, which are separate from the body's other genes, are passed on to children only by mothers, not by fathers. Studies of the genes allow researchers to trace maternal ancestry, Wallace explained. The research on American Indians showed that the vast majority descended from four women in that original migrating group. ``That's a striking finding,'' said Michael Silverstein, an anthropologist at the University of Chicago who studies American Indian languages. If the finding is confirmed, Silverstein said, it significantly extends the conclusions about Indian origins that can be made using language studies. In March, anthropologists met in Boulder, Colo., to debate a suggestion by Joseph Greenberg of Stanford University that most American Indian languages derived from one ancestral language. That controversial view is supported by Wallace's studies, which trace most American Indians to the migration of a single small group of people who presumably spoke the same language, Wallace said. Other researchers have identified up to 200 linguistic groups, said Greenberg. That would suggest there had been many separate migrations or that the migrations occurred so long ago that the original language had had time to split into many different forms. Wallace said his data argues strongly against those possibilities. Wallace is trying to determine when the small group of Indian pioneers lived. The land bridge across the Bering Strait existed from about 30,000 years ago, when the glaciers that covered it receded, until about 15,000 years ago, when the glaciers melted and water covered the bridge. He hopes to establish the time of migration using techniques to find how much time it took for the ancestors' genes to diversify to the way they are among Indians today. The studies might also be used to test the longshot theory that American Indians descended from Polynesians who managed to migrate from their islands in the south and central Pacific. Wallace, one of the leading authorities on mitochondrial genes, has linked them to several unusual inherited diseases, including one called myoclonic epilepsy and ragged-red fiber disease, or MERRF. The discovery that the disease is related to a genetic defect in the mitochondria underscores the importance of these ``little fireplaces in the body,'' Wallace said. ``It's the first epilepsy that's ever been worked out at the molecular level,'' Wallace said. He was able to show that this disease, which can produce severe, handicapping muscle spasms, is inherited. Its origin until now has been unknown, Wallace said. Although the discovery will not lead immediately to a new treatment, it is an important step toward that goal, he said. Preliminary success has been obtained in treating other mitochondrial diseases, he said. Wallace also has suggested that the accumulation of defects in the mitochondria during aging could be a cause of the body's normal degeneration, although that hypothesis remains to be examined. ``As we age, our mitochondrial activity is declining,'' he said. Organs that depend heavily on energy _ such as the brain and the heart _ are among the organs that begin to fail in old age, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq Reduces War of Words With Kuwait, Withdraws Troops
With AM-OPEC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iraq scaled back a weeklong intimidation campaign against Kuwait on Thursday and began preparing for direct talks with its neighbor on ending a bitter dispute over land rights and oil production. Travelers returning from the border area said there were fewer weapons on display. Diplomatic sources in the Persian Gulf said Iraq had agreed to remove extra troops reportedly deployed along the disputed border. Iraq denied ever increasing its military strength in the area, despite reports from diplomats and the media that it moved as many as 30,000 men to the border. Iraqi newspaper officials said they received instructions from the ministry of information Wednesday night to halt propaganda attacks on Kuwait as part of an agreement to defuse the crisis. An Iraqi official said representatives of Iraq and Kuwait would start direct negotiations in the Saudi Arabian port of Jiddah on Saturday or Sunday. Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak sent an adviser to Baghdad and Kuwait to help organize the talks. Diplomatic sources in Cairo said the meeting would be between oil and financial experts, who would outline the countries' differences and make suggestions to their governments for solving them, the Kuwait News Agency reported. In Jiddah, the 46-member Organization of Islamic Conference urged the two member states to resolve their differences peacefully. It warned that any escalation of tension might bring foreign intervention to the region, especially from Israel. The Iraqi source, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had not backed down on demands that Kuwait cut oil production, pay for oil Baghdad claims Kuwait stole, and forget billions of dollars in wartime loans to Iraq. Saddam has demanded Kuwait compensate Iraq for $2.4 billion worth of oil he accused Kuwait of stealing from an oil field that includes land claimed by both countries. The disputed Rumaila oil field extends two miles into Kuwait, but Iraq claims it owns the entire field. Saddam also claims Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates deprived his nation of $14 billion in revenue by exceeding their OPEC production quotas and depressing the international price of crude oil. He threatened to use force against OPEC cheaters. Kuwait and and U.A.E. deny that they have cheated. In a move that could help soothe Iraqi anger, OPEC ministers were expected Friday to sign an agreement to raise the cartel's price of crude oil and try to limit production. Under the proposal, Kuwait and the U.A.E. would be limited to producing 1.5 million barrels a day. Analysts say each has been pumping about 2 million barrels a day.

DOC.HEAD: Fans Recalled After Blades Found to Separate From Motor
DOC.TEXT: A ceiling fan distributor said Thursday it is recalling 10,000 of the fans because of a defect that can cause the blades to separate from the motor. ``Builders Square said these ceiling fans are equipped with metal fan blade bracket holders which may break, allowing the blade to separate from the motor while the fan is in use,'' said the Consumer Product Safety Commission. The company has received seven customer complaints, one reporting a minor injury, involving its fans, the agency said. The voluntary recall involves eight models of 52-inch ``Bay Breeze'' ceiling fans distributed by Builders Square, Inc. of San Antonio. The fans, sold with and without lights, were distributed nationwide from October 1989 until two months ago. Consumers should stop using the fans and return them to any Builders Square store for a refund or call the company at 1-800-634-5949.

DOC.HEAD: Congressmen Hit Administration's Reluctance to Sign Women's Rights Treaty
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration is dragging its feet on a proposed U.S. treaty that calls for eliminating human rights abuses against women around the world, members of Congress said Thursday. Rep. Gus Yatron, D-Pa., head of a House human rights subcommittee, said the United States is one of the few developed countries that has not ratified the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Joining Yatron in criticism was Rep. Douglas Bereuter, R-Neb. He said the United States tarnished its image in the eyes of other nations by failing to act on the U.N. convention that was signed a decade ago. He said the measure has been ratified by more than 100 countries. ``Abuse against women takes a number of forms, from denial of access to education to physical mutilation and even death,'' Yatron said at a hearing. ``The human rights situation of women has been largely an invisible issue,'' he said. ``It is the purpose of these hearings to bring women's rights into the mainstream of our human rights policy.'' Jackie Wolcott, deputy assistant secretary of State, said as a first step the Bush administration wants the Senate to ratify another convention banning torture. Treaties must be ratified by two-thirds of the Senate. Meantime, she said the State Department has asked the Justice Department to review the convention to determine whether any of its provisions conflict with current law. ``The process of determining which human rights conventions should be recommended for ratification will undoubtedly be time-consuming,'' she said. ``However, we hope that it will proceed without undue delay following approval of the torture convention.'' Paula Dobriansky, the deputy secretary of State for human rights, said the administration believes the U.S. priority ``must be on the reform of governmental policies and institutions responsible for those abuses.'' Ms. Dobriansky testified that many countries continue to single out women for abuse. In India, for example, more than 2,000 women were killed _ usually burned _ in ``dowry deaths'' in 1988. Their crime? They couldn't meet the property demands of their husband's families. In Iran, women have been raped before being executed and tortured after giving birth, according to testimony obtained by the United Nations. In Brazil, women often from the lower classes are killed and assaulted with virtual impunity in crimes of passion because a man's ``honor'' is so important. In Africa, the painful, unhygienic practice of genital mutilation, usually circumcision, continues in various countries. In China, reports of forced abortion and sterilization continue as the country attempts to rein in its population growth. These and other examples were brought up at a congressional hearing focusing on human rights abuses against women around the world.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Western Aid Needed to Continue Reforms
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Thursday his country needs Western aid to rebuild its consumer industries in the next two critical years of reform. Speaking to reporters following a meeting with Italian Premier Guilio Andreotti, Gorbachev also said NATO's steps to transform itself were crucial in his decision not to block a united Germany's membership in the Western alliance. He also warmly praised Pope John Paul II, and did not exlude a papal visit to the Soviet Union. Andreotti, as president of the European Community for the last half of 1990, has been Europe's point man on the issue of providing assistance to the Soviet Union. He has said he believes Gorbachev's reform program cannot succeed without a rapid infusion of Western aid. The question of Italian financial credits to the Soviet Union was discussed in the meetings, Andreotti said, but no agreements were reached. Gorbachev has said his 5-year-old reform program would have to show results in the next two years or the Soviet leadership should quit. The consumer market is in disarray. There are shortages everywhere of basic consumer goods and food items, and many regions have gone to rationing or limiting sales to those who can prove local residence. Asked how foreign assistance could help, Gorbachev said the Soviet Union must move to convert its defense industries to peaceful production, produce more food and consumer goods for the market, and give factories a chance to work with foreign firms to boost their productivity. ``In these two years, in which we will have to make the most difficult changes, we need this kind of help,'' Gorbachev said. Some aid should be provided quickly ``to reduce the difficulty of the problems, and so perestroika does not slow down,'' he said. But the Soviet Union ``cannot depend on foreign sponsors'' to fix its economy, and aid to Moscow will not be ``a handout,'' he said. Andreotti said assistance to the Soviet Union could help stabilize all of Europe. The West German government has guaranteed $3.1 billion in bank loans to the Soviet Union, and together with France pushed the European Community to endorse an immediate $15 billion aid program. President Bush says providing Moscow with Western advisers and know-how would help more than economic aid until the Soviet Union makes more changes in its economy and cuts down assistance to countries like Cuba. Gorbachev was asked about the Soviet decision, announced by last week, to refrain from trying to block a united Germany's membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. He credited NATO compromises. Meeting in London, NATO leaders agreed to reduce the alliance's dependence on nuclear weapons and to study changes in its forces and military strategy. ``I am sure that if there had been no London declaration ... it would have been very difficult to formulate our declaration,'' Gorbachev said. Asked by reporters after the news conference about the possibility of a papal visit to the Soviet Union, Gorbachev said: ``Of course, everything is possible.'' The Soviet Union had received ``good words'' from the Vatican through the visiting Italian officials, Gorbachev said. Gorbachev has been criticized by traditionalist Communist officials for establishing relations with the Vatican and meeting with the pope on a visit to Italy last December.

DOC.HEAD: Springsteen Girlfriend Gives Birth to Singer's First Baby
DOC.TEXT: The girlfriend of Bruce Springsteen, who sang ``Born to Run'' and `Born in the U.S.A.,'' has given birth to the rock balladeer's first child _ a boy _ Springsteen's lawyer said Thursday. Patti Scialfa, a back-up singer in Springsteen's band, delivered the 7-pound, 9-ounce boy at a California hospital sometime since Tuesday, said lawyer Barry Slott of Asbury Park. Slott did not know the boy's name, the name of the hospital or the condition of the mother or child. Springsteen, 40, and Scialfa, 38, were rumored to be linked romantically after she joined his E Street Band as a backup singer in 1984 for the ``Born in the U.S.A.'' tour. ``The Boss'' married model-actress Julianne Phillips on May 13, 1985, but their divorce became effective in March 1989. Like Springsteen, Scialfa is a New Jersey native. Springsteen has been reported to be producing her first solo album.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Frank-Ethics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the seven House members who have been reprimanded by their colleagues. In addition, 22 House members have been censured, a more serious punishment, and four have been expelled. _ Barney Frank, D-Mass., reprimanded Thursday for actions on behalf of a male prostitute. _ Austin J. Murphy, D-Pa., reprimanded in 1987 for ghost voting. _ George V. Hansen, R-Ind., in 1984 for financial misconduct. _ Charles H. Wilson, D-Calif., in 1978 for false statements. _ John J. McFall, D-Calif., in 1978 for campaign violation. _ Edward R. Roybal, D-Calif., in 1978 for lying under oath. The Ethics Committee had recommended censure. _ Robert Sikes, D-Fla., in 1976 for financial misconduct.

DOC.HEAD: East Germany's Former Secret Police Chief Goes to Jail
DOC.TEXT: East Germany on Thursday jailed the former chief of the Communist secret police on suspicion he had hidden some of the world's most notorious terrorists. However, officials said deposed Communist leader Erich Honecker was too sick to prosecute on allegations of abuse of office and corruption. Authorities arrested 82-year-old Erich Mielke, who ran the sprawling foreign and domestic spy network that touched nearly every East German and bolstered Honecker's 19 years of iron-fisted rule. Mielke was held pending investigation of charges he abused his power, jailed people for criticizing the old regime, and turned East Germany into a haven for left-wing terrorists linked to some of the most spectacular attacks of the past two decades. The government said even though the allegations against Honecker would justify a similar criminal investigation, the 77-year-old former leader's health is too precarious. He is suffering from kidney cancer at a Soviet military hospital outside Berlin. Some leaders of the ousted regime were arrested late last year or early this year but were freed because of poor health or advanced age. East Germany's democratic government has changed its mind several times about whether to prosecute the ousted Communists, and whether to grant amnesty to most of the 100,000 people who worked for its intelligence network. It is unclear how unification in December, when East Germany will come under West Germany's justice system, will affect the criminal investigations. The East Germany ADN news agency quoted Federal Prosecutor Guenter Seidel as saying authorities had ``no other choice'' but to arrest Mielke in light of the mounting evidence of complicity in harboring terrorists. He added that medical difficulties still could stand in the way of eventual prosecution of Mielke and other former officials. There have been many reports in West German newspapers that Mielke's mental state had deteriorated. Mielke's arrest follows a sensational string of allegations that the former Communist government hid, trained and perhaps financed notorious left-wing terrorists. Eight reputed members of the Red Army Faction, blamed for a series of killings and bombings in West Germany in the 1970s and 1980s, were arrested in the past several week in East Germany. Some had been living there for more than a decade. All had assumed names and phony identification papers. Some said they were given housing and false identities by the former secret police. There have been numerous reports that several other terrorist suspects regularly lived or traveled to East Germany with the approval of authorities. Among them was Illich Ramirez Sanchez, the notorious ``Carlos the Jackal,'' who masterminded the Dec. 21, 1975, kidnapping of 11 OPEC oil ministers and several other fatal attacks. Officials have said Mielke also personally aided Abu Daoud, the Palestinian accused of orchestrating the massacre of 17 Israeli athletes during the 1972 Olympics in Munich. Besides aiding leftist terrorists, the Stasi purportedly also aided right-wing radicals, West German news reports have said recently. In addition to East German allegations, West Germany is pursuing murder charges against Honecker for his part in promulgating the shoot-to-kill order that led to the deaths of at least 192 people trying to flee from the old regime into West Germany. Besides Mielke, two other former Communist officials, labor union chief Harry Tisch and party economist Guenter Mittag, have been judged competent to face an investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts' Ongoing Chaos Could Ripple into Economy
DOC.TEXT: The Massachusetts Legislature has become mired in political gridlock, threatening to further damage an already weak economy, analysts said Thursday. ``As long as chaos continues, there's always a tendency to postpone making any kind of decisions,'' said David Wyss, an economist at DRI-McGraw Hill in Lexington. ``That means businesses are not expanding, people aren't making investments.'' Lawmakers have been struggling for months to solve the state's fiscal disaster. While the Legislature was gripped with political paralysis, the state's budget deficit climbed above $1 billion and the government bond ratings dropped to the nation's lowest. State officials hoped they were sending encouraging signs last week when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis signed a $1.2 billion tax package. That was followed by a legislative conference committee's approval of a budget for the fiscal year that began July 1. But events grew out of control this week when House lawmakers refused to agree to the budget, and then House leaders tried to appease them by offering a substitute tax package. That maneuver failed. Meantime, Standard and Poors, a major Wall Street bond rating agency, was preparing an annual credit report on Massachusetts, to be released Monday. Standard & Poors last year gave Massachusetts a BBB bond rating, lowest in the nation. Moody's Investors Service Inc. also has given Massachusetts its lowest rating of any state. ``It's unfortunate that the budget delays persist,'' a statement from S&P said. The firm said it would have a comprehensive evaluation of the state once the budget and the financing of last year's deficit are resolved, along with the newly enacted tax package. The protracted debate, itself, can hurt the state's credit status, said Wyss, who follows bond rating issues. ``The basic problem is not the ability to pay, but a lack of willingness to pay,'' he said. ``This is a further indication of it.'' The state economy, which started to weaken more than a year ago, contributed to the fiscal crisis by shrinking tax collections. But now the fiscal crisis is casting a shadow over the general economic picture, some observers say. ``It has the heavy hand of depression on all of us,'' said James Howell, a leading private economist in Boston. Howell has proposed some form of private sector intervention, where members of the business community would work with legislators to restructure the state's finances. ``There is a time when this fiscal crisis cannot be allowed to continue,'' he said. Some political observers blamed a leadership vacuum in the House for the inaction. Marty Linsky, a former GOP legislator now affiliated with Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government, said House Speaker George Keverian traditionally has relied on personal friendships rather than strong-armed tactics to win support. But because Keverian is now running for the Democratic nomination for state treasurer, he ``has taken himself out,'' Linsky said. ``That gives him much less leverage.''

DOC.HEAD: For Durenberger, Thursday a Lot Better Day
With AM-Frank-Ethics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thursday was a better day for Dave Durenberger. Wednesday night, the Minnesota senator sat at a front-row desk in the Senate chamber as colleagues stood one by one to vote for a resolution formally denouncing him for financial misconduct. Thursday morning he was on the White House lawn, saluted by President Bush along with a handful of fellow senators for their efforts in passing a popular bill barring discrimination against disabled Americans. Durenberger waded into the crowd on the White House's South Lawn, his red, white and blue tie emblazoned with tiny wheelchairs, to greet dozens of men, women and children in wheelchairs. Later he crouched to talk with a group of children, answering questions about the new law. A Minneapolis station's TV camera took it all in, along with his conversation with a polio-stricken Minnesota woman he brought to Washington for the ceremony. A few minutes later, he took a plane to Vermont for the weekend wedding of his third son, Michael. ``It was just meant to be,'' the Republican senator said over and over about the morning's events, the day after the darkest moment in his political career. Thursday morning, he awoke to see his picture splashed in ignominy across newspaper front pages from coast to coast. And in the Twin Cities, the Saint Paul Pioneer Press and WCCO-TV released poll results that showed Durenberger's home-state approval rating had plunged to 40 percent. But by 10 a.m. all that was pushed aside as Durenberger took his seat at the White House and began what he hopes will be a return to more routine Senate life. ``This is the real Dave Durenberger,'' he told reporters. ``This is the kind of an event that I think is an opportunity to rejoice in all the good things that I do as a United States senator. ``We've put a couple of bad things that I did a couple of years ago behind. I do this sort of thing every day. I do it for a living and I do it as a person. This is the good part of my life.''

DOC.HEAD: `Smoke on the Mountain' Is Good, Down-Homey Fare
DOC.NOTE: Eds: No PMs Planned
DOC.TEXT: ``Smoke on the Mountain'' is an evening of musical theater as down-home and satisfying as the sweet potato pie sold at intermission. It is the depiction of a gospel-singing family's Saturday evening appearance at the Mount Pleasant Baptist Church, Mount Pleasant, N.C., in 1938. It's made more dramatic and musically varied than the real thing would have been but, except for a few too many smirks from Kevin Chamberlin as Mervin Oglethorpe, the resident preacher, it isn't condescending. ``Smoke on the Mountain'' has been running since May at the off-Broadway Lamb's Theater. The acting, singing and instrumental musicianship of the actors playing the Sanders family is astounding. Instead of one rural, white gospel song after another, some of the songs are country, blues and western swing. Everybody ``testifies,'' telling interesting stories. Dan Manning, as Stanley, tells of disappointing his mother by being the one of her five sons who went to prison. It might have been the most hokey of the stories but was actually the most touching. ``I like a good mother song,'' Rev. Oglethorpe had said earlier. And Manning sang a dandy, ``They're All Going Home to Mother Tonight (They're all going home but one).'' Dennis (Robert Olsen) plays violin and his twin sister Denise (Jane Potter) plays a tiny guitar. Burl, the dad, is played by Reathel Bean who looks more rural than most farmers. He plays guitar. Vera, the mom, (Linda Kerns), plants her feet wide, likes to interrupt and plays piano. Stanley, Burl's brother, plays upright bass. Everybody switches around on different instruments. But Manning, as Stanley, gets a better tone on bass than anybody else and is also a dab hand with mandolin and harmonica. The preacher, besides looking longingly at the family daughters, throws himself into the singing from time to time and once brings on his accordion. The audience joins in on ``Bringing in the Sheaves.'' June Sanders, the twins' nonmusical sister, is played by Connie Ray, who wrote ``Smoke on the Mountain.'' June is learning to sign for the deaf, which the Mount Pleasant congregation doesn't need. The drama which ends Act 1 is the huffy exit from the amen corner of two old maids when the Sanders girls ``move with the spirit'' to ``There Is a Place Beyond the River of Life.'' ``We don't dance here,'' screeches the preacher, trying to save the evening. Alan Bailey, who directed, had the idea for ``Smoke on the Mountain.'' It was first performed at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., in 1988. Some of the songs will be familiar to those with a Protestant upbringing. Familiar songs or not, the evening is a beguiling joy.

DOC.HEAD: Producer of TV's `thirtysomething' Producer Sues Star over Pay
DOC.TEXT: The producer of the ``thirtysomething'' television show sued star Timothy Busfield, claiming the actor has threatened to boycott filming of the series' fourth season unless he gets a raise. The suit, filed Wednesday in Los Angeles Superior Court by MGM-UA Television Production Group Inc., alleges Busfield has refused to report for work on Aug. 3, the start of filming for the fall season. It asks a judge to order him to return to work. The suit alleged that Busfield wants to be paid $36,375 per episode. MGM-UA said it offered the red-haired actor $28,750 for each 1990-1991 installment of the popular series. ``MGM has failed to live up to their agreement with Mr. Busfield,'' Edward Burg, the actor's attorney, responded Thursday. ``They are trying to coerce him into returning to work and he won't be coerced.'' Burg declined further comment. The suit claims Busfield, who also has appeared in feature films including ``Field of Dreams,'' has breached his five-year contract by threatening to stay off the set. It seeks unspecified compensatory and punitive damages. It also seeks to bar the actor, who currently is starring on Broadway in ``A Few Good Men,'' from appearing in movies, television productions and theater plays until the dispute is resolved. In opposition papers, Busfield's attorney alleged that such a court-ordered injunction would prohibit the actor from earning a living. Busfield portrays Elliot Weston in the ABC drama about the everyday lives of a group of friends approaching middle age in Pennsylvania. Busfield's character is married to Nancy, whose battle with cancer is expected to be a crucial aspect of the new season. ABC, ``thirtysomething'' supervising producer Scott Winant and Busfield's agent all declined comment Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Six Indian Tribes Given Greater Control Over Finances
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of six Indian tribes on Thursday formally accepted an Interior Department agreement that gives them direct access to federal funds and more control over how to spend them. The Self-Governance Demonstration Project is designed to test whether the tribes can do a better job of managing their own affairs than the federal government. Tribes from Washington, Oklahoma, California and Minnesota were chosen to participate in the three-year program, which begins Oct. 1. Under the program, the tribes will get federal funds directly, rather than through the Bureau of Indian Affairs. They will be free to spend the money as they choose. The Senate Select Committee on Indian Affairs reported last year that very little of the $3.3 billion allocated for Indian programs actually reached Indian people. ``This is a major step for the six tribes represented here today,'' Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan said as he gave the tribal leaders a copy of the agreement, which was signed July 3. ``Through their individual agreements, they are taking control of their budgets, and they are setting priorities for future development in their unique cultural communities,'' Lujan said. Participating in the program are the Quinault, Lummi and Klallam tribes of Washington; the Hoopa tribe of California; the Cherokee Nation of Oklahoma and the Chippewa's Mille Lacs Band of Minnesota. Lujan said that if the program is judged successful, it will be extended to other tribes. The chairman of the Senate panel, Sen. Daniel Inouye, D-Hawaii, said the new system will allow tribes to target particular needs in of health and education. It also will give them a new sense of autonomy, he said. ``This ceremony here will bring in a new relationship, a United States-Indian partnership,'' he said. The 1991 amounts are: Quinault, $3.9 million; Lummi $2.2 million; Hoopa Valley, $2 million; Jamestown Klallam, $687,000; Cherokee, $6.1 million; and Mille Lacs $267,210. New annual funding agreements will be negotiated for 1992 and 1993. Don Wedll of the Mille Lacs Band challenged the distribution of the funds. He said Mille Lacs received $112 per member, while other tribes received between $1,000 and $3,000 per member. Tribe officials say 80 percent of the Mille Lacs Band live below the federal poverty level. Wedll said the tribe is renegotiating its allotment with the Interior Department.

DOC.HEAD: New President Named for NBC's Cable Venture
DOC.TEXT: NBC on Thursday appointed senior network executive Albert Barber to head the company's year-old cable venture, the Consumer News and Business Channel. He replaces Michael Eskridge as CNBC president. Eskridge is leaving to form a broadcast management company. CNBC is co-owned by NBC and Cablevision Systems Corp. of New York's Long Island. The cable operation, based in Fort Lee, N.J., began in April 1989 with reported start-up costs of $65 million. CNBC has a staff of 275 and is seen in 16.8 million homes and offices, about half the number served by its older rival, New York-based Financial News Network. Barber said one of his top priorities ``is to get CNBC carried around the world,'' but as a business, consumer and financial news service, not as a rival to Cable News Network. ``This not not a general news network,'' Barber said of CNBC which, unlike Ted Turner's 24-hour cable news service, is seen only in the United States. CNN, established 10 years ago, is seen in 90 countries. Barber, 44, has been NBC's executive vice president and chief financial officer since 1987. Before that, he served in various managerial positions at General Electric Co., which bought NBC in June 1986. CNBC still is running in the red and doesn't expect to turn a profit until its fourth year, when executives hope it will have 30 million U.S. subscribers. Barber said a priority will be visiting cable operators who don't carry CNBC to sell the service. He said he might consider changing CNBC's prime-time operations, which consist mainly of interview shows, but added, ``we are very pleased with our daytime programming'' of financial and business news reports. CNBC in May hired Andrew Friendly, a former ``Entertainment Tonight'' producer, to overhaul its prime-time programming. Unlike FNN, CNBC isn't yet carried by cable in Manhattan and thus isn't seen by the influential Wall Street and advertising crowd. But Barber said he will work hard to get it shown by Manhattan cable operators. In trying to get CNBC a global audience, Barber said, he will seek distribution in hotels and brokerage houses, among other places. Last month, CNBC began that attempt with a three-week satellite transmission of the service's programs to London and Paris, hoping to interest cable and television companies in carrying CNBC.

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Rebels in Retreat Kill 41, Military Claims
AM-Bicycle Brigade, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The military claimed Thursday that fleeing Tamil rebels hacked and shot to death 41 Sinhalese and Moslem villagers suspected of helping the army in Sri Lanka's civil war. In a separate development in the south, unidentified assailants shot to death 13 Sinhalese villagers, military officials said. They said the killings could mean the resurgence of a Sinhalese extremist group that believes the government has been too soft on the Tamils. Rebels made no immediate comment on the military's charge they killed 41 villagers. It was not possible to independently confirm the report. The military officials, who cannot be identified under briefing rules, said the killings occurred in five northern and eastern villages on Tuesday and Wednesday. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne told reporters government troops in the north and east have scattered guerrillas of the separatist Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. ``The Tamil terrorists are on the run into the jungles, and in desperation they want to kill as many as possible before they get killed,'' Wijeratne said. The military officials said militants hacked and shot to death 19 Sinhalese villagers at midnight Wednesday in the northcentral Medawahchiya district. They reported 20 people died but later said one seriously injured man was mistaken for dead. They said 18 more Sinhalese and four Moslems were killed in four attacks in the northeastern, northcentral and eastern districts. Four rebels and a soldier were also reported killed in fighting. Most fighting in this nation off the southern tip of India is concentrated below the northern peninsula of Jaffna, the militant stronghold. Government troops Tuesday took control of a six-mile corridor that connects the peninsula with the mainland. The peninsula has been under rebel control since the fighting started June 11, which ended a 13-month-old cease-fire in the Tamil war for a separate homeland. Since then, at least 2,900 combatants have been killed in the fighting for control of the north and the east. Besides the Sinhalese and Moslem deaths reported Thursday, a large but unknown number of other civilians, including Tamils, have been killed. Military officials who reported the 13 killings in the south said they suspected the Sinhalese extremist organization, the People's Liberation Front. The gunmen dragged the victims out of their homes from Diyadawa and Siyamablagoda villages and took them to jungles where they were shot, said the officials. The bodies were later burned, they said. The victims were members of a peace committee appointed by the government to oversee arms surrender by extremists of the front. If the Sinhalese radicals are responsible for the attack, it would be the first by the front since its top leaders were killed by security forces in December. The Sinhalese uprising started in 1987 to protest the government's peace overtures to the Tamil separatists. The Tamil rebellion started in 1983 with the separatist groups complaining of discrimination by the Sinhalese majority. Tamils form 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people. The majority Sinhalese, who control the government and military, comprise 75 percent of the population. More than 13,500 people have been killed in the 7-year-old ethnic war.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
House Reprimands Frank, Rejecting Stiffer Penalties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates in top 21 grafs with quotes, detail, picking up in 12th graf pvs, The House
DOC.TEXT: The House voted 408-18 on Thursday to reprimand Rep. Barney Frank for using his official influence on behalf of a male prostitute. ``I should have known better,'' the Massachusetts Democrat apologized. The vote came after the House overwhelmingly turned back conservative Republican efforts to expel Frank or to censure him and strip him of a subcommittee chairmanship. In a statement of contrition shortly before the vote, Frank said he had taken some of the actions cited by the ethics committee in part to ``conceal my homosexuality,'' which he later publicly revealed. Frank said he knows better now ``but it's a little late.'' Frank was punished for using his office to fix parking tickets for prostitute Stephen L. Gobie, and for writing a misleading memo designed to shorten Gobie's probation for sex and drug convictions. The memo found its way to a Virginia prosecutor and the ethics panel said it could have been perceived as an attempt to pressure authorities. Frank first met Gobie when he hired him for sexual relations in 1985. He later employed him as a personal assistant, paying him out of personal funds. Several lawmakers took pains to say they were not judging the Massachusetts Democrat for his sexual preference. ``We are neither condemning today nor condoning that lifestyle,'' said Rep. John T. Myers, R-Ind., the ranking Republican on the House ethics committee, which is officially the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct. The vote marked the second time in as many days that Congress had meted out punishment to one of its own. On Wednesday, the Senate denounced Sen. Dave Durenberger, R-Minn., for financial improprieties. On a vote of 96-0, the Senate also ordered him to make restitution of up to $123,000. Frank was ordered to make restitution to the District of Columbia for an unspecific amount to pay for the improperly dismissed tickets. The House first voted 390-38 to reject a move by California Rep. William Dannemeyer to expel Frank, a motion that required a two-thirds vote and had not been expected to pass. More than an hour later, House members voted 287-141 against a move by GOP Whip Newt Gingrich of Georgia to censure the Massachusetts Democrat, a move that would have stripped him of his subcommittee chairmanship. ``We are here to repair the integrity of the House of Representatives,'' Gingrich said. The 50-year-old Frank listened from a seat on the House floor as his fate was debated, surrounded by his Democratic colleagues from Massachusetts. Other members stopped by to pat the five-term lawmaker on the back. He said in advance he would not contest the ethics committee recommendation. In his floor speech, Frank called the memo he wrote during Gobie's probation ``the most serious'' of his mistakes and admitted, ``I shouldn't have written it. There was in my life a central element of dishonesty for about 40 years. It had to do with my private life. I did in that memorandum misrepresent the facts because ... it was necessary to conceal my homosexuality. ``Three years ago, I decided that concealment didn't work.'' Ethics committee chairman Julian C. Dixon, D-Calif., told the House in pushing for a reprimand, ``We have set aside all of the color, all of the filth, and examined the facts.'' ``It is not Barney Frank's lifestyle that should be judged here today, but rather what he did or did not do'' in his official capacity. Another committee member, Republican Rep. Fred Grandy of Iowa, said, ``We do not enhance or enshrine family values by damning individuals whose lifestyles differ from our own. We are here to prosecute, not persecute.'' And Rep. Thomas Foglietta added, ``Barney Frank stands accused of being stupid. If stupidity suddenly became the grounds for expulsion from this body, there would be very few of us left here.'' Voting for the reprimand were 244 Democrats and 164 Republicans. Voting no were seven Democrats and 11 Republicans. Four members, including Frank, voted present. It is traditional for lawmakers in his situation to vote that way. The House has censured 22 members in its two-century history and expelled only four. Six had been reprimanded before that action was recommended for Frank. Dannemeyer, who needed a two-thirds vote and had not been expected to succeed in his expulsion move, asked the House, ``Are there standards in our society that we will affirm for ourselves and our children? That's the issue.'' Rep. Bob Dornan, R-Calif., said he had not intended to support expulsion for Frank but changed his mind. ``I am going to vote for expulsion because he didn't have the honor and decency to resign,'' he said. Dannemeyer accused the ethics committee of failing to see Frank as a law breaker. He said Frank knew that Gobie was operating a prostitution ring in the lawmaker's apartment, a conclusion that was contradicted by the committee's finding that Frank was unaware of the business. Dixon called Dannemeyer's version of the facts ``the most edited, selective garbage that has ever been put forth in my opinion in this House.'' His remark was followed by a round of applause. The ethics committee chairman said Dannemeyer announced months ago he would move to expel Frank, when ``information on Congressman Frank's lifestyle ... is the only information he had at the time.'' Frank originally paid $80 for sexual relations with Gobie and then hired him in 1985 as an assistant. Frank said he fired him in 1987 after learning of Gobie's activities in the lawmaker's apartment. The committee accused him of improperly using his congressional authority to avoid paying 33 parking tickets, incurred by Gobie when he used Frank's car for personal business.
