Before recounting the crash, Hasenfus, 49, now a construction worker in Marinette, Wis., said he worked for CIA-owned Air America during the Vietnam War. When Central American hostilities heated up in July 1986, he was contacted by Cooper and brought to the Southern Air headquarters at Miami International Airport. He signed a contract with Corporate Air Services, but said he understood it was a front for Southern Air, which was paying his expenses. He said the crews complained that there was no safety equipment such as parachutes or survival gear, and that the navigation radios did not work properly. But he said he accepted the defects, thinking it was a patriotic, shoestring effort to fight communists in Central America. Only when the Iran-Contra affair became public, he said, did he become aware that Reagan aide Oliver North, Secord and Southern Air were running the supply effort as a profit-making enterprise, even buying a Lear jet. On cross-examination, Southern Air attorney Robert Beckman focused on the role of Corporate Air Services, forcing Hasenfus to show that his pay drafts, tax returns and even unemployment compensation claim all reflected that company's name rather than Southern Air. Beckman also sought to show Hasenfus had violated a secrecy agreement he signed, riling the witness. Hasenfus said the case ``was already blown by Congress'' when he later sold the rights to his story for $10,000 to CBS. Beckman referred to the hostilities as a ``war'' to bolster the defense contention that Hasenfus and Sawyer had willingly accepted the risks when they signed on. ``It wasn't a war, and Vietnam wasn't a war,'' Hasenfus responded. Under questioning by Secord's attorney, Thomas Spencer, Hasenfus agreed he had never met the man he was suing, nor did he have any documents signed by Secord. Hasenfus also acknowledged he had received some money after the crash.He said a brown bag containing $6,000 was given to his wife by a man who said ``this is from the boys.'' Secord's attorneys have said their client never had any legal relationship with Hasenfus and Sawyer, and had never met them. Secord pleaded guilty on Nov. 8, 1989, to lying to congressional investigators when he said he wasn't aware of any money that went to North's benefit from the maze of companies he used in the Iran-Contra affair. He was sentenced to two years' probation.

DOC.HEAD: Convoy Begins Removing Deadly Nerve Gas from Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf `The first' to UPDATE with locators on two towns. Picks up 14th pvs, `At Miesau...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KAI3
DOC.TEXT: A closely guarded truck convoy Thursday began spiriting away a vast cache of deadly nerve gas secretly stored by the United States near this small West German town for more than 20 years. West German authorities said someone phoned in a bomb threat against the toxic convoy but that the transport of the first shipment of nerve gas proceeded without any hitches. It was the beginning of the end for the United States' sole chemical weapons' depot in Europe _ a huge arsenal of 102,000 artillery shells covertly bunkered here since the Cold War days as a deterrent against Soviet aggression. Clausen residents breathed a collective sigh of relief while watching the removal of deadly weapons whose existence they were told about just a few months ago. ``I'm glad they're going,'' said Deputy Mayor Emil Cronauer, among the citizens lining Clausen's main street to watch the U.S. army container trucks rumble by. ``I think the same thing that's now happening with chemical weapons is going to happen to atomic weapons.'' Joseph Wadle, a 72-year-old Clausen resident, echoed concerns among many Germans about the safety of the transport. ``I'm relieved that they're being removed. I just hope that everything goes well,'' he said. German residents weren't the only ones curious about the parade of lethal chemicals. Soviet observers, permitted to monitor some military operations under agreement with the West, also watched the convoy, U.S. military officials said. The lethal cargo, destined for destruction on an atoll in the Pacific Ocean, is being removed under a 1986 U.S.-West German agreement. The operation is costing $83 million. A massive security operation guarded the cargo as a convoy of nearly 80 military vehicles left the U.S. Army depot at Clausen. West German police helicopters followed the convoy as it snaked along its route and crack West German paramilitary squads stood in fields along the highway, or manned positions on overpasses. Green vans filled with West German paramilitary troopers were interspersed within the convoy. Riot helmets and shields could be seen through the vans' rear windows. The first trucks arrived at Miesau, 30 miles from Clausen, about 2{ hours later. Both towns are in the southwest part of the country _ Clausen is 15 miles south of Kaiserslautern, and Miesau is 18 miles west of Kaiserslautern. At Miesau, the containers are to be loaded onto special trains that will take them to Nordenham, on the North Sea, where they will be placed aboard U.S. Navy ships for transport to Johnston Atoll. The weapons will be destroyed at a later date in a specially built incinerator on the U.S. atoll, 800 miles southwest of Hawaii. The chemical weapons were hauled on 20 giant U.S. Army tractor-trailer rigs. The cargo was sealed in air-tight containers. Other vehicles contained decontamination crews, firefighters, West German and American soldiers, police, monitoring teams and medical staff. Only four demonstrators were spotted. They draped posters, including one that said: ``Evil is simply being shifted from here to the Pacific,'' over a stone wall next a church along the convoy route in Clausen. West German activists were also angry that even though the presence of U.S. chemical weapons on German soil was widely assumed, Washington refused to acknowledge their exact location until March. The West German government is paying $31 million for removal of the chemical weapons, and the U.S. cost is $52 million. The artillery shells _ some 6 inches in diameter, some 8 inches _ are loaded with liquid nerve agents, U.S. military officials said. They were brought to Clausen between 1958 and 1968, where they have remained ever since. One convoy will take the weapons daily from Clausen to Miesau over the next 30 days. The rail transport to the North Sea port will take about a week and will be conducted at night. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl and former President Reagan agreed in 1986 to remove the chemical weapons by 1992. President Bush advanced the timetable. Lt. Gen. John Shalikashvili, deputy commander in chief of U.S. Army-Europe, defended what he said had been a joint U.S.-German decision to keep the weapons depot a secret. ``The safety and security of those weapons dictated that their location remain classified,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Drop Case Against Photo of Nude Father, Son
DOC.TEXT: A federal prosecutor dropped his obscenity case Thursday against a confiscated photograph of a nude father and son that was described as a recognized work of art. ``Having completed my review of this matter, I am satisfied, to the extent that I can be, that there is no actionable child sexual victimization implicit in or resulting from the taking and production of this photograph,'' U.S. Attorney Richard S. Cohen said in a statement. The Maine Arts Commission called Cohen's retreat ``an extremely strong vote for the freedom of artistic expression.'' The government had at first sought to destroy the picture, a 1962 work by photographer Walter Chappell that has been exhibited throughout the nation. The picture shows a naked Chappell holding his infant son next to his erect penis. Cohen said Thursday the print had been returned to the attorney of its owner, Birgit Lenderink, who lives in a Buddhist meditation center in Barnet, Vt. The government's case, entitled ``United States of America vs. One Obscene Photograph,'' drew fire from artists as well as newspaper editorial writers, who noted that the photograph was exhibited in many galleries and reprinted in a Harper & Row book on American nude photography. Cohen's statement also cited ``the ready availability of this photograph in other parts of the country.'' Federal officials seized the framed, black and white print this winter at the state line in Houlton as friends were trying to bring it to Ms. Lenderink. None of the people who made or possessed the picture were charged in the case. Chappell, who lives in El Rito, N.M., a tiny farming community north of Santa Fe, did not respond to messages left at his home by The Associated Press. Maine Arts Commission spokesman Dick Dyer said he understood how someone unfamiliar with Chappell's work could question the photograph. ``When he (Cohen) saw the image, without any explanation whatsoever, to his credit, he did investigate,'' said Dyer. ``We're very pleased that he has had the wisdom to see through the process and decide not to prosecute the photograph.'' The case was withdrawn from U.S. District Court in Bangor.

DOC.HEAD: Pittsburgh Man Acquires British Lordship
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. man paid $169,000 on Thursday for the ancient manorial title to a town in the heart of Shakespearean England, the Manorial Auctioneers said. He gets the title, a bit of pomp and ceremony, and that's it. Joseph Hardy of Pittsburgh receives no land or property with his Lordship of the Manor of Henley-in-Arden, and he is not granted seat in the House of Lords. But he is entitled to preside over the annual ceremonial parade held each year in the town, 80 miles northwest of London. The document also confers the right to hold a weekly market and sit at the head of the long table at the annual dinner in the Guildhall, built in 1448. The quaint village is nestled in the Forest of Arden, seven miles northwest of Stratford-upon-Avon, the birthplace of William Shakespeare. Every year on the second Tuesday in November, a procession gathers at the 13th-century market cross in Henley-in-Arden. The ceremonial court parade proceeds to the manorial church of St. John the Baptist and ends at the old Guildhall for a dinner attended by local officials and other lords of the manor. Hardy, accompanied at the London auction by his wife and three daughters, is expected to take an active interest in preserving the traditions attached to his acquisition, said Robert Smith, chairman of the Manorial Society of Great Britain, which helped arrange the auction. Other titles sold at auction Thursday included the barony and manor of Morpeth, Northumberland, which brought $99,500, and the barony lordship of Frenchpark, County Roscommon, Ireland, for $54,000. Lordships of the manor are the oldest titles in England, predating the Norman Conquest of 1066. They once carried considerable land rights but their significance today is largely symbolic.

DOC.HEAD: New Academy Launched for Science, Math Teachers
DOC.TEXT: Teachers will be the students at a new school designed to sharpen instructors' math and science skills so they can pass those abilities to undereducated Chicago youngsters. ``I hope it will make the Chicago public school system the number one system in the country, a prototype ... for other big cities,'' Nobel laureate Leon Lederman said of the Academy for Mathematics and Science Teachers in Chicago, which was dedicated Thursday. Classes at the academy's South Side campus are to begin in as early as September. Plans call for all elementary teachers and all secondary teachers of math and science _ a total of about 17,000 public school instructors _ to attend the academy over the next six years. Teachers will typically attend the academy two or three days a week for up to 10 weeks, with the rest of the week spent at their schools so they can try out their new skills. ``We have to recognize that inner cities represent a repository of human resources not represented in math, science and the technical areas,'' said Lederman, who won the 1988 Nobel Prize in physics. ``The world can get along very easily without us. If we want to be a player, we have to do something about math and science.'' American public school students rank 18th out of world's 20 most industrial nations in science knowledge, officials said. New teachers who want to work in Chicago's 400,000-student public school system will be asked to first spend a year at the academy, said acting director Gordon Berry, a physicist on leave from Argonne National Laboratory. ``We must reach out and bring all of America's children into science in greater numbers than ever before if our work force is to remain competitive in the global market,'' Secretary of Energy James Watkins said at the ribbon-cutting ceremony attended by about 300 teachers. The Energy Department will provide initial funding and technical assistance to the academy, he said. ``By initiating the academy in a major urban area ... we will be able to create new education opportunities for black, Hispanic and other students currently under-represented in science and technology,'' Watkins said in a statement. Federal funding will account for $25 million of the academy's annual $35 million operating budget, said Lederman, who helped design the program. The rest would come from city, state and private sources, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Four Italian Ministers Resign in Dispute Over TV Law
DOC.TEXT: Four Christian Democrat ministers resigned from the government Thursday night in a dispute over a proposed television law, possibly threatening Premier Giulio Andreotti's five-party coalition. The four ministers are part of a wing of the party loyal to former premier and party leader Ciriaco De Mita, who was ousted from his leadership role last year. One of the four, Education Minister Sergio Mattarella, said they were resigning because the government was trying to force through an amendment to the bill that would clash with European Community regulations on TV advertising. Among other things, the bill would give Italian TV stations until 1993 to limit the number of commercial interruptions of films, while EC norms call for this to be done by 1991. However, political observers saw the resignations as a continuation of an internal party struggle between De Mita and Andreotti. It was not immediately clear what effect the resignations would have on the government. But the five parties in the governing coalition have been saying that a crisis should be avoided during the six months beginning in July when Italy holds the rotating presidency of the EC. Other than Mattarella, those resigning were State Industry Minister Carlo Francanzani, Defense Minister Mino Martinazzoli, and Riccardo Misasi, minister of extraordinary aid to the south. There are 16 Christian Democrat ministers in the 32-member Cabinet. The other coalition parties are the Socialists and the tiny Republicans, Liberals and Social Democrats. Andreotti's coalition, the 49th government in Italy's postwar history, has been in office since July 22, 1989. The television bill is part of a long sought law to regulate the country's public and private airwaves. Parties have been wrangling over various versions of the bill for years.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
DOC.TEXT: LOS ANGELES: split verdict. The 31-year-old Camarena was kidnapped off a Guadalajara street in February 1985, a crime that strained relations between the United States and Mexico. The trial was the second stemming from the murders of Camarena and his pilot, a crime which angry U.S. authorities characterized as a reflection of official corruption in Mexico. Disputes between Mexico and the United States over the case have erupted on several occasions throughout the investigation and trials. The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in the slaying. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country and more than 20 convicted in Mexico. Testimony at both American trials has shown the agent was taken to a house where he was tortured and interrogated by drug lords before being slain along with his pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. Their bodies were found a month later on a ranch 65 miles outside Guadalajara. The four men who stood trial together were Ruben Zuno Arce, a Guadalajara businessman who is the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican homicide officer and Javier Vasquez Velasco, a former bodyguard accused of murdering two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing.

DOC.HEAD: Barr's Anthem Rendition A `Disgrace,' Say Critics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 11th graf, `Noting the...' to UPDATE with Barr comment in television interview.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos GOS1, NY13
DOC.TEXT: It was crude, even lewd. But this time fans were spared seeing where she's tattooed. Still, many people said Thursday that Roseanne Barr was a disgrace for her shrill rendition of the national anthem at a National League baseball doubleheader and a crude on-field gesture afterward. Chris Roberts, a sports reporter for KFI radio in Los Angeles, said: ``She couldn't carry a note if she was on her way to the post office.'' But others said simply: Lighten up. They maintained the corpulent, caustic comedian who stars on the popular ABC-TV sitcom ``Roseanne'' did the best she could or may have become confused by the sound system's delay and resorted to shtick. KFI's entertainment reporter Tracy Miller said Barr was doing a parody of baseball players when she grabbed her crotch and spit after singing ``The Star-Spangled Banner'' at Wednesday night's games between the San Diego Padres and Cincinnati Reds. In the stands during a World Series game in Oakland last fall, Barr bared her bottom, revealing a tattoo declaring ``Tom'' _ her husband, Tom Arnold. ``They knew what kind of singer she is. She's just an average singer. She's not an opera singer,'' Arnold told The Associated Press Thursday from the couple's Malibu home. ``She did the best she could.'' Barr, who wouldn't come to the telephone, was troubled by the criticism, he said. ``She's very sorry. She's very upset that people think she meant disrespect. We weren't trying to disrespect that song at all,'' Arnold said. Noting the Padres won both games, Arnold added: ``I think they should have her back every night. But we know that won't happen with all this grief.'' In a television interview, Arnold complained that publicity about Barr has become ``vicious, it's just out of control. ... It's only negative: `Is she self-destructing?''' ``You can't call it self-destructive when it's being done to you,'' Barr told the interviewer from NBC News. ``That's like the final icing on the cake, that they do it to me and then call it self-destructive. But they do that to all women.'' Tom Werner, who became the chairman and managing partner of the Padres this season, also is the co-creator and executive producer of ``Roseanne.'' He met privately with Padres officials for 45 minutes Wednesday night and then refused to talk to reporters directly. Repeated messages left at his Los Angeles office went unanswered Thursday. Padres officials said they fielded about 1,200 calls Thursday, most of them complaints about Barr's performance. The team issued an apology, saying: ``The Padres recognize their obligation to ensure that the national anthem is sung with respect and dignity. ... It is apparent we did not do our part because many fans were offended both by the rendition and Roseanne's gestures. To those fans, we apologize and make the commitment that in the future we will strive to see the anthem is presented with the dignity it is due.'' National League President Bill White said: ``We have discussed it with the Padres and are in agreement with their apology. We are satisfied that they will take all necessary steps to assure it will not happen again.'' Opera star Robert Merrill, who has sung the national anthem in New York's Yankee Stadium for 18 years, was among those appalled by Barr's performance. ``This woman, who obviously has no taste at all, went out to sing the national anthem and distorted the song,'' he said. ``It was to me like burning of the flag. It was like, `Here I am and to hell with you.' It was a complete mockery and outlandish.'' Merrill, who also has sung the anthem for nine U.S. presidents, added: ``She's a disgrace. Did you see what she did when she walked off? I almost upchucked my dinner. I was ill to my stomach. I don't know if I've ever felt that angry. ``It isn't good for baseball. Baseball is like apple pie, Cracker Jacks and peanuts. It's the national pastime. This is a national disgrace.'' About 30,000 people attended the doubleheader at Jack Murphy Stadium. The club promoted the twin bill as ``Working Women's Night.'' ``I was embarrassed for the women who showed up,'' said spectator Jannette Davis of San Diego. ``This was supposed to be a night of saluting those who worked hard and she made us all feel like crap.'' Barr, who had said last week that she wouldn't be trying for laughs when she sang the national anthem, plugged her ears with her hands at the start of the song, then gave a wailing rendition. When the boos rose, Barr grabbed herself and spit on the ground. Said Padres pitcher Eric Show: ``I can't believe it happened. It's an insult. There are people who died for that song. Our national anthem exemplifies a lot of things.'' Barr's husband later made a ceremonial pitch, but the crowd didn't react. When Barr left the field with him later, though, the boos resumed. ``I think I did great and people wanted more,'' Barr told a reporter for KFMB-TV before leaving the field.

DOC.HEAD: Panama's Lawsuit to Accuse Noriega of Murder, Drug Trafficking
DOC.TEXT: A Panamanian lawsuit to be filed in Miami accuses former strongman Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of involvement in murder, torture and drug trafficking, according to legal papers obtained Thursday. The government is seeking up to $6.5 billion in damages. The 40-page suit, obtained from government sources by The Associated Press, carries a laundry list of accusations with 11 specific charges, including fraud, illicit enrichment, racketeering and offenses against the Panamanian people. The suit asks that Noriega and his allies repay Panama at least $500 million in damages. It also asks for any damage award to be tripled _ which would make for a maximum of $1.5 billion. In addition, the suit seeks a separate $5 billion punitive payment. Panamanian officials have said they do not expect to recover that full amount but intend it as a statement of damage done to Panama. They said the suit will be filed within days. The suit outlines cases of alleged assassination, torture, drug trafficking, money laundering, embezzlement, illegal sale of visas and passports, and abuse of authority while Noriega headed the defunct Panama Defense Forces. From that position, he controlled Panama's government until he was ousted in December by the U.S. invasion. Noriega was brought back to Miami, where he now faces U.S. drug-trafficking charges. The 1988 U.S. indictment accuses Noriega of taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a way station for cocaine trafficking. Panama's suit claims Noriega earned about $700,000 during his 28 years as a military officer but is now worth an estimated $300 million. The government's lawyers _ John G. Kester, Gregory B. Craig and Kevin J. Hasson _ contend in the suit that Noriega's activities caused Panama ``enormous material losses.'' The suit says Panama was damaged by a loss of tourism and an American trade embargo. The suit names 19 co-defendants. They include Marcos Justines, Noriega's chief of staff, who is jailed in Panama City; Carlos Duque, the 1989 presidential candidate of Noriega's party; Michael Harari, a former Israeli military officer; three former ambassadors; Noriega's wife Felicidad; and his mistress Vicki Amado. However, it was not clear if the Panamanian government could recover money from those co-defendants not in the United States. The suit claims Noriega was involved in the murder of army officers who plotted against him. It also says Noriega was paid $7.95 million for letting drugs flow through Panama and $4 million to $7 million for protecting members of Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. It says that during the eight years Noriega headed the armed forces, he sold at least eight government planes for $7 million, which he kept. It did not name any buyer. The suit also claims Noriega diverted $1.2 million in government agricultural funds to his own use. It claims government functionaries issued government checks for about $96 million to pay personal debts, and that $12 million of that amount went to Noriega. It also accuses Noriega of selling 2,000 illegal passports at $50,000 each. Panama's attorney general, Rogelio Cruz, is to go to Washington this week to further discuss the suit with the law firm of Williams & Connolly.

DOC.HEAD: Carter: Haiti Not Yet Ready for Elections
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ Former President Carter said Thursday that Haiti is not ready for elections because of a climate of fear following the return from exile of figures linked to the Duvalier regime. Carter spoke after meeting Haitian leaders who are struggling to lead this impoverished Caribbean nation toward its first free elections. ``At present, the climate ... is not conducive to holding elections,'' Carter said at a news conference. ``There's much doubt about security and much doubt that election laws will be followed.'' But Carter, wrapping up a two-day visit, said he thinks ``there will be the proper climate'' months before the scheduled Nov. 4 elections. Carter, heading a delegation sponsored by the Washington-based National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, met Wednesday with provisional President Ertha Pascal-Trouillot and Armed Forces commander Lt. Gen. Herard Abraham to discuss election security. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot was appointed provisional president in March after the ouster of military ruler Lt. Gen. Prosper Avril. At that time, there was great hope her civilian caretaker government could lead Haiti to democracy, but she is now viewed as exercising little control over the 6,000-member military. Haiti has been ruled by military force for most of its history since winning independence from France in 1804. Mrs. Pascal-Trouillot has requested the United Nations send 300 civilian and 40 military officials to monitor the vote. Carter said he believes the United Nations will approve that request. Carter has recently monitored elections in Panama, Nicaragua and the Dominican Republic. Carter also said he received assurances from the military they would serve a warrant for the arrest of Roger Lafontant. Lafontant, who returned to Haiti from exile in early July, reportedly headed the Tonton Macoutes private militia that enforced the Duvalier dictatorship for 29 years until Jean-Claude Duvalier was deposed in 1986. The return of Lafontant and other officials linked to brutal regimes has cast doubt a free and fair vote can occur. The return of Williams Regala, a retired army officer believed responsible for an election-day massacre in November 1987, has also alarmed Haitians. In the massacre, thugs backed by soldiers shot or hacked to death 34 voters. ``We've heard everywhere of the dangers of the presence of Roger Lafontant and Williams Regala,'' said Carter. He said he hoped Lafontant would ``leave the country and stay out of the country until after elections.'' He said Regala had indicated he would return to the United States, where he has been exiled. Lafontant has hired three laywers to fight a warrant and has told the Haitian media he wants to run for president.

DOC.HEAD: Last-Minute Provision Bars Drilling on Old Offshore Carolina Lease
With AM-Oil Spill a0776
DOC.TEXT: A provision that blocks drilling for natural gas and oil off the mid-Atlantic coast was tacked onto compromise oil spill legislation Thursday in a last minute maneuver that caught the petroleum industry by surprise. The drilling plans by Mobil Corp, which bought rights to leases 40 miles off the coast of Cape Hatteras nearly a decade ago, have been the focus of longstanding controversy in North Carolina. Mobil and several other oil companies have plans to drill the leases in expectations of finding significant amounts of natural gas. But Rep. Walter Jones, D-N.C., the chairman of a conference committee considering the oil spill bill, won approval from his colleagues for an amendment that would block such drilling for at least 14 months and could cause further complications for Mobil after that. The compromise bill then was approved by a voice vote. It now will be considered by both the House and Senate for final passage. Jones' amdendment, approved despite opposition from oil state congressmen, calls for no drilling by Mobil until additional environmental studies are undertaken by a scientific panel. It prohibits any leasing, oil drilling or exploratory activity in the offshore areas near North Carolina, South Carolina and part of Virginia before Oct. 1, 1991. Rep. Jack Fields, D-Texas, who has championed oil industry interests, argued against the measure and said he had been notified of Jones' plans to offer the amendment only hours before. ``This is a pure and simple moratorium,'' declared Rep. Ron Marlenee, R-Mont., also in opposition. He said he expects the provision to be challenged when the compromise oil spill bill comes up for final approval. The Senate members of the conference committee did not object to the measure. President Bush recently postponed oil lease sales along much of the U.S. coast where there have been environmental concerns. The mid-Atlantic lease areas, including the coastal area off North Carolina, were not included in Bush's action. ``This amendment establishes a fair process,'' said Jones in proposing his amendment as a concluding piece of business before the House-Senate conferees took a final vote on the oil spill legsilation. Jones said his amendment ``establishes an objective benchmark to assess the adequacy of environmental information'' about drilling in the mid-Atlantic areas of the Outer Continental Shelf. He said environmental impact studies used by Mobil are outdated. Mobil and several other oil companies bought the leases off the Carolinas in 1981 and 1983. In September 1988 Mobil announced plans to explore for natural gas in the area, prompting outcries from environmentalists and others in the region. Residents in the Cape Hatteras area have expressed concern about the impact drilling might have on tourism and recreational fishing. State officials have refused to allow Mobil to proceed, but Jones said there was fear the state might be overruled in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Food, Medicine Shipments Approved in Mohawk-Quebec Standoff
DOC.TEXT: Quebec's native affairs minister said Thursday that food and medicine will be allowed to circulate freely past police barricades at Oka and Kahnawake, where police and Mohawks are in the third week of a showdown. Police have drawn criticism from residents and human rights groups for long, rigorous searches of everyone going behind police lines at the two sites. Minister John Ciaccia told a news conference, ``There will be no restrictions in terms of the delivery of food. It has never been the policy of this government to do that. I want to clarify this once for all.'' Food supplies have sometimes run low in the Kahnawake reserve south of Montreal and in Oka, where a July 11 gun battle between Mohawks and provincial police left one officer dead and began the long siege. Blame in the death has not been fixed. Police were trying to remove barricades the Indians set up to protect a parcel of what they say is ancestral land, designated to become the back nine holes of the local golf course, 18 miles west of Montrteal. Other armed Mohawks have blockaded the Mercier Bridge to Montreal Island, forcing commuters into long detours, in sympathy with the Mohawks at Oka. Ciaccia said searches of people will continue, but no food will be confiscated and people will not be detained for hours as they try to get past with supplies. Red Cross relief convoys brought in some food and other basics, but the Mohawks complained it wasn't enough. Free passage of food was one condition laid down by the Mohawks to get negotiations going again. Another condition was unimpeded access to Mohawk positions by their advisers and lawyers. Ciaccia has not agreed to that. Tom Siddon, the federal Indian Affairs minister, indicated to reporters in Ottawa that the federal and Quebec governments may be on the road to defusing the crisis. But he suggested federal efforts to work out a land deal now must be matched by provincial efforts to resolve police and security issues with the Mohawks. Federal and Quebec officials, the town of Oka and French developer Maxime Rousseau, who owns some of the disputed land, have reportedly been working on a deal that would see Canada buy the land and hand it over to the Mohawks. Area residents have expressed fear for their lives and property in the event of another clash. But Maj. Gerald Baril, public relations officer for the army in Quebec, told a news conference in Montreal the Canadian army has no plans for any attacks on Mohawk barricades in the area. Baril said Quebec has not asked for military intervention ``and there is no indication they will ask.''

DOC.HEAD: Suspected Death Toll Climbs to 41 in Drug Cult Slayings
DOC.TEXT: Police investigating a satanic cult said Thursday they believe the group has killed at least 41 people in human sacrifices to protect their marijuana crop. Authorities said they had seized a leather quiver with 41 arrows. They quoted the cult leader's chief aide as saying each arrow represents the spirit of a person killed. Fourteen men and boys suspected of participating in the occult rites were arrested Thursday and placed in a Nayarit state prison in the state capital of Tepic after making statements to authorities. Police said they arrested the group Tuesday as cult members were cultivating marijuana near Acaponeta in the remote mountain region on the border of Nayarit and Durango states 450 miles northwest of Mexico City. Group members are being held for homicide, arms possession, criminal association and drug charges. Police said Wednesday they suspected the group was responsible slaying people in devil-worshipping rituals reminiscent of the Palo Mayombe religion from the Congo in Africa. Police said the group sacrificed its victims before a 16-inch clay monkey they called ``El Amigo,'' or ``The Friend.'' They said they had not yet unearthed any bodies. But they said they found a dagger and bloodstains in caves. However, alleged cult leader Olayo Soto Soto told The Associated Press on Thursday he is not a devil worshiper. ``Those are rumors and lies of the authorities,'' Soto said in an interview at police headquarters before being taken to jail. His right-hand man, Esteban Mendoza Cervantes, 19, testified that each of the 41 arrows in police possession represents the spirit a victim sacrificed in rituals carried on since 1983, Nayarit district attorney's investigator Jose Fernando Armas Hernandez said. The arrows appeared to be tipped in blood. In an earlier drug-cult case, police in April 1989 found 15 bodies buried on a ranch near the northern city of Matamoros across the U.S.-Mexico border from Brownsville, Texas. They claimed the victims were slain by drug smugglers who believed human sacrifices would protect them from police. Four members of that group are on trial in Mexico City and Matamoros. Group leader Adolfo de Jesus Constanzo and his bodyguard died of gunshot wounds as police closed in on them in a Mexico City apartment in May 1989.

DOC.HEAD: House Approves D.C. Budget With Funds For Abortion
By LeROY TILLMAN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The House on Thursday left intact funds for abortions in the District of Columbia but cut money for the city's university in what officials there say is a dispute over art and obscenity. The spending bill, allocating $542 million for fiscal 1991, was adopted by a 241-178 vote. Provisions allowing abortions for poor women in the nation's capital were included in the resolution without a floor fight, even though President Bush has repeatedly threatened to veto such a measure and has successfully done so in the past. City funds, not federal money, would be used to pay for such operations, said Rep. Chris Smith, R-N.J. ``D.C. funds pay for abortions upon demand. The language was included even though the city budget got sent back to Congress twice last year because of White House opposition to the inclusion of abortion language,'' he said. The House also voted 297-123 in favor of an amendment by Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., to cut $1.6 million from the $94.8 million appropriation for the University of the District of Columbia. That amount matches a bond issue approved by the City Council that would pay for renovation of the Carnegie Library in downtown Washington where the sculpture ``The Dinner Party'' by feminist artist Judy Chicago is to be permanently displayed. The ceramic piece depicts a large triangular table that contains female genitalia on 39 place settings. The university's Board of Trustees approved spending $80,000 of school funds to transport the work from California, where it is stored, to Washington. Nira Hardon Long, chairwoman of the university trustees, said the acquisition of the sculpture would serve as the centerpiece of the school's endowment. She called the expenditure ``seed money.'' ``This has no bearing on the university's ability to pay its employees,'' she said at the news conference announcing the acquisition of the sculpture. Parris disputed that, saying that several critics had called the work obscene, and also that the university was lagging in paying its employees. ``I have no quarrel with people who like the sculpture and I have no desire to act as a censor,'' he said. The Senate still has to take up the bill.

DOC.HEAD: Dizzy Gillespie, Katharine Hepburn Among Kennedy Center Honorees
DOC.TEXT: Five outstanding performing artists were selected Thursday as winners of the 1990 Kennedy Center Honors for their contributions to the cultural life of the nation. Chosen by the board of trustees of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts were jazz trumpeter Dizzy Gillespie, actress Katharine Hepburn, opera singer Rise Stevens, composer Jule Steyne and film director and writer Billy Wilder. The five will be honored at a black-tie gala performance in the Kennedy Center Opera House on Dec. 2, which will be taped for broadcast later as a two-hour CBS TV special. President and Mrs. Bush will salute the honorees at a White House ceremony before the gala. Kennedy Center Chairman James D. Wolfensohn said the five were honored ``for enriching all our lives through their lifelong dedication to their art.'' The 13th annual honors gala is the Kennedy Center's biggest fund-raising event of the year. Proceeds will support performing arts education, public service programming and discount tickets for students and the elderly.

DOC.HEAD: Continental to Start In-Flight Entertainment
DOC.TEXT: Stand-up comedians and business lecturers will entertain passengers on Continental Express flights next month between Detroit and Cleveland. The 30-passenger flights, which take 45 minutes from gate to gate, spend 17 minutes in the air, too little time for travelers to accomplish serious business, Continental Express spokesman Steve Mason said. Business executives from Cleveland and Detroit will give the lectures on mornings flights from Aug. 6-10. Topics will include illiteracy in the workplace and trends in radio and television, said carrier spokeswoman Nancy Compel. Professional comedians will entertain during afternoon flights the same week. The entertainment, good only on flights between Cleveland and Detroit City Airport, won't increase the $280 round-trip price, Compel said. Continental Express is the commuter division of Continental Airlines. ``We're doing it to call attention to the fact that Continental has the service,'' Compel said.

DOC.HEAD: In Newton, Support Shown for Frank
With AM-Frank Ethics
DOC.TEXT: Constituents and colleagues in the 4th Congressional District had mixed reactions to the reprimand issued to U.S. Rep. Barney Frank Thursday, but many remained supportive of their congressman. ``I'm torn,'' said Nicole Tufo, 21, who was jogging through Newton Thursday. ``I think what he did was wrong but I guess I feel bad for him.'' Newton City Clerk Edward G. English said Thursday he still supports Frank. English cited a letter the congressman wrote him in 1981 congratulating him for 10 years of public service. ``At a time when so many negative things are being said about people in public life, it is important to remind people, especially young people, that public service can be a noble cause,'' the letter read. ``I think he still believes in those principles,'' English said. The House voted Thursday to reprimand Frank, D-Mass., for using his influence on behalf of a male prostitute. The 408-18 vote imposed the lightest punishment the full House could have given. Frank apologized to the House and told a hushed chamber he was being punished, in part, for actions he took to ``conceal my homosexuality'' at a time when he had not yet made his gay lifestyle public. Others expressed hope that the incident would finally be over. ``I'm sad for Barney,'' said Newton Mayor Thomas Mann. ``I'm sad for everybody that's gone through so much. I wonder how well others would have taken this. It's a very sad experience for all of us.'' Brookline resident Kathi Sadow, who was shopping at a local mall Thursday, praised Frank despite the House action. ``I'm pleased he was just reprimanded even though I have some concerns about the whole thing. He's an extremely good congressman who showed extremely bad judgment and we'll vote for him again.'' Tom Dole, a Framingham mechanic, paused outside his garage and said he did not support Frank. ``You got to look at it this way,'' he said. ``What did they do to Gerry Studds? They're all crooks. I wouldn't vote for him. I wouldn't vote for any Democrat.'' Dole was referring to U.S. Rep. Studds, D-Mass., the only other acknowledged homosexual member of the House, who was censured in 1983 for sexual relations with a male congressional page. Ina Gibson of Roxbury echoed the sentiments of many as she praised Frank. ``Barney Frank has been a very good politician,'' she said. ``I think he's done a good job. His personal life is his own business as far as I'm concerned. But George Fattell, of Brighton, said House representatives were ``too lenient.'' ``I think he should have been censured,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Lawyer: Black Leaders Targeted By FBI Team
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 12th graf: ``Asked about,'' with comment from Young spokesman
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has a team of agents that targeted Julian Bond, Andrew Young and other black leaders for undercover sting operations, Marion Barry's lawyer said Thursday at the mayor's cocaine and perjury trial. R. Kenneth Mundy said the team operated in Atlanta, Chicago and California as well as during the Jan. 18 sting in which Barry was arrested after being videotaped smoking crack cocaine. The FBI initially said it would be inappropriate to comment on an ongoing trial, but the agency later issued a statement that said Mundy's allegations were ``totally unfounded and categorically denied.'' After testimony ended for the day, Barry told reporters as he left the courtroom: ``I got the impression that Stern is notorious for going around the country trying to sting black elected officials.'' Mundy's contentions came as the defense neared the end of its case, questioning agent Ronald Stern, one of the participants in the Barry sting. The defense spent the day trying to prove the FBI had entrapped Barry. ``Stern in effect moves around the country as the head of an ... assault force of FBI agents,'' Mundy said during in a bench conference. The jury could not hear the discussion, and U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson refused to allow Mundy to question Stern about the allegations. Mundy said he wanted to put his comments on the record in case there was an appeal in the case. ``Prior to coming here to organize and orchestrate the sting against Mr. Barry, Mr. Stern had been in Atlanta trying to set up a sting of Julian Bond, Andrew Young and two other black politicians and public figures in Atlanta,'' Mundy said. Alice Bond, then the wife of former Georgia state Sen. Julian Bond, told Atlanta police in 1987 that her estranged husband and other prominent officials had used cocaine. She recanted her story after a telephone conversation with then-Mayor Andrew Young. Bond denied using drugs and was never charged. Young, who faces an Aug. 7 runoff for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination, was criticized for calling Mrs. Bond. Asked about Mundy's statements, a spokesman for Young, Nehl Horton, said in Atlanta, ``We have no knowledge of that whatsoever.'' Mundy said the information came from two lawyers for government witnesses in the Barry case, a congressional office and a figure convicted in the HUD scandal. Mundy said the FBI approached a half-dozen women ``in the life of Mr. Barry'' and tried to get them to cooperate. ``Money was offered to them,'' but the women refused, Mundy said. The defese, Mundy said, had been prepared to present witnesses to back up his statements and that several black female FBI agents were offered the role of undercover agent but ``turned it down because ... they considered it to be morally repulsive.'' A law enforcement source, speaking on condition of anonymity, denied Mundy's assertions that other black agents turned down the sting operation or that a series of women were offered money to participate in an undercover operation against the mayor. Stern testified earlier that agents were ready to abandon the sting until the mayor suddenly asked for crack cocaine. An undercover agent carrying crack had left the room after Barry said he didn't want any, and ``as far as we were concerned, the operation was over,'' he said. ``Mr. Barry called them back into the room,'' Stern said. Barry was arrested after being videotaped smoking the crack. Stern said Barry was allowed to smoke the crack because to have stopped the operation before he did would have provided Barry ``too many possible defenses.'' ``He could have called his security agents and said: `This woman just gave me drugs. I want her arrested,''' Stern said. A federal prosecutor was in a nearby hotel room watching the operation and advised the agents that Barry taking the cocaine was not sufficient for an arrest, Stern said. Mundy claimed that sting operations are usually completed ``once the subject possesses the drugs.'' He has said the government endangered Barry's health by allowing him to ingest the drugs. Mundy said the FBI had pushed the case too far after Barry ``repeatedly'' denied opportunities to use drugs. But Stern said Barry brought up the subject of drugs as soon as he entered the room by asking former model Rasheeda Moore ``whether she had been good.'' ``Prior to the operation, Miss Moore told me Mr. Barry will ask if I've been good,'' Stern said. ``She told me that denotes drugs.'' Ms. Moore testified earlier that she and Barry used drugs ``over 100 times'' and had code words to refer to the drugs. Stern said that while they expected Barry to ``bring drugs to the room or ask for drugs after he got there,'' the government had some on hand as a contingency. Barry is charged with 10 counts of cocaine possession, three counts of perjury and one count of conspiracy. Jury selection for the trial began June 4.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Precede PANMUNJOM
North Korea Says Five of Its Civilians Crossing into South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with North saying civilians will be crossing into South on Friday. Picks up 12th graf, `Paik Nam ...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos SEL1,4,7
DOC.TEXT: A North Korean broadcast said Friday that five North Korean citizens will cross the heavily fortified border into South Korea during the day, officials said. On Thursday, Communist North and capitalist South agreed to have their prime ministers meet in an unprecedented attempt to end hostility, but within an hour of signing, a row over the border crossing had the nations trading insults again. The five were invited to Seoul for a two-day meeting to plan a joint unification rally with South Korean dissidents, scheduled for Aug. 15. It would be the first crossing by civilians with approval of both governments on the divided Korean peninsula since a 1985 family exchange. South Korean authorities quoted North Korea as saying the five will pass over at Panmunjom, the truce village in the Demilitarized Zone, and asking that they be met by the South Korean dissidents. South Korea cautioned it will allow the border crossing only if North Korea follows agreed-upon rules to coordinate crossings between the two governments. The five originally were expected to cross the border Thursday. They arrived at the frontier, but a last-minute glitch developed over Seoul's housing arrangements. South Korea wanted the group to stay in a luxury hotel, citing security reasons. The North Koreans wanted to stay with South Korean dissidents at a church house, and travel in the dissidents' cars. The outcome of that wrangle was not immediately disclosed. Name-calling, protests and rhetoric over the accommodations issue threatened to cloud the premiers' talks. North and South Korea were divided in 1945 at the end of World War II. Despite years of hostility and a three-year civil war in the early 1950s, unification of their homeland remains a cherished dream by Koreans on both sides of the border. ``A political show,'' said Lee Hae-hak, one of three South Korean dissident leaders who had gone to the truce village of Panmunjom to welcome the North Koreans. ``Down with (President) Roh Tae-woo who blocks unification!'' the dissidents shouted on Thursday after being told the border crossing was canceled. ``Our desire is unification,'' the three sang. But even then, South Korea's unification minister, Hong Sung-chul, insisted, ``Our door remains open.'' Paik Nam Jun, North Korea's chief delegate at the prime ministers' talks, warned that disputes over the unification rally could spill over into the premiers' talks. North Korean radio blasted South Korea for ``poking their nose into the rally ... and laying artificial hurdles to foil.'' The 19-point agreement for prime ministers' talks calls for the two sides to meet in Seoul Sept. 4-7, and again in the North's capital of Pyongyang Oct. 16-19. By signing the accord, North Korea's Communist government granted tacit recognition to the legitimacy of the Seoul government for the first time since separate governments were formed in 1948. ``This precious fruit will open a decisive chapter in a road to ending national division and achieving peaceful unification,'' said South Korean chief delegate Song Han-ho. Song's North Korean counterpart, Paik, said the agreement ``will open a new chapter in the history of the national division.'' The two prime ministers _ Kang Young-hoon of South Korea and Yon Hyung Muk of North Korea _ are ceremonial figureheads with little policy-making roles. But their meeting would be symbolically significant as they would be the highest-ranking officials of the rival states to ever meet. The outcome of the rally and the prime ministers' talks are seen as a gauge of future Korean relations. The rally would mark the first contact between civilian organizations of the two Koreas. In the past, South Korean authorities have blocked such contacts out of fear they could turn into radical anti-Seoul protests. Proposed sites for the rally include the capitals of either North or South Korea or Panmunjom. The Aug. 15 date is the 45th anniversary of the liberation of Korea from Japanese colonial rule and is a sentimental holiday on both sides of the border. South Korea offered last week to open its border to North Koreans for unrestricted travel for five days starting Aug. 13. It challenged North Korea to do the same for South Koreans. North Korea has said it would open the border on a limited basis on Aug. 15 to Koreans desiring unification.

DOC.HEAD: Marshall Suggests Souter Nomination Politically Motiviated
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 10th graf: ``Marshall did not,'' to show no details in interview
DOC.TEXT: Supreme Court Justice Thurgood Marshall says he is unsure what to make of President Bush's choice of David H. Souter for the high court, but suggested it is a politically motivated appointment dictated by a presidential aide. In an interview broadcast Thursday on ABC's ``Primetime Live,'' Marshall also said he would vote against Bush if he runs for re-election. ``It's said that if you can't say something good about a dead person, don't say it,'' Marshall said of Bush. ``Well, I consider him dead.'' Asked by interviewer Sam Donaldson why he thought Bush picked Souter to replace retired Justice William J. Brennan, Marshall replied: ``I don't have the slightest idea. Never heard of him (Souter). I just don't understand what he (Bush) is doing...This last appointment is the epitome of what he's been doing. I think somebody's calling his shots.'' Marshall said the Souter appointment might be the work of conservative White House Chief of Staff John Sununu, who as governor of New Hampshire put Souter on that state's Supreme Court. Marshall said when Souter's appointment was announced on TV, he turned to his wife and said, ``Have I ever heard of this man?'' He said he then called Brennan's home to find out whether he knew Souter. Marshall said Brennan's wife answered the phone and said Brennan ``never heard of him either.'' Asked about his feelings toward Bush, Marshall said, ``If he came up for election, I'd vote against him.'' Asked if he believes Bush is running for re-election, the justice said, ``I don't think he's ever stopped.'' Marshall did not detail what political considerations he thought might be underlying the Souter nomination. Marshall, 82, a staunch liberal ally of Brennan on the high court, has been outspoken in the past about another Republican president, Ronald Reagan. In a televised interview in 1987, Marshall said Reagan ``ranks at the bottom'' among U.S. presidents in terms of their civil rights records. In the ABC interview, which was conducted Wednesday in Marshall's office in the Supreme Court building, the justice said he expects to be voting in the minority a lot more because of Brennan's departure. ``There's nobody here that can persuade the way Brennan can persuade,'' Marshall said. ``Brennan will sit down and talk to you and show you where you're wrong. Well, there's nobody with that power on the court today. I say that Brennan cannot be replaced.'' Marshall also praised Brennan for his sense of humor and ability to deal with adversaries as friends. ``If you're wrong, he'll _ in the most gentle language _ let you down. There's not a vicious bone in his body. He's a real ... Bill's a gentleman,'' Marshall said. He added that he is not discouraged by Brennan's retirement. ``It's not going to slow me down at all,'' he said. ``I asked each one of my law clerks that I hired for this year ...`Do you mind writing dissenting opinions?''' Brennan announced his retirement last Friday, and Bush picked Souter to replace him on Monday. Before then, Souter was largely unknown outside of New Hampshire. Marshall also repeated what he has said many times before _ that he was appointed to a life term on the court and means to serve it. But, he said, ``I have a deal with my wife that when I begin to show any signs of senility, she'll tell me. And she will.'' Marshall also said one of the differences between him and Brennan is that ``He tells jokes. He doesn't tell dirty ones like I tell.''

DOC.HEAD: Explorer Awarded Libel Damages from Canadian Magazine
DOC.TEXT: Explorer Sir Ranulph Fiennes was awarded $181,000 in libel damages Wednesday for an article in the Canadian magazine Maclean's, which said his exploits achieved nothing of historical or scientific value. The magazine said it will appeal. A High Court jury in London took only 40 minutes to decide that Fiennes was justified in complaining that an article in the weekly magazine was ``nasty, mean-minded and spiteful.'' He asked the jury to ``nail the lie'' that his expeditionary efforts were valueless. The April 1988 article said: ``Prince Charles always supports him, claiming great results for British exports, but no one has ever been able to demonstrate that any scientific or historical benefits have resulted.'' The damages, and an estimated $135,750 in legal costs, were awarded against editor Kevin Doyle, journalist Allan Fotheringham and British publishers Maclean Hunter. The defendants denied the words bore any defamatory meaning. ``I feel completely vindicated. But I will have to wait for it to sink in properly,'' Fiennes, 46, said after the verdict. His wife, Virginia, who accompanied him on many expeditions, said: ``The damages are astonishingly high. We never expected anything like that.'' Judge Sir Michael Davies imposed a freeze order on all but $13,500 of the award, pending a possible appeal by the magazine on the issues of liability and damages. In Toronto, Doyle said an appeal has been filed. Doyle said of the amount awarded, ``I think the award was crazy. It was not commensurate with the words that were written. '' Fiennes flew home for the three-day trial from Dhofar in the Persian Gulf state of Oman, where he is preparing for an archaeological expedition in search of remains of the Sumerians, founders of the Babylonian culture in about 4000 B.C. He told the jury the article poked fun at him and his background, calling him a ``professional bore'' and a ``cadger of the first order.'' He said Maclean's sells 600,000 copies in Canada and only 400 in Britain, but it goes to the Foreign Office, foreign libraries and embassies. Summing up, the judge said the whole article might suggest that Fiennes was ``an upper class twit, not a real explorer but a bumbling playboy.'' Fiennes said there was danger that potential sponsors of his future expeditions would withdraw financial backing if they read the article. The explorer is a former army officer who has led expeditions to both poles, Sudan and Norway and one around the world's polar axis, as well as a score of research projects.

DOC.HEAD: Honduran Convicted of Kidnapping in Drug Agent's Death
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 9-10 pvs, `The trial...,' to ADD background on investigation, previous case. INSERTS 1 graf after 18th graf pvs, `But jurors...,' to UPDATE with sentencing date.
DOC.TEXT: A Honduran drug trafficker was found guilty Thursday of racketeering, kidnapping and conspiracy in the 1985 abduction of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena and his pilot, who were killed in Mexico. The jury that convicted Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros acquitted him of Camarena's murder, a crime that has strained relations between the United States and Mexico. Matta's lawyer, Martin Stolar, said outside court the verdict was inconsistent and showed ``jury confusion.'' Stolar told reporters he believed extensive testimony about drug trafficking and corruption in the Mexican government had distracted jurors from the main issue _ Camarena's killing _ and had created the confusion. He said he would appeal the convictions, and asked U.S. District Judge Edward Rafeedie to overrule the jury's findings. Matta was one of four defendants charged in the Camarena case, but the jurors did not return verdicts against the others. They didn't give a progress report on deliberations on the other three defendants, and Rafeedie told the they could return Friday to resume their deliberations. The 31-year-old Camarena was kidnapped off a street in Guadalajara, Mexico, in February 1985, tortured and interrogated by drug lords before being slain along with his Mexican pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar. After Camarena's battered body was discovered a month later, Mexican authorities eventually pinned the blame on Rafael Caro Quintero, a swaggering 29-year-old leader of the powerful Guadalajara drug cartel. Camarena's colleagues were skeptical that the reckless, illiterate ``Rafa'' had acted alone. The American authorities broadened their investigation to seek out the brains in the cartel, including members of Mexico's power elite and Matta, a wealthy Honduran businessman also known as ``El Negro.'' Prosecutors have said the cartel was incensed after Camarena's undercover work led to the November 1984 seizure of 10,000 tons of marijuana. The trial was the second stemming from Camarena's murder, a crime which angry U.S. authorities characterized as a reflection of official corruption in Mexico. Judge Rafeedie also presided over the first trial, which resulted in the conviction of three men in 1988. Disputes between Mexico and the United States over the case have erupted on several occasions throughout the investigation and trials. Earlier this month, Mexico said it would seek the extradition of a Los Angeles-based DEA agent and a Mexican informant who allegedly plotted the kidnapping of a Guadalajara doctor accused in the killing. Matta, a ealthy Honduran businessman, showed little reaction to the verdict, except to shake his head slightly as if in disbelief. Matta's stature in his native Honduras was such that his forced extradition in 1988 touched off street riots that left five people dead and torched the U.S. Embassy annex. Hondurans apparently were angered by the extradition and alarmed that Matta's prosecution might harm the nation's economy because he owned so many businesses. Tears streamed down the faces of his family, who sat in the courtroom as the verdicts were announced. Earlier this year, Matta was convicted by another jury of operating a cocaine smuggling business. Matta was convicted in the ninth day of jury deliberations on charges of racketeering in the kidnapping and murder of Camarena, conspiring to kidnap Camarena and the actual crime of kidnapping the agent and holding him for interrogation. But jurors rejected the count that charged Matta with actually murdering the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent. Sentencing was set for Sept. 25. Earlier, the jury had suggested in a note to the judge that some of the counts seemed to be convicting the defendant twice for the same crime _ a possible reason for the split verdict. Stolar insisted in his out-of-court statements that Matta was tried illegally, both in the Camarena case and in the earlier drug trafficking case, because he had been kidnapped from Tegucigalpa by American authorities. Stolar had filed numerous challenges based on Matta's arrest, and all were rejected on appeal. Matta has been serving a life sentence on the drug conviction. The DEA has vowed to capture every person involved in the slaying. So far, 22 people have been charged in this country and more than 20 convicted in Mexico. Among those held is Rafael Caro Quintero, alleged leader of the drug operation. The other defendants in the current trial, who were present during the reading of verdicts against Matta, were: Ruben Zuno Arce, a Guadalajara businessman who is the brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Jose Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican homicide officer and Javier Vasquez Velasco, a former bodyguard accused of murdering two American tourists in an apparent mistake killing.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Says Ethiopia Scrapping Communist Goal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, to UPDATE with comments after meeting; SUBS throughout to CORRECT second references to Ethopian names; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Ethiopia's foreign minister said Thursday the East African country is abandoning communist goals and wants to improve relations with the United States. Foreign Minister Tesfaye Dinka also accused Eritrean insurgents, who control parts of Northern Ethiopia of blocking food relief shipments to Ethiopians threatened with starvation as a result of the 29-year rebellion. He appealed for international pressure for the rebels to relent. The accusation echoed a statement earlier this week by Andrew Natsios, an American disaster assistance official, who said the rebels had closed Massawa port to a food-laden Danish freighter flying the U.N. flag. Tesfaye's comments came at a news conference prior to his meeting with Deputy Secretary of State Lawrence Eagleburger, marking one of the highest-level U.S.-Ethiopian talks in a decade. Later, Tesfaye called called his one-hour meeting with Eagleburger ``an important milestone'' toward improving relations long downgraded in disagreement over human rights abuses in Ethiopia. The foreign minister denied ``any kind of linkage'' between a supply of weapons from Israel to Ethiopian Jews being allowed to emigrate. He said Ethiopia had not received any arms from Israel since reopening relations with the Jewish state last November. The Ethiopian and Israeli governments are in ``complete understanding'' on the emigration issue and the flow of emigrants is continuing, he said. A U.S. official, who insisted on anonymity, said that a reported supply of Israeli weapons for Ethiopia was limited to rifles and did not include cluster bombs which Ethiopia was said to be seeking for use against the rebels. The Ethiopian government, led by Mengistu Haile Mariam, is undertaking economic and political changes that will result in a market-oriented economy, greater incentives for domestic and foreign investors and political diversity, Tesfaye said. He said 65 percent to 70 percent of Ethiopia's economy always had been operated by an entrenched private sector. Perestroika, the Soviet reform policy, helped influence the changes in Ethiopia, he said, adding that relations with Moscow remain good. Tesfaye said he was hopeful of improved U.S.-Ethiopian relations after a meeting Wednesday with Assistant Secretary of State Herman Cohen. The two governments have maintained low-level diplomatic relations without ambassadors for the past 10 years amid disagreement over repression and human rights abuse in Ethiopia.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Juror Who Admits Calling Drug Lords
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th graf pvs to fix garble.
DOC.TEXT: A juror who phoned members of the Medellin drug cartel was kicked off a panel deciding a $32 million drug money-laundering case Thursday, but the remaining 11 jurors continued deliberating. U.S. District Judge WIlliam Terrell Hodges scolded the juror, Robert ``Skip'' Spanczak, but decided the incident wasn't prejudicial enough to declare a mistrial in the case of five international bankers and a Colombian associated with the Bank of Credit and Commerce International. ``It was simply curiosity on my part and nothing happened,'' Spanczak, a 54-year-old Clearwater limousine driver, explained to the judge during a three-hour hearing. ``Nothing came of this, you know. ... No real bad intent was meant.'' Hodges sent Spanczak home with a warning not to talk about the case until a verdict is reached, but decided against charging him with contempt of court. But he immediately sequestered the 11 remaining members of the panel, which has sat through more than six months of testimony and was in its fifth day of deliberations. In Spanczak's account, released in court transcripts, he admitted making a call to Colombia on Friday, the first day of jury deliberations. He said he dialed a number taken from an address book that authorities seized from one of the defendants, Rudolf Armbrecht of Colombia, when Armbrecht was arrested in October 1988. Prosecutors introduced the book as evidence, and testimony indicated the numbers belonged to members of the drug cartel. Spanczak said a Spanish-speaking man answered and later passed the phone to a man who spoke broken English. When the juror asked to speak about Armbrecht, the reply was ``No, no, no.'' But jurors said they received a different version of Spanczak's call when he told them about it over lunch. They said the voice on the phone simply told him to destroy the number and never call again. Another juror told the FBI that Spanczak conducted his own investigation of Armbrecht because he once said ``he would do anything it took to nail this guy.'' The jurors husband reported the incident to the FBI, which reportedly relayed the information to the U.S. Attorney's office and the judge. Attorneys and defendants in the case refused to comment on the judge's decision to proceed with the case because a gag order has been in effect since the beginning of the trial. The Bank of Credit and Commerce International officials were arrested Oct. 6, 1988, at a bachelor party and wedding staged by the U.S. Customs Service to lure them to Tampa. They are accused of conspiring with an undercover Customs agent to launder $14 million in proceeds from the sale of cocaine in six U.S. cities. During the two-year investigation, the government processed $32 million in partnership with a Medellin cash launderer. Two subsidiaries of the Luxembourg-based bank, known as BCCI, pleaded guilty in January to the money-laundering charges and forfeited $15 million to the government, by far the largest laundering penalty ever assessed against a bank. The defendants in the case are Ian Howard and Sibte Hassan of BCCI's Paris branch; Amjad Awan, who is from a prominent Pakistani family; and Akbar A. Bilgrami of the bank's Miami branch; Syed Aftab Hussain, who worked in Panama; and the Colombian aircraft broker, Armbrecht. Awan has claimed to be deposed Panamanian ruler Manuel Noriega's personal banker.

Apparently successful in intimidating Kuwait into ending oil overproduction, Iraq has agreed to pull thousands of troops back from the countries' disputed border and negotiate, diplomatic sources say. Official Iraqi newspapers suddenly stopped their daily attacks on Kuwait today. Diplomatic sources said late Wednesday that tens of thousands of troops reportedly sent to the border earlier this week by President Saddam Hussein would begin withdrawing today. But Saddam has not backed down on demands that Kuwait cut oil production, pay for oil Baghdad claims was pumped illegally from a field that straddles the countries' border and forgive billions of dollars in loans. Oil-rich Iraq, strapped for cash after a fall in crude prices and a costly war with Iran, last week threatened military action against fellow oil producers Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates for contributing to the overproduction that has driven down the price of crude.

It might have been a tribute to an honored elder statesman, so lavish was the praise _ and not the unanimous condemnation of a senator for deliberately breaking Senate rules. The Senate voted 96-0 Wednesday to denounce Sen. Dave Durenberger for financial wrongdoing. But first, senators called the Minnesota Republican a man of conscience, of influence, of decency. Afterward they lined up to hug him, shake his hand and pat his shoulder. He is, after all, one of them. And, as Sen. Bill Armstrong, R-Okla., put it, ``After this is all over and we denounce him, we still want him to be our friend.''

As a state judge nine years ago, Supreme Court nominee David Souter urged New Hampshire's legislature not to adopt a law that would have empowered judges to approve abortions for minors if their parents refuse permission. Souter did not express a personal stand on the issue, but said his fellow judges had decided that a measure then pending before the state legislature would promote ``shopping for judges'' because it did not include guidelines on how judges should act. Therefore, he said, the bill would unfairly leave such decisions up to individual judges with varied opinions on abortion, resulting in inconsistent application of any such law. The 1981 letter, written to the chairwoman of the legislative committee considering a parental consent bill, is one of Souter's few public actions addressing the abortion issue. In his one abortion-related decision on the issue as a judge, Souter gave little insight as to how he might vote if confirmed and confronted with the opportunity to overturn the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision legalizing abortion.

North and South Korea signed a historic agreement today calling for their prime ministers to meet for talks aimed at easing four decades of Cold War confrontation on the divided peninsula. The planned fall talks would be the first of their kind since 1948 and would focus on easing political and military tensions, promoting exchanges and other moves toward cooperation between the two long-hostile states. By signing the accord, the North Korean government of Kim Il Sung tacitly recognized the legitimacy of the Seoul government of President Roh Tae-woo, a recognition denied since the rival countries were formed 42 years ago. ``This precious fruit will open a decisive chapter in a road to ending national division and achieving peaceful unification,'' said South Korean chief delegate Song Han-ho.

NASA's failure to fix Atlantis' hydrogen leak bumped another shuttle flight into 1991. A team of NASA experts, meanwhile, began looking into the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope's woes. But the space agency also got a bit of good news Wednesday: A thrice-delayed launch of an unmanned Atlas rocket went off without a flaw. ``It's good to have something positive happen,'' NASA spokesman Jim Cast said. ``It's a definite boost to NASA morale.'' After three postponements due to mechanical problems and bad weather, the rocket blasted into space with a NASA and Air Force satellite that will study electric and radiation fields far above Earth.

Eastern Airlines may have put thousands of passengers at risk by falsifying jet maintenance records, federal prosecutors said in announcing indictments against the carrier and nine of its managers. Eastern, struggling to rebuild in bankruptcy court after a bitter strike, replied that corrective actions have been taken and the airline now is safe. Federal regulators agreed. Unprecedented in the airline industry, the 60-count indictment unsealed Wednesday charged Eastern and high-level managers with conspiring to falsify safety and maintenance records to avoid flight delays and cancellations. ``The motivation was to get the airplanes into the air. An airline only makes money with planes in the air,'' said Andrew J. Maloney, a U.S. attorney in New York.

Emergency workers and bystanders showered in the middle of a busy street to wash off a powdery residue, 22 people were taken to the hospital and two federal agencies are investigating. A major chemical spill? No, a minor rear-end auto accident in which one car's air bag deployed. ``Nobody at the scene had a handle on the procedures for the situation and there were a lot of people there with a lot of emergency experience,'' said Jeff Wells, who heads the ambulance service in neighboring Weehawken. Federal transportation and consumer officials say that the hysteria was unnecessary and that the incident in this New York City suburb points up the need for rescue workers to learn how to handle accidents involving air bags, standard equipment in about 3 million 1990 cars.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv03
For Release PMs Friday Aug 2 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Medellin Police Suspected Of Kidnapping, Torture and Murder ^LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: Some policemen react to the slaughter of comrades by the drug lords' hired killers with the midnight knock, torture and summary executions, say witnesses and relatives of civilian victims. A teen-ager in a Medellin slum said he was standing on a corner a few weeks ago when a car roared up and screeched to a halt. ``Some men jumped out and tried to shove me into the trunk,'' he said. ``I fought back and managed to get away when neighbors of my family started screaming.'' Hundreds of other slum youngsters suspected of taking drug money to kill policemen have been less fortunate. More than 200 policemen in the Medellin area have been killed this year in a war between the cocaine cartel and security forces. No official figures are available on slain teen-agers, but the weekly news magazine La Semana said in its July 16 edition that Medellin death squads had killed about 1,500 people in 1990. Mayor Omar Florez of Medellin said there was little doubt some policemen and soldiers were violating human rights. ``Security forces who act outside the law are aggravating the state of violence and must be held accountable for their actions,'' he said in an interview. So far, the central government in Bogota has been unwilling or unable to stop the killings, which occur almost daily. People are snatched from the streets of slums and their bodies, bound hand and foot, often turn up in vacant lots or along highways. The attorney general's office has concluded in the past that policemen were involved in death squads. Medellin police deny the accusations and say most of the killings result from gang rivalry. Emilio Suarez, a 62-year-old resident of Medellin, said of the war between drug traffickers and police: ``You in the United States see this as a battle of the good guys against the bad guys, but we view it as the bad guys against the bad guys.'' A woman who lives in the El Playon slum spoke tearfully of her 15-year-old son, now dead: ``The law itself killed my boy. He was just a regular, hard-working high school student. That boy was my last hope. We are poor, and I was counting on him for survival.'' She and many others interviewed asked that their names not be used. They were afraid of being killed by one side or the other. Death squad activity has diluted public confidence in the authorities. ``The fact that officials have so little support from the people explains their failure in smashing the drug trade,'' a human rights activist said. He said the human rights organization he leads had scores of reports of murder, disappearances and torture committed by policemen and soldiers. People are blindfolded, hanged by the neck, beaten with sticks or forced to spend the night with bags over their heads while being questioned, he said. ``The army and police have become a symbol of death,'' the activist declared. ``They are carrying out a policy of extermination.'' He asked not to be identified because his three predecessors were murdered. Mayor Florez has invited victims of police abuse to speak out and press charges. ``We are trying to reach the people to tell them they can come to us, the mayor's office, for help, but they are mostly keeping quiet because a climate of terror has been created here,'' he said.. The mother of the murdered 15-year-old said she was too frightened to step forward because ``I have been told that I too would be killed if I say anything.'' President Virgilio Barco has been praised abroad for the crackdown on drug traffickers he began a year ago, but domestic critics say his emergency measures opened the way to human rights violations. Cesar Gaviria, the president elect, told reporters recently the government cannot fight the drug war with repression alone. ``The country's gravest problem now is violence in Medellin and this will require special treatment from my government, a treatment that transcends just military, police and public order measures,'' he said. Gaviria, who takes office Aug. 7, pledged to support Florez's $100 million plan for rebuilding poor neighborhoods in this city of 2 million people.
