Julio Jaramillo, a priest who recently published a study of Medellin violence, said the president and national security chiefs still had enough public support to bring offending policemen to justice. Many ranking officers have been replaced during an ambitious reorganization of the army and police begun in June. Florez said the shakeup would demonstrate that the government's intentions were good and ``will create an atmosphere which will allow people to trust authorities again.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Friday Aug 3

DOC.HEAD: NY GEN-pls tally
DOC.NOTE: $adv30
For Release MON PMs Jul 30 and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Schneider vs. Pell _ Personalities Aside, They're Similar People
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 19th graf, Pell supported, to CORRECT title to Providence Business News sted Providence Business Journal
DOC.TEXT: Rhode Island's U.S. Senate race is a study in contrasts and a contest between soulmates. It is a matchup between two very different individuals with very similar voting records. Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell is 71. His GOP challenger, Rep. Claudine Schneider, is 43. Pell is a dignified, soft-spoken man, usually with a rumpled suit draped over his tall, bony frame. Miss Schneider is a zealous, energetic woman given to wearing brightly colored dresses and known more by her first name than her last. ``The ideological differences between them are subtle, if any,'' says Washington analyst Charles Cook. ``Name one member of Congress who's like either one of them,'' Cook said. ``You can't.'' Although intense campaigning won't begin until Labor Day, Pell has the early advantage. He held a 51 percent to 36 percent lead over Miss Schneider in a recent Brown University poll, a lead that has grown since an earlier survey in February. The latest poll had a margin of error of plus or minus 5 percentage points. Pell also has the edge at the bank. As of June 30, his warchest was double that of Miss Schneider's _ $1.3 million to $627,000. But those numbers could change quickly in a race where both candidates have popularity ratings higher than 80 percent. Neither candidate has any opposition in Rhode Island's Sept. 11 primary. Even when it comes to the paranormal, there aren't many distinctions between the two candidates. Both have been called a bit eccentric because of their well-publicized affinities for such subjects _ Pell for his interest in UFOs and Miss Schneider for hers in astrology. It is a race where both candidates have pledged to keep themselves out of the negative-campaigning gutter _ each has aired commercials that don't mention the other's name. Last week, Miss Schneider launched the first real offensive of the campaign. But rather than call Pell a liar, she politely asked him to ``correct misleading information'' about a Social Security proposal. Nor does she have a monopoly on manners. Pell ordered his campaign manager, Mary Beth Cahill, to call Miss Schneider's campaign to inform them that his first commercial would be airing the next day. ``I was stunned,'' said Ellen Conaway, Miss Schneider's campaign manager. ``In all my years in the business I've never seen anyone telegraph their moves like that.'' ``I expect as positive a campaign as both of us can wage. I know it will be on my side,'' Pell said. ``I've always sought to talk about my own plans, not to mention or be critical of my adversary. Except for correcting my record, I would not want to go negative myself.'' Miss Schneider's challenge is to attract Democratic votes in a heavily Democratic state. She has done it in the past, but not against Pell. ``After 10 years in the House,'' she told a meeting of Pawtucket Rotarians recently, ``I am of the opinion that if I can't be in a position of greater power ... I do not want to remain in public service.'' The senator's camp believes Miss Schneider can't give voters a good reason to make the switch. Voters hoping to find some clarity in the candidates' voting records are out of luck. Miss Schneider, long considered a GOP maverick, voted against President Bush more often than did Pell. Pell supported Bush's position 51 times in 1989 and opposed the White House 48 times, according to the Providence Business News. Miss Schneider voted with the administration 38 times, and opposed it on 56 occasions. Miss Schneider is a firm believer in the adage of former House Speaker Thomas P. ``Tip'' O'Neill that ``all politics is local,'' a line she repeats often. Pell, on the other hand, is chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, a prestigious post but not one that lends itself to local politics. Therefore, Pell plays up his work in education. It's hard to find a college student or graduate who hasn't heard of Pell grants, a source of federal aid for millions of needy students. It's been a long time since either candidate faced serious competition. Pell won with 73 percent of the vote in 1984 and 75 percent in 1978. Miss Schneider lost to Democratic Rep. Edward Beard in 1978, but beat him two years later and her winning margins have increased steadily since. In 1986 and 1988, she won re-election with 72 percent of the vote.

DOC.HEAD: `American Masters' Looks at the Life and Times of Edward R. Murrow
DOC.TEXT: It is time for another generation to learn about Edward R. Murrow, a CBS newsman who died 25 years ago. And there is no better way to begin than with ``Edward R. Murrow: This Reporter'' airing Monday nights on PBS' series ``American Masters'' for the next two weeks. Director Susan Steinberg and writer Ed Apfel wisely let Murrow's story tell itself, with archival footage and interviews with his colleagues, friends and family. It's narrated by the gorgeous beefsteak voice of Charles Kuralt. ``This Reporter'' is a definitive TV portrait of America's greatest broadcast journalist. Murrow personified the highest standards of his craft and ended his 22-year career as its conscience and its prophet. Murrow's broadcast career began in 1937, when he was a CBS news executive sent to Europe to set up a network of correspondents to cover the gathering storm. From the start, he insisted on good reporters, not professional announcers. ``Murrow's Boys,'' who included Eric Sevareid, Howard K. Smith, Charles Collingwood, William Shirer, Richard C. Hottelet and Bill Shadel, reported World War II from all fronts. Murrow, though, became the greatest of them. ``This ... is London,'' his deep, resonant baritone reported from the embattled city at the height of the Blitz, electrifying the U.S. radio audience in the days before this country entered World War II. After the war, with the advent of television, he and his colleagues learned the new medium, virtually inventing the form of TV news documentary. Murrow's high, furrowed brow and ever-present cigarette _ he smoked three or four packs a day _ were trademarks of his weekly prime time news show ``See It Now,'' which began in 1951. He took television to cover its first war, Korea in 1952. In 1953, ``See It Now'' reported the case of an Air Force officer who was discharged on the grounds that his father and sister were communist sympathizers. Public reactions forced the officer's reinstatement. ``It was the first time, I think, that Ed and all of us understood the power of television,'' said Murrow's longtime producer Fred W. Friendly, who went on to head CBS News. Murrow's career peaked in March 1954, when ``See It Now'' reported on Sen. Joseph McCarthy, R-Wis., and his demagogic, Red-baiting investigation of alleged Communist infiltration of the U.S. government. Murrow's wrapup: ``The actions of the junior senator from Wisconsin have caused alarm and dismay amongst our allies abroad and given considerable comfort to our enemies, and whose fault is that? Not really his. He didn't create this situation of fear; he merely exploited it, and rather successfully. Cassius was right: `The fault, dear Brutus, is not in our stars but in ourselves.''' Then, brow furrowed, Murrow ended with his trademark closing: ``Goodnight and good luck.'' It was one of the greatest moments in television history. It marked the beginning of the end for McCarthyism. And it marked the beginning of Murrow's downfall. He had become too powerful and CBS knew it. Over the next six years his declining health let the network erode his power and influence. No journalist ever again will be as powerful. In a 1958 speech, Murrow accused television of breaking its promise: ``If this instrument is good for nothing but to entertain, amuse and insulate, then the tube is flickering now and we will soon see that the struggle is lost,'' he said. ``This instrument can teach, it can illuminate, yes, and even it can inspire. But it can do so only to the extent that humans are determined to use it to those ends. Otherwise it's nothing but wires and lights in a box.'' Murrow died of lung cancer on April 27, 1965. As Eric Sevareid said on that day, ``He was a shooting star; we will live in his afterglow a very long time.''

Elsewhere in television ... FURTHER EVIDENCE THAT MURROW WAS RIGHT: Words like ``shudderingly hideous,'' ``stupid'' and ``awful'' just bubble right out of people who've seen ``Room for Romance,'' a one-hour anthology series starting on CBS tonight. It's brought to you by Douglas S. Cramer, who's partly to blame for ``Love Boat.'' The publicity says the show's about ``the happy, poignant, romantic and humorous situations facing residents of an upscale apartment building.'' Right. And ``Love Boat'' was an epic of the sea. Rebecca Harrell plays an awful, precocious, wise-cracking kid. Dom Irrerra plays a sardonic concierge. Don Novello (best known as Father Guido Sarducci) was supposed to play him, but must have seen the script. ``Room for Romance'' takes dead aim on issues of the day. Unfortunately, the day is sometime in the '70s, and the issues are superstition, breaking up and living with your fiancee. It's so stupid it'll take points off your IQ. You have been warned.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Hopes Traditionally Democratic `Dog' Won't Hunt
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The strong turnout was reflected in Clayton Williams' broad grin. It was 9 a.m. on a weekday morning, and more than 150 people were gathered on the tree-shaded lawn of the Cumberland Presbyterian Church to meet Williams, the Republican candidate for governor. ``That,'' he said, ``is great.'' ``It's the biggest gathering for a Republican candidate ever since we've been here _ about 20 years,'' said Harry Bartlett, whose son, Steve, is a GOP congressman from Dallas. ``This is a very strong Democratic county.'' Williams is a West Texas oilman-rancher who wants East Texas votes. To get them, he knows he must attract ``Yellow Dog'' Democrats _ party loyalists whom legend says would vote for a yellow dog as long as it ran as a Democrat. Stumping in churchyards, restaurants and courthouse squares on a recent campaign swing, Williams offers them a handshake, a speech, a little barbecue, and what he hopes will be a winning message. ``I'm a farmer. I'm a rancher. I grew up in a small town. Small-town values, old-fashioned values, are still the horse I believe is the one to ride,'' he said. ``I probably more truly represent what Texans think they need and what they want in a governor.'' The Texas governor's office is one of the top prizes of the 1990 elections. Texas stands to pick up three or four U.S. House seats from redistricting based on the results of the 1990 census, and both parties want to have the governor on their side when the lines are redrawn. Republican Gov. Bill Clements is retiring. Williams jumped out to an early lead in the race but his Democratic rival, two-term state Treasurer Ann Richards, is putting up a spirited fight to narrow the gap. Williams' foray into the Democratic stronghold of East Texas is part of his strategy to woo the rural votes that will play a big role in selecting Texas' next governor. In his campaign speeches, Williams discusses a string of issues he believes give him a ``values'' edge over Richards. _ Abortion. He's opposed except in cases of rape, incest and danger to a mother's life. He wants a law requiring parents to consent before a minor daughter could obtain an abortion. _ Gun control. No more laws. ``We need to keep our guns,'' he said. _ Flag-burning. ``It makes my blood boil,'' he said. _ Crime. Williams promises to double the number of prison cells and introduce youthful offenders to ``the joys of bustin' rocks.'' That line from his TV commercials is so popular, audiences shout it out before he does. ``I'm here in East Texas appealing to people whose values are my values ... I have a lot in common with the folks here,'' he said. The 29-county East Texas region is Democratic territory. Williams was reminded at a stop in Gilmer that no GOP candidate had won a county office in a half century. But Republicans say they are making inroads. In the 1984 U.S. Senate race, Republican Phil Gramm carried 18 of the counties. In 1986, Democratic Gov. Mark White lost the region to Clements. ``Philosophically, the people of East Texas are very conservative,'' said state GOP Chairman Fred Meyer. ``Their values are very much the values of the Republican Party. But they've got a little more of that yellow dog tradition.'' With Gramm seeking re-election and Williams hitting small towns, Meyer is optimistic. ``Frankly, our organization has been a little weaker in East Texas than many other areas of the state ... But whatever we've done in the past, we're going to do better this time,'' he said. Democrats say they are taking nothing for granted, and Richards is working hard to win East Texas votes. ``It's an important region for victory for anybody running statewide,'' said Richards campaign consultant Glenn Smith. ``She's been there a lot.'' Ed Martin, executive director of the Texas Democratic Party, said East Texans won't change parties just because Republicans call themselves the conservatives. ``East Texans are conservative, but they're also populists. They think government ought to work for the little guy, for working people,'' Martin said. ``The Republicans aren't conservative. What they do is come down to Austin and try to stuff money into the pockets of rich people.'' Some conservative Democrats disagree. Democratic state Rep. Bill Hollowell endorsed Williams over Richards last week. ``Her platform is so foreign to those of us who believe in conservative to moderate values that I'm going to have to cross the party line on this race,'' said Hollowell. He acknowledged having voted for some Republicans in the past as well. Martin downplayed such defections and accused Williams of distorting Richards' record on issues such as gun control, where she supports a waiting period for people who want to buy semiautomatic assault rifles. ``Clayton Williams claims she favors gun control. That's just not true,'' Martin said. ``Ann Richards thinks a law-abiding Texan ought to be able to buy a handgun to protect his home, or a deer rifle to go hunting.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tuesday AMs, July 31
$Adv29
For Release Sunday, July 29, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Fans and Locals Flock to Filmmaker's Store
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ``Mo Better Blues'' opens Aug. 3.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Filmmaker Spike Lee has been celebrated as a trailblazing filmmaker, the talk of the Cannes Film Festival and a Hollywood maverick. But residents of the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn _ where he recently opened a store that sells memorabilia from his movies _ insist that he's still one of their own. ``You have to respect Spike,'' said Marc Sweeting, 20, a college student, as he looked at T-shirts inside the shop called Spike's Joint. ``He came from Brooklyn. He makes his movies in Brooklyn. And he put his store right here. He didn't go off to Hollywood with everything. There's not enough black-owned businesses here and he's still trying to support the community.'' Juliette Spencer, a model and waitress, was in Spike's Joint the same day, buying a key chain bearing the words ``Forty Acres and a Mule,'' the name of Lee's production company a block away from the store. ``I've seen him on the street a lot of times, and his father and sister, too,'' she said. ``He's always very friendly. He always says hello.'' Customers who shop at Spike's Joint have their choice of T-shirts, posters, books, caps, postcards and other items commemorating his movies ``Do the Right Thing,'' ``She's Gotta Have It,'' ``School Daze'' and his latest film, ``Mo' Better Blues,'' which premiered in New York on July 23 and opens nationwide Aug. 3. For the truly avant-garde Spike Lee fan, there are shirts bearing the words ``Jungle Fever,'' the name of his next movie, to be released in 1991. There's also something for the fan who can't get enough of ``Do the Right Thing,'' which depicted racial tensions that led to a boycott and the eventual destruction of an Italian-owned pizzeria in Bedford-Stuyvesant, a predominantly black neighborhood about a mile from Fort Greene. During a recent visit to Spike's Joint, a videotape of ``Do the Right Thing'' played on two televisions _ one inside the store and one in the window _ with the sound piped into the street. A small crowd stood watching throughout the afternoon. Lee's first film was ``Joe's Bed-Stuy Barbershop: We Cut Heads'' in 1982. It was his thesis work at New York University Film School, and won the student academy award from the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences. When Island Pictures released ``She's Gotta Have It,'' about a sexually independent young woman, Lee was lionized as the leader of a new wave of independent filmmaking. He had made the 1986 lusty black-and-white movie for an amazing $175,000. ``She's Gotta Have It'' grossed $8 million, impressing David Puttnam, then head of Columbia Pictures. Puttnam commissioned ``School Daze,'' a musical satire of fraternity life at a black campus. Although it received mixed reviews, it was Columbia's biggest moneymaker for 1988, grossing $14.5 million. With ``Do the Right Thing,'' a frank, realistic and beautifully filmed portrait of racism and its byproducts, the brash young filmmaker entered the mainstream. Born in Atlanta, Lee was raised in Brooklyn by his father, Bill, a jazz musician who composes his son's film scores, and a mother who taught art. He attended Morehouse College as an undergraduate, and then went to NYU. Lee, 33, opened Spike's Joint on July 22 in the middle-class Fort Greene neighborhood where neatly kept brownstones and grand, tall trees line nearly every street. Lee lives in Fort Greene, and his film crews have shot scenes there. His sister, Joie Lee, who played his sister in ``Do the Right Thing,'' had a small role in ``She's Gotta Have It'' and co-stars with Denzel Washington in ``Mo' Better Blues,'' is often spotted getting on the D train at the local subway station. ``I ran into Spike a few times on the street,'' said Kyle Ridley, 26, a student at the Brooklyn campus of Long Island University, about six blocks from the store. ``We put our money into seeing his movies; why not the store?'' Spike's Joint is across the street from Brooklyn Technical High School. One customer, Michael Tracy, a Tech graduate and now a City College student, made a pilgrimage back to the area to buy a T-shirt. ``I've seen all his films, and I'm hoping to be a filmmaker myself,'' he said. Lee opened the store because he was besieged by fan mail and phone calls requesting buttons, T-shirts and other movie memorabilia. On opening day at the store, Lee bristled when a reporter suggested that some of the store's profits might be funneled back to the community. ``When white people start a business no one says a word. Black people want to make some money, it's, `So Spike, are you going to give all your money back to the community?''' he mocked. Lee said he hopes to use his profits to finance his own movies. Now he relies on studio financing, including $10 million for ``Mo' Better Blues.'' His customers were concerned with smaller sums, however _ postcards, two for $1, T-shirts, $12 and $15, unframed posters, $10, and a leather-sleeved ``Do the Right Thing'' jacket, a cool $300. ``I like that jacket,'' said Sweeting's friend, Desiree Clarke. ``I have a strong feeling I'm going to be spending $300 at some point,'' he said with a grin.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, July 29

DOC.HEAD: Little Hope for Quick End to Sri Lankan Conflict
LaserPhoto planned
DOC.TEXT: At the crack of dawn one Wednesday, 1,500 soldiers swarmed into this seaside town and herded thousands of people onto the cricket field. One by one, the people were forced to pass through a tent. Men wearing hoods picked out those believed to be Tamil guerrillas or their sympathizers, and other soldiers searched homes. By day's end, hundreds of men and women were taken away from Trincomalee, according to the government, press reports and a Western aid worker based in the town. The operation was repeated over the next few days in each sector of this town of 48,000 people, the government said. Since mid-June, government forces and separatist rebels have fought for control of the north and east, ending a 13-month truce in the 7-year-old ethnic civil war. Few expect an early end to the war for a separate Tamil homeland in Sri Lanka, the island off India's tip that once was a paradise noted for tea, spices, beauty and peace. Many fear continued conflict will bring chaos. More than 20,000 Tamils have fled to India, which has a Tamil population of about 60 million, since the latest round of hostilities began. Fighting has reached a deadlock, with the government controlling several main towns in the east but the guerrillas in charge of the north and the jungles. Maj. Gen. Gerry de Silva, the regional commander, now says a political solution is the only way out, a far cry from earlier army claims that it would quickly eliminate the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam. Government commanders add, however, that negotiations are possible only from a position of strength. A cycle of atrocities against civilians by both sides has resumed. Funerals of young children and mothers have become routine in Trincomalee. Townspeople fly white flags on their bamboo fences as if they were surrendering to fate. ``We are waiting to die,'' said Gloria Williams, whose small orphanage in a Methodist church outside Trincomalee was transformed into a refugee camp for 1,000 old people and children, all Tamils. ``All the teen-agers have gone to the jungle to fight,'' she said. ``I pray to God, but it doesn't help.'' Tamil rebels are believed to have massacred 600 unarmed policemen who surrendered when fighting resumed June 11. Reports say they also killed hundreds of civilians, most of them Moslems, whom the Tigers accuse of helping the government. According to other reports, the government has executed many Tamil civilians suspected of backing the militants. Masked police death squads led by members of Tamil splinter groups working for the government comb major towns on the east coast, picking out alleged supporters of the Tigers. ``The hooded ones came to my house last night,'' Ritah Sivakamasundary, a 36-year-old Tamil woman, said in a refugee camp near Trincomalee. ``I heard gunshots after they took my husband away. I don't know, but I think he's dead.'' Western diplomats say the government has been the more restrained of the two sides. ``There are no good guys in Sri Lanka, but at least the government has made an effort to be disciplined,'' one said, on condition of anonymity. He cited the rebels' increasing use of pressure mines that blow off limbs, a ``particularly inhumane type of weapon.'' The mines, nicknamed ``dice'' by Sri Lankan troops, have maimed nearly 40 soldiers. Sri Lanka is one of Asia's most beautiful countries. Earlier this year, while the cease-fire held, the International Monetary Fund said its development prospects were among the region's brightest. With a literacy rate of 90 percent, relatively cheap labor, liberal economic policies and abundant natural resources, the island nation of 16 million people was touted as another Singapore. Renewed hostilities will increase defense spending 50 percent this year to $170 million, using up money neded for development. A projected growth rate of 5.5 percent will not be achieved, and international bankers say the country will be lucky to beat the 1989 rate of 2.3 percent. Foreign investment, which had been picking up after the United States helped establish a stock market, is expected to lag. The neglected southern half of the island could become even poorer, raising the possibility of insurrection on two fronts. A Sinhalese nationalist movement centered in the south was crushed in 1989. Its terror campaign and the government's response cost 6,000 lives. The Tamil war has taken nearly 13,000. Ethnic tensions between Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the population, and Sinhalese, a predominant 75 percent, go back hundreds of years. In the teak and ivory drawing rooms of Colombo, the capital, debate about which ethnic group arrived first harks back to centuries before Christ. In the modern era, trouble began in 1956, eight years after Sri Lanka gained independence from Britain. Tamils dominated Sri Lanka in colonial days. The British gave them the best jobs and American missionaries set up the best schools in Jaffna, the Tamil stronghold on the island's northern tip. After independence, the Sinhalese majority voted its men into power. In 1956, the government made Sinhala the national language and Buddhism the state religion. This angered the Tamils, who have their own language and practice Hinduism or Christianity. The day the law was passed, riots broke out nationwide. Hundreds of people were killed. The problem simmered, boiled and simmered for 25 years. Sri Lanka, which entered the 1960s with a higher per capita income than South Korea or Malaysia, fell behind in the economic race. Now the average citizen makes $367 a year, near the bottom in Asia. Ethnic tension turned into civil war in 1983, when 13 Sinhalese soldiers were blown up by a land mine and Sinhalese rioted in Colombo, killing scores of Tamils. Tamil militants took to the jungles and fought until 1987, when India arranged a peace agreement and sent thousands of soldiers to disarm Tamil guerrillas. Rebel groups agreed to the accord but the Tigers reneged. Indian troops spent 32 months fighting the Tigers, then withdrew without success in March 1990. Western diplomats agree the Tigers started the latest violence, but say they do not understand why. After the cease-fire in May 1989, the government gave the Tigers wide autonomy in the north and east. Police were not allowed to make arrests unless the Tigers approved. The Tigers levied taxes. Army troops were confined to barracks. The Tigers set up offices and roadblocks throughout the area and consolidated control. One theory says the Tigers, jungle fighters for a decade, could not adjust to the demands of a democratic political process. In the past, they had killed their enemies. With peace, they were forced to argue with them. ``We had been thinking that we could evolve as a nation, but this situation is terribly demoralizing,'' said Neelan Tiruchelvam, a moderate Tamil leader. ``We are back to square one.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, Aug 5

For Release Sunday, Aug. 5, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Temple of Hope for War Orphans
With Sri Lanka's Tragedy
DOC.TEXT: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka _ A 13-year-old monk sat under a tree outside a temple, reciting legends about Lord Buddha to a few children not much younger than he. It is a common sight in this predominantly Buddhist country, except that the Sinhalese child-monk, Devamitra, and his disciples are orphans who lost their parents to ethnic violence that has ravaged the island since 1983. Devamitra remembers the hot July day in 1986 when he and his elder brother, Wasantha Ekanayake, returned from school to find their parents dead, riddled with bullets. They were among 46 residents of Morawewa, a village in the northeast, killed by Tamil separatists. The boys hid in the jungle for two days and were found by Sinhalese soldiers, who took them to the temple in Colombo, the capital, which operates a rehabilitation center for war orphans. Devamitra, named Shantha by his parents, was ordained a year later, at age 10, because of his religious inclination and now is a full-fledged monk. His second love after the scriptures is soccer, the favorite sport of many of the 276 orphan boys at the Vajra Sri Rehabilitation Children's Home. A Buddhist monk, Vijira Sri Thero, founded the home in 1983, declaring that his affection for children compelled him to demolish some buildings in the temple to accommodate 25 orphans. The number of orphans has grown to 326, ranging in age from 5 months to 17 years. They include 50 girls, who live in separate quarters 10 miles away. Six Tamils, most of whom are Hindus, and 24 Moslems are among the temple's orphans. Many of the children lost both parents because of the Tamil separatist war in the north and east or an ultranationalist Sinhalese insurgency in the south that was crushed last year. In other cases, one parent is living but no longer is able to care for a child. ``Mothers and fathers who lost their spouses and now find they cannot cope with their children bring them here,'' Thero said. Ethnic violence began in 1983 when Tamil militants started fighting for a separate homeland apart from the Sinhalese majority. Nearly 13,000 people have been killed. Separatists claim Tamils, 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, are discriminated against in jobs and education by the Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the population. Officials of the Rehabilitation Ministry say more than 500,000 Sinhalese, Tamils and Moslems fled the northeast at the height of the Tamil campaign in 1987. Colombo and several towns in the east are dotted with refugee camps that receive government aid to provide living quarters and monthly allowance. Thero's center is run with private donations only. It provides basic education and teaches the children such vocational skills as auto mechanics, masonry, carpentry, refrigeration, gem cutting and foreign languages. While Devamitra chose religion as the way out of his nightmare, a 16-year orphan from the same Sinhalese village wants to become a soldier. ``For the sake of my country, I will join the army,'' said Aruna Jayasundera, whose parents also were slain in the massacre.

DOC.HEAD: Tourism Revives Despite Civil War
With Sri Lanka's Tragedy
DOC.TEXT: After several seasons of deserted beaches and empty hotel rooms, Sri Lanka is attracting tourists again this year despite a new outbreak of fighting. The number of tourists from January to May reached 102,694, a 91 percent increase over the same period of 1989, when two insurgencies raged. A 7-year-old ethnic rebellion by Tamils in the north and east, and an anti-government revolt last year by ultranationalist Sinhalese in the south, nearly destroyed tourism. Tamil rebels reached an agreement with the government in May 1989 and the Sinhalese movement was crushed, but the Tamils began fighting again in June of this year. Hotels are a barometer of the war. ``Going by how our windows are lit up at night, the message is clear: We are back in business,'' said Gamini Fernando, general manager of the Colombo Hilton. ``The walk-in guest days are over. Our guests now need to make a reservation.'' Occupancy slumped after fighting resumed, ``but not alarmingly,'' said another hotel executive, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Nearly 2,000 people have been killed since June, but warfare has been confined to the north and east, where Tamils predominate. Officials warn tourists not to travel beyond Anuradhapura, an ancient Sinhalese town 100 miles north of Colombo. About 85 miles farther north is the Jaffna Peninsula, scene of the fiercest battles between the army and Tamil Tiger rebels. The last good year for tourism in Sri Lanka was in 1982, when more than 400,000 foreigners visited the island and spent $125.8 million. Last year, the numbers were down to 182,000 and $75.6 million. Before fighting resumed in June, Cyril Gardiner, owner of the 126-year-old Galle Face Hotel, had predicted a tourist boom this winter if the cease-fire continued. ``We have turned the bend,'' he said. ``We are back on the holiday map and the best is yet to come.'' Winter is the main tourist season in Sri Lanka because its sun and sand attract people from colder climates. Late last year the beaches were known more for bodies floating ashore than for swimmers and surfers. Colombo was under curfew nearly every other day and, when it wasn't, few residents ventured outside for fear of Sinhalese gunmen or security forces, who tended to shoot first and ask questions later.

DOC.HEAD: Telephone Call to Police Brings IRA Death Threat
DOC.TEXT: Michael Williams says he heard an elderly neighbor screaming ``Don't kill me! Don't kill me!'' So he called the police. His family and his bishop say Williams was trying to be a good neighbor, but that can be risky in Northern Ireland. Williams has been driven into hiding in England and the Irish Republican Army says he is an informer, who will be killed if he ever returns. Anyone in Williams' neighborhood who sees masked men has only bad choices: Turn up the television; confront the gunmen; call the police and risk death as an ``informer''; don't call the police and risk jail for withholding information. ``We're pigs in the middle,'' said Williams' sister-in-law, Eileen Mahony. ``We have no comeback from anyone.'' ``I intend to clear his name if it takes me all my life,'' said Mavis Williams, who urged her 54-year-old husband to flee and is campaigning publicly to get the IRA death threat lifted. ``It's the first time anybody's stood up to them, and the reason why we're standing up is because it's the truth,'' said her sister, Mrs. Mahony. This family argument with the IRA is not conducted by people cowering behind locked doors or peeping fearfully through window blinds. The Mahonys and Williamses, like many of their neighbors, leave the key in the front door and no one is surprised to find a neighbor or stranger coming or going. The family's defense is not that Michael Williams had a right and duty to call the police. They say he made a mistake, an honest mistake, in not recognizing an IRA operation. ``In Ireland, to inform is the worst possible crime anyone can commit; it's worse than a murder, worse than a rape,'' said Eileen Mahony's husband, Jim. ``So to call him an informer, they're taking his honor away.'' Mrs. Williams is 51, born and raised in Londonderry, and said she would not have called the police. She would have gone next door to see what was happening and stayed with her neighbor until it was over, she said. When her husband told her what he had done, Mrs. Williams said, ``I just went to pieces.'' Williams was born in London and settled in Northern Ireland after their marriage 31 years ago. The Williamses raised 12 children in the Creggan Estate, a Roman Catholic neighborhood, through the Catholic civil rights marches of the late 1960s, the street warfare of 1969 and the early 1970s, the British army patrols and house searches, and IRA hijackings of homes and cars. Despite all that, his wife said, Williams didn't understand what was happening that afternoon, March 1. At 2:45 p.m., Williams saw two men in stocking caps enter Rose Garnon's house, his wife said. Later, he heard Mrs. Garnon screaming and, since the Williamses do not have a telephone, went to another neighbor's home to call the Royal Ulster Constabulary. Mrs. Williams said 45 minutes passed before the arrival of police, who have to anticipate that a call for help may be an invitation to an ambush. As it turned out, the IRA men went to the house to hijack a car and hold Mrs. Garnon hostage until the end of whatever operation was planned. It was a costly afternoon for the IRA. Police confiscated a handgun, a rifle, an RPG7 rocket launcher and several grenades. The IRA demanded an explanation and Williams agreed to a meeting, he told The Sunday Times of London. He was taken to a house and told to sit facing the wall. Williams sensed the room filling behind him, he said, ``but there were no threats. On the contrary, they told me that, if I was threatened or my children had hassle, I had only to contact them.'' He assumed he was cleared, but on March 9, police seized more IRA weapons in Creggan. Mrs. Williams, fearing the IRA would blame her husband, insisted he run away. On March 13, four masked men called at the Williams home, where they confronted 16-year-old Robert Williams and two sisters, aged 8 and 10. Mrs. Williams said her son was told: ``Tell your mother: If your father comes back he will be executed.'' The family tried to settle things through Sinn Fein, the IRA's legal political wing, but negotiations came to nothing and Mrs. Williams took her case to the Derry Journal, the local newspaper. ``I think a lot of people might be frightened to confront the IRA on their own patch,'' Bishop Edward Daly said. ``I think the Williams family perhaps is somewhat exceptional in that regard.'' Daly has contacted journalists about the case, but thinks that, in the short run, publicity may only make the gunmen dig in their heels. ``Ultimately, I think what will change their attitude will be the community, and I think very large numbers of people now in the community are asking very large questions about this and feeling that it is wrong,'' the bishop said. Creggan is a stronghold of Sinn Fein and the IRA in a city whose very name symbolizes the feud between Protestants, who call it Londonderry, and Roman Catholics, who use the old name, Derry. Even here, Sinn Fein ran second in last year's local elections to the Social Democratic and Labor Party, which shares the IRA's goal of a united Ireland but rejects its violent methods. Martin McGuinness, the local Sinn Fein leader, said the clerics and Social Democratic politicians supporting Williams were, in effect, ``suggesting that nationalists should give information'' to the police. After Williams called police, he encountered Mrs. Garnon's son, Clifford, and one of his friends. They said Williams told them of the call and urged them not to tell Sinn Fein. Hugh Brady, a city councilor from Sinn Fein, has said the story told by those two men disputed Williams' claim that he didn't know it was an IRA operation. Brady now refuses to discuss the case. ``I've said everything I intend to say,'' he declared in a short telephone conversation. On April 20, Clifford Garnon was found drowned in the Foyle River, an apparent suicide. Mrs. Garnon also refuses to discuss the case. Daly has protested IRA tactics that make accomplices of neighbors. He said many people in Creggan feared their homes would be taken over for ambushes or their cars commandeered to ferry bombs or guns. ``It's the great nightmare here,'' he said. In August 1988, a Creggan man who hadn't seen his neighbor for days broke into the man's apartment to investigate. He accidentally set off an IRA bomb intended for security forces. It killed him and another neighbor. Mavis Williams and Eileen Mahony share cigarettes and pots of tea as they talk their problem out in a sort of duet: Mrs. Mahony: ``Children have been terrorized. There've been elderly people ...'' Mrs. Williams: ``... have been terrorized ...'' ``... you know, with a gun put to your head. It's no joke .. .'' ``They take your car ...'' ``You're told not to report it ...'' ``If you don't report it, and the police find out the car was used, you're taken in ...'' ``and you're questioned ...'' ``and you're charged ...'' ``for withholding information.''

DOC.HEAD: Litmus! Litmus! Why is Everyone Talking About a Color Test?
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: The password is litmus. That's the test nobody is supposed to give David H. Souter. And it is likely to wind up as his shield against question A: whether he'd say yes or no on abortion rights. To ask directly would be to apply the litmus test shunned by President Bush and most Democrats. Only the most ardent of abortion rights activists argue that a Supreme Court nominee can properly be required to say how he would rule on an issue certain to confront him on the bench. So Souter will be asked obliquely, as a Democratic senator put it. Litmus is the compound that turns red in acid solutions; the test of the same name is one in which a single standard determines the outcome. ``. . . There was no single issue, no litmus test or standard dominating my decision to nominate,'' Bush said, campaigning in Philadelphia a day after choosing Souter, a New Hampshire jurist with a nearly blank slate on abortion cases. ``And I will add, there should be no litmus test in the process of confirmation.'' The White House began issuing such injunctions even before Bush chose his nominee, to fend off the question of whether he would name anyone who did not agree with his view that the abortion rights decision of 1973 should be reversed. Souter himself was quoted by his friend, Sen. Warren B. Rudman, R-N.H., as saying he wouldn't have been interested in his appointment as a federal appeals judge earlier this year, or in the Supreme Court, if the administration had any litmus tests to apply. Rudman said nobody should ask a nominee how he would rule on specific cases, that it would violate judicial ethics to answer such questions, and make confirmation proceedings into a political popularity contest. In that view of the way the Senate should Supreme Court nominees, the issues questions should be general, about a nominee's judicial philosophy, view of the Constitution and its guarantees _ not about specifics. Sen. Paul Simon, D-Ill., said Souter won't be asked directly about things he might be ruling on from the bench. ``But I think obliquely you do that,'' he said, by asking about his views on the right to privacy, underpinning of the 1973 decision legalizing abortion. That route to the A word has been used before. Robert H. Bork, whose nomination was rejected by the Senate in 1987, said a constitutional right to privacy was invented by the court, which then used it to invent a right to abortion. There never was any doubt about his opposition to the abortion ruling, or his stance on a catalogue of other issues. Bork had spoken, written and ruled on them, which armed his critics with confirmation questions about positions he had taken for years. ``It is amusing that some senators claimed that the White House imposed a litmus test for the president's nominees,'' Bork wrote later. ``No one in the administration asked me a single question about my views on any topic of law. They were satisfied that they knew my approach to judging.'' He said the litmus came at the Senate hearings, where ``by contrast, various senators not only asked my views, but insisted that I adopt what they thought the correct position.'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, who finally got the seat Bork was denied, said at his confirmation hearing that his personal view on abortion was irrelevant, and that he wasn't going to signal how he might rule on any specific case. He did call privacy a constitutionally protected right. He is now aligned with what has so far been the four-justice minority that favors reversing the 1973 abortion decision. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor said at her 1981 confirmation hearing that while she found abortion personally abhorrent, she would deal with the issue on the basis of the facts and the Constitution. When she was pressed on that and on other specifics, she replied with a carefully prepared counter to litmus testing: ``I do not believe that, as a nominee, I can tell you how I might vote on a particular issue which may come before the court, or endorse or criticize specific Supreme Court decisions presenting issues which may well come before the court again. To do so would mean I have prejudged the matter . . . '' In a 1989 ruling, she joined the 5-to-4 majority giving states new power to limit abortions, but stopped short of providing a fifth vote to overturn the basic abortion rights ruling. With the retirement of William J. Brennan Jr., the court is evenly divided on that question and Souter's position is crucial. Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., said Souter would not be confirmed if the Senate knew or believed it would mean reversal of the abortion decision. Souter hasn't said, and won't. He's as litmus-proof a nominee as Bush could find.

DOC.HEAD: Supermarkets Concentrate on Convenience Foods, Produce Shelves
DOC.TEXT: Convenience foods and produce shelves are among the biggest attractions for supermarket shoppers, perhaps showing that while consumers want to put dinner on the table with ease, they are trying to eat well. Baby boomers with babies are eating at home more, and that gives supermarkets an opportunity to provide takeout food to compete with restaurants, Timothy M. Hammonds, senior vice president of the non-profit trade group the Food Marketing Institute, said at the organization's seminar earlier this month. Research shows that these parents are saying they no longer have time to eat in restaurants. ``Not cooking is becoming a substitute for eating out,'' he said. ``If you think about the supermarket, we really started 50 years ago as an outlet for manufacturers and farmers. Now we are the purchasing agent for the consumer,'' Hammonds said. Today's supermarkets carry an average of 25,855 items apiece, according to FMI. Consumers are becoming increasingly interested in convenience. And, according to Hammonds, convenience foods don't come wrapped in all the guilt they once did, leaving consumers feeling that they were not doing all they should to provide good meals. ``That's why the cake mix people had you add that egg,'' to ease the feelings of guilt for not making the cake from scratch, he said. Now, however, convenience carries another meaning. It ``lets you spend more time with your family.'' Still, none of this has hurt the sale of produce. Fruit, Hammonds speculated, is considered ``nature's convenience food.'' And consumers still are taking time for vegetables. In its annual survey of consumers, FMI found that 46 percent of those surveyed buy takeout food at fast-food restaurants, 27 perent at other restaurants and 14 percent at supermarkets. However, that number has increased steadily since 1987, when 9 percent of shoppers said they bought takeout food at supermarkets. Food labeling, a big issue in Washington these days as changes are proposed to current regulations, is less of an issue with consumers. Just 36 percent said they always read beyond the expiration date to the nutrition and ingredient information, though an additional 45 percent to 48 percent said they sometimes read those labels. Manufacturers' health claims on labels were considered very believable by 8 percent of those surveyed but somewhat believable by 52 percent. The most often-cited reason for skepticism was that the labels don't tell the whole story. ``Only 8 percent said current health claims are very believable. There's a problem out there, folks,'' Hammonds said. FMI's survey, taken annually for two decades, questioned 1,005 primary shoppers in a household. The survey also found that 65 percent of those questioned said their diets could be at least somewhat healthier. Fifty-seven percent of shoppers said they eat more fruits and vegetables than a year ago; 34 percent are eating less meat; 27 percent eat less fat. Only 16 percent said they eat more fiber, and 18 percent said they eat more fish. Still, taste ranked first among factors influencing supermarket purchases, rated very important by 88 percent of those surveyed. Nutrition was cited by 75 percent and product safety by 71 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Newsletter for and by Young People Promotes Healthy Eating
DOC.TEXT: Plenty of research suggests young Americans are not well informed about nutrition and don't eat as well as they should. A newsletter called ``Kids for Healthy Hearts News'' addresses the problem. Written by people ages 11 to 17, ``Kids for Healthy Hearts'' is available free and includes puzzles and tips about healthy eating and recipes. A recent issue, printed in bright green and pink, is about complex carbohydrates. It has a recipe for honey raisin bran muffins, two puzzles, an essay on smoking and tips on eating. The newsletter is part of an education program sponsored by Kellogg Co. Subscriptions are available free by writing to ``Kids for Healthy Hearts, P.O. Box 3449, Battle Creek, MI 49016.
DOC.HEAD: Lyme Disease Vaccine for Dogs Unveiled
DOC.TEXT: A dog vaccine against Lyme disease has been approved by the U.S. Department of Agriculture and should be on the market this summer, officials of a veterinary medicine manufacturer said. Officials said a vaccine for humans is not imminent. ``Unfortunately, a lot of research would be needed before a vaccine could be approved for human consumption,'' said Michael Gregoricka, a veterinary medicine researcher at Fort Dodge Laboratories, which is manufacturing the dog vaccine. Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of the deer tick, a tiny creature found on deer, mice, birds and other animals in woods or fields. It can cause arthritis, lethargy, heart disorders and other symptoms in animals and humans. It is treated with antibiotics. The disease was identified in the United States in 1975, and cases have been found in 44 states. The vaccine was developed by researchers at the University of Minnesota. Fort Dodge Laboratories bought marketing rights to the drug and engaged in four years of testing on dogs, Gregoricka said. Gregoricka said the vaccine must be approved by individual state veterinary officials. Vaccines for other animals are being studied, he said. Researchers believe dogs and other animals can spread Lyme disease to people, and Fort Dodge officials said development of the animal vaccine is a step in curbing the disease.
DOC.HEAD: Tampa, Oakland, Calif., Targeted for Water-Use Study
DOC.TEXT: Tampa and Oakland, Calif., have been picked as tentative test sites for a study of how people use water in their homes and how much they could save if they installed high-tech plumbing devices. Researchers plan to attach monitors to toilets, shower heads and water meters at a sampling of homes in both cities. ``The information will enable us to project future demand and allow us to make realistic projections on how much water we can save through conservation,'' said Wendy Nero, conservation manager at the Tampa Water Department. The Stevens Institute of Technology in Hoboken, N.J., will conduct the research, pending approval by the Tampa and Oakland city councils. If approved, the study should begin by January. Researchers also will study whether people using devices like low-flow shower heads really save water _ or just take longer showers, said civil engineer Thomas Konen, the study's coordinator. To make sure the study includes a cross-section, officials will pick households based on income levels, geography and household types, Nero said. Data collected in the homes will be transmitted via telephone lines to researchers in New Jersey every night.

DOC.HEAD: Scientist Finds New Evidence for Giant Quakes in Pacific Northwest
DOC.TEXT: Old mud dumped on the sea floor by giant underwater landslides provides new evidence that 13 devastating earthquakes may have rocked the Pacific Northwest during the last 6,900 years. The study by John Adams of the Geological Survey of Canada also suggests there is a 2 percent to 10 percent chance that a quake measuring 8 or more on the Richter scale will shake the region within the next 50 years. Several previous studies furnished evidence that at least six great earthquakes jolted the coasts of Oregon and Washington during the past several thousand years, although no such quake has happened since pioneers settled the region. Adams' study, scheduled for publication in the August issue of the journal Tectonics, revealed a new line of evidence that the Northwest is prone to giant earthquakes. It also found geologic signs of 13 such quakes. Adams studied sea floor sediments called turbidites, or layers of mud. Rivers carry mud and other debris into the ocean, where it settles on the continental shelf and on the slope leading down to the deep sea floor. The mud accumulates until the slope becomes too steep, collapsing in a sudden undersea landslide called a turbidity current. This current carries the mud into undersea channels or canyons, where it settles to form turbidite deposits. Adams identified 13 layers of the turbidite muds in each of several undersea channels. The remarkable discovery was that each layer was deposited simultaneously in all the channels. That is, for example, the sixth layer in one channel was deposited at the same time as the sixth layer in the other channels. That indicated each layer was created by a great earthquake, which shook the sea floor so intensely it triggered huge undersea landslides up and down the Oregon-Washington coast, he said. ``It would have to be substantial to shake loose that much sediment,'' Adams said in a telephone interview from Ottawa. The 13 layers correspond to 13 great earthquakes, which occurred an average of every 590 years, give or take 170 years, he said. Based on the frequency and evidence strongly indicating the most recent big jolt happened 300 years ago, Adams estimated the Northwest is 2 percent to 10 percent likely to have another such quake within 50 years. Adams' study was based on reanalysis of core samples of sea floor sediments collected from 1965 to 1968 by La Verne Kulm and other researchers at Oregon State University. He was able to date and correlate the turbidite layers in the various channels because they all were deposited after the eruption of the Mount Mazama volcano in Oregon's Cascade Range, 6,800 to 6,900 years ago. The eruption is best known for creating the crater now named Crater Lake, but it also spewed volcanic glass, formed by the very rapid cooling of molten lava, that was carried to sea and deposited on the ocean floor. Adams' study adds to other evidence that the Northwest has been rocked by powerful quakes, said Brian Atwater, a U.S. Geological Survey geophysicist who uncovered some of the first evidence for such prehistoric seismic disasters. But Atwater and Kulm said another possible explanation for Adams' findings is that sediment perched on the continental shelf merely breaks loose at regular intervals after big storms or when enough has accumulated to trigger an undersea landslide. ``You can get that kind of regularity by loading sediment on the ocean shelf,'' Kulm said, noting that turbidity currents happen every 10 to 25 years near the mouth of the Mississippi River in the Gulf of Mexico. But he said sediments accumulate more rapidly there than off the Northwest coast, and that 400- to 600-year intervals between turbidity currents is ``a pretty long time'' if the landslides were triggered by slope collapse rather than big earthquakes. So ``earthquakes are most certainly a strong possibility'' to explain the turbidites off Oregon and Washington, Kulm said. Atwater said that early this century, the great Grand Banks earthquake off Newfoundland's coast sent debris crashing down the undersea channels of the Atlantic to snap telephone cables. Adams said it is possible that simple sediment accumulation or even major storms could have triggered the turbidity currents. But the range and frequency indicate the most likely cause is a major earthquake, he said. Atwater unearthed some of the first evidence of prehistoric great quakes in the Northwest several years ago. He found that estuaries such as Washington's Willapa Bay and Oregon's Netarts Bay contained alternating layers of peat covered by sand. That indicated repeated instances in which the coastline dropped vertically in a great quake, then was inundated by tsunamis, or giant sea waves, that dumped sand on coastal marshes. David Yamaguchi, a University of Colorado scientist, has found evidence in tree rings that trees along 60 miles of the Washington coast died suddenly 300 years ago when they were submerged by a tsunami. Adams' study ``certainly complements the estuary evidence and the tree ring studies,'' Atwater said.

DOC.HEAD: Geologist Digs Up Ancient Quakes To Forecast Future Catastrophes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Lucile in 16th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: On a barren windswept plain, Kerry Sieh digs trenches across the San Andreas Fault, trying to unravel the secrets of prehistoric earthquakes so he can forecast disasters. Here, in the shadow of the Temblor Range, 130 miles northwest of Los Angeles, Sieh spends hundreds of hours 15 feet underground. Using a tape measure, fine-point pencil and laptop drawing board, he makes detailed maps of beds of sediment in the walls of his trenches. ``I expose layers that go back hundreds or thousands of years, and I see where the San Andreas Fault has broken those sediments,'' said Sieh, a 39-year-old geologist at the California Institute of Technology. ``By dating those sediments with radiocarbon methods, I can tell when prehistoric earthquakes occurred. That helps me understand what is likely to happen in the future.'' Over the past 15 years, Sieh's meticulous research helped alert millions of Southern Californians to a horrible secret once hidden in the Earth: Within the next few decades, there is at least a 60 percent chance that the region will be rocked by the Big One, a disastrous quake measuring 7.5 to 8 or more on the Richter scale. Scientists know the last such disaster _ the Fort Tejon earthquake _ shook a sparsely populated Southern California in 1857, decades before a similar jolt at the northern end of the San Andreas ravaged San Francisco in 1906. Before Sieh's pioneering studies of the southern San Andreas, no one knew how often great earthquakes shook Southern California. So people had no idea when another such quake might be expected. ``His work certainly has had a major impact on our view of the probability of major earthquakes in Southern California,'' said Robert Wallace, retired chief scientist of the U.S. Geological Survey's Office of Earthquake Studies. ``His work drove the policy of the Los Angeles area toward real serious planning for a major earthquake.'' Los Angeles City Councilman Hal Bernson credited Sieh's findings for ``triggering many of the measures we've undertaken as far as public preparedness is concerned.'' He cited a 1981 ordinance requiring reinforcement or demolition of thousands of vulnerable brick buildings. California is quake-prone because it straddles two great plates that make up Earth's crust. Quakes happen as the Pacific plate grinds slowly northwest past the North American plate along the 700-mile-long San Andreas and a network of related faults. The entire fault doesn't snap at once. Because of changes in rock type or bends in the fault, separate segments of the San Andreas break alone or in combination to cause quakes. Three segments that extend 200 miles ruptured to cause the 1857 Fort Tejon earthquake. From northwest to southeast, they were the Cholame segment in central California, the Carrizo Plain segment and the Mojave segment, which extends from Tejon Pass north of Los Angeles to Cajon Pass north of San Bernardino. As a geology student at the University of California, Riverside, in the early 1970s, Sieh theorized that by digging trenches across various segments of the fault, he could determine how often great quakes had ruptured each section. The method, known as paleoseismology, let him estimate how soon big jolts might happen again. He showed seismologists they could learn something from geologists, who study rocks and sediments instead of seismographic records of recent quakes. ``The whole idea that we can talk about probabilities of future earthquakes happened because of Kerry's work,'' said Lucile Jones, a seismologist with the U.S. Geological Survey. ``His work is so fundamental it has changed the field.'' In the mid-1970s, Sieh's work indicated there was a 50 percent to 90 percent chance a great quake would shake Southern California within 50 years. Later research by Sieh and others prompted a formal forecast in 1988 by the Geological Survey, which said there was at least a 60 percent chance of such a disaster within 30 years. Sieh's early research indicated the next Big One would rupture the fault's Mojave segment, the segment closest to Los Angeles. A 1980 federal report estimated such a quake could kill up to 14,000 people, hospitalize 55,000 and cause $17 billion in damage. But Sieh's more recent findings suggest the Big One is most likely to rupture the San Andreas Fault's Coachella Valley segment, between the Palm Springs area and the Salton Sea. Because such a quake would be more distant from Los Angeles, damage likely would be less than envisioned in the 1980 estimate _ unless the fault continued to rupture northward, breaking both the Coachella Valley and Mojave segments. On the Carrizo Plain, the most recent findings by Sieh and USGS scientist Carol Prentice indicate that segment of the fault is unlikely to break soon in an exact repeat of the great quake of 1857. While Sieh's continuing studies changed details about the likely location of Southern California's next Big One, his work provided ``hard-and-fast proof'' it is inevitable, author John Nance wrote in the 1988 book ``On Shaky Ground.'' ``No longer could residents or government officials of Southern California treat the prospect of great earthquakes on the southern San Andreas as the mere armchair postulations of theorizing scientists,'' Nance said. Sieh said that when he digs into the mighty San Andreas, he doesn't think about the catastrophes it ultimately will unleash. ``I do what I do because it's fun,'' he said. ``But I enjoy doing something that helps other people. ``So often what people do in response to earthquake hazards is stick their heads in the sand. We need to do whatever we can to reduce the property losses and to reduce losses of life. If I can say roughly when and where earthquakes are going to happen, I'd hope people would be responsible and rational enough to deal with it.''

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Projections Bring Unwanted Publicity
DOC.TEXT: Iben Browning holds dozens of patents in several specialties, but it's his earthquake projections that are stirring up notoriety he says he'd rather do without. Browning said at a conference in Missouri last year there was a high probability of an earthquake along the New Madrid Fault this Dec. 2. He was deluged by calls. He insists he did not predict an earthquake. ``The public always wants everything in black and white,'' Browning said. ``No one can tell you there is going to be an earthquake on Dec. 2, no one can know that. ... Everybody knows when he drives a car that he's taking a risk that it will malfunction or crash. Yet people do drive cars. They're dealing in probabilities.'' Browning, 72, a large man with a graying burr haircut, says the public does not understand _ and the press does not know how to communicate _ the idea of probability. ``The closest you can translate probability into English is `maybe.' But unless you say `maybe not,' they take it as an absolute,'' he said. Browning is chief scientist for Summa Medical Corp., an Albuquerque biotechnology research and development company. His Summa resume says he holds 66 U.S. and foreign patents in optics, electronics, mechanics, chemistry, electro-optics, hydraulics and educational toys. Summa credits him _ he won't discuss what he does for the company _ with developing new technology for compressing electronically transmitted human speech. Over the years, he's been a development physicist with American Optical Co., worked in optics for Bell Aircraft Corp. and was a scientist for Sandia National Laboratories. But gradually his interest in climatology grew, and he now publishes the Browning Newslettter on world climate. He said he's been accepted commercially as a climatologist since 1974 when he became a consultant for Paine Webber Inc. His formal training was elsewhere: a bachelor's degree in math and physics from Southwest Texas State University, and a master's degree in bacteriology physiology and a doctorate in physiology, genetics and bacteriology from the University of Texas at Austin. ``It turned out that in my observations of climate that all of the soft tools with which I approached biology were applicable to climate,'' he said. ``It's a subject that is comparable in complexity to biology.'' Business needs climate information because the weather determines how much food will be produced and where, whether the transportation industry can get over the roads, whether anything can be built, he said. He provided forecasts for the 1989 edition of the Rocky Mountain Almanac and ``did as well or better than the Old Farmers' Almanac predictions,'' said Lee Olson, almanac editor. ``He did predict the usual monsoons that come up in Arizona in late August, that the Colorado Great Plains would receive extra moisture and store up adequate moisture for the 1990 year,'' Olson said. ``He had the ski season only partly. He had it right for an early start, but it got dry around Christmas as I recall and his timing was a little off on that.'' Browning said his climatological observations are based on high tidal forces, produced by four causes: the proximity of the moon to Earth; the proximity of Earth to the sun; the alignment of the Earth, moon and sun during the full moon and new moon; and the more perfect alignment of those bodies during eclipses. The vector sum would be the total tidal force produced. Such forces can trigger earthquakes, he said, and on Dec. 2, there will be the highest vector sum high tidal force in 60 years from 30 to 60 degrees north latitude. That area includes the New Madrid Fault, running roughly from Marked Tree, Ark., through New Madrid, Mo., to Cairo, Ill. Since last year, when Browning raised the possibility of a December New Madrid quake, the Arkansas National Guard has scheduled earthquake exercises for around that time, one Arkansas school district is considering canceling classes and sales of earthquake insurance have picked up. But Browning said whether a given fault is actually triggered would depend on the pressure built up along it. That information should come from area seismologists, he said firmly. If no earthquake occurs in or around December, Browning said people will be more inclined to ignore the danger of the New Madrid Fault. ``That's what I fear more than anything else,'' he said. ``People don't trust authorities anymore; they never did trust them much. Why should they? What have authorities done for them except tax them to death?'' Browning's earthquake projections are controversial among seismologists. Klaus Jacob, senior research scientist at Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory of Columbia University in Palisades, N.Y., said correlating earthquakes to tidal forces doesn't work. ``It's more likely that in the next 10 years or 20 years we'll have something (quake activity), rather than on this particular day,'' Jacob said. ``You see, earthquakes don't care about predictions. And people shouldn't worry about predictions. They should worry about earthquakes.'' Browning said he told a convention of chief executive officers in San Francisco on Oct. 10, 1989, that there was a 50-50 chance of an earthquake registering 7 on the Richter scale on or about Oct. 16 because a high triggering force was expected that date and geologists had determined there was a strain on the San Andreas Fault. An earthquake registering 7.1 hit Oct. 17, killing 67 people. Jacob said: ``He was just lucky. That's the law of large numbers.'' Arch Johnston, director of the Center for Earthquake Research and Information at Memphis State University in Tennessee, said Browning ``is certainly not justified scientifically.'' ``The tidal force that Dr. Browning bases his theory on has been examined thoroughly by seismologists, and there's no evidence that tidal forces can trigger earthquakes. ... Earthquakes depend on the internal processes of the Earth, not the external processes of the sun and moon.''

DOC.HEAD: More Competition Ups Ante in Fight for Federal Science Aid
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: The government's research and development programs, a $64 billion source of technological breakthroughs and national pride, are also a vulnerable target for budget-cutters. This is the third in an occasional series examining one portion of this year's federal budget _ science spending.

The two companies competing to build $1 billion worth of bus-sized magnets for the superconducting super collider both have promised to manufacture them in the home state of a key senator. The National Science Foundation, a government agency hoping to expand its budget, treated five congressional staffers to a tour of U.S. research stations in Antarctica. And the private National Foundation for Ileitis and Colitis got the actress Mary Ann Mobley to beseech a congressional committee to boost spending on the digestive diseases. It's all part of the increasingly intense competition for federal research and development dollars. Though the kitty will reach $64 billion this year _ of a $1.2 trillion overall budget _ scientists say it is too small. Federal science spending is feeling pressure from within and without. The huge federal deficit means there is less money for all government programs, including science. There also are demands on the government's science dollar from a growing number of big-ticket projects like the $8 billion super collider, an atom smasher to be built in Texas, and the $30 billion space station. Thus, researchers are vying ever harder to persuade Congress to give them a piece of the budget pie. ``There is a lot of money out there, but these sums are considerably less than is needed to do the job and the competition is greater,'' said Jerold Roschwalb, lobbyist for the National Association of State Universities and Land Grant Colleges, whose schools rely heavily on federal research aid. The situation has driven some scientists to venture into Congress' budget process as never before. Recently, two groups _ the American Society for Cell Biology and the American Society for Biochemistry and Molecular Biology _ hired former Maine Democratic Rep. Peter Kyros for about $100,000 to lobby Congress to increase federal medical research grants. ``Our members felt the situation had gotten so bad that it was time for something new and innovative,'' said Peter Farnham, spokesman for the biochemistry society. ``All of our members live and die on the availability of these grants.'' Other scientific organizations have long believed that getting active in the budget process is a must. About 20 colleges and universities have lobbying offices in Washington, while dozens of others have retained lobbying firms. John Farrar, president of the Digestive Disease National Coalition, testified before the House and Senate Appropriations committees for five years before showing up this year with Mobley, an actress who has battled her own digestive ailments. ``The fact is nobody knows'' what his appearances accomplish, Farrar said. ``But it seems to me if you don't show up, you know you won't get your share.'' Dangling jobs is another approach. Last summer, General Dynamics announced that if the Department of Energy picked it to build giant magnets for the super collider, it would manufacture them in Hammond, La. Its competitor, Grumman Corp., said in May of this year that it would build the magnets in Shreveport, La., if it won the competition. Executives for both contractors cited the proximity of the Louisiana sites to Waxahachie, Texas, where the atom smasher is to be built. They also cited supplies of skilled workers. But the firms also had positioned themselves to deliver hundreds of jobs to Sen. J. Bennett Johnston's home state. The Louisiana Democrat is chairman of the Senate's Appropriations energy and water subcommittee and the Energy and Natural Resources Committee. Both panels play crucial rules in providing money for the super collider. ``I guess it didn't hurt,'' General Dynamics spokesman Jack Isabel said of the relation between the company's decision to locate in Louisiana and the fact that it is Johnston's state. ``That's not a factor,'' said Grumman spokeswoman Miriam L. Reid, adding, ``We certainly are aware of Senator Johnston.'' Another way to draw attention to a project is to bring decision-makers out to the lab _ all expenses paid. Last December, the National Science Foundation _ one of 96 federal agencies and agency subdivisions involved in science _ did what it does every year: It invited congressional staffers to visit federal bases in Antarctica. Five aides accepted, all from Congress' budget and appropriations committees. They were flown commercially to New Zealand and carried to Antarctica on a scheduled cargo run by a foundation-owned C-130 aircraft. There, they spent four days being ferried by helicopter to research facilities. The cost to taxpayers was about $27,000, according to figures provided by Joel Widder, the foundation's head of congressional affairs. The benefit far exceeds that, he said. ``We've instilled in them a never-to-be-forgotten experience,'' Widder said. ``The next time a member turns to staff and says, `Why should we support this?', that staffer has been there.'' Competitors for federal science dollars do battle in two legislative arenas. One is the budget resolution, which makes recommendations for broad areas of spending such as health, defense and environment. While not binding, the blueprint is an important statement of priorities that frequently is heeded later in the budget process. The second target is the 13 annual appropriations bills, which actually provide the money for government. Each bill finances one or more agencies, and federal science spending is spread among nine of the measures. In 1988 _ the most recent year for which the National Science Foundation has figures _ the government distributed science funds to 2,769 colleges and universities, 46 academic system offices such as state university headquarters, and 717 non-profit, independent institutions like hospitals. There also are 218,000 scientists and engineers on the government payroll and many of them are additionally eligible for federal grants. And the foundation says that last year, there were 41,270 companies involved in high technology, many of which sought government contracts. With that kind of competition, ``you've just got to get in there and market yourself,'' said Cleon Arrington, vice president for research at Georgia State University.
