DOC.HEAD: Super Collider Ads Aimed at Exclusive Audience
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Statue of limitations in 2nd graf is cq.
DOC.HEAD: With BC-Science Spending, b0999
DOC.TEXT: One advertisement depicted a portion of the globe with only stars and the blackness of space where the United States should be and asked, ``Where would America be without basic research?'' Another showed a close-up of the Statue of Liberty and proclaimed, ``This has never been a statue of limitations.'' A third pictured only a horseshoe magnet and announced, ``It takes more than luck to build superconducting magnets.'' The ads _ full-color and full-page _ have run about 20 times over the last two years in a pair of publications that circulate to many of the nation's policy makers. All three tout the superconducting super collider, the $8 billion government atom smasher planned for Waxahachie, Texas. But only one ad _ the one with the horseshoe magnet _ provides more than a mention of the sponsor, General Dynamics. The ad campaign shows how a large corporation can fight for a share of the federal science budget. The St. Louis-based defense contractor is hot after a contract from the Department of Energy to build at least some of the 12,000 superconducting magnets the super collider will need. These magnets _ each about 50 feet long _ will guide protons to high-speed collisions in the giant accelerator so scientists can study nature's building blocks. The Energy Department says the overall worth of the magnet contract will be more than $1 billion. But General Dynamics knows Congress first has to agree that the super collider should be built. And that's a top priority at General Dynamics' office in suburban Arlington, Va., where the 100 employees include six registered lobbyists. ``You're not goig to sell your magnets without the project,'' Alvin Spivak, Washington spokesman for the company, said recently. While Congress considers whether to provide $318 million for the super collider, as President Bush requested in his fiscal 1991 budget, General Dynamics is keeping its name in circulation through the ad campaign. Company spokesman Fred Bettinger in San Diego said the ads cost about $80,000 _ more than many small companies, universities and other groups can afford to spend in pursuit of federal science aid. Two of the ads mentioned General Dynamics only at the bottom of the copy: ``General Dynamics _ A Strong Company for A Strong Country.'' Only the horseshoe magnet ads touted the company's own attributes: 14 years of building superconducting magnets for other particle accelerators. ``General Dynamics is ready to join the team that will build America's most powerful research tool,'' it said. The ads were taken out in Roll Call, a twice-a-week newspaper that covers Congress, and The National Journal, a weekly magazine that features in-depth articles on issues and personalities in Washington. Both publications boast readerships that include large numbers of lawmakers, legislative aides and agency officials.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, July 30

DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines and several top managers were charged with falsifying safety and maintenance records in New York and Atlanta in a scheme that allegedly allowed unsafe planes to fly. The 60-count criminal indictment cited tampering with log books, work cards and computerized maintenance records at John F. Kennedy International and La Guardia airports in New York, Hartsfied International Airport in Atlanta and Eastern headquarters in Miami. The federal charges capped a 10-month investigation and plea bargain talks that collapsed when Eastern refused to admit to a conspiracy.

The nation's privately run savings institutions lost $271 million in the first three months of this year, a worse showing than in the same period a year ago but a sharp improvement over the previous quarter. The Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision said Wednesday the red ink compared with a $3.1 billion loss in the fourth quarter of 1989 and a $10 million profit in the first quarter of 1989. The figures do not include 350 thrifts which were still open at the end of March but were controlled by the Resolution Trust Corp., a new agency charged with closing and selling failed S&Ls.

The savings and loan crisis should not deter Congress from permitting commercial banks to venture into the insurance and securities industries, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady said. The thrift industry was deregulated without requiring S&L owners to risk more of their own money, Brady told the Senate Banking Committee Wednesday. Consequently, any expansion of bank powers ought to be linked to strong capital requirements, he said.

The Securities and Exchange Commission reluctantly approved a proposed New York Stock Exchange rule change that would limit index arbitrage when the the Dow Jones industrial average rises or falls 50 points. The change was approved unanimously Wednesday by the SEC although all four commissioners expressed misgivings about the 50-point threshhold and one said he would file a additional comments critical of the move. The change is a one-year pilot program, with the Big Board required to give the SEC a progress report after six months.

Factory orders for ``big-ticket'' durable goods plummeted 3.2 percent in June, the government said in a report that raised new concerns that the United States could be flirting with a recession. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that demand for durable goods, items ranging from bicycles to battleships, fell $4.14 billion to a seasonally adjusted $124.69 billion last month.

Digital Equipment Corp. reported a $256.7 million fourth-quarter loss, the computer giant's first ever quarterly loss and a reflection of a voluntary severance program under which 3,000 employees left over the last 12 months. Digital said Wednesday that its restructuring program included plans to cut another 5,000 to 6,000 people in the coming months through voluntary severance and attrition.

OPEC ministers began preliminary talks aimed at raising the price of crude oil worldwide and soothing Iraqi anger over cartel members exceeding production quotas. The ministers, who start formal meetings Thursday, appeared willing to bring the price per barrel to at least $20. The current price is $18. Cash-hungry Iraq wants an increase to $25, and it has accused Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates of pushing down oil prices by exceeding their OPEC production quotas.

Sales of existing homes posted their first increase in nine months in June, but analysts were divided on whether the modest 1.2 percent gain offered a glimmer of hope for the depressed housing sector. The National Association of Realtors said Wednesday that sales of existing single-family homes edged up to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.34 million units.

The House sustained President Bush's veto of a bill guaranteeing unpaid family and medical leave for American workers. The House voted 232-195 on Wednesday to override Bush's veto, falling 53 votes short of the required two-thirds majority. Supporters lost five votes from the bill's original passage in May.

Stock prices struggled to a small gain Wednesday, extending their cautious comeback from the selloff that swept through the market at the start of the week. The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 industrials rose 8.42 to 2,930.94. The dollar was mixed in foreign exchange. Bond prices were moderately higher. Gold futures prices rose substantially; copper futures advanced; energy futures fell; livestock and meat futures were higher; and grains and soybean retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Shocking? Hardly
Also moved in advance
DOC.TEXT: A shock a day seems to send quivers through the world of business and economics of late, and the surprising thing about it is that none of them should be a shock at all. The White House announcement that the budget deficit might be bigger than anticipated was almost in the nature of things _ it has happened just about every year in the past 20, but it was widely referred to as a shock. ``It should have come as no surprise to anyone,'' said economist William Dunkelberg, ``except for recent arrivals from Mars.'' Similarly, presidents have a long tradition of promising to keep a rein on taxes, but few succeed. Still, millions were surprised when President Bush reversed himself and said he might consider a tax increase. Judging by the reaction of stock market analysts, one of the most violent shocks in recent weeks was the slide in corporate profits, although that slide has been underway for well over a year, and extensively documented. Perhaps equally or even more shocking is that the evidence of a downturn was ignored by so many people who claim to have a deep understanding of corporate finances. Did their hopes suffocate their intellect? Perhaps. There even remains some residual dismay about the downturn of building and real estate in some parts of the country, although there has never been a time this century when these areas of the economy were not subject to cycles. The economy and its parts oscillate. Seldom do they draw a straight line up or down for very long, and one of the more pronounced up-down cycles is in real estate. It's there to be seen in the charts and graphs. Equally pronounced are cycles in securities markets, but you'd never have guessed it from the public display of shock when stocks took a dive on Monday, July 23. The real shock was that so many should have been shocked. Consider some of the evidence that investor expectations might have been stronger than profits: _Various statistical indicators had for months shown the disparity: price- to-earnings ratios, stock yields in relation to bond yields, dividend yields. _Earnings improvements had crested more than a year ago. _Various companies were issuing notices that earnings might be worse than anticipated. You may be sure, too, that there will be expressions of shock if the economy as a whole falls into recession, but that's the lesson of history. To experience eight years of expansion, as now, is a rare experience in America. Inevitably, economies disrupt themselves; their own actions, mainly their excesses, undermine their health. Excesses such as overly large inventories, waste, overhiring, sloppy management, poor workmanship. If these don't bring an end to expansion, then poor fiscal policy, such as excessive taxes or spending, or unwise monetary policy, such as overly tight money, might accomplish the deed. Whatever the cause, the economy eventually needs to take a rest, rid itself of excesses, regroup. It must lay low before expanding again, and during that time people who should know better will say it is down for the count. That's the way it has been and most likely that's the way it will continue for a while more.

DOC.HEAD: From Pie Charts To Pie Recipes, Tandy Unveils New Home Computer
LaserPhotos NY37, NY85 of July 25
DOC.TEXT: Tandy Corp.'s newest home computer has joined the ranks of Hoover vaccuum cleaners and Del Monte canned fruit in earning the Good Housekeeping seal of approval. The Tandy 1000 RL, which was unveiled Wednesday and is available at more than 7,000 Radio Shack stores nationwide, incorporated dozens of tasks families said they performed most frequently, like compiling a grocery list, balancing a checkbook, taking messages and charting expenses. The computer, the first to be sanctioned by Good Housekeeping magazine, contains 30 recipes from the New Good Housekeeping Cookbook and can instantly alter recipes to vary the number of servings. The introduction of the 1000 RL comes a month after IBM introduced a relatively low-priced home machine, also designed for people who are not well versed in complicated computer technology. The 1000 RL, which Tandy recommends be placed in the kitchen, also provides access to toll-free phone numbers for many airlines and hotel chains and can link the user to other information services such as Prodigy and CompuServe. ``It can become a central point in any home,'' said Howard Elias, Tandy's vice president of computer marketing, while demonstrating the machine at a press conference in a Manhattan penthouse. The Tandy systems are priced as low as $749.90, but accessories like a mouse and modem are extra. A color monitor with mouse, modem, clock and expanded memory runs about $1,199.70. The comparable IBM PS-1 system costs about $2,105. But the question remains whether consumers will accept the 1000 RL as an essential home appliance or merely dismiss it as a flashy entertainment center. ``Will this create a new habit?'' said Barry Bosak, an analyst with Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``You have to leave that open-ended right now.'' Currently about 20 million homes have computers, but experts suspect many of those machines are used for work taken home from the office rather than to help the consumer with household chores. ``The home market has not been exploited because it has been difficult to define,'' Bosak said. ``The office market has been much easier to define, and, of course, the dollars were there to spend.'' But Tandy Chairman and Chief Executive John V. Roach insists the tide is changing. ``The VCR boom absorbed a lot of disposable income, but that has abated, and now there is a heightened interest in home computers.'' He credited the latest introduction from IBM with helping to stir up interest in the home product category. And Apple Computer Corp., maker of the Macintosh line, is believed to be working on a lower-priced home computer for introduction this fall. Tandy's Elias said the home computer market has become the fastest growing segment in the industry, posting annual gains of 10 percent to 17 percent. Comparatively, the office computer market is expanding at a pace of between 5 percent and 10 percent a year. The 1000 RL has the ``potential to significantly increase unit sales in the desk-top area over the next six months,'' Roach said. The machine is designed to be left on at all times. The screen goes dark if the machine is not used for a specified number of minutes, but pages reappear at the touch of a key. And since it has no fan, the machine is silent. The PC-compatible 1000 RL is so easy to use that Tandy, traditionally viewed as the leader in the home computer market, is guaranteeing consumers can figure it out in about 15 minutes. ``We will work with you until we give up on you,'' Roach said. The 1000 RL is visually appealing. Tiny illustrated thumbtacks hold notes for family members on a computer ``bulletin board,'' and a diary, which can be accessed with a secret password, is illustrated as a book with lock and key. The machine also can produce pie charts detailing just what percentage of a consumer's monthly expenses went to pay utility bills. Tandy officials said the company is considering marketing the 1000 RL software package to be used on other machines.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Market, Ethics Focus of Money Management Camp
Also in AMs report.
LaserPhoto BA1 of July 25
DOC.TEXT: Twelve-year-old Megan Leef and her fellow summer campers aren't spending their time weaving baskets or shooting hoops _ they're watching the ticker tape. The 40 youngsters at the Money Management Camp for Young People at Loyola College are not necessarily junior tycoons. They are spending the week away from home to learn about earning money, saving it, and spending it wisely. They had barely said goodbye to their parents Monday when the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 100 points in 90 minutes as they watched the action at a brokerage house. But it didn't dampen their enthusiasm. ``I like what I already know about money. When I am a teen-ager, I'll be able to manage money instead of wasting it. I already wasted it today. I bought a New Kids on the Block key chain,'' said Megan, who will be in eighth grade at Bethesda's Westland Intermediate School in the fall. For the campers, games and swimming took a back seat to sessions on ethics, entrepreneurship, checking accounts and credit cards. A session on buying car insurance was a topic close to their hearts. Most of the campers know one thing about money _ they don't have much of it. ``I wanted to learn how to manage money because there's a great need to know the value of money when you have money, and not just throw it away,'' said 13-year-old Jeffrey Barzyk, who is entering eighth grade at Loyola Blakefield High School in suburban Baltimore County. Therese Steen, assistant director of continuing education in the Sellinger School of Business and Management at Loyola, is the head counselor. ``There is a great need for business education even for this age group, and this can be a fun aspect of their education,'' Steen said. ``Compound interest, what is a security, the difference between being smart and being an inside trader. ... There is a great concern about the misuse of credit in our society,'' Steen said. ``They will learn that credit helps businesses and new homeowners, if you don't abuse it.'' The campers are students from the Baltimore-Washington area and from Philadelphia who are ahead of their peers in math or English. The camp appears to be unique. ``This is the first I've heard of a camp of that nature for that age group,'' said Doug Barber, executive vice president of Future Business Leaders of America, a Washington-based organization for high school and college students. Jim Stone, a professor at the University of Minnesota and a researcher in a national study that looks at how schools relate class work to the world of work, said some schools offer programs on career options, but few students participate. ``The summer camp idea is a little different, but exciting,'' Stone said. ``Even though it's only a one-week shot, it offers the opportunity to become more aware than what they would normally see in the course of a day.''

DOC.HEAD: Last of Berkshire Town's Big Textile Mills to Close
Also in AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The last of the big, brick textile mills that once dominated this little town in the Berkshires is scheduled to close next spring, putting nearly 400 people out of work. ``This is a tremendous loss,'' said Mark Pasquini, executive director of the Northern Berkshire Industrial Park and Development after company officials announced they were closing the Waverly Fabrics mill and shifting its operations to South Carolina and Delaware. Last fall, officials of New York-based F. Schumacher & Co., which owns Waverly, announced they planned to cut back the Adams operation to a regional distribution and custom sewing center employing about 230 workers. But on Tuesday, James Hinthorn, vice president of human resources for F. Schumacher, announced the entire Adams operation would be phased out by April 1991, except for a retail outlet store. ``Our concept of a regional distribution center and regional customer workroom was predicated on sales continuing to grow rapidly,'' he said. ``Unfortunately, sales in the Northeast are substantially below what we had anticipated and that made it very difficult from a business standpoint to justify continuing operations.'' For decades, Waverly has been known for fine fabrics for home furnishings. The Adams plant produces draperies, bed covers, curtains and pillows. Its future in this community of 9,000 people has been uncertain since the Arnold Print Works, a dyeing plant that had been one of its main suppliers, shut down in 1984, despite state efforts to save it. The two plants had together employed more than 1,000 people. The sprawling Waverly plant was once part of the massive four-mill Berkshire Cotton Manufacturing Co. complex that employed 3,000 people at the turn of the century. In 1910, when the mills were booming, they swelled the population of the town to 13,106 people, a figure never since equalled. But in the 1930s the company was sold to Berkshire Hathaway and by the 1950s the last of its operations here had left for the South. Waverly and the state Department of Employment and Training set up a workers assistance center last month to help workers cope with the layoffs the company announced last fall. ``We'll have to find new jobs, we have no choice. But where?'' said Norma Sebastino. She has worked at the plant for 18 years and her husband for 28 years. ``My husband is 61. Where is he going to start? I'm 53, where am I going to start?'' she said. ``We've got a home. We've got children.''

DOC.HEAD: SEC Okays Big Board Circuit Breaker on Index Arbitrage
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators approved a rule that will allow a ``circuit breaker'' to limit index arbitrage on the New York Stock Exchange when the Dow Jones industrial average rises or falls 50 points. The change was approved unanimously by the Securities and Exchange Commission although all four commissioners expressed misgivings about the 50-point threshhold. The change is a one-year pilot program, with the Big Board required to give the SEC a progress report after six months. The proposal, actually an amendment to an existing NYSE rule, would limit index arbitrage to selling at or above the previous lowest price when the Dow Jones average is down 50 points. I would also limit buying at or below the previous highest price when the average is above 50 points. Index arbitrage is a computerized trading strategy through which traders try to take advantage of small price differences between the stock and futures markets by simultaneously buying large orders in one market while selling in the other. Critics have blamed program trading, particularly index arbitrage, for worsening market drops like the 1987 stock market crash, the 190-point drop last Oct. 13 and Monday's 100-point fall. Monday's drop triggered ``circuit breakers'' which prompted brief trading halts on futures markets at the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The NYSE first proposed an index arbitrage circuit breaker last February. In a written statement issued after the SEC vote, the Big Board said the rule change would minimize excess market volatility that might be due to index arbitrage. The move should promote market stabilization and enhance investor confidence, the exchange said. Under the rule change, when the Dow Jones average goes below 50 points or more from the previous day's close, index arbitrage orders to sell any stock listed in the S&P 500 stock price index can only be executed when the price is at or above the previous lowest price. Conversely, when the Dow rises 50 or more points, buy orders can only be executed when the price is at or below the previous highest price. SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden said he was voting for the rule change ``although I am unhappy with some of the aspects of this.'' Breeden said he's rather cure the disease instead of just treating it. For him, the disease is the low level of margins in the futures markets. Margins are the downpayments or collateral paid by investors who buy securities or futures contracts on credit. Currently, futures margins are set by the exchanges, usually only a fraction of the amount required in securities transactions. Breeden has been lobbying Congress to have authority for stock index futures and their margins transferred to the SEC. ``I have substantial doubts whether 50 points is the right trigger,'' said Commissioner Phil Lochner. ``The staff has that concern as does, obviously, a number of commissioners,'' Richard Ketchum, head of the SEC's Division of Market Regulation, after the vote. ``Fifty points triggers a reasonable number of times in a year. And there is a worry about any artificial impediments to trading at that level.'' ``On the other hand, trading on Monday was a pretty good indication that where the stock prices really picked up speed, where the slope of the decline increased was around 50 points. And where the futures price diverged from the stock price also was around 50 points,'' added Ketchum, who called 50 points ``a reasonable indicator.''

DOC.HEAD: Conde Nast Closes Woman Magazine, Woman's Day Auction Ends Without Sale
DOC.TEXT: In a pair of developments reflecting difficult times in the magazine business, Woman magazine is being closed and Woman's Day has been taken off the auction block for lack of an acceptable bid. Conde Nast Publications Inc. said Wednesday it would close Woman magazine after its September issue. Woman is the first Conde Nast magazine to cease publication since the Newhouse family took control of the company in 1959. Woman has been published for 10 years but was acquired by Conde Nast about 18 months ago. Separately, France's Hachette SA said it no longer plans to sell Woman's Day magazine, saying it was dissatisfied with the bids it received over the past two months and now will invest in improving it. Both Woman's Day and Woman have had double-digit declines in advertising pages for the first six months of the year amid an industrywide ad slump. Consumer magazine ad pages were off 3.3 percent industrywide in the first half of the year compared with the January-to-June period in 1989, with traditionally heavy magazine advertisers such as automotive and tobacco companies making major cutbacks in the spending. Magazine industry analyst Martin S. Walker said the two latest developments show ``the market has really decided that there is no longterm future in broadly-based women service magaines.'' He said the audience for such magazines is aging rapidly and that younger women appear to prefer more contemporary approaches. Conde Nast spent heavily over the past 18 months on Woman, improving the color and graphics, hiring top writers, getting space at the checkout stands and boosting circulation to nearly 600,000, publisher Rebecca Darwin. But in a statement, Conde Nast Chairman S.I. Newhouse Jr. said ``the magazine did not develop as we hoped it would.'' Newhouse was said to be unavailable for further comment, but Ms. Darwin said the magazine had been up for sale for several weeks and no serious bidders emerged. ``The feeling was that in this market it might take a long time to sell and the economics of it were that he felt it was best to cease publication,'' she said. The magazine was believed to be losing money. Conde Nast publishes 13 magazines including Vanity Fair, Vogue, Glamour, GQ, Gourmet and Mademoiselle. Hachette put Woman's Day up for sale in mid-May, saying it would enable the company's U.S. operation to trim its debt while focusing its attention on creating or acquiring special interest publications with international appeal. Along with Woman's DAy, a monthly magazine that claims current circulation of 4.6 million, Hachette had planned to sell the 21 Woman's Day Specials that appear periodically. ``The bids we received on Woman's Day did not reflect the true worth of this very valuable franchise,'' said Peter Diamandis, president and chief executive of Hachette's Diamandis Communications Inc. ``It is not in the best interests of the magazine or the company to sell,'' he said in a statement. Hachette now plans to invest in the magazine. The company never disclosed what minimum price it wanted for the magazine, which had an operating profit of more than $25 million last year. Didier Guerin, president of Hachette Publications Inc., which oversees Diamandis Communications, declined to say how many bids were received or who the bidders were. But the bidders reportedly included Britain's Robert Maxwell, Reader's Digest Association Inc. and Macfadden Holdings Inc., a partner in the National Enquirer tabloid. He said Hachette Publications had wanted to reduce its debt but was under no immediate pressure to do so. Most of the company's unspecified debt resulted from Hachette's $712 million purchase of the CBS magazine group from CBS Inc. in 1988. Hachette Publications owns 18 magazines, including Road & Track, Flying, Boating, Car and Driver, Elle and Memories. Guerin said all but two or three are profitable and that the company would now ``examine all the options'' for those that are unprofitable. He said Memories, an 18-month-old magazine that re-examines major stories years after they have happened, is one of the magazines being examined for possible sale. But he cautioned that a decision on whether to sell it has not been made.

DOC.HEAD: 1Q90 1Q89
Subsidies Still Alive and Well in Floor Debates
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Senate resumes debate 10 a.m. EDT; no House debate scheduled; lead prospects uncertain. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Government subsidies that assure farmers certain income and the nation a predictable food supply are holding fast as Congress moves toward completion of the 1990 farm bill. After vigorous debate, the House on Wednesday defeated, 263-169, a proposal by Reps. Richard Armey, R-Texas, and Charles Schumer, D-N.Y., to strip subsidies from farmers with adjusted gross incomes of $100,000 or more. It would have affected about 20,000 farm operations. Members of the Agriculture Committee persuaded colleagues to stick with the panel's intention to support huge and small farmers alike as a means of controlling the food supply. The House planned to complete debate and pass its version of the approximately $55 billion, five-year bill on Friday. The Senate was resuming debate today. ``I honestly was surprised,'' Agriculture Committee Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said of the vote on the Armey-Schumer amendment. ``I was feeling a much closer vote.'' He said environmental and labor organizations were helping his side. ``If you drive farmers out of the program, you take acres out of the program that you will not be able to keep environmentally sound,'' de la Garza said. As for organized labor, he said, ``I think their interest is jobs. Like I tell my friends in the UAW (United Auto Workers) in Detroit: no farmer, no pickup.'' Armey said he and his supporters knew they were underdogs before the vote. ``We wanted to shape the debate with the interests of consumers, taxpayers and small farmers in mind, and we were successful in that regard,'' he said. Urban lawmakers said they did not understand why the wealthiest farmers could not be cut free when aid to the poor was consistently being reduced. Armey said the amendment would have saved $900 million annually from the approximately $10 billion a year the bill foresees spending to support wheat, corn, cotton, soybeans and rice. ``These people are not the family farmer,'' said Schumer. Their income from the farm is only 4 percent of their income. ``Yes, they are the large agricultural businesses that don't need subsidies. ... the investors and the multimillionaires who farm for a hobby. ... They are investors who live far away and don't even till the soil. Rep. Edward Madigan of Illinois, the ranking Republican on the Agriculture Committee, argued that the Schumer-Armey amendment would cost the taxpayers more than the program in the bill. It would take farmers out of control of the government, enabling them to put more land into production and cause surpluses that would drive prices down, Madigan said. Farmers still in the program would get high deficiency payments from the government if prices went too low, he said. Besides establishing price support programs for commodities, the farm bill sets policy for nutrition programs, agricultural exports, soil and water conservation, agricultural research and extension work, food inspection and other responsibilities of the Agriculture Department. In other action Wednesday, both the House and Senate fended off attacks on the peanut program, one of the most protectionist programs in agriculture. A Senate amendment that would have ended quotas, removed all restrictions on the planting of peanuts and authorized the secretary of agriculture to establish a new price support for the crop was defeated, 57-41. The House ruled an identical amendment out of order after Rep. Charles Hatcher, D-Ga., cited a Congressional Budget Office estimate that the amendment would cost the taxpayers $55 million next year. The House also: _Accepted an amendment, 256-164, that would require the agriculture secretary to start a management program for dairy products if surpluses reached 6 billion pounds, instead of the 7 billion pounds originally in the bill. _Approved an amendment on voice vote to gradually lower supports on wool and mohair from $200,000 per producer in 1991 to $100,000 in 1994. The Senate, meanwhile, rejected, 72-26, an effort to tie target prices to the Consumer Price Index minus 4.3 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Union Asks NLRB Help In Getting Greyhound Drivers Back Behind Wheel
DOC.TEXT: Union attorneys have asked for federal help in forcing Greyhound Lines Inc. to reinstate immediately its 6,300 striking bus drivers. In a letter to the National Labor Relations Board, the Amalgamated Transit Union says pending court battles against Greyhound will take too long to resolve and even if the union wins, members could be left with no jobs and no money. NLRB spokesman David Parker said Wednesday the agency had not received the letter and would not comment on the request. NLRB General Counsel Jerry Hunter already has obtained an injunction against the union barring it from further violent acts in the dispute. ``The striking employees' resources are now depleted, and their health care and homes are at risk,'' the letter from union attorney Martin J. Burns said. The request is the latest move by the union, whose drivers went on strike March 2 in a dispute over wages and job security. Dallas-based Greyhound, which operates the only nationwide bus system, has continued running at reduced levels since the strike began. The union cites the company's financial troubles in asking the NLRB to seek an injunction requiring the reinstatement. Greyhound filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy court protection from creditors on June 4, citing increased expenses from fighting the initially violent strike. In addition the NLRB's Hunter said Greyhound had committed an unfair labor practice by immediately instituting a new contract on March 2 when no impasse existed in negotiations. Greyhound maintains an impasse did exist and is challenging the finding in hearings before an administrative law judge in Minneapolis. If the company loses, it could be forced to reinstate the 6,300 striking drivers and give them back pay from the time the strike began. Hearings aren't scheduled to begin on the dispute until mid-September, however, and could drag on through the courts for years. ``Meanwhile, the employees who have exercised their ... rights will be confronted with financial ruin,'' Burns said. The ATU says the potential back pay is accumulating at between $3 million and $4 million a week, and the burden of such a claim would insure Greyhound's financial failure and leave the drivers with no jobs and no money, even if they eventually win. ``Greyhound's refusal to reinstate the striking employees denies them and the union of statutorily protected rights now which can never be fully vindicated,'' Burns said. ``The board's and the union's interests can be served with a simple injunction directing Greyhound to reinstate striking drivers under terms and conditions that existed prior to Greyhound's unfair labor practice.'' Greyhound spokesman George Gravley did not comment on the request. He said the company was preparing for the Minneapolis trial.

DOC.HEAD: NII Lacks Votes For Board Candidates, Chairman Says
DOC.TEXT: A partnership seeking control of National Intergroup Inc. has enough votes to fill three seats on a 10-member board of directors, keeping NII's own candidates out, according to the partners and the company's chairman. ``Our tally shows that we don't have enough votes to elect our directors,'' Chief Executive Officer Howard M. Love said at a news conference Wednesday after the holding company's annual shareholders' meeting in Pittsburgh. About 200 NII stockholders and proxies attended the meeting to elect three new directors. Candidate slates were nominated by the company and the dissident group, Centaur Partners of New York, NII's largest stockholder with 16.5 percent of outstanding shares. Centaur principals Melvyn J. Estrin and Abbey J. Butler said they believed stockholder support for them was overwhelming but would not say how many votes they thought they had. ``It is not a slight victory, not a slight win,'' Butler said. If Centaur's candidates are elected as expected, the shareholder group will have three seats on a board of 10. Estrin said he believed the seven directors already seated would respond to the arguments of the three new members. ``We do think that the shareholder vote is a mandate,'' Estrin added. They said board nominees el in Vichy after viewing director Claude Berri's new film ``Uranus.'' Both cars were traveling about 25 mph, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Stotler Group Plansd to Close its Main Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: Stotler Group Inc. has announced that it will shut down its principal subsidiary, once a giant among the nation's commodity brokerages. Stotler, headed by Chicago Board of trade Chairman Karsten Mahlmann, said in a news release Wednesday that subsidiary Stotler and Co. ``determined that it is in its and its customers' best interests to wind down its commodity futures brokerage business in an orderly manner over the coming days.'' The announcement came at the same time that Chicago-based Stotler Group reported that it had failed to meet about a $750,000 obligation on its short-term loans and faces $7.6 million in additional obligations maturing or otherwise coming due in the next 30 days, including a $1.1 million interest payment. Stotler officials did not return telephone calls seeking further comment on the company's plans. Mahlmann was in meetings Wednesday and a spokesman said he was unavailable for comment. On Tuesday, Stotler lost its top-rank trading status on all futures exchanges and faced a struggle for survival after a proposed bailout of its parent company collapsed. Stotler Group announced the tentative bailout offer _ reportedly $10 million from a Taiwanese party _ last week. But the deal was subject to approval from the investor's board of directors, ``which approval was not obtained,'' Stotler said. As a result, ``Stotler Group's debt obligations must immediately be financed or restructured,'' the company said. The publicly owned Stotler Group also said it was considering selling some of its subsidiaries or assets to meet its debt obligations. Stotler and Co. is the Stotler Group's principal subsidiary. Stotler also owns R.G. Dickinson & Co., a futures brokerage in Des Moines, Iowa. Mahlmann is Stotler's managing partner, but has not run the firm's day-to-day operations for more than year. He is better known as chairman of the Board of Trade, the world's oldest and largest futures exchange. Stotler officials have not discussed publicly the reasons for the firm's financial problems. They are believed to stem in part from a recent rapid expansion, including the opening of new domestic branch offices and joint ventures with South American and European partners. Stotler, an old-line brokerage with roots in the grain business, once was one of the nation's 10 largest commodity brokerage firms, controlling nearly $300 million in customer funds.

DOC.HEAD: UAW: Chrysler Setting Poor Tone for Talks
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp.'s chief negotiator has set a tone for talks with the United Auto Workers that will make it tough to agree to a contract this summer, a union official says. ``The attitude of Chrysler management is far more arrogant than it is for the other two'' automakers, UAW Vice President Stan Marshall, head of the union's Chrysler Department, said Wednesday. ``That sets a tone right off. I did not like the opening session by a long ways... And I'm sure that will carry on through,'' he said. Marshall specifically criticized Chrysler's labor Vice President Anthony St. John for broadly outlining to the media three concepts the company wanted to pursue at the talks. They included some form of an employee ownership plan, a plant-by-plant reward system linked to productivity and a multi-employer health-care trust plan designed to cut rising costs. Marshall said talking about the issues with the media before discussing them with the UAW bargaining team made a ``mockery'' out of the negotiation process. Chrysler issued a statement Wednesday afternoon through spokesman Tom Houston saying: ``It is very important that all Chrysler's constituents be aware of the very difficult situation the company faces. We put our concerns before the union in a general context and will be spelling out the details as negotiations unfold. ``The UAW is a respected partner and it is our hope that they will work with us toward a successful conclusion to these negotiations.'' Since before the talks began last week at General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler, there has been speculation that there may be a break in a tradition of pattern bargaining, or arriving at a contract at one automaker and then more or less imposing it on the other two. When negotiations opened with Chrysler last Friday, UAW President Owen Bieber said flatly that the union was basing its bargaining strategy on the pattern tradition. Ford has far fewer employees on layoff status than does Chrysler and is not planning on closing any plants. Chrysler plans to stop production at its St. Louis car plant a week after UAW contracts with each of the Big Three expire Sept. 14. The negotiations involve about 450,000 UAW-covered employees at the Big Three, about 60,000 of them at Chrysler. Marshall said Chrysler is not in nearly the same financial health as are Ford and GM. Chrysler, which reports second-quarter earnings next week, has said it made $71 million in the first quarter, an 80 percent drop from that period last year. Ford and GM earnings dropped in the first quarter, but not as steeply as Chrysler's.

DOC.HEAD: Columbia Sells Junk Bonds for $3 Billion
DOC.TEXT: Troubled Columbia Savings & Loan said it has agreed to sell its high-risk junk bonds to a Canadian-led investment group for $3 billion. However, the buyer will make only a 10 percent down payment, and borrow the rest from Columbia with the bonds themselves as security. That means taxpayers could still wind up holding the bonds if there is a default and the thrift is seized. The price is $68 million more than the bonds' value on Columbia's books as last reported publicly, but the gain is too little to offset its insolvency. Last year's thrift bailout legislation forced Columbia to write down the value of its junk bonds by $1 billion. It was $215 million in the red at last report, as of March 31, and needs hundreds of millions of dollars beyond that to avoid the possibility of seizure by regulators. Columbia's former chief, Thomas Spiegel, was accused this month of squandering $19 million on various ventures, some in partnership with his friend and financial ally, junk bond pioneer Michael Milken. Spiegel angrily denied the charges, which regulators made in a civil lawsuit. Most of Columbia's bonds were sold by Milken to Spiegel, who was paid $9 million in 1985, the highest amount ever for a thrift manager. Not sold Wednesday was another unusual investment, a package of private equity securities that Columbia has estimated could be sold at a profit of up to $200 million. ``We have reason to believe that sale of those could bring us back to a positive capital position,'' Columbia Chief Executive Edward G. Harshfield said in a telephone interview. Asked if Columbia can avoid seizure by regulators, Harshfield said: ``I still think we've got a fighting chance here.'' The buyer of the junk bonds is a partnership assembled by Gordon Investment Corp., a merchant bank based in New York and Toronto. Gordon America L.P. will pay $300 million down and give Columbia a note for the remaining $2.7 billion at a 10.5 percent interest rate. ``The contract that we executed today with Columbia Savings and Loan reflects our view that the portfolio represents attractive investment values over the long term,'' Thomas I.A. Allen, a partner in Gordon Investment Corp., said in a statement. The twist in the deal is that the junk bond package itself will serve as security. That means the insolvent Columbia _ or taxpayers if the thrift is seized _ could wind up holding the junk bonds again if Gordon America defaults. In its statement, Columbia acknowledged Gordon America paid a premium for the bonds. And Harshfield acknowledged that the thrift might wind up with the bonds again. But, he said, ``In the meantime, we put $300 million between the taxpayer and the bondholder.'' Regulators allowed Columbia to continue operating even though it was insolvent while its managers tried to find a buyer for the junk bonds. As part of last year's savings and loan bailout, thrifts were forced to sell their junk bonds. That coincided with a steep decline in the value of the securities, catching thrifts with big junk bond portfolios in a double bind.

DOC.HEAD: Reports: Securities Companies Investigated In Wake of Black Monday
DOC.TEXT: More than 10 Japanese securities companies are being investigated for allegedly compensating favored customers for 16 billion yen, or $107 million, in losses following the 1987 stock market crash, major Japanese newspapers reported Thursday. The reports, which came out in the early afternoon Thursday, appeared to have an immediate impact on Tokyo currency and stock markets, stimulating a fall in both the yen and in share prices. Yamaichi Securities Co., Daiwa Securities Co. and about 10 other brokerage firms were said to have compensated favored clients after the Oct. 20 crash, in which the benchmark Nikkei Stock Average fell 14.9 percent, the largest daily fall on the Tokyo exchange. The reports were attributed to an investigation by the Tokyo Tax Administration, which refused to comment. The securities companies allegedly sold warrants, convertible bonds and other market instruments at bargain prices to special institutional and individual clients who later sold them back to the brokers at market rates for a profit, the reports said. The companies then recorded the sums used for repurchasing the bonds as losses and deducted them from their taxes in fiscal 1987. The reports said that the Tokyo Tax Administration has been reviewing such transactions and planned to assess the companies a total of 7 billion yen, or $46.6 million, in additional taxes. The administration reportedly views such writeoffs as contributions or entertainment fees which are therefore taxable, they said. Among the companies named, Yamaichi Securities was said to have compensated clients for the largest amount of losses of up to 8 billion yen, or $53.3 million. In a statement, Masazumi Konichi, a senior Yamaichi official, said tax authorities had already completed their review of Yamaichi financil proceedings during 1987. ``We understand that all bond transactions that took place during that time were fair transactions. There is no truth in the reports of loss compensation,'' he said. The release of the report, which appeared in the evening edition of each of Japan's major national newspapers, had a major impact on Tokyo financial markets. The dollar closed higher at 150.11 yen, up 0.98 yen from Wednesday's finish of 149.13 yen. On the stock market, the Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues lost 331.52 points, or 1.05 percent, closing at 31,369.75. ``The news of made many market players lose confidence,'' said Yozo Asai, an analyst with Yamaichi.

The stock market declined broadly today, beset by persistent worries about corporate profits. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 12.13 to 2,918.81 in the first half hour of trading. Advancing issues outnumbered declines by about 5 to 3 on the NYSE, with 897 up, 574 down and 501 unchanged. DOC.HEAD: Cult Leader Seeks Ties With Miami's Mainstream
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The menu included white wine, pasta salad and _ for some _ the first taste of Yahweh ben Yahweh. ``Egypt has her pyramids. India has her Taj Mahal. France has her Eiffel Tower,'' the self-proclaimed son of God told business leaders and politicians. ``Miami has the son of Yahweh. The world's greatest attraction is in your midst...I'm here.'' Yahweh's lunch appearance before the elite Manatee Bay Club in May was full of self-glorifying rhetoric, his trademark since arriving in Miami 11 years ago. But it also signified another important step in his strategy to win acceptance among business and political power brokers. At times, the 54-year-old former Hulon Mitchell Jr. sounds more like a Rotary Club booster than leader of a white-robed sect under federal investigation for alleged crimes that could include extortion and the murder of ``blasphemers.'' Yahweh ben Yahweh boasts of his estimated $8 million in meticulously renovated real estate, including motels, a recording studio and a new supermarket. He speaks passionately about improving blighted neighorhoods and using capitalism to help impoverished blacks. He's hobnobbed with developers, city commissioners and Mayor Xavier Suarez. Followers have abandoned their six-foot wooden staffs for briefcases and are encouraged to learn a little Japanese to help business. Yahweh ben Yahweh is just as committed to denying allegations against his Temple of Love Inc., subject of a federal grand jury probe. He calls detractors jealous, spiteful and drug-addicted. He calls himself the ``prince of peace.'' ``You know well that good is going to overcome evil,'' said Yahweh at a recent interview in his attorney's office. ``That's what `Star Wars' is all about.'' The story of Yahweh ben Yahweh could also be movie material. Drought and depression were strangling Oklahoma in October 1937 when Hulon and Pearl Olive Mitchell had the first of 13 children. The son, named after his father, grew up in the black section of Enid, Okla. The Mitchell children sang in the choir of their father's Pentecostal church. One, Leona Mitchell, would become a soprano with New York's Metropolitan Opera. Mitchell Jr. married at 19 and studied psychology at Phillips University in Enid. After a divorce, he moved to Atlanta and earned a master's degree in economics at Atlanta University. A second marriage ended in separation. In Atlanta, he began to preach interpretations of the Bible under the name Father Michel. He moved to Miami's Liberty City section in 1979 claiming to be the messiah of a lost black tribe of Israel. His turban is held by a gold pin bearing his name in Hebrew _ ``God, the son of God.'' In the early 1980s, Yahweh and followers mostly confined themselves to Miami's black neighborhoods seeking money and converts. They began to acquire both. They also began to establish a militant reputation. In 1986, tenants of an apartment building north of Miami resisted eviction after the sect purchased it. There were scuffles, shouting matches and slayings. A former Yahweh member, Robert Rozier, pleaded guilty to killing two tenants and two other slayings. He was sentenced to 22 years in prison and is helping federal prosecutors investigate the sect. Last year, a federal judge in Miami awarded 27 tenants more than $1.5 million for wrongful eviction and blasted the Yahwehs for a ``terrorist occupation strategy.'' Thomas Equels, an attorney for the tenants, said two wrongful death suits were settled for about $500,000. Yahweh ben Yahweh testified in court he had no role in the violence. He has not been charged. Since the apartment incident and other allegations of Yahweh-related harassment, Yahweh ben Yahweh has worked diligently to recast the group's image. He's backed away from fist-pounding messages about white oppression and retribution against ``blasphemers.'' He says he was speaking figuratively about toppling white-dominated industries when he told followers to bring him ``the head of a white man.'' He cultivates ties with political leaders, black and white, and belongs to mainstream business groups, including the Greater Miami Chamber of Commerce and the American Hotel Motel Association. ``The focus is always on my detractors, on negativity,'' he said. ``They may focus for two seconds on a physical building or something that I've swept out of the ghetto. And they ignore how I've brought this building alive without drugs, without crime...For all around that building is still full of crime, drugs, alcholism, fights and destruction.'' The Yahwehs' work has not gone completely unheralded. Three years ago, the Miami's Urban League chapter gave Yahweh ben Yahweh its highest honor, the Whitney M. Young Humanitarian Award, named for the league's national president during the '60s. ``Yahweh ben Yahweh demonstrates that you can take depressed properties and turn them around,'' said Urban League T. Willard Fair, president of the Urban League of Greater Miami. ``He's an inspiration to the entire community.'' ``You have very few mainstream religious groups willing to invest in the community like the Yahwehs,'' said Newell Daughtrey, director of the Business Assistance Center, a development group focusing on black neighborhoods. ``I don't know where there money comes from. I don't know why someone would follow him. All I know is what I observe. And all I've seen has been good economically.'' Yahweh ben Yahweh denies he requires disciples to surrender their money, but declined to give details on the group's finances or membership. Yahweh followers approached on the streets refused to discuss their faith or finances. State records show the Temple of Love is incorporated as a non-profit company. But Yahweh ben Yahweh is not among the executives listed with the Secretary of State's office. The sect also tightly regulates contact with its leader. Interviews with him are videotaped. He claims a metal detector at the Temple of Love is used to screen guns and other ``weapons made of man.'' ``My people are good. There is nothing to hide,'' he said. ``I teach my people to drive 29 in a 30 mile-per-hour zone.'' A federal grand jury is looking into whether Yahweh and close aides in the Temple of Love ran a criminal enterprise from 1981 to 1986. Press reports suggest the probe includes allegations of extortion, arson and murder. But Ellis Rubin, attorney for Yahweh ben Yahweh, says the grand jury proceedings are secret and any details ``would just be an educated guess.'' Rozier, now under the federal witness protection program, is the principal informant, said Rubin. The U.S. Attorneys Office in Miami refused to comment. Yahweh says he is like the pope or a rabbi and should not be held accountable for alleged misdeeds of followers. ``I will never believe that the majority of the people of the earth are bad...I don't believe that the good people of this earth will ever swallow the made-up machinations of my detractors. The real issue is what I teach.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday July 30

DOC.HEAD: Posts Profit for Second-Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The Black & Decker Corp. said Thursday it posted a profit of $16.1 million in the second quarter after losing $5.2 million in the same period a year ago as its revenue soared 44 percent. The maker of power tools and other products used commercially and around the house said its profit amouynted to 26 cents a share in the three months ended July 1 in contrast to a loss of nine cents per share a year earlier. Revenue climbed to $1.22 billion from $847.6 million a year earlier. The results include revenues and earnings of Information and Electronic Systems and Dynapert, formerly reported on the consolidated balance sheet as businesses held for sale. The companies contributed approximately $220 million in revenue during the quarter. For the firtst half, the company said it earned $26.1 million, or 43 cents a share, up 23 percent from $20.7 million, or 35 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the first half rose 45 percent to $2.05 billion from $1.42 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Overproducers Kuwait, U.A.E. Express Willingness To Cut Output
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 5 grafs to UPDATE with first session ending, report of general preliminary agreement to raise prices. Pickup 4th, `At today's...' TRIMS. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: OPEC oil ministers said today there was general agreement among them to try to raise oil prices, and feuding cartel members Kuwait and Iraq publicly played down their differences over production quotas. ``We will have a new minimum reference price,'' Algerian oil minister Sadek Boussena, OPEC's new president, told reporters after the first two-hour session of the cartel's mid-year meeting. ``There are several positions but all of them are accepting higher prices.'' Libya indicated it wanted a higher quota for itself before it would agree to an overall production cap that would bolster prices, and Iraq wants a higher target price than some other members. But ministers expressed optimism they would reach an accord. Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Hisham Nazer, said the ministers wanted a strong pact to help in ``getting OPEC back on its feet.'' In the days leading up to the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries conference, Iraq had threatened to retaliate, possibly with military force, against Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, which it accused of exceeding production quotas. At today's gathering, Kuwait and Iraq made a show of friendliness amid indications that behind-the-scenes talks had cooled down their dispute. Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi, asked whether he would press his country's concerns about excess production, said: ``We have discussed performance ... and we are going to concentrate on what needs to be done from now on.'' Seated next to him in the conference room at a luxury Geneva hotel was the Kuwaiti delegation. ``We are friends. We are shaking hands with each other,'' said Kuwait's oil minister, Rasheed Salem al-Ameeri. ``It is just something which will be resolved.'' Iraq had reportedly massed troops along its disputed border with Kuwait to bolster oil and land claims. But diplomatic sources in Baghdad said Iraq had agreed to pull the troops back, and an Iraqi official confirmed that representatives of the countries would open talks this weekend in Saudi Arabia. Chalabi denied today that the troops were even dispatched. ``There is no such thing as massing of troops along the border,'' he said. The OPEC ministers have been under intense pressure to try to defuse the crisis between the two Persian Gulf producers and forge a united front on prices and production. Boussena, the cartel president, said OPEC's ``fortunes have faded badly,'' carrying the risk of bring member countries' economies ``to the brink of collapse.'' He told his colleagues today that the ``core of our problems lies ... in the lack of determination to keep a steady course of action.'' Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates have indicated a willingness to end the overproduction that prompted Iraq's threats. Publicly, however, the oil ministers of both countries denied they were pumping too much oil. ``We don't cheat,'' Mana Saeed Otaiba of the United Arab Emirates said today. ``We produce what we say is our quota.'' Ameeri, the Kuwaiti oil minister, said his country was ``producing within'' its supply quota of 1.5 million barrels a day. However, analysts say both countries have been pumping as much as 2 million barrels a day. The ministers of the 13-nation cartel appeared to be in agreement that their target price of $18 a barrel should be raised by at least $2. ``There is a general feeling that we want to have the price at least $20,'' Indonesian Oil Minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita said today. Iraq has proposed a target of $25 a barrel. But any new target price would have little effect on the world markets without a tight rein on production. The current world oil glut is keeping the cartel's average price down to about $16 a barrel. Crude oil prices dropped sharply in the spring, a decline blamed mostly on overproduction by Kuwait and the U.A.E. The average price of a basket of crudes monitored by the cartel soared to $20.46 a barrel in early January, but plunged to $13.64 less than six months later. It bounced back to $16.25 last week. To try to lift prices even more, the ministers were expected to agree to a proposal arranged by Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf producers to limit total production to about 22.5 million barrels a day in the coming months. Such an accord would require the cartel to slice output, with Kuwait and the U.A.E. holding output to 1.5 million barrels a day each. A confidential OPEC report, according to sources, estimated the group's supply at 23.5 million barrels a day in the April-June quarter of this year. OPEC Secretary-General Subroto said demand for the cartel's oil was expected to run at 21.8 million barrels a day in the third quarter, rising to 24.4 million barrels in the last three months of the year. OPEC members are: Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the U.A.E. and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Edge Higher; Grains Open Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices edged higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid reports of stronger soybean meal trade in Europe. Corn and wheat futures opened narrowly mixed. Speculation that the Soviet Union is preparing to buy more U.S. agricultural products also supported the grain and soybean markets, analysts said. That stemmed from reports that the Soviets received a $1 billion advance from the De Beers diamond cartel as part of an agreement under which De Beers will market Soviet diamonds. But gains were tempered by forecasts for more beneficial crop weather in the Midwest. The National Weather Service's latest six-to-10-day outlook predicts warmer- and wetter-than-normal conditions for the region during most of next week. In early trading, wheat futures were 1 cent lower to { cent higher with the contract for delivery in September at $3.01{ a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 1\ cents higher with September at $2.60\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower to 1 cent higher with September at $1.30 a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 4 cents higher with August at $5.86} a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed while pork bellies were sharply higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were .20 cent lower to .27 cent higher with August 77.47 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .30 cent lower to .13 cent higher with August at 88.47 cents a pound; live hogs were unchanged to .45 cent lower with August at 60.27 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .55 cent to 1.25 cents higher with August at 48.35 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures rose sharply on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Tourist Trinket Joint Also Has Customers at 1600 Pennsylvania Ave
Laserphoto
DOC.TEXT: An unassuming blue building along the highway north of town snags motorists' eyes with a sparkling silver goblet atop a sign that reads, ``Salisbury Pewter, Buses Welcome, Gift Shop.'' Sounds like one of those tourist places to buy last-minute gifts for relatives you forgot about while on vacation. It is. Prices start at $5. But Salisbury Pewter is more than an inexpensive trinket joint. It makes pewter for presidents. The Reagans took 352 pewter jewelry boxes from Salisbury Pewter to the Moscow Summit in Helsinki in 1988. Nancy Reagan gave pewter candy dishes, engraved with her signature, to senators' wives. The couple once ordered 6-inch trays engraved with the presidential seal and both their names. ``We did a mess of work for the Reagans,'' said Salisbury native Terry Gladden, president and co-owner of the company, which is projecting $1.5 million to $2 million in sales this year. Vice President Dan Quayle orders small, rounded baby cups engraved with a replica of the vice president's Washington residence. The Quayle name is stamped on the bottom. ``They usually get about 25 to 50 at a time. I guess they give them out as gifts to friends with babies,'' Gladden said. Regular customers include members of the Senate and House, every branch of the armed services, colleges and universities nationwide, the Maryland legislature and the Du Pont Co., among others. Tiffany & Co.'s 1990 corporate Christmas catalog included four items from Salisbury Pewter _ a candy dish, cup, jewelry box and purse mirror. Tiffany has been a customer for several years, but all its products must be stamped with Tiffany's name, Gladden said. The name doesn't matter. Gladden and his employees know who made it. ``I never thought I'd be in a Tiffany catalog. But it's because of the quality of the work we're giving,'' Gladden said. His employees ``really get fascinated when we get these special orders in here. It builds their ego.'' He said 85 to 90 percent of the business is custom work. Each piece is made by hand with a polished pewter that looks like silver but is much cheaper, Gladden said. The most expensive item is a 10-inch punch bowl for $250. The baby cups bought by the Quayles sell for $25. An engraved, sterling silver cup would cost about $250 and still look like one of Salisbury Pewter's cups, Gladden said. ``Everything here is made one piece at a time. It's all handcrafted like it was in the 1800s,'' he said. ``It's hand-spun, then hand-trademarked, then hand-polished.'' Still, there's one modern embellishment. Some engraving is done by computer, said Lynn L. Parsons, the engraving supervisor. She engraves by hand if the design is not available on a computer disk. ``You have to learn the right pressure for your hand so you know how deep to go. It takes a steady hand,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Continental Moving to Gain Back Control of it Stocks
DOC.TEXT: Continental Bank Corp. announced today it was moving to terminate a federal regulating agency's control of its interests. Continental officials said they planned to file a shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission that would bring about the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.'s release of its remaining 26 percent equity interest in the bank holding company. The FDIC acquired ownership of Continental stock in 1984 as part of a restructuring agreement providing federal assistance to the company. In recent years, the FDIC has sold nearly 36 million shares of Continental common stock for about $788 million in three public offerings and in a sale to the Continental Employees Stock Ownership Plan. The federal agency has also sold 12.8 million shares of Class A preferred stock to Continental for $273 million. The restructuring agreement will be terminated if the FDIC releases its remaining interest, with the proceeds of the sale going to the FDIC. ``This is a milestone with both financial and psychological significance for us,'' said Continental Chairman Thomas C. Theobald. ``Many people have worked long and hard to get us back to this point.''

DOC.HEAD: Smith to Drive First Saturn Day Before Retirement
DOC.TEXT: Retiring General Motors Corp. Chairman Roger Smith will drive the first completed Saturn car off the assembly line next week, a Saturn spokesman said Thursday. Spokesman Don Haberek said Smith will drive the car off the line at the Spring Hill, Tenn., manufacturing complex in a private ceremony on Monday, the day before Smith ends 41 years with GM, the last 9{ as chairman. Haberek declined to say what GM planned to do with the car, but said only that it was ``a car intended for sale.'' Saturn plans to begin supplying cars to a separate dealer network this fall. Base prices haven't been announced, but are expected to be between $10,000 and $12,000. GM said the car, conceived more than eight years ago, is designed to compete with cars made in the United States and Japan by Japanese automakers. There had been speculation that problems with plastic car parts put Saturn in danger of failing to complete the first Saturn car in time for Smith to drive it, but GM had said the deadline would be met.

The stock market drifted lower today, beset by persistent worries about corporate profits. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 10.64 to 2,920.30 by noontime on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 578 up, 708 down and 537 unchanged. Analysts said traders remained fearful of sudden selloffs in individual stocks in cases where company earnings reports fall short of expectations. That phenomenon has occurred over the past few weeks in such big-name issues as American Telephone & Telegraph, Dow Chemical and McDonald's Corp. Today, much attention was focused on automobile stocks as major American manufacturers posted their results for the second quarter of the year. Energy stocks fell for the second straight session. Exxon was down | at 49; Chevron 1[ at 76|; Mobil 1[ at 64~, and Atlantic Richfield 1] at 124].
