DOC.HEAD: CNBC Names New President
DOC.TEXT: The National Broadcasting Co., moving quickly to find a replacement for the head of its Consumer News and Business Channel cable service, appointed Albert Barber on Thursday as president of CNBC. Barber, 44, has been NBC's executive vice president and chief financial officer since 1987, and before that served in various management positions for 20 years at General Electric Co., which bought NBC in June, 1986. He will succeed Michael Eskridge, 45, who has been CNBC's president since it began in April last year. Eskridge said Monday he is leaving to form an independent company that manages broadcast properties.

DOC.HEAD: Procter & Gamble Completes Purchase
DOC.TEXT: The Procter & Gamble Co. said Thursday it has completed the purchase of the toiletries and fragrances portion of American Cyanamid's Shulton Group, excluding the Pierre Cardin fragrance line. Under the agreement announced last month, P&G acquired Shulton's Old Spice and Sante Fe men's toiletries and fragrances, and several other products. Terms of the sale were not announced. Procter & Gamble manufactures and markets a wide range of food and consumer products. It reported sales of $23.3 billion last fiscal year.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Has New Budget Proposal, But Talks Still Stalled
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with White House threat to keep Congress in town during recess; picks up 3rd graf pvs, White House... Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Republican budget negotiators are proposing higher taxes on alcohol as part a $50 billion package of taxes and spending cuts for next year, Sen. Bob Packwood said today. President Bush, meanwhile, is considering asking Congress to forego its month-long August recess if a budget deal is not struck soon, his spokesman said. ``There is a possibility that the president would ask the Congress to stay,'' said presidential press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. Bush would ``probably stay as well'' and give up his planned three-week vacation in Kennebunkport, Maine, next month if that becomes necessary, Fitzwater said. ``We would like to reach an agreement before the recess, that is the goal certainly that we have and we hope that the Democrats share that general time frame,'' Fitzwater said. He said ``no decision has been made'' yet on whether to keep Congress in town, suggesting there was still time to strike a deal. Bush and congressional leaders held their third consecutive morning meeting to discuss the slow-moving, 11-week-old negotiations today, but broke no new ground. Fiscal 1991 begins in just more than two months, on Oct. 1, and Congress plans to begin a month-long recess after next week. White House officials took a new budget proposal to Capitol Hill Wednesday evening and got the backing of most GOP leaders involved in the talks. The package consists of slightly more than $50 billion in savings, split roughly evenly between new taxes and spending cuts, according to Packwood, an Oregon Republican, and others. The 1991 deficit is expected to reach at least $169 billion unless action is taken, more than enough to trigger huge spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman law. The proposal includes higher excise taxes on alcohol, but otherwise resembles the taxes Bush proposed in the budget he released in January, Packwood told reporters today. Bush's spending plan included a cut in the capital gains tax rate, which Republicans argue would increase revenues because it would encourage the sales of property, and several minor new taxes. The new administration proposal would raise about $3 billion by limiting the deductability of state and local income taxes on federal tax returns, a GOP bargainer said today. Such deductions would be limited to no more than $10,000, said the negotiator, who asked not to be identified. The package does not include two other types of taxes _ on tobacco and on luxury items such as jewelry _ that the negotiators have been considering, said the official. The official also said the new administration package would slash benefit programs by $16 billion, including $6 billion in cuts to Medicare. It would cut defense spending by about $7 billion _ several billion dollars less than Democrats prefer _ and pare domestic and foreign aid programs by $4 billion more. House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, speaking with reporters after today's White House session, said major disagreement remains with the administration and Republicans over taxes, ``the composition of the package, who pays and how much.'' Gephardt, D-Mo., said today's talks included a discussion of tax options, including Democratic proposals for raising taxes on the richest Americans. Some Democrats have advocated doing away with the so-called ``bubble'' in the tax code, where middle-income Americans are taxed at a rate of 33 percent but joint filers earning upwards of $162,000 pay a lower 28 percent rate. ``We feel the tax code has become unprogressive,'' Gephardt said. However, ideas for eliminating the bubble by increasing taxes on the wealthy to 33 percent have not been well received by Republicans, participants in budget talks have suggested. There remain ``large and tough and difficult disagreements to bridge,'' Gephardt said. But Senate Minority Leade Bob Dole, R-Kan., said: ``We're making some progress. It may be hard to tell from the outside. But from the inside, I think we're making progress.'' ``We're at the hard stage now, trying to decide whether to stay here in August and get it done,'' he added. The GOP plan would save more than $500 billion over five years, relying heavily on cuts in benefit programs such as Medicare but leaving Social Security untouched, said one participant who asked to not be identified. Bargainers declined to discuss other details. But it remained unclear just when _ and how _ the Republicans would offer the plan to Democrats. ``We'll have one to present to them if they give one to us,'' said Packwood. Democratic negotiators met among themselves Wednesday and did not complete a proposal of their own. They are also at savings of $50 billion in 1991 and $500 billion over five years. ``We haven't gotten to the point where you put it all together yet,'' said Sen. Wyche Fowler, D-Ga. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said that as early as today, both sides will ``simultaneously'' put proposals on the table. But Democrats disputed that, saying no decision had been made on exchanging offers. They said they were reluctant to advance a proposal unless they knew the Republicans had a serious offer of their own. They also evidenced lingering distrust from recent Bush attacks on Democratic spending policies and an informal vote by House Republicans to oppose tax increases. ``If the president wants an agreement, the president is going to have to help both publicly and privately,'' Fowler said. Separately, the House Ways and Means Committee approved legislation extending federal authority to borrow money. The government is expected to reach its $3.122 trillion limit on borrowing next month. Because Congress will be in recess, lawmakers must approve legislation extending that ceiling before leaving town.

DOC.HEAD: National Power Posts Huge Loss, To Cut 5,000 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: National Power PLC, a British electricity generating company preparing for privatization, on Thursday posted a loss of 605 million pounds, or $1.1 billion, for the year and said it was cutting 5,000 jobs over the next five years. The state-owned company said it expected the job cuts to be achieved through attrition and voluntary retirements. It currently employs about 16,000 people, following 800 job cuts earlier this year. The results for the year ended March 31 were presented as if National Power had been an autonomous business throughout the year. National Power and the smaller PowerGen are the two generating companies officially formed in March from the break-up of the Central Electricity Generating Board. Their shares were to be offered to the public next year. But earlier this week, the government said it has held discussions with British conglomerate Hanson PLC that might lead to the private sale of PowerGen, which produces 18,700 megawatts of electricity annually. Energy Secretary John Wakeham said that if a serious takeover proposal also was made for National Power, which produces 29,700 megawatts annually, he would have to examine that as well. If sold to the public, National Power could raise between 2 billion and 2.5 billion pounds, or $3.6 billion to $4.5 billion, and PowerGen could raise 1 billion pounds, or $1.81 billion, analysts say. National Power said its results included extraordinary losses of 914 million pounds, or $1.7 billion, stemming mainly from costs associated with its restructuring ahead of privatization and the revaluation of its coal stocks. During the fiscal year, National Power had an operating profit of 456 million pounds, ot $825 million, and sales of 4 billion pounds, or $7.2 billion. Per-share and year-earlier figures weren't available, the company said.

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian Troubles Cut Appliance Maker's Profits
DOC.TEXT: Whirlpool Corp. said Thursday its second-quarter profit tumbled 26 percent despite a 4.1 percent increase in revenue and cited economic troubles affecting its Brazilian operations. The manufacturer of major home appliances said its net income sagged to $37 million, or 54 cents a share, for the three months ended June 30, compared with $50 million, or 72 cents a share, in the second quarter of 1989. Revenue for the period rose to $1.71 billion from $1.64 billion in the April-June period in 1989. Whirlpool said if the results of its Brazilian appliance making and marketing affiliates were excluded, net earnings for the quarter would have been up 18 percent. Chairman David R. Whitwam said results in North America were strong, due to higher shipment volumes, effective material cost controls, productivity improvement and aggressive marketing efforts. For the first six months of the year, Whirlpool reported net income of $66 million, or 96 cents a share, down 27.5 percent from $91 million, or $1.31 a share, a year earlier. Revenue for the first half rose 4 percent to $3.34 billion from $3.21 billion for the first half of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Sharply Lower
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices ended sharply lower on London's Stock Exchange Thursday, depressed by weaker-than-expected earnings from Imperial Chemical Industries PLC, a bellwether of British industry. ``The chemistry of the (ICI earnings) combined with the market's recent twitchy mood made the entire market volatile,'' one dealer said. ICI reported a 21 percent fall in half-year pre-tax profit to 733 million pounds, or about $1.3 billion. The results were well below market expectations of around 800 million pounds, or $1.4 billion. Shares in ICI, a major component of the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index, lost 65 pence, about $1.18, to close at 10.40 pounds, or $18.82. A hefty 7.6 million ICI shares changed hands. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 20.6 points, 0.9 percent, at 2,344.1 at the close. The low was 2,337.9 and the peak, 2,369.7. The Financial Times 30-share index closed down 14.2 points at 1,851.5. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 8.80 points to close at 1,266.56. Volume was 468.8 million shares compared with 427.5 million shares Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: GE to Pay $10 Million Criminal Fine In Defense Fraud Case
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to include GE statement and CLARIFY the breakdown between criminal and civil components of agreement
DOC.TEXT: General Electric Co. reached an agreement with the government today to pay a $10 million criminal fine for defrauding the Army on an $8 million battlefield computer system. The punishment, stemming from GE's conviction in a case earlier this year, is one of the largest levied against a company in a defense fraud but far less than the government initially wanted, which could have exceeded $50 million. The agreement also called for the nation's fifth-largest industrial company to pay $8.3 million to settle related civil suits and $11.7 million settle unrelated matters with the government that hadn't reached the litigation stage. U.S. District Judge Lowell Reed Jr., who accepted the agreement and sentenced two former company employees involved in the case, called the criminal fine against the company ``adequate, fair, and in the best interest of the public.'' GE said in a statement that company executives ``felt it was time to close these old cases which date back to the early 1980s and were pleased that the government has recognized the significance and the value of the improved procedures that GE started in 1985 by recommending a fine that is far less than the amount they originally sought.'' The judge said he had concluded the fine against GE was appropriate as he accepted the agreement, which also says GE relinquishes rights to appeal. The fine put GE into the ranks of large companies that have paid multimillion dollar fines for cheating the government on defense work in recent years. Northrop Corp. agreed to pay a $17 million fine in February for falsifying records on parts for the Cruise missile and Harrier jet. In 1988, Sundstrand Corp. agreed to pay a record fine of $115 million, the largest fraud settlement in Pentagon history. Former GE employee Gerald A. Leo, 52, who was convicted of four counts of mail fraud and one count of trying to deceive federal investigators, was sentenced to 10 months in prison and fined $15,000. ``He never did anything,'' yelled his sobbing wife, Mary, when the sentence was imposed. Co-defendant James Badolato, 43, convicted of misleading auditors and smbmitting false documents, was to be sentenced later. Both had worked for a GE subsidiary, Management & Technical Services Co. The company and the two employees were convicted this February on a case stemming from a 1983 investigation. The government charged that the GE subsidiary did not tell the government in 1983 that it had found substantially less expensive subcontractors to help build the battlefield computer system, part of a $250 million defense contract.

DOC.HEAD: Reports Loss in Second Quarter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs lede to CORRECT day of week.
DOC.TEXT: The Goodyear Tire & Rubber Co. reported Thursday it lost $9.4 million in the second quarter due to charges resulting from the restructuring of tire operations and the closing of a roofing systems plant. The loss amounted to 16 cents per share for the quarter ended June 30 compared with a profit of $27.1 million, or 47 cents per share, a year ago. Sales in the quarter rose slightly to $2.87 billion from $2.81 billion. The latest results include a charge of $21.4 million, or 37 cents a share, against earnings due to restructuring, while the 1989 results include a $95 million loss after taxes involving sales of its South African subsidiary which has since been sold and unused pipe owned by a pipeline subsidiary. For the first half, Goodyear earned $11.5 million, or 20 cents per share, on sales of $5.56 billion compared with $121.6 million, $2.11 per share, on sales of $5.45 billion. The restructuring of the North American tire operations involved a pre-tax charge of $20 million, while a decision to close the New Bedford, Mass., roofing plant resulted a pre-tax charge of $15 million. Goodyear said earnings were also adversely influenced by depreciation of the company's All American Pipeline System, price competition, higher costs, a strike at tire plants in Turkey and economic reform in Brazil. Goodyear Chairman Tom H. Barrett said tire sales rose 2.9 percent in the quarter anmd 2.1 percent in the first half, on the strength of gains in the U.S. replacement market.

DOC.HEAD: GM, Ford Report Lower Second-Quarter Earnings, as Expected
DOC.TEXT: Economic problems in Brazil and higher incentive costs pushed General Motors Corp.'s second-quarter profits down 40 percent and Ford Motor Co.'s earnings down 45 percent from last year's levels, the automakers said Thursday. Ford also said lingering effects of strikes in Britain and Belgium contributed to sharply lower European earnings, longtime strengths for the company. Chrysler Corp. is expected to announce second-quarter profits Tuesday. Analysts expect net income to be about half the $341 million the company earned during the period last year. GM, the nation's largest automaker, said it earned $900.1 million or $1.32 a share in the second quarter compared with $1.5 billion or $2.23 a share in the same period last year. Its second-quarter revenue rose 1.2 percent to $33.9 billion from $33.5 billion. Ford said it earned $770.7 million or $1.67 a share during the April-June period this year compared with $1.4 billion or $3 a share last year. The earnings came on revenues of $26.9 billion, up 3.9 percent from $25.9 billion a year ago. The GM and Ford figures were in line with what Wall Street analysts estimated. Analyst Scott Merlis of Morgan Stanley & Co. of New York said GM's and Ford's automotive earnings were a shade better than he anticipated in light of Brazil's troubles and increased tax payments. ``The earnings are much better than they look,'' he said. Ford and GM each have large operations in Brazil _ GM its own, and Ford with West German automaker Volkswagen AG in the Autolatina joint project. Both said their second-quarter earnings were dented by economic problems in that country, where inflation was running at an annual rate of more than 1,000 percent until the government put the brakes on the economy earlier this year with such moves as a currency freeze. In Europe, Ford had labor problems in the United Kingdom in the first quarter and in Belgium in the second. Although the strikes have ended, the effects of lost production and higher costs continue to take their toll. Ford Vice President and Treasurer David McCammon said he expected the Brazilian problems to continue draining potential profit from the company in the second half of the year. The company is having to deal with higher material and labor costs, which have not been recovered in sales of vehicles it makes in the Autolatina joint venture. ``I think Brazil will take a while,'' McCammon said. ``Europe probably in the third quarter will continue to be a little slow for us because we are launching the new Escort there. The fourth quarter should be better.'' In the United States, McCammon said, Ford spent an average of $1,050 on incentives for each of the 889,043 cars and trucks it sold during the period, 9 percent fewer sold than last year. GM's sales for the quarter fell 5.6 percent to 1,323,521. Chrysler's cars and truck sales for the quarter dropped 19.3 percent to 432,097. Through the first six months of the year, GM said its earnings fell 46.7 percent to $1.6 billion or $2.34 a share, from $3 billion or $4.60 a share a year ago. Revenue for the first six months fell 4.2 percent to $64 billion from $66.8 billion last year. For the first half of the year, Ford's earnings fell 56.7 percent to $1.2 billion or $2.77 a share, from $3 billion or $6.45 a share during the first six months of 1989. First-half revenue fell 2.5 percent to $50.5 billion from $51.8 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 30 Percent Drop in Quarterly Profit, Announces Fertilizer Restructuring
DOC.TEXT: Imperial Chemical Industries PLC said Thursday its profit dropped 30 percent in the second quarter and announced it was restructuring its fertilizer business. The restructuring calls for the closure of a plant in northeast England, which will cut 640 jobs, and the sale of part of its British fertilizer operations to Kemira Oy of Finland for an undisclosed sum, the company said. The British chemical and pharmaceuticals company said its net profit for the three months ended June 30 came to 207 million pounds, or $360 million, compared with 294 million pounds, or $512 million, in the same period a year ago. The latest results included a restructuring charge of 100 million pounds, or $174 million. Sales were flat at 3.4 billion pounds, or $5.9 billion. Pre-tax profit fell 34 percent to 319 million pounds, or $555 million, from 483 million pounds, or $840 million. ICI said its profit for the first half fell 34 percent to 372 million pounds, or $647 million, from 562 million pounds, or $978 million, in the same period a year ago. Sales rose 2.7 percent to 6.82 billion pounds, or $11.9 billion, from 6.64 billion pounds, or $11.6 billion. Pre-tax profit fell 21 percent to 733 million pounds, or $1.3 billion, from 925 million pounds, or $1.6 billion. ICI Chairman Denys Henderson said the half-year results were disappointing. The ``next few months are going to be tough,'' he said, but added the company was pursuing the right strategy. ICI said trading profit, or profit before tax and other considerations, increased 13 percent in the consumer and specialty products division to 356 million pounds, or $619 million. In the industrial products division, trading profit was down 53 percent to 216 million pounds, or $376 million. ICI said competitive pressures ``eroded selling prices while costs continued to rise.'' Trading profit at the agricultural division, including the fertilizers businesses, was down 6.2 percent at 151 million pounds, or $263 million. The fertilizer business' trading profit alone fell 87 percent to 2 million pounds, or $3.5 million. The figures were converted at a company-provided exchange rate of 1.74 dollars to the pound.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 164,105 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 163,079, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is higher than the same week a year ago, in which 147,994 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 86,517 cars this week, compared with 90,433 a week ago and 84,312 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 77,588, compared with last week's year's 63,682. Canadian automakers were to build 17,730 cars this week, do 72,646 and lastwn from 22,288 a week ago and up from last year's 15,638. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 11,210, compared with 8,101 a week ago and 12,870 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Surge on Soymeal Strength, USSR Factors
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices surged Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a rally fueled by active soybean meal trading in Europe and speculation the Soviet Union is preparing to make a large meal purchase. Grain futures ended mostly higher as bullish enthusiasm spread from the soybean pits to the nearby wheat, corn and oat rings. Perceptions of an impending Soviet purchase of soybean meal stemmed from reports that the Soviet Union received a $1 billion advance from the De Beers diamond cartel for rough diamonds that De Beers has agreed to market for Moscow. Some analysts believe the hard currency will ease a cash crunch that has prevented the Soviets from buying agricultural commodities on the world market. The Soviets also were reported to have repaid debts to soymeal exporters, which further raised speculation they are preparing to buy meal. Mickey Luth, a grains analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the talk of Soviet buying interest gave the soymeal market an excuse to rally. ``They haven't bought any for so long, we'll take the rumor when we can get it,'' he said. Soybean meal futures closed 80 cents to $4 higher with the contract for delivery in August at $171.20 per ton. At the close, wheat was unchanged to 1{ cents higher with the contract for September delivery at $3.01{ a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to 2{ cents higher with September at $2.63\ a bushel; oats were 2} cents to 4 cents higher with September at $1.33 a bushel; soybeans were 7 cents to 12{ cents higher with August at $5.93 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Westinghouse Buying Furniture Maker
DOC.TEXT: Westinghouse Electric Corp. said Thursday it has agreed to buy Knoll International Inc. for stock, making the electric company one of the world's three largest makers of office furniture. Terms of the deal were not disclosed. ``Knoll's commanding European presence in all eight Common Market countries will help establish Westinghouse as a leading designer and manufacturer of office furniture systems worldwide,'' Westinghouse Chairman Paul E. Lego said in a statement. Knoll, a privately held company, designs, makes and sells modular office systems, desks, chairs and office accessories. It has about 2,800 employees. Under the agreement, Westinghouse will acquire the company's headquarters in New York and manufacturing operations in East Greenville and Iron Run, both near Philadelphia, and in Montreal, Milan and Paris. Westinghouse also will acquire Knoll's field sales and branch offices. Westinghouse said it plans to combine Knoll with existing Westinghouse North American furniture operations but will continue to offer Westinghouse, Shaw-Walker and Reff brands along with Knoll's. The acquisition is expected to be completed by the end of September, Westinghouse said.

DOC.HEAD: Saturn Workers Getting Private `Job One' Ceremony
DOC.TEXT: Workers at General Motors Corp.'s Saturn plant want a private ceremony for retiring Chairman Roger Smith to drive the ceremonial first car off the assembly line next Monday, GM officials said Thursday. Smith, who retires Tuesday, has vowed to drive the first new Saturn out of the factory in Spring Hill, Tenn. His successor, Robert Stempel, has said he will drive the ceremonial second car. Saturn's 2,600 employees _ called ``team members'' _ have invited United Auto Workers union President Owen Bieber and Vice President Stephen Yokich to the ceremony. ``The team members had asked that it be a family affair and the opportunity to meet with Mr. Smith and Owen Beiber,'' said Bruce G. McDonald, Saturn's vice president for communications. ``They asked that this be a day they could spend with the chairman.'' Bieber had not confirmed Thursday whether the union leaders will be on hand, McDonald said. GM plans an October launch of Saturn, a project conceived in 1982 to recapture a market the company lost to competitors, namely the Japanese. The original concept was a $6,000 car that got 50 miles per gallon, Smith said, although the final version is priced at $10,000 to $12,000 and should average about 35 miles per gallon. ``It's changed and gotten better as technology has moved, as the market has moved and as our targets have moved,'' Smith said. There was no rush to make the first car available before his retirement, Smith told the Nashville Banner. ``It was much more important that the car be right than I drive it,'' he said Wednesday night. ``We set this kind of thing that I was going to drive it off five years ago, but we wanted to have something to shoot for. As it got closer and closer, I tried to explain to them that it was much more important for the car to be ready than for me to drive it.'' Smith said he does not know the color or model of car he will be driving. Saturn produces three models at the plant _ a two-door, a basic four-door and an upscale four-door. ``It's going to be a secret until I get there,'' he said. Smith said he has no plans to keep the car. ``You have to always be careful of driving the first anything off,'' he said. ``Those things belong in museums, like the first ZR1 Corvette.''

DOC.HEAD: Banks Extending Loans; Trump Considers Debt-Swap Plan For Casinos
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump and his teetering real estate empire received another reprieve Thursday as banks prepared to extend an emergency bridge loan the was part of a package that saved the developer from bankruptcy. Sources close to the transaction said a $20 million, 30-day loan that was to expire Thursday was in the process of being extended by the banks involved, including Citibank, Chase Manhattan, Bankers Trust and Manufacturers Hanover, among others. The loan was approved to tide Trump over until details on a longer-term, $65 million rescue package could be finalized. Since that financing package is moving along on schedule, and since Trump has adequate cash flow, there is ``no problem at all'' with extending the bridge loan, a source said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Separately, a spokesman for Merrill Lynch & Co. had no comment on a report that the investment firm was advising Trump on a plan that would allow bondholders in his Atlantic City, N.J., casinos to receive equity in the gambling operations for the debt they hold. Such a move would mean Trump could forego some interest payments on the bonds. The Wall Street Journal said in Thursday's editions the deal involves some $1.3 billion in debt on the casinos, which have suffered from a general decline in the Northeast economy. Documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission and cited by the Journal show that in mid-November, Trump will owe $47 million out of $210 million in interest and principal payments on the casinos. Analysts are skeptical of his ability to come up with the necessary cash by fall. The Trump Organization had no comment on either the extension of the bridge loan or the debt-for-equity swap plan. Last month, Trump's major lenders extended the bridge loan so he could make overdue payments on bonds sold to finance his Trump's Castle hotel and casino. Had Trump failed to make the payments, he would have been in formal default, and the assets backing those debts could have been seized by creditors. The negotiations yielded a new five-year commitment from Trump's bankers that will spread out payment on more than $2 billion in outstanding loans over the term of the pact.

DOC.HEAD: Reebok Chairman Agrees to $11 Million Pay Cut
DOC.TEXT: Reebok's board of directors let the air out of chairman Paul Fireman's huge pay package, cutting it by more than $11 million under a new five-year deal that begins Jan. 1, the company announced Thursday. Fireman, a key to the company's growth into a footwear giant that sells ``The Pump'' athletic shoe for $170, would receive no more than $2 million in annual salary and bonuses under the new agreement. His earnings could increase, however, through an option to purchase 2.5 million shares of the company's common stock. Under the current agreement, which expires Dec. 31, Fireman, also Reebok's chief executive officer, received an average of $13.6 million in salary and bonuses per year during the past four years. That deal, struck when Reebok was much smaller, based most of his compensation on a percentage of the company's pre-tax earnings. The new agreement, reached at a board meeting attended by Fireman Tuesday, provides him with a $1 million annual salary and a maximum potential bonus of $1 million a year, based on achievement of the firm's profit objectives. ``I don't imagine he'll have trouble buying that new car,'' said Elizabeth A. Armstrong, an analyst with Prescott Ball and Turben. ``Two million dollars is still not a bad income.'' Fireman was on vacation and not available for comment, said Ken Lightcap, Reebok's vice president for corporate communications. Reebok's sales have risen from $300 million in 1985 to $1.822 billion last year, while net income increased from $38.9 million to $174.9 million during the same period, Lightcap said. He said more than 95 percent of Fireman's compensation under his current agreement was in bonuses tied to pre-tax earnings. Forbes Magazine listed Fireman fifth last year and fourth this year in its rankings of U.S. chief executives according to salary and bonuses. ``His compensation before was much higher than is normal,'' Armstrong said, ``largely due to the fact that a lot of his compensation was tied to earnings levels of the company. Probably no one really expected the company to get the earnings levels they achieved. ``I would not be surprised if he was one of the people who arranged'' the compensation level of the new agreement, she added. His reduced compensation ``is really not a surprise,'' said Heidi R. Steinberg, an analyst with Salomon Brothers Inc. ``It was pretty well known that he would be taking this pay cut. The contract that he's been on was negotiated before Reebok had made its stellar success.'' The deal gives Fireman the option of buying 2.5 million shares of stock in stages over a five-year period. He can exercise the option for 10 years from the agreement's starting date. ``It's not a question of him getting a big bonus as he did in the past,'' Lightcap said. ``Now his stock options are on the same basis as anybody else's stock options are.'' Armstrong said the new agreement ``is better for the company because, just doing simple math, it will save the company about six cents a share after tax. And yet there's still the incentive, obviously, for Mr. Fireman to be rewarded for improving the company, not only the cash bonus ... but also the award of the options.''

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises Against Yen; Mixed Elsewhere
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the Japanese yen but finished mixed against most other major currencies in seesaw trading Thursday. Gold prices ended mostly lower. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.30 a troy ounce, down $2.70 from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $368.80 an ounce, $2.20 lower. The dollar got a boost initially in Tokyo when traders began selling yen, which lost ground across the board. Analysts said investors remain concerned about recent stock market swings in Tokyo as well as the uncertainty over whether the Bank of Japan will move to raise interest rates. Higher interest rates in Japan would tend to support then yen by making yen-denominated fixed-income investments more attractive. Bob Morrissey, senior trader at the Bank of Boston's New York office, said there were rumors that the Federal Reserve had entered the market to sell dollars and buy yen in an effort to stem the dollar's rise. But those rumors were not confirmed. Trading was active. The dollar finished mixed in Europe and traded higher when dealings shifted to the United States. But profit-taking late in the U.S. session left the dollar lower against all currencies but the yen at the close. Morrissey noted there was some position-squaring ahead of Friday's release of second-quarter U.S. gross national product data. The figures might provide an impetus for the Fed to trim interest rates in an effort to stimulate the economy. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.98 yen to a closing 150.11 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a rate of 150.10 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 150.35 yen, up from 149.83 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.8133 from $1.8125 late Wednesday. In New York it cost $1.8145 to buy one pound, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.8120. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.6230 West German marks, down from 1.6245; 1.3773 Swiss francs, down form 1.3800; 5.4360 French francs, down from 5.4445; 1,187.50 Italian lire, down from 1,188.75; and 1.1527 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1536. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates included: 1.6220 West German marks, up from 1.6170; 1.3780 Swiss francs, up from 1.3715; 5.4355 French francs, up from 5.4185; 1.8290 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8215; 1,187.50 Italian lire, up from 1,183.62, and 1.1513 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1518. Gold fell in London to a late bid of $368.65 a troy ounce from $373.25 late Wednesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $368.50 an ounce from $372.50 late Wednesday. Gold rose $2.11 in Hong Kong to close at $369.94 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current deliver settled at $4.850 a troy ounce, up from $4.828 on Wednesday. But in London, silver fell to a late bid of $4.85 a troy ounce from $4.89.

DOC.HEAD: Rose $1.93 Billion, Third Straight Weekly Rise
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 513 money market mutual funds rose $1.93 billion in the latest week to $391.84 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The rise followed a $3.67 billion increase in the fund assets the previous week, the Washington-based mutual fund trade group said. It was the third straight weekly rise despite a recent weakness in interest rates, which can draw money out of money market funds and into other investments. Fund assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 251 general purpose funds rose $1.21 billion to $135.91 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds rose $356.6 million to $160.75 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds rose $366 million to $95.18 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.59 percent from 7.66 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield fell to 7.65 percent from 7.66 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 44 days, up from 43 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.12 percent as of Wednesday from 6.14 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, remained unchanged from a week earlier at 5.03 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.86 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.89 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.03 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.06 percent; 8.06 percent on 2{-year CDs, down from 8.08 percent; and 8.14 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.16 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Unleaded Gasoline Futures Soar
DOC.TEXT: Wholesale unleaded gasoline soared more than 2 cents a gallon in choppy, nervous trading Thursday on technical factors and anticipation that OPEC members may soon reach a formal agreement for slashing oil production. Crude oil prices, meanwhile, settled slightly lower and heating oil posted a moderate gain. ``The market perception is that OPEC is serious this time'' in adjusting its oil output, said William Byers, an energy analyst with Bear, Stearns & Co. ``If OPEC can reach an accord and make it stick, it's going to mean higher prices for consumers at the (gasoline) pumps.'' Unleaded gasoline futures have risen around 10 cents a gallon since June just on anticipation of an OPEC cut, Byers said. In Thursday trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange, the August contract for unleaded gasoline settled up 2.22 cents to 65.26 cents a gallon, after losing 0.24 cent on Wednesday. Other contract months were higher. Traders said reports of substantial progress in this week's OPEC production talks in Geneva, along with technical factors, were pushing up gasoline futures. Oil ministers from the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries confirmed Thursday they had agreed to raise the cartel's price for crude oil. According to an OPEC source, formal agreement is near on raising OPEC's target price to between $21 and $22 per barrel from the current $18 target price that was set nearly four years ago. An oil glut had sent prices to as low as $13.64 a barrel earlier this year. To raise prices OPEC reportedly will be proposing a new production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day for the entire cartel, an increase over the current ceiling of 22.09 million, but far short of the 23.5 million experts say the cartel actually has been producing. Among other refined petroluem products traded on the exchange Thursday, the August contract for wholesale heating oil settled at 57.32 cents a gallon, gaining 0.56 cent, the same amount it had declined on Wednesday. The September contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, dropped 8 cents to $20.30 a 42-gallon barrel, after falling 18 cents the previous session. Other contract months, however, were moderately higher. In natural gas trading, the September contract settled at $1.435 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.440 Wednesday. Contracts for later delivery were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Iraq-Kuwait Developments at a Glance
With AM-OPEC, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a look at major developments Thursday in the dispute involving Iraqi allegations of oil over-production by Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates.

TROOPS: _Diplomats in the Persian Gulf said Iraq had agreed to remove troops it deployed along the Kuwaiti border last week. Iraqi newspaper officials said they were told to end propaganda attacks on Kuwait to help end the crisis.

TALKS: _An Iraqi official in Baghdad confirmed that Iraqi and Kuwaiti representatives would hold direct talks in Saudi Arabia this weekend. The official said Iraq had not backed down on demands for Kuwaiti compensation for oil Iraq claims it stole; an end to cheating on OPEC output quotas; and the writing off of loans made to Iraq during the Iran-Iraq war. _Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, blamed for plummeting prices, denied Iraqi charges that they have exceeded their oil production quotas.

OIL PRICES: _Ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries met in Geneva and said they had agreed to try to raise the cartel's target price from $18 a barrel to at least $20. It would be part of a package that would require members to limit overall production to 22.5 million barrels a day.
OPEC ANGER: _OPEC's president, Algerian oil minister Sadek Boussena, angrily criticized members who have cheated on output quotas and driven prices down worldwide.
