DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Surge With Signs Of Soviet Demand
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices surged Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade in a rally fueled by perceptions that the Soviet Union is shopping for soybean meal after a months-long absence from world commodity markets. Grain futures ended mostly higher as bullish enthusiasm spread from the soybean pits to the nearby wheat, corn and oat rings. On other commodity markets, gasoline futures rose sharply; copper extended recent gains; precious metals were mixed; and livestock and meat futures were mixed. Soybean futures settled 7 cents to 12 cents higher in Chicago with the contract for delivery in August at $5.92{ a bushel. Soybean meal futures settled 80 cents to $4 higher with August at $171.10 per ton. Wheat futures ended unchanged to 1{ cents higher with September at $3.01} a bushel; corn was \ cent to 2} cents higher with September at $2.63{ a bushel; oats were 2} cents to 4 cents higher with September at $1.33 a bushel. Analysts cited various signs that the Soviet Union has returned or will soon return to the marketplace after suspending much of its import buying several months ago due to a lack of hard currency. Traders made much of a $1 billion advance Moscow received from the De Beers diamond cartel as part of deal under which De Beers will market Soviet diamonds. The Soviets also are believed to have received billions of dollars in credit in recent weeks from West Germany and several other nations. ``They've gotten in the last two weeks a total of $9 billion in an assortment of cash and credit. That's a lot of money they can buy food and pay off debt with,'' said William Biedermann, research director with the commodities brokerage Allendale Inc. in Crystal Lake, Ill. Heavy trading of soybean meal in Europe Thursday was taken as a sign of Soviet buying. And reports that the Soviets had repaid debts to some U.S. soy meal exporters raised speculation that Moscow was preparing to make new purchases. Mickey Luth, grains analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said the talk of Soviet buying interest was a good excuse for the soybean complex to rally, whether the speculation pans out or not. ``They haven't bought any for so long, we'll take the rumor when we can get it,'' he said. Gasoline futures rose strongly on the New York Mercantile Exchange, reflecting signs of tightening supplies of gasoline for prompt delivery in the Northeast. Petroleum futures also were supported by news that OPEC oil ministers meeting in Geneva are expected to ratify on Friday a higher target price for crude oil and new crude production quotas. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 8 cents lower to 21 cents higher with September at $20.30 a barrel; heating oil was .02 cent to .57 cent higher with August at 57.32 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .12 cent to 2.22 cents higher with August at 65.26 cents a gallon. Copper futures made their fourth strong advance in the last five sessions on New York's Commodity Exchange amid continuing concerns over available supplies. Mining and refinery employees of Peru's state-owned Mineroperu metals company began a strike Thursday, which also supported the copper market. Copper finished 1.15 cents to 1.80 cents higher with July at $1.255 a pound. Gold futures fell in New York, erasing more than half of Wednesday's gains. Gold settled $2.80 to $2.90 lower with August at $369.60 a troy ounce; silver was 2 cents to 2.2 cents higher with July at $4.85 a troy ounce. On the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, live cattle futures were .02 cent lower to .32 cent higher with August at 77.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .15 cent lower to .35 cent higher with August at 88.62 cents a pound; live hogs were .55 cent lower to .03 cent higher with August at 60.12 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to 1.83 cents higher with August at 48.95 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Lower
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply fell in the week ended July 16, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 fell to a seasonally adjusted $3,273.7 billion from a revised $3,274.0 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, fell to a seasonally adjusted $4,051.6 billion from $4,058.0 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $807.9 billion from $810.5 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 3.5 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 was 0.8 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 1 percent to 5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,269.0 billion, a 1.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,056.0 billion, down 0.3 percent, while M1 rose 2.5 percent to an average of $807.7 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $653 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $409 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $303 million in the two weeks ended July 18, down from a revised $502 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $307.7 billion in the two-week period ended July 11, down from $309.1 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Earnings Up 5 Percent; Delta Slumps; Midway Loss $11 Million In Quarter
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines parent UAL Corp. posted a 5 percent gain in second-quarter profits on Thursday, partly because of gains from aircraft sales, while Delta Air Lines said its net income tumbled by 61 percent due to competition and rising fuel prices. Separately, Chicago-based Midway Airlines Inc. posted an $11.4 million net loss during the three months ended June 30.

UAL said it had net income of $148.3 million, or $6.81 per share, in the second quarter, including a gain of $77.3 million from the sale of nine aircraft. The profit compared with net income of $141.1 million, or $6.52 per share, in the year-earlier quarter, which included a $5 million gain from aircraft sales. Sales during the quarter rose to $2.74 billion from $2.52 billion. Operating income fell to $178.5 million from $221.6 million in the second quarter of 1989, while operating expenses rose to $2.57 billion from $2.29 billion, UAL said. UAL has accepted a $4.38 billion buyout offer from its employees, who have until Aug. 9 to obtain financing for the acquisition. Stephen Wolf, UAL's chairman, said the latest results showed that United ``is very much on target in executing the strategic plan we formulated two years ago.'' For the first six months of 1990, UAL had net income of $111.9 million, or $5.14 per share, on sales of $5.26 billion. That compared with net income of $206.5 million, or $9.55 per share, on sales of $4.84 billion in the first half of 1989.

The Atlanta-based airline said its net income for the three months ended June 30 fell to $74.1 million, or $1.47 a share, from $190.8 million, or $3.87 a share, a year earlier. Revenue fell to $2.24 billion from $2.31 billion. Thomas J. Roeck Jr., Delta's chief financial officer, said results were depressed by fare competition that produced widespread rate-cutting and rising fuel prices. Delta also suffered from a comparison with a year-earlier results that were inflated because of the devastating strike against competitor Eastern Airlines, Roeck said in a news release. For its full fiscal year, Delta saw its profit drop 34.3 percent to $302.8 million, or $5.79 per share, from $460.9 million, or $9.37 per share. Operating revenue rose to $8.58 billion from $8.01 billion the previous year.

Chicago-based Midway's financial performance continued to reflect the high costs of the airline's expansion into Philadelphia, where Midway has opened a second hub. Midway had a net loss of $11.4 million, or $1.24 a share, in its second quarter compared with net income of $5.1 million, or 45 cents per share, for the same period a year earlier. Sales rose to $170.6 million in the quarter from $126.5 million. Alfred Altschul, Midway's vice president of finance and chief financial officer, said the results represented a ``significant improvement'' over the first quarter, when Midway posted a $23 million loss. ``We are making excellent progress in the development of our new Philadelphia hub and we are encouraged by strong growth trends in our traffic and advanced bookings of the months of July and August,'' said Alfred Altschul, Midway's vice president of finance and chief financial officer. For the first six months of 1990, Midway lost $34.4 million, or $3.63 per share, on sales of $327.7 million. That compared with net income of $8 million, or 72 cents per share, on sales of $243.7 million in the first six months of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Attacks Merrill Lynch Report
With AM-Trump
DOC.TEXT: Gaming giant Bally Manufacturing Corp. accused Merrill Lynch & Co. on Thursday of smearing its financial reputation to divert attention from support that the nation's biggest brokerage gave Donald Trump's Taj Mahal resort. Merrill denied the accusation. Bally chairman Robert Mullane said he was outraged because of a July 11 analysis by Merrill analysts Richard Byrne and David Waill, which said Bally was excessively indebted and must take aggressive action to stay solvent through 1991. Bally is one of Trump's main rivals in the gambling business. ``The smell of this is awful,'' Mullane said. ``It's hard to believe they would do that, unless they had a preconceived notion to get this company,'' he said. ``I think somebody ought to remember the people that brought you the Bally criticism brought you the Taj Mahal bonds.'' Merrill Lynch is one of the underwriters of bonds for the Taj Mahal in Atlantic City, N.J., one of the most extravagant gaming casino-hotels in the country. But brokerage officials denied Mullane's contentions and said they stood by the analysis of Bally, a leading gaming equipment and hotel-casino company, based in Chicago. The investment firm, the nation's largest, had no comment Thursday on a report that it was advising Trump on a plan that would allow bondholders in his Atlantic City casinos to receive equity for the debt they hold. That would mean Trump could forego some interest payments on the bonds, which have but enormous pressure on the New York developer's own shaky financial structure. The Wall Street Journal said in Thursday's editions the deal involves $1.3 billion in debt on the casinos, which have suffered from a general decline in the Northeast economy. ``It's my personal opinion there has been a concentrated effort by a major brokerage house to discredit Bally in an effort to help direct attention away from the problem they had,'' Mullane said in a telephone interview Thursday from his Chicago office. Martin Fridson, managing director in charge of high yield research at Merrill Lynch's New York office, denied any relationship between the Bally report and the Trump bonds. ``A given report has nothing to do with another company,'' Fridson said. ``We see no reason to modify the (Bally) report.'' Bally operates two hotel-casinos in Atlantic City, where Trump opened his Taj Mahal earlier this year. The company also has a hotel-casino in Las Vegas, and one in Reno. In addition, the company has a chain of health fitness centers and manufactures gaming and amusement equipment. Mullane spoke after issuing a financial report that showed Bally's second-quarter earnings totaled $9.2 million. The results compared with earnings of $21.5 million a year earlier, but that stemmed from a one-time, $34 million gain on the sale of a subsidiary, without which Bally would have shown a loss. Company revenues increased from $519 million in the second quarter of 1989 to $554 million in the same period this year. Mullane charged the writers of the Merrill Lynch report had grossly undervalued Bally properties in Las Vegas and Reno. The report said the 2,900-room hotel-casino in Las Vegas and the 2,000-room resort in Reno were appraised at $525 million but had an actual value of $225 million to $300 million. ``The hotel in Las Vegas sits on the most valuable piece of land in the casino business,'' Mullane said. ``If that property isn't in the $500 million range, I'd be shocked.'' He estimated the value of the Reno property at $100 million to $125 million, but added ``I'm not in the mode to sell them. ``They went out and put ridiculous prices on them to create this nonsense story,'' Mullane said. Mullane said the company was considering selling its health and fitness division, but denied the company needed to sell any assets to meet principal and interest payments. He agreed with the analysts that the opening of the Mirage Hotel in Las Vegas and the Taj Mahal in Atlantic City had cut into Bally's business. ``Sure they've had an impact, but not to the point of being terribly serious,'' Mullane said. ``Everybody's off. When a new place opens, everybody goes for that first look. But we'll weather that storm very nicely.''

DOC.HEAD: Yields Fall on New Bills
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS ``yields'' to ``interest rates'' in lede; CORRECTS ``yield'' to ``discount rate'' in 2nd graf; CORRECTS ``coupon interest rate'' to ``equivalent coupon interest rate'' in 4th graf: ``The bills,''
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on 52-week Treasury bills fell in Thursday's auction to the lowest level since January. The average discount rate was 7.34 percent, down from 7.52 percent at the last auction on June 28. It was the lowest rate since 52-week bills averaged 7.21 percent on Jan. 11. The bills will carry an equivalent coupon interest rate of 7.88 percent with each $10,000 in face value selling for $9,257.80. A total of $10.54 billion in bills was sold out of bids totaling $30.57 billion.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC Ministers Reach Preliminary Agreement on Raising Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with OPEC gets assurances on lower production, prices affected in New York. Picks up 4th graf `Iraqi Oil' with minor editing to conform and trim
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto GEV1
DOC.TEXT: OPEC oil ministers said Thursday they agreed to raise the cartel's ceiling price for crude oil, and OPEC President Sadek Boussena criticized members who drove down the price by exceeding production quotas. His comments were apparently directed in part at Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, who are blamed for keeping oil prices low by cheating on their quotas. OPEC's decision to raise the ceiling price came after it received assurances that overproduction by Kuwait and the U.A.E. would end and that overall world production of oil would decrease. The price of wholesale unleaded gasoline rose 2.2 cents a gallon Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, settling at 65.26 cents _ partly in anticipation that OPEC members may soon reach a formal agreement for cutting oil production. ``The market perception is that OPEC is serious this time,'' William Byers, an energy analyst with Bear, Stearns & Co., said. ``If OPEC can reach an accord and make it stick, it's going to mean higher prices for consumers at the pumps.'' A row between Kuwait and Iraq over the quota issue appeared to have been defused as the ministers of the 13-nation group began their regular mid-year conference. Iraqi Oil Minister Issam Abdul Raheem al-Chalabi sat next to his Kuwaiti counterpart, Rashid Saleem al-Ameeri, at the conference table. The two chatted and laughed before the start of the meeting. Iraq on Thursday scaled back a weeklong intimidation campaign against Kuwait, which reportedly included a military buildup along the Iraq-Kuwait border. Leaders of Kuwait and Iraq were scheduled to meet in Saudi Arabia this weekend to try to resolve their differences. A ministerial source said formal agreement was near on raising OPEC's target price several dollars a barrel and setting a new production ceiling of 22.5 million barrels a day for the entire cartel. This would be an increase over the current ceiling of 22.09 million, but far short of the 23.5 million barrels that experts say the cartel has actually been producing. The new benchmark price is expected to be $21 to $22 per barrel, the source said. Iraq had hoped for $25 a barrel. The current $18 target price was set in December 1986, but an oil glut sent prices down to as low as $13.64 a barrel this year. The price rose to $16.25 a barrel last week. Every dollar decline or rise in the price of a barrel of oil amounts to about a five-cent change in gas prices for consumers at the pump. The source predicted the ministers of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries would ratify the accord Friday, when formal talks resumed. Algerian Oil Minister Boussena, OPEC's new president, told reporters after a two-hour midday session: ``We will have a new minimum reference price.'' ``There are several positions but all of them are accepting higher prices,'' he said. Indonesian minister Ginandjar Kartasasmita, elected OPEC's alternate president, said: ``There is a general feeling that we want to have the price at least $20.'' Libyan minister Fawzi Shakshuki demanded a higher production quota for his country before agreeing to a new cartel production cap of 22.5 million barrels a day, as proposed by Saudi Arabia and other Persian Gulf producers. Under the proposal, only the U.A.E. production quota would increase, by 400,000 barrels a day. All other quotas would remain the same. Shakshuki said: ``There should be no increase unless Libya shares.'' The ministers of Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates denied their countries have been producing more than their quotas _ 1.5 million barrels for Kuwait and 1.1 million for the U.A.E. Analysts say each has been pumping about 2 million barrels daily. The alleged overproduction was at the heart of the recent rise in tensions involving Iraq. Iraq, badly in need of cash to rebuild after eight years of war with Iran, claims it has lost $14 billion in oil revenues because of low prices caused by overproduction. Iraqi President Saddam Hussein last week threatened to retaliate against countries ignoring their OPEC production caps. He also accused Kuwait of stealing $2.4 billion worth of oil from a field that includes land claimed by both countries. Boussena denounced violations of output caps. OPEC's ``fortunes have faded badly'' and the nations' economies risk being brought ``to the brink of collapse,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: New Budget Package Readied; Lawmakers Consider Canceling Recess
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top six grafs new with more details of GOP plan, Democrats expecting compromise in September; picks up 5th graf pvs: ``The third,''
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration readied a budget-cutting plan Thursday that would boost taxes on wine and beer more than five-fold next year, limit the deductibility of state and local income taxes and cut social programs, Republican negotiators said. Their proposal, to be submitted to congressional Democrats at the 11-week-old budget summit talks, envisioned overall deficit cuts next year of about $54 billion, split about evenly between new taxes and lower spending, a GOP bargainer said. As part of the plan, the 3-cent levy on the standard 750 milliliter bottle of wine would be boosted to 76 cents. The tax on a six-pack of beer, now 16 cents, would be increased five-fold to 81 cents, the official said. Combined, the higher levies would add $7 billion to the government's coffers. Democratic congressional leaders, meanwhile, met separately and all but concluded that no budget compromise will be reached until at least September. Congress' month-long summer recess begins in early August, and many lawmakers fear that a partially completed pact would lose support while senators and representatives were at home. ``That is the clear preference of the congressional leadership,'' said House Budget Committee Chairman Leon Panetta, D-Calif. ``But it is also clear that if the president wishes to proceed, the leadership will concur with that.'' The third consecutive day of high-level budget talks at the White House got down to specific tax suggestions as administration officials circulated a new proposal among key congressional Republicans. Although details of the package were sketchy, Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., said it included higher excise taxes on alcohol but otherwise resembled the taxes Bush proposed in his January budget. Packwood and others said the proposal, which may be formally presented to budget negotiators Friday, consists of slightly more than $50 billion in savings, split about evenly between new taxes and spending cuts. It also renews Bush's call for a cut in the capital gains tax rate and proposes several minor new taxes. The deficit in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, is expected to reach at least $169 billion unless action is taken. That size shortfall would trigger $100 billion or more in spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law, slashing most domestic programs by 40 percent and defense programs by 25 percent. The new administration proposal would raise about $3 billion by limiting the deductibility of state and local income taxes on federal tax returns, a GOP bargainer said. Such deductions would be limited to no more than $10,000, said the negotiator, who asked not to be identified. However, Gov. Mario Cuomo said the administration could balance the budget if it raised the taxes of wealthy Americans. ``If you want to find wealth, don't come to us and take it out of the pockets of children,'' Cuomo said at a news conference here with state and local officials who oppose limiting the deductibility of state and local income taxes. The latest administration package does not include taxes on tobacco or luxury items such as jewelry, which negotiators have been considering, said the negotiator who asked not to be identified. The official also said the package would cut benefit programs by $16 billion, including $6 billion from Medicare. It would cut defense spending by about $7 billion _ several billion dollars less than Democrats want _ and pare domestic and foreign aid programs by $4 billion more. The GOP plan would save more than $500 billion over five years, relying heavily on cuts in benefit programs such as Medicare but leaving Social Security untouched. Fitzwater would not comment on details of the package, but said White House officials had ``had a lot of discussions'' with congressional Republicans. ``They know our thinking and we know theirs and we've talked about a lot of ideas,'' he said. Failing an agreement, ``there is a possibility that the president would ask the Congress to stay,'' Fitzwater said, adding that he assumed Bush also would cancel part of his three-week vacation in Kennebunkport, Maine. Postponing the recess ``is one of the options out there,'' Gephardt said. He said there were discussions Thursday of specific strategies for higher taxes, including a proposal favored by some leading Democrats to even out the tax code by raising taxes on the richest Americans. Middle-income Americans are taxed at a rate of 33 percent, but joint filers earning more than about $162,000 pay a lower 28 percent rate. ``We feel the tax code has become unprogressive and that the middle class and the people below have been paying too much of their share,'' Gephardt said. ``We would like to change those things.'' The administration has opposed such a tax-law change.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Doubles Quarterly Earnings
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co. on Thursday reported record second-quarter profits double those of a year earlier, saying its soaring commercial jet sales and healthier profit margins offset major losses in its defense business. Boeing, the world's largest manufacturer of commercial aircraft, had profits of $387 million, or $1.12 a share, for the quarter ended June 30. That's up 98.5 percent from the $195 million, or 57 cents a share, in second-quarter 1989. Sales were up 37.4 percent, from $5.07 billion to $6.97 billion. Frank Shrontz, Boeing chairman and chief executive officer, attributed the profit growth to higher commercial aircraft sales and operating margins. Boeing has had five consecutive years of record jetliner orders, which are now translating into record sales. All seven of its current aircraft models also are well into production and past the expensive development and start-up phases. The company has steadily boosted its production to where it now averages better than one plane a day. For the first six months of 1990, net earnings were a record $689 million, or $1.99 a share, up 93.5 percent from $356 million, or $1.03 a share, for the first half of 1989. Sales rose 47.7 percent, from $9.07 billion to $13.4 billion. Boeing changed its accounting for income taxes in 1989, which resulted in a one-time addition of $298 million or 86 cents per share in net earnings in first-quarter 1989. Including that restatement, first-half 1989 earnings were $654 million or $1.89 a share. For first-half 1990, Boeing turned out 186 planes, including 37 747 jumbo jets, each of which are worth about $125 million. That compares with 148 planes in the first half of 1989, including just 13 747s. Boeing introduced its new 747-400 in early 1989. Commercial sales totaled about $10.2 billion in the first six months of 1990, while defense and space sales totaled $2.95 billion, up $329 million from the same period of 1989. But Shrontz said troubles with defense programs and pressures to cut military spending ``will result in a significant 1990 operating loss'' for space and military business. ``Technical, cost and schedule problems on certain U.S. government developmental and production programs have not been fully resolved,'' Shrontz said, including problems with the Advanced Tactical Fighter, or ATF. Boeing is developing a version of the 21st century jet with Lockheed and General Dynamics. Boeing did not release quarterly profits or losses for its commercial or defense segments, said spokesman Paul Binder. Last year, however, defense and space lost $474 million. The company is trying to save money by streamlining its defense and space segments. But it is a participant in a number of programs in danger of being cut, including the B-2 stealth bomber, V-22 tilt-rotor aircraft, the ATF, the space station and the Army's proposed light helicopter. Boeing did manage to gain a defense contract in the second quarter, to develop a tactical derivative of the new short-range attack missile it is developing for the Air Force. Boeing charged $354 million to earnings for research and development in the first half of 1990 and plans to spend another $400 million on R&D the rest of the year. It had $207 million in other business in first-half 1990, including the sale of a 15 percent interest in Peabody Holding Co. Shrontz repeated his earlier forecast of a record $27 billion in total sales for 1990. Boeing had a total backlog of firm orders at June 30 of $84.3 billion, up from $80.6 billion a year earlier. Of that total, $78.1 billion was for commercial customers, for 1,862 announced aircraft orders. Fifteen customers announced orders for 128 jetliners and five de Havilland commuter planes in the second quarter, worth a total $11.5 billion. Boeing is negotiating with airlines to obtain orders to launch its proposed new 777 twinjet. The plane would seat 300-350 passengers. Shrontz said Boeing had cash and short-term investments of $3.61 billion on June 30, double the $1.86 billion on Dec. 31.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Third-Quarter Net Earnings Up 23 Percent
DOC.TEXT: Walt Disney Co. third-quarter profits rose 23 percent, with a big lift from its movie business thanks to ``Pretty Woman'' in theaters and ``The Little Mermaid'' on home video. Disney also reported Thursday that profits rose 21 percent for the nine months ending June 30, keeping the entertainment company on track for its goal of 20 percent profit growth during each of the next five years. Revenues grew even faster, 32 percent for the April-June quarter and 27 percent for the nine months. For the quarter, Disney earned $238.4 million, or $1.75 per share, on revenue of $1.54 billion, compared with a profit of $193.3 million, or $1.40 per share, on revenue of $1.17 billion a year earlier. For the nine months, Disney earned $591.3 million, or $4.29 per share, on revenue of $4.13 billion, compared with net income of $490.6 million, $3.56 per share, on revenue of $3.25 billion in the first nine months of the 1989 fiscal year. Since Chief Executive Michael D. Eisner and President Frank G. Wells took control in 1984, yearly revenues have tripled to $4.6 billion last year and profits have increased seven times, to $703 million. Their new goals, reiterated last week by Wells during an interview at Disneyland, are to keep profits chugging upward at a 20 percent clip. For all of 1989, they rose 35 percent. Eisner and Wells, in a joint statement Thursday, said revenue and operating income was up at all three Disney divisions: theme parks and resorts, consumer products and filmed entertainment. In the first category, record attendance, higher per-capita guest spending, expanded resort operations and benefit from Disney's 49 percent stake in Eurodisneyland pushed quarterly operating income up 14 percent to $289 million and revenue up 18 percent to $858 million. Licensing of ``Dick Tracy'' and ``Little Mermaid'' items helped the consumer products division, where operating income was up 18 percent to $46 million for the quarter and revenue shot up 47 percent to $125 million. Filmed entertainment revenue rose 57 percent to $556 million. Operating income was up 35 percent to $73 million. Disney said the strong performance was led by home video sales of the Oscar-winning ``Mermaid'' and theatrical release of ``Pretty Woman,'' Hollywood's highest-grossing film this year. Next quarter's results should get a boost from ``Dick Tracy,'' which was released in late June, and ``Arachnophobia,'' the killer spider thriller from Disney's new Hollywood Pictures studio, which Wells has predicted will be one of the summer's biggest smashes.

DOC.HEAD: Major Oil Companies Report Mixed Earnings
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Pennzoil results.
DOC.HEAD: By The Associated Press
DOC.TEXT: A drop in crude oil prices worked to depress earnings at Texaco Inc. and Phillips Petroleum Co. during the second quarter, but Mobil Corp. and Chevron Corp. managed to improve results during the period, the companies reported Tuesday. Though relatively strong during the year's first quarter, crude oil prices fell an average of $4 a barrel in the subsequent quarter because of worldwide oversupply. As a result, Texaco's profits during the period slipped 4 percent, while Phillips reported a 47 percent tumble in net income. Several other major oil companies have reported lower earnings due to lower crude prices, including Atlantic Richfield Co., Amoco, and Amerada Hess Corp. But Mobil, the nation's second-largest oil concern, reported a 24 percent jump in net income, largely due to special factors, and profits at Chevron were up a sharp 60 percent. Pennzoil Co. reported a 96 percent drop in profits, blaming the sale of short-term securities and purchase of Chevron common stock and restructuring charges in the second quarter of 1990. The company also said a one-time gain recorded in last year's second quarter contributed to the steep drop.
DOC.HEAD: Mobil Corp.
DOC.TEXT: Mobil estimated net income for the second quarter at $498 million, or $1.19 a share, up from $401 million, or 98 cents a share a year earlier. The 1990 quarter got a $182 million boost from the sale of a 5 percent stake in a North Sea oil field and the sale of Mobil's refining and fuels marketing business in Italy. Revenue for the period was $13.8 billion, off 1 percent from $14 billion in the year-ago period. Mobil Chairman Allen E. Murray said excluding special items, petroleum operations were slightly lower than a year earlier, and stronger refining margins did not offset sharply lower crude oil prices. The company's chemical operations also reported lower results. For the first half, Mobil estimated net earnings at $898 million, or $2.13 a share, up 8 percent from $830 million, or $2.02 a share in the first half of 1989. Excluding special items, first-half earnings of $856 million were down $114 million from the year-ago level. Revenue for the period increased 3 percent to $28.9 billion, from $28.1 billion in the first half of 1989.

Texaco, the nation's third-largest oil company, said net income during the quarter totaled $353 million, or $1.26 a share, down from $366 million, or $1.39 a share a year ago. Revenue rose 3 percent to $8.72 billion, from $8.45 billion a year ago largely because of higher crude and oil product sales volumes. In addition to lower crude prices during the second quarter, natural gas prices also fell and petrochemical results were ``significantly lower ... because of oversupply and reduced demand,'' Texaco Chief Executive and President James W. Kinnear said in a statement from the company's White Plains, N.Y., headquarters. For the year's first half, Texaco reported net income of $681 million, or $2.41 a share, down 63 percent from $1.82 billion, or $7.19 a share in the year-ago period, which included a $1.19 billion gain from the sale of Texaco Canada Inc. Without the gain, net income was up 8 percent, the company said. First-half revenue was off 1 percent at $17.88 billion from $18.06 billion.

San Francisco-based Chevron said $58 million in special items boosted second-quarter earnings to $648 million, or $1.83 a share, from $404 million, or $1.18 a share a year ago. Revenue totaled $8.9 billion, up 9 percent from $8.2 billion a year ago. For the year's first half, the nation's fourth-largest oil company said net income totaled $1.12 billion, or $3.16 a share, up 56 percent from $717 million, or $2.09 a share in the 1989 first half. Revenue rose 15 percent to $18.3 billion, from $15.9 billion on higher sales volumes for crude oil, natural gas and petroleum products, particularly in the first quarter.

Phillips, of Bartlesville, Okla., reported second-quarter net income of $105 million, or 43 cents a share, down from $197 million, or 81 cents a share a year ago. The recent quarter included $58 million in insurance reimbursement that compensated for lost earnings at Phillips' Houston chemical complex, which was shut down after an accident in October 1989 and remains closed. Revenue declined 9 percent to $2.98 billion, from $3.3 billion a year ago. For the year's first half, Phillips' profits slipped 6 percent to $364 million, or $1.49 a share, from $387 million, or $1.59 a share. Revenue declined by 5 percent to $6.11 billion, from $6.40 billion in the second half of 1989.

Sun Co., of Radnor, Pa., said second-quarter profits rose 10 percent to $115 million, or $1.07 a share from $105 million, or 98 cents a share a year ago. Revenue totaled $2.89 billion, down 1 percent from $2.92 billion a year ago. For the first six months, net income was unchanged at $186 million, or $1.73 a share, compared with a per-share profit of $1.74, on revenue of $6 billion, up 8 percent from $5.56 billion a year earlier.

Pennzoil, of Houston, reported Wednesday its net income for the quarter ending June 30 was $4.7 million, or 12 cents a share, on revenues of $551.1 million. In the same quarter a year ago, the company made $118 million, or $3.15 a share, on revenues of $684.1 million. The sale of Burlington Resources Inc. and Burlington Northern Inc. common stock last year inflated earnings for the second quarter of 1989 by $140.6 million, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Takeover Specialist Gets 16 Months to Four Years on Larceny and Tax Fraud
DOC.TEXT: Donald C. Carter, the takeover specialist who pleaded guilty to stealing $1 million from clients in March, was sentenced to 16 months to four years in state prison. Carter, 41, was also ordered to pay a $50,000 fine and put $1 million in a fund to compensate his victims. Acting New York Supreme Court Justice George F. Roberts handed down the sentence Wednesday. The firm Carter started in 1974, the Carter Organization, agreed to forfeit $1 million to New York state, which will make it available to those who can prove they were defrauded. Carter sold the firm, now doing business as Quorum Communications Inc., to the VPI Group PLC, a British public relations firm, in 1987 for $76 million. Ronald Goldstock, director of the New York State Organized Crime Task Force, which headed the Carter investigation, said that between 1984 and 1989 Carter routinely billed his clients for non-existent or inflated expenses. When questioned about the expenses, Carter supplied fraudulent documentation to justify them, Goldstock said. The corporate clients he was said to have defrauded included Union Carbide Corp., Shell Oil, Caesars World Inc., UNUM, an insurance company, and MacAndrews & Forbes Group Inc., which owns the Revlon cosmetics company. Carter pleaded guilty March 20 to grand larceny and filing a false and fradulent personal income tax return.
